Abstract: We present the first data on photon-photon annihilation into hadrons for CM energies > 1 GeV obtained with the detector PLUTO at the e+e- storage ring PETRA. Cross sections are extracted using an inelastic eγ scattering formalism. The results are compared to expectations from Regge-like models. © 1979.

Title: Monte Carlo calculation of photon, electron, and position production from primary proton beams
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Ranft, J., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Nelson, W.R., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: Combining the Monte Carlo calculations of the hadron cascade and electromagnetic cascade within a nuclear target irradiated by a high-energy proton beam, we calculate the yields of secondary photons, electrons, and positrons from the target. These yields are useful for the design and optimization of secondary photon, electron and positron beams. Furthermore, the calculations allow one to study the filling of electron or position storage rings operating together with a proton synchrotron or storage ring such as the CERN SPS, the BNL ISABELLE, or the proposed Serpukhov UNK. © 1979.

Authors: Goggi G., Conta C., Fraternali M., Livan M., Mantovani G.C., Pastore F., Alberi G., Baldracchini F.
Title: Analysis of single and coherent nucleon diffraction dissociation at ISR energies
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Istituto di Fisica, Università di Pavia, Italy; Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Pavia, Italy; Istituto di Fisica Teorica, Università di Trieste, Italy; Istituto di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Trieste, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Goggi, G., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Conta, C., Istituto di Fisica, Università di Pavia, Italy, Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Pavia, Italy; Fraternali, M., Istituto di Fisica, Università di Pavia, Italy, Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Pavia, Italy; Livan, M., Istituto di Fisica, Università di Pavia, Italy, Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Pavia, Italy; Mantovani, G.C., Istituto di Fisica, Università di Pavia, Italy, Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Pavia, Italy; Pastore, F., Istituto di Fisica, Università di Pavia, Italy, Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Pavia, Italy; Alberi, G., Istituto di Fisica Teorica, Università di Trieste, Italy, Istituto di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Trieste, Italy; Baldracchini, F., Istituto di Fisica Teorica, Università di Trieste, Italy, Istituto di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Trieste, Italy
Abstract: We present the analysis of a combined measurement of neutron and proton diffraction dissociation into (Nπ) and (Nππ) final states, both on proton and deuteron targets. The experiment was performed at the CERN Intersecting Storage Rings with the Split Field Magnet detector using proton and deuteron colliding beams. Mass spectra and decay angular distributions are compared with the predictions of a dual-reggeized Deck model. Strong decay angular correlations are observed in all cases. Pronounced structures observed in the differential cross sections of the coherent diffractive processes for small produced masses are interpreted in terms of constructive interference between the single- and double-scattering terms in a Glauber analysis. These interference effects cannot be reproduced by a central dissociation mechanism and require a peripheral description of the elementary nucleon-nucleon diffractive production amplitudes. © 1979.

Authors: Borisevich G.P., Noks P.P., Kononenko A.A., Rubin A.B., Vozari E.
Title: Polarization of photosynthetic membranes and the reaction centres of Rhodopseudomonas sphaeroides, 1760-1 in an external electric field
Affiliations: Biological Faculty, the Lomonosov State University, Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Borisevich, G.P., Biological Faculty, the Lomonosov State University, Moscow, Russian Federation; Noks, P.P., Biological Faculty, the Lomonosov State University, Moscow, Russian Federation; Kononenko, A.A., Biological Faculty, the Lomonosov State University, Moscow, Russian Federation; Rubin, A.B., Biological Faculty, the Lomonosov State University, Moscow, Russian Federation; Vozari, E., Biological Faculty, the Lomonosov State University, Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: The external electric field with a strength of 105 V/cm causes the appearance of a polarized state in films of chromatophores and photosynthetic reaction centres (r.c.) of purple bacteria. A natural indicator of the polarized state is provided by the pigments of the photosynthetic apparatus, in particular, the carotenoids the absorption spectra of which change in the electric field. Polarization is due to change in the position and orientation of the various charged groups and may be fixed at low temperature (- 120 °C). On thawing the sample this altered state relaxes to the initial and in the external measuring circuit the current of the thermaldepolarization is recorded. The dependence of the current on the degree of hydration, the chemical modification and the thermal treatment of the preparations indicates the participation of the macromolecular components in the formation of the polarized state. In lightadapted samples the degree of polarization rises, which may indicate the presence of conformational rearrangements in the course of the primary photoreactions. It is assumed that polarization in the r.c. during electron transport may serve as the mechanism ensuring stabilization of the separated charges and storage of energy. © 1980.

Authors: Willner I., Ford W.E., Otvos J.W., Calvin M.
Title: Photoinduced electron transfer across a water-oil boundary as a model for redox reaction separation [3]
Affiliations: Laboratory of Chemical Biodynamics, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Authors with affiliations: Willner, I., Laboratory of Chemical Biodynamics, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Ford, W.E., Laboratory of Chemical Biodynamics, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Otvos, J.W., Laboratory of Chemical Biodynamics, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Calvin, M., Laboratory of Chemical Biodynamics, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Abstract: THE creation of artificial solar energy conversion and storage systems that mimic the photosynthetic pathway has evoked great interest in recent years 1. One approach to the photolysis of water involves the mediation of two photosystems in the generation of reduced and oxidised species that are the active components in the decomposition of water2,3. However, homogeneous (aqueous) solutions of these components suffer from the basic limitation that the reducing and oxidising agents can react with each other and thus no net reaction can be observed. Several kinds of synthetic 'photosynthetic membranes' have been suggested as a means of separating the two redox units and overcoming these fundamental difficulties3. Recently, photo-sensitised electron transfer across vesicle walls has been demonstrated and suggested as a means for generating oxidising and reducing agents in separate water compartments4. We report here a photochemical electron transfer across the interface of a water-in-toluene microemulsion, and propose this system as a model for the separation of oxidised and reduced species. It is well known that surfactant molecules aggregate to reversed micelles in organic solvents5. Reversed micelles entrap water to form 'water pools' in a continuous oil phase. The proposed general model for the compartmentalisation of two water phases and its utilisation in the photolysis of water is shown in Fig. 1. © 1979 Nature Publishing Group.

Title: Three imperatives: Food storage, energy, work ...
