Title: Risk with energy from conventional and nonconventional sources
Affiliations: Atomic Energy Control Board, P.O. Box 1046, Ottawa, Ont. K1P 5S9, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Inhaber, H., Atomic Energy Control Board, P.O. Box 1046, Ottawa, Ont. K1P 5S9, Canada
Abstract: Risk to human health was compared for five conventional and six nonconventional energy systems. The entire cycle for producing energy was considered, not just part. The most important conclusion drawn is that the risk to human health from nonconventional sources can be as high as, or even higher than, that of conventional sources. This result is produced only when the risk per unit energy is considered, rather than the risk per solar panel or windmill. The risk from nonconventional energy sources derives from the large amount of material and labor needed, along with their backup and storage requirements. Risk evaluation is a relatively new discipline, and therefore the results presented here can be considered only a beginning. However, society should keep relative risk in mind when evaluating present and future energy sources. Copyright © 1979 AAAS.
Index Keywords: energy transfer; short survey; Humans; Industrial Waste; Occupational Medicine; Power Plants; Public Health; Risk

Authors: Girard J., Pintado E., Ferre P.
Title: Fuel metabolism in the mammalian fetus
Source title: Annales de Biologie Animale, Biochimie, Biophysique
Affiliations: Lab. Physiol. Developpem., Coll. France, 75231 Paris Cedex 05, France
Authors with affiliations: Girard, J., Lab. Physiol. Developpem., Coll. France, 75231 Paris Cedex 05, France; Pintado, E., Lab. Physiol. Developpem., Coll. France, 75231 Paris Cedex 05, France; Ferre, P., Lab. Physiol. Developpem., Coll. France, 75231 Paris Cedex 05, France
Abstract: The mammalian fetus receives energy fuels from its mother through the placenta. The placental transfer of substrates depends upon the placental permeability to the substrate and upon the difference of concentration of the substrate in maternal and fetal blood. The fetus uses the substrates for 3 purposes: synthesis of new tissues (growth), oxidative metabolism and building of energy stores. Since the O2 consumption per Kg of body weight is relatively constant among the different species, the partitioning of substrates in anabolic and catabolic pathways is related to the rate of fetal growth. Glucose and lactate account for a large part of the exidative needs of the fetus, but amino acids catabolism plays also an important role. During maternal starvation, ketone bodies can be used as oxidative substrates by the fetus of monogastrics. The fetus has a low capacity to oxidize free fatty acids, even in species in which the placental transfer of these substrates occurs rapidly. Free fatty acids are used as precursors of complex lipids or are stored in fetal adipose tissues or liver. Several recent observations suggest that gluconeogenesis could occur in the fetus of ruminants, and thus could allow the transformation of lactate and amino acids into glucose before utilization by individual tissues of the fetus (brain, skeletal muscle, heart). The hormones secreted by the fetus have been shown to play an important role in inducing the storage of glycogen in fetal liver (glucocorticoids and a pituitary hormone) and the accumulation of triglycerides in fetal adipose tissue (insulin).
Index Keywords: amino acid; glucocorticoid; glucose; insulin; lactic acid; triacylglycerol; endocrine system; fetus; short survey

Title: Energy recovery from wastewater treatment plant effluent
Source title: Journal of the Water Pollution Control Federation
Affiliations: Strand Associates, Inc., Madison, Wis., United States
Authors with affiliations: Budde, P.E., Strand Associates, Inc., Madison, Wis., United States; Doran, M.D., Strand Associates, Inc., Madison, Wis., United States
Abstract: A centralized building heating system designed for a wastewater treatment plant in the northern Midwest uses a heat pump to recover the energy contained within the treatment plant effluent. The system also provides for energy storage to take advantage of off-peak electrical rates. Overall thermal efficiency is about 50% higher than that of a conventional oilfired system, and total system present worth (including operation and maintenance) is 195,000 as opposed to $232,000 for the oil system. Secondary effluent at 9°C enters the heat pump evaporator and is returned to the waste stream downstream of the supply point at 6°C . In the heat pump, compression and condensation impart a temperature of 49°C to the hot-water heating system.
Index Keywords: cost; economic aspect; energy; sewage treatment; therapy

Authors: Bressler N.M., Broekman M.J., Marcus A.J.
Title: Concurrent studies of oxygen consumption and aggregation in stimulated human platelets
Affiliations: Div. Hematol. Oncol., Dept. Med., New York VA Hosp, New York, N.Y. 10010, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bressler, N.M., Div. Hematol. Oncol., Dept. Med., New York VA Hosp, New York, N.Y. 10010, United States; Broekman, M.J., Div. Hematol. Oncol., Dept. Med., New York VA Hosp, New York, N.Y. 10010, United States; Marcus, A.J., Div. Hematol. Oncol., Dept. Med., New York VA Hosp, New York, N.Y. 10010, United States
Abstract: A new approach to the study of the 'burst' of oxygen consumption in stimulated human platelets is described. Following addition of collagen, thrombin, or arachidonic acid to washed platelets, O2 consumption and aggregation was measured concurrently. In contrast to thrombin and arachidonic acid, collagen induced a calcium-dependent O2 burst after a lag phase of 25-35 sec. Elevation of platelet cAMP levels completely inhibited the oxygen burst and aggregation response. Blockade of energy metabolism also prevented the oxygen burst; however, the aggregation response was not completely suppressed. Eicosatetraynoic acid and indomethacin, inhibitors or arachidonic acid oxygenation, also abolished the collagen induced O2 burst but not aggregation. These findings indicate that the platelet O2 burst is utilized for formation of prostaglandin endoperoxides, which are apparently not essential for collagen induced aggregation. Comparison of the oxygen consumption and aggregation curves elicited by arachidonic acid in the presence of increasing amounts of ADP scavengers demonstrated the obligatory participation of released ADP in aggregation induced by this fatty acid. Stored platelets did not exhibit an oxygen burst when challenged by collagen or thrombin, although the aggregation response was relatively intact. In contrast, addition of arachidonic acid to stored platelets elicited both an O2 burst and aggregation, suggesting that phospholipase A2 activity, or steps leading to its activation, are more liable to storage than the platelet cyclooxygenase. It is concluded that concurrent comparison of oxygen consumption and aggregation responses permits a direct evaluation of the role of endoperoxide formation in human platelet aggregation.
Index Keywords: prostaglandin; blood and hemopoietic system; human cell; in vitro study; oxygen consumption; thrombocyte aggregation; thrombocyte metabolism

Title: The derivation of a reference standard for maximum thigh circumference of preschool children, aged 0-5 years
Affiliations: MIT Internat. Nutrit. Program, Cambridge Mass. 02139, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zeitlin, M., MIT Internat. Nutrit. Program, Cambridge Mass. 02139, United States
Abstract: Percentile curves are derived to serve as a reference standard for the maximum thigh circumference (TC) of children aged 0-5 years. A sample of 1,080 economically-favored children from the Boston area and from New Haven, Connecticut, were used for the derivation. Tests for sex differences and of the usefulness of TC for identifying malnutrition also were conducted using measurments from low-income Filipino children. Thigh circumference differs from other anthropometric measurements in that a single standard appears applicable for both sexes. Boys and girls have the same average thigh girth over the preschool age range, although the girls have a thigh fatfold wich averages 1.14 mm larger than that of the boys. TC proved slightly more consistent in identifying undernourished infants and young children than mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC). TC remains almost constant between 12-21 months, during which period the average thigh fatfold decreases by almost two mm. This decrease suggests that the thigh serves as a storage depot of fat which is used for energy during a period of low appetite and relatively high energy expenditure when the child is learning to walk.
Index Keywords: animal experiment; infant; normal human; preschool child; thigh circumference; Age Factors; Anthropometry; Child, Preschool; Female; Human; Infant; Infant, Newborn; Male; Nutrition Disorders; Reference Standards; Sex Factors; Thigh

Authors: Owen O.E., Reichard Jr. G.A., Patel M.S., Boden G.
Title: Energy metabolism in feasting and fasting.
Source title: Advances in experimental medicine and biology
Authors with affiliations: Owen, O.E.; Reichard Jr., G.A.; Patel, M.S.; Boden, G.
Abstract: During feasting on a balanced carbohydrate, fat, and protein meal resting metabolic rate, body temperature and respiratory quotient all increase. The dietary components are utilized to replenish and augment glycogen and fat stores in the body. Excessive carbohydrate is also converted to lipid in the liver and stored along with the excessive lipids of dietary origin as triglycerides in adipose tissue, the major fuel storage depot. Amino acids in excess of those needed for protein synthesis are preferentially catabolized over glucose and fat for energy production. This occurs because there are no significant storage sites for amino acids or proteins, and the accumulation of nitrogenous compounds is ill tolerated. During fasting, adipose tissue, muscle, liver, and kidneys work in concert to supply, to convert, and to conserve fuels for the body. During the brief postabsorptive period, blood fuel homeostasis is maintained primarily by hepatic glycogenolysis and adipose tissue lipolysis. As fasting progresses, muscle proteolysis supplies glycogenic amino acids for heightened hepatic gluconeogenesis for a short period of time. After about three days of starvation, the metabolic profile is set to conserve protein and to supply greater quantities of alternate fuels. In particular, free fatty acids and ketone bodies are utilized to maintain energy needs. The ability of the kidney to conserve ketone bodies prevents the loss of large quantities of these valuable fuels in the urine. This delicate interplay among liver, muscle, kidney, and adipose tissue maintains blood fuel homeostasis and allows humans to survive caloric deprivation for extended periods.
Index Keywords: fatty acid; glycogen; insulin; ketone body; nitrogen; acid base balance; animal; basal metabolic rate; diet; diet restriction; energy metabolism; female; gluconeogenesis; metabolism; oxidation reduction reaction; physiology; review; urine; Acid-Base Equilibrium; Animals; Basal Metabolism; Diet; Energy Metabolism; Fasting; Fatty Acids, Nonesterified; Female; Gluconeogenesis; Glycogen; Insulin; Ketone Bodies; Nitrogen; Oxidation-Reduction; MLCS; MLOWN

Title: Long-Term Storage of Mitochondria to Preserve Energy-Linked Functions
Authors with affiliations: Fleischer, S.
Abstract: This chapter describes a procedure for the storage of rat liver mitochondria to preserve mitochondrial functions for prolonged periods (months). The availability of many tubes of mitochondria from one large-scale preparation emancipates the investigator from the daily tedium of isolation. Such a stock eliminates individual differences in animals and inadvertent changes in the isolation procedure. The chapter discusses three parameters of mitochondrial function, each of which has been preserved by the method of long-term storage. In this method, the mitochondria are fortified with bovine plasma albumin and dimethyl sulfoxide, a cryoprotective substance. They are quick-frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored in a liquid-nitrogen refrigerator at −196°C. Studies have suggested that mitochondria are one of the lists of biological materials that can be successfully preserved for prolonged periods. A recent procedure has also been devised to store a rat liver homogenate for prolonged periods (many months) for subsequent subcellular fractionation. Mitochondria isolated from such homogenates that has been frozen for many months retain energy-linked functions. © 1979, Elsevier Inc. All right reserved.

Title: An approach for time-resolved x-ray scattering
Authors with affiliations: Stamatoff, J.
Abstract: Recent biological optical spectroscopic studies have correlated discrete spectroscopic states with biological function in several systems. One of the challenges of molecular biophysics is to correlate structural changes with these spectroscopic states. From small-angle x-ray scattering one can obtain a key structural parameter, the radius of gyration of solubilized proteins. The method described in this paper would permit determination small changes in the radius using polychromatic synchrotron radiation. The high flux of the storage ring combined with an enhancement factor of approximately 10(4), obtained by removing the requirement for monochromatic radiation, will permit determining the radius on a millisecond time scale. Unlike energy-dispersive methods, this method would use all available energies over a wide range of angles. © 1979, The Biophysical Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: radiation scattering; Mathematics; Molecular Conformation; X-Ray Diffraction

Title: Thermoelasticity of red blood cell membrane
Authors with affiliations: Waugh, R.; Evans, E.A.
Abstract: The elastic properties of the human red blood cell membrane have been measured as functions of temperature. The area compressibility modulus and the elastic shear modulus, which together characterize the surface elastic behavior of the membrane, have been measured over the temperature range of 2–50 degrees C with micropipette aspiration of flaccid and osmotically swollen red cells. In addition, the fractional increase in membrane surface area from 2–50 degrees C has been measured to give a value for the thermal area expansivity. The value of the elastic shear modulus at 25 degrees C was measured to be 6.6 X 10(-3) dyne/cm. The change in the elastic shear modulus with temperature was -6 X 10(-5) dyne/cm degrees C. Fractional forces were shown to be only on the order of 10–15%. The area compressibility modulus at 25 degrees C was measured to be 450 dyne/cm. The change in the area compressibility modulus with temperature was -6 dyne/cm degrees C. The thermal area expansivity for red cell membrane was measured to be 1.2 X 10(-3)/degrees C. With this data and thermoelastic relations the heat of expansion is determined to be 110–200 ergs/cm2; the heat of extension is 2 X 10(-2) ergs/cm2 for unit extension of the red cell membrane. The heat of expansion is of the order anticipated for a lipid bilayer idealized as twice the behavior of a monolayer at an oil-water interface. The observation that the heat of extension is positive demonstrates that the entropy of the material increases with extension, and that the dominant mechanism of elastic energy storage is energetic. Assuming that the red cell membrane shear rigidity is associated with "spectrin," unit extension of the membrane increases the configurational entropy of spectrin by 500 cal/mol. © 1979, The Biophysical Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: blood and hemopoietic system; elasticity; erythrocyte membrane; human cell; in vitro study; normal human; temperature

Authors: Salomon J.W., Swyer P.R., Jequier E.
Title: Thermic effects of glucose, amino acid and lipid in the term newborn
Affiliations: Dept. Ped., Univ. Lausanne, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Salomon, J.W., Dept. Ped., Univ. Lausanne, Switzerland; Swyer, P.R., Dept. Ped., Univ. Lausanne, Switzerland; Jequier, E., Dept. Ped., Univ. Lausanne, Switzerland
Abstract: The thermic effect in term infants of intragastric isocaloric amounts of glucose, lipid and amino acid have been compared with control infants given water on the third to fifth days of life. In contrast with adults, the thermic effect of glucose was found to be non-existent and for lipids weak and ill-sustained. These results suggest that these nutrients are mainly oxidised and that processes involving an elevated metabolic cost, such as lipid synthesis, play a minor role. The ingestion of an isocaloric load of amino acids induced a small thermic effect (4.4% of the energy content of the load in 2 h). This effect is probably related to a low rate of protein synthesis or amino acid catabolism and an absence of tissue deposition. The small thermic effect observed suggests that a significant part of the load is not metabolised or channeled into protein synthesis. In term infants the weak thermic effect after amino acid and the failure of glucose and lipid to stimulate metabolism may possibly be analogous to the lack of post-prandial thermic effect reported in non-growing children suffering from malnutrition. It can be hypothesised that in both cases the energy storage related to lipid and protein synthesis is absent or minimal. Therefore, there is no stimulation of energy expenditure to produce a thermic effect.
Index Keywords: amino acid; glucose; lipid; body temperature; calorimetry; human cell; metabolism; methodology; newborn; normal human

Authors: Bess F.H., Peek B.F., Chapman J.J.
Title: Further observations on noise levels in infant incubators
Affiliations: Div. Hear. Speech Sci., Vanderbilt Univ. Sch. Med., Nashville, Tenn. 37212, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bess, F.H., Div. Hear. Speech Sci., Vanderbilt Univ. Sch. Med., Nashville, Tenn. 37212, United States; Peek, B.F., Div. Hear. Speech Sci., Vanderbilt Univ. Sch. Med., Nashville, Tenn. 37212, United States; Chapman, J.J., Div. Hear. Speech Sci., Vanderbilt Univ. Sch. Med., Nashville, Tenn. 37212, United States
Abstract: The purpose of this study was to conduct an acoustic analysis of incubator noise under two conditions: when the incubator was associated with different types of like-support equipment; and when impulse noise was created by striking the side of the incubator or by opening and closing the doors of the storage unit. It was found that the life-support equipment increased the overall noise levels of incubators by as much as 15 to 20 dB. Much of this increased energy was in the high frequency region. Impulse signals created by striking the side of the incubator ranged from 130 to 140 dB. A representative impulse for opening the incubator was 92.8 dB, whereas closing the door produced a peak amplitude of 114 dB.

Authors: Peube Jean Laurent, D'Utruy Bernard, Blay Dominique
Title: Heat Storage and Transient Regimes in Solar Electric Power Plants. [STOCKAGE THERMIQUE ET REGIMES TRANSITOIRES DANS LES CENTRALES ELECTROSOLAIRES.]
Authors with affiliations: Peube, Jean Laurent; D'Utruy, Bernard; Blay, Dominique
Abstract: After a brief description of the solar power station at Odeillo, a few results of the heat-balance of certain components of the plant are given. The scale of heat losses in the network and storage tank are noted. It is observed that the quality of heat restitution depends essentially on good stratification of the heat in the tank and on losses in the circuits in transient state. The experiments described make it possible to specify the conditions of heat storage and regulation of solar power stations which guarantee the storage and restitution of heat at a constant temperature, whatever the variations in the solar flux.
Index Keywords: SOLAR ENERGY; SOLAR RADIATION

Title: Solar Chemistry. [LA CHIMIE SOLAIRE.]
Authors with affiliations: Vialaron, Andre
Abstract: After a brief summary of the first attempts to domesticate solar energy, the author describes the scale of the solar problems and lists the objectives of the CNRS's Interdisciplinary Research Programme for the Development of Solar Energy, in the context of solar chemistry. These objectives involve the chemical transfer and storage of solar energy, the conversion of solar energy into chemical vectors, and the preparatory use of solar energy. On these lines, the author suggests a few interesting subjects for research, most of which are already being studied, both in France and abroad.
Index Keywords: SOLAR RADIATION

Title: Chemical Energetics and Solar Energy. [ENERGETIQUE CHIMIQUE ET ENERGIE SOLAIRE.]
Authors with affiliations: Mahenc, Jean
Abstract: It is conceivable to use solar energy in endothermic physicochemical processes, either for the purpose of separation or for chemical reactions. Correlatively, chemistry can solve problems of converting, storing and transporting solar energy. The use of solar energy in thermal form raises the problem of the temperature at which it is collected. The sun is comparable to a black body radiating at 6000 degree K, and if degradation of its energy is to be avoided it should be collected at as high a temperature level as possible. This can be demonstrated by making a thermodynamic analysis of an endothermic process which in fact only requires a low-temperature heat delivery (t less than 200 degree C). The simplicity of the collecting devices is not generally compatible with the best energy use of the solar flux. Similarly, chemical heat conveyors degrade energy. In the field of conversion and storage, thermogalvanic motors offer solutions that are of interest from the energy point of view: a thermodynamic analysis of their operation makes it possible to eliminate certain inefficient systems.
Index Keywords: SOLAR RADIATION

Title: An acquisition, storage, display and processing system for electron energy-loss spectra
Affiliations: Physics Department, University of Alberta, Edmonton, T6G 2J1, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Egerton, R.F., Physics Department, University of Alberta, Edmonton, T6G 2J1, Canada; Kenway, D., Physics Department, University of Alberta, Edmonton, T6G 2J1, Canada
Abstract: An electronic recording system is described which can be used in conjunction with a transmission electron microscope fitted with an electron spectrometer. The system is based on a Texas Instruments 990/4 microcomputer and TI 733 data terminal. The minicomputer is programmed from a cassette tape which contains the software necessary for acquiring spectral data, displaying the spectra on a cathode ray tube and simple data processing. The latter includes performing a least-squares fit to a power-law energy dependence, which is used for stripping the background contribution from inner shell losses for quantitative microanalysis of light elements. © 1979 North-Holland Publishing Company.

Abstract: sensitivity of the performance of the reservoir is evaluated with respect to reservoir parameters, which include reservoir geometry, reservoir material properties, residual water content, and operating conditions. The pressure response of the reservoir is evaluated by consideration of those parameters that define the flow resistance and the air storage volume. The thermal behaviour of the reservoir is characterized by consideration of thermal cycling within the vicinity of the wellbore and by the growth of a thermal pillar surrounding the wellbore. The potential impact of residual water on both the pressure and thermal response is evaluated. Results of the analysis are interpreted to characterize the behaviour of the reservoir under conditions of daily air cycling. The results also provide, or will provide, or will assist in providing, design guidelines for the efficient and stable operation of the reservoir. (A) The analysis of the hydrodynamic and thermodynamic response to moist air cycling in a compressed air energy storage (CAES) porous rock reservoir is described. The analysis is based upon the numerical solution of the appropriate set of conservation equations, which define the pressure and thermal behaviour of the reservoir. The

Title: On the formulation of stability and design criteria for compressed air energy storage in hard rock caverns.
Source title: IN: PROC. 14TH INTERSOCIETY ENERGY CONVERSION ENGNG. CONF. (BOSTON, U.S.A., AUG. 5-10, 1979)
Volume: 1 . Washington D.C., Am. Chem. Soc., 1979, paper 799091
Authors with affiliations: Gnirk, P.F.; Fossum, A.F.
Abstract: The primary objectives of this paper involve formulation of appropriate stability and design criteria for the construction, operational, and decommissioning phases of CAES caverns in hard rock; presentation of the elements of a numerical simulation model for cavern stability assessment; and discussion of the concept of failure probability assessment for CAES caverns. The basic notions of stability and instability are established, and the relevant phenomenological modes of cavern instability identified in conjunction with their corresponding constitutive laws. Precedent design and stability considerations are briefly addressed in the context of overall application to underground cavern development and use. Cavern shakedown for enhancement of cavern stability and the use of probabilistic design procedures are two important features of this paper. (A)

Authors: Yaney D.S., Nelson J.T., Vanskike L.L.
Title: Alpha-Particle Tracks in Silicon and their Effect on Dynamic MOS RAM Reliability
Affiliations: Bell Laboratories, Inc., Allentown, PA, 18103, United States
Authors with affiliations: Yaney, D.S., Bell Laboratories, Inc., Allentown, PA, 18103, United States; Nelson, J.T., Bell Laboratories, Inc., Allentown, PA, 18103, United States; Vanskike, L.L., Bell Laboratories, Inc., Allentown, PA, 18103, United States
Abstract: Recent investigations [1] have found low levels of alpha particles (< 0.1 counts/cm2· h) emitted from the immediate chip environment to be responsible for soft errors in 16K MOS dynamic RAM's. We have investigated this problem in two related studies. First, we review the interaction of alpha particles with the Si lattice and present range-energy and specific ionization data. Experimental values of the actual charge collected at shallow junctions for 4.9-MeV alpha events are presented. The dynamics of the collection process and the influence of the interface electric field in p-p epitaxial material are identified. We further show the dependence of the collected charge on the incident particle energy and angle. Second, we review the operation of current memory devices and indicate how soft failures due to alpha particles can be identified. We present soft error rate versus duty cycle data for a number of devices displaying different failure modes. The dependence of the soft error rate on incident particle energy and angle is also shown. Finally, we propose a simple accelerated test to evaluate device susceptibility to this failure mode. Copyright © 1979 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.

Title: Low-temperature Thermal Energy Storage program annual operating plan, FY 1979.
Authors with affiliations: Eissenberg, D.M.; Hoffman, H.W.
Abstract: The low temperature Thermal Energy Storage (LTTES) program operating plans for FY 1979 are described in terms of general program objectives and the technical activities being implemented to achieve these objectives. The program structure provides emphasis on several principal thrusts; namely, seasonal thermal storage, daily/short-term thermal storage, and recovery and reuse of waste heat. Fiscal data are summarized according to thrust area, individual efforts, and funding source. (A) (Microfiche)

Title: Compressed air storage systems for power generation - a thermodynamic and economic analysis.
Authors with affiliations: Hill, P.G.; MacMillan, C.
Abstract: A review of previous studies of power generation using underground air storage and gas turbines indicates the need for re-examination of the thermodynamics and economics of conventional systems in the light of present fuel, electricity and capital costs. this paper describes the methods and results of such a study, which includes a general examination of several configurations, some including independent storage capacities for air and thermal energy. The analysis includes appraisal of thermodynamic losses of each component and approximate allowance for gas property variations. Approximate capital costs of each components is estimated. Generation costs are calculated via a present worth analysis as a function of electricity and fuel costs, capital charge rate, generation and storage periods and cycles parameters. Results for air storage systems are compared with those of advanced-concept gas turbines for peak load power. Compressed air storage with a recuperated gas turbine is economically superior under all conditions considered, to the equivalent conventional (recuperated) gas turbine. So is the unrecuperated gas turbine storage system with thermal energy storage. However, thermal energy storage and recuperation are not cost-effective together, if both are used for turbine preheating. Whether the thermal energy storage system is competitive with the recuperated system depends strongly on whether the incremental cost or the base load cost is assigned the the value of the electricity consumed during the storage phase. With electricity assessed at incremental cost from a nuclear-fired plant, the analysis shows that the unfired gas turbine storage system would be economically competitive, as long as thermal energy storage in water at temperatures as high as 200SUPC is feasible. This is so despite overall storage efficiency (kWh out/kWh in) of the order of 50%. (A).

Title: Renewable energy.
Authors with affiliations: Sorenson, B.
Abstract: Contents : Perspective; the origin of renewable energy flows; the individual energy sources; the energy conversion processes; energy transport and storage; energy supply systems; socio-economic assessment of energy supply systems; references; index .

Authors: Lustenader E.L., Edelfelt I.H., Jones D.W., Plunkett A.B., Richter E., Turnbull F.G.
Title: Regenerative flywheel energy storage system.
Authors with affiliations: Lustenader, E.L.; Edelfelt, I.H.; Jones, D.W.; Plunkett, A.B.; Richter, E.; Turnbull, F.G.
Abstract: The current status of a program to develop and evlauate a regenerative flywheel energy storage system is described. The system was designed for a battery/flywheel electric vehicle in the 3000 pound class.

Authors: Gajanana B.C., HYL+ Brown, Hamel B.B.
Title: Operational optimization of an HVac system coupled with a multi-tank thermal storage.
Source title: IN: PROC. 14TH INTERSOCIETY ENERGY CONVERSION ENGNG. CONF., (BOSTON U.S.A.: AUG.5-10, 1979)
Volume: 1 , Washington, D.C., U.S.A., Am' Chem. Soc., 1979, Paper 799102, p'500-506' (IEEE 79CH1477-9 Energy).
Authors with affiliations: Gajanana, B.C.; HYL+ Brown; Hamel, B.B.
Abstract: The incorporation of thermal storage elements and diesel engines in conventional HVAC systems, produces complex systems in terms of operational strategies. A systematic study of the performance of such a system is made for various heating and cooling loads. A method of developing an optimal operating strategy has been established by classifying heating and cooling loads into specific 'regimes.' Using these load profile regimes, optimum operation of diesel-chiller system with multi-tank thermal storage system is analyzed. The results of this optimization study are applied to a commercial building; the performance of a diesel chiller with thermal storage (DCDTS) system is compared with that of a conventional HVAC system. The application of the DCDTS system to a commercial building shows that the on-peak electric demand is reduced by 84%, the total energy consumption is reduced by 23% and the reduction in operating cost, for a demand charge of 8/KW, is 47%. For this demand charges, the system has a simple payback period of 6 years. (A)

Authors: Waters E.D., W' Saaski E., Martini W.R.
Title: A thermal energy storage' System for a stirring engine powered highway vehicle.
Source title: IN: PROC. 14TH INTERSOCIETY ENERGY CONVERSION ENGNG. CONF', (BOSTON, U'S.A.: AUG'5-10, 1979)
Volume: 1 , Washington, D'C., U.S.., Am. Chem. Soc., 1979, Paper 799098, p'475-480. (IEEE 79CH1477-9 Energy).
Authors with affiliations: Waters, E.D.; W' Saaski, E.; Martini, W.R.
Abstract: The conceptual design of an automotive propulsion, thermal energy storage system has been developed that utilizes the sensible and latent heat of fusion of a molten fluoride salt. Electromagnetically pumped potassium serves in the vapor-liquid heat transport system, and high-performance nonmetallic insulation is utilized to substantiate adequate thermal and material performance to provide at least 161-km range for a 500-kg system, with power bursts in excess of 200 kW available. The thermal energy storage system is compared with advanced electrochemical storage devices' Preliminary production costs and life-cycle costs are presented, and safety and other public acceptance issues are reviewed' (A)

Authors: Brown K.C., Edesess M., Jayadev T.S.
Title: Solar ponds for industrial process heat.
Authors with affiliations: Brown, K.C.; Edesess, M.; Jayadev, T.S.
Abstract: Solar ponds offer perhaps the simplest technique for conversion of solar energy to thermal energy, which can be used for industrial process heat (IPH). It is unique in its capability to act both as a collector and a storage medium. Further, the cost of the solar pond per unit area is less than any active collectors available today. A combination of these economic and technical factors make solar ponds attractive as a fuel saver in IPH applications. This paper presents detailed calculations: providing hot water for aluminium can washing in a manufacturing plant and hot water for washing in a large commercial laundry. With the help of computer codes developed at SERI for other solar IPH systems, it is shown that solar ponds are far more cost effective than any other solar IPH technology for these applications. (A)

Title: Pacific Northwest Laboratory Annual Report for 1978 to the DOE Division of Energy Storage Systems. Compressed Air Energy Storage Technology Program.
Authors with affiliations: Loscutoff, W.V.
Abstract: Part 1 reports on research performed to establish design and stability criteria for CAES reservoirs. Part II reports progress on research performed on advanced CAES concepts.

Title: Dissociation pressure measurements on salts proposed for thermochemical energy storage.
Authors with affiliations: Carling, R.W.
Abstract: Sandia Laboratories, Livermore, has been conducting research pertaining to the development of chemical heat pumps. Promising current models of chemical heat pumps employ salt hydrates, ammoniates, or methanolates for energy storage. The efficient operation of a chemical heat pump depends strongly upon the reaction energies and pressure/temperature relationships of these salts. Unfortunately, most of the needed data are either old, of uncertain reliability, or not available. Therefore, an apparatus had been assembled to measure pressure/temperature relationships and derive reaction energies. Incorporated in this apparatus is a sensitive cantilever balance used to prepare salt samples in situ so that the stoichiometry of the salt hydrate, ammoniate, or methanolate is known prior to the pressure measurements.

Title: Review of the economics of selected passive and hybrid systems.
Authors with affiliations: Buchanan, D.L.
Abstract: Performance and economic information on passive and hybrid systems has been compiled as part of the solar commercial readiness activity at the US Solar Energy Research Institute. The results of selected performance simulation and cost estimate studies are presented as well as actual cost and performance data from buildings in operation. Systems representative of each major passive design concept are included: direct gain, indirect gain (thermal storage wall or thermal storage roof), and isolated gain (convective loop-thermosiphon or attached sunspace-greenhouse).

Title: Heat exchange fluids and techniques.
Authors with affiliations: Ranney, M.W.
Abstract: This book reviews United States Patents issued between January 1975 and April 1979 and dealing with heat transfer fluid and techniques. The review deals with patents under the headings General heat exchanger construction and design (Tubular construction, Other Heat Exchanger Constructions, Particulate exchange medium, Surface treatment and Tube cleaning); Heat transfer fluids (Fluid composition, and Absorption heating); Low temperature processes (Refrigerant processes and fluids); Thermal energy storage and transport (Chemical reaction processes, Fusion processes and Other processes); Control of heat transfer in building structures (Air conditioning and other processes); Solar and geothermal energy processes (Solar energy and transfer systems, General solar heating processes and Geothermal energy); Industrial applications (Air separation plants, Flue gas, Electric generating plant, Gasification processes, Nuclear power plants, Pipelines, Plastics and textile processing, and Other applications and processes); and Specialized applications (Cryobiology and blood treatment, Automotive applications, Aircraft applications, Food service, Electronic applications, Glass processing and Other applications). (N.G.G.)
Index Keywords: heat pump; Insulation; plate; rotary heat exchanger; thermosyphon

Title: Evaluation of thermal energy storage for a large urban hot water district heating system in the United States.
Authors with affiliations: Meyer, C.F.
Abstract: A report on the results of a study which TEMPO completed in July 1979 evaluating the potential benefits of thermal energy storage (TES) in a specific cogeneration-district heating system, proposed for the Minneapolis/St. Paul area (the Twin Cities) in the United States. A complete report has been submitted to the sponsor of the study, the U.S. Department of Energy via the Oak Ridge National Laboratory. In this paper, the concept of storing hot water in aquifers will be reviewed. Then the benefits believed possible by use of aquifer storage in the proposed Twin Cities system will be described.

Authors: Ozis U., Harmancioglu N., Benzeden E., Alpaslan N.
Title: Trends and apportunities in water power exploitation.
Source title: IN: III WORLD CONGRESS ON WATER RESOURCES,
Volume: 2 , Washington, D.C., U.S.A., Int. Water Resour. Assoc., no date, Subtheme 2
Authors with affiliations: Ozis, U.; Harmancioglu, N.; Benzeden, E.; Alpaslan, N.
Abstract: Almost one fifth of the electrical energy is generated from water power. This ratio is, however, well above 79% in several developed as well as developing countries. Furthermore, in several other developed countries, that ratio was also very high in the near past, but began to decrease gradually where water power development has not kept pace along with the rapid increase in energy demand. Although most of the European and North American countries have already exploited a large part of their economically feasible water power potential, the overall ratio for the entire world is barely 5%; so that the bulk of the developing countries have to harness their water power during the next decades. In fact, based on the analysis of the past trends, the period of development of 95% of the water power potential is in the order of 60 years, varying mainly between 30 to 100 years. Since full exploitation of water power and other conventional energy sources will not be sufficient in the next century, unconventional energy resources like solar energy have to be harnessed. In this respect, pumped-storage hydroelectric plants may greatly contribute to solar energy storage. (A)
Index Keywords: energy; hydropower; Water resources

Title: Flywheel energy storage interface unit for photovoltaic applications.
Source title: IN: PROC. 14TH INTERSOCIETY ENERGY CONVERSION ENGNG. CONF., (BOSTON, U.S.A.: AUG. 5-10, 1979)
Volume: 1 , Washington D.C., U.S.A., Am. Chem. Soc., 1979, Paper 799084
Authors with affiliations: Millner, A.R.; Hay, R.D.
Abstract: A flywheel energy storage and conversion system has been designed and a prototype is now being built at Massachusetts Institute of Technology/Lincoln Laboratory for the U.S. Department of Energy. It is intended to serve as an interface between a solar photovoltaic array and an AC load, providing output waveform regulation as well as energy storage. Important features include magnetic bearings, an ironless armature motor generator and a low-cost flywheel rotor. This paper describes the system design and prototype characteristics and includes a preliminary economic analysis. (A)

Authors: Clewer G.E., Davidson B.J., Spurr A.
Title: Thermal energy storage using hot liquids.
Source title: IN. PROC. INT. CONF. ON FUTURE ENERGY CONCEPTS, (LONDON, U.K.: JAN.30-FEB.1, 1979), LONDON, U.K., INST. ELECTR. ENGRS., 1979
Authors with affiliations: Clewer, G.E.; Davidson, B.J.; Spurr, A.
Abstract: Systems are described where heat is stored using liquids. Boiler feed water or saturated water may be stored under pressure; a further option considers the transfer of heat to an oil store at atmospheric pressure. The cost of the store is a key factor and three designs are considered. (from paper)

Title: National solar heating and cooling program of NewZealand.
Authors with affiliations: Benseman, R.F.; Collins, M.A.
Abstract: The direction and rate of progress of solar utilization in New Zealand has been conditioned by the particular energy and climatic structure. Solar water heating has always been the obvious line for development. The next step will be research directed at the problem of long term thermal storage.

Authors: Sharma A., Chiu H.H., Ahrens F.W., Ahluwalia R.K., Ragsdell K.M.
Title: Design of optimum compressed air energy-storage systems
Affiliations: University of Illinois at Chicago Circle, Chicago, IL 60680, U.S.A.; Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL 60439, United States; Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sharma, A., University of Illinois at Chicago Circle, Chicago, IL 60680, U.S.A.; Chiu, H.H., University of Illinois at Chicago Circle, Chicago, IL 60680, U.S.A.; Ahrens, F.W., Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL 60439, United States; Ahluwalia, R.K., Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL 60439, United States; Ragsdell, K.M., Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907, United States
Abstract: Compressed air energy storage (CAES) power systems are being considered by electric utilities for load-leveling application. Their economic benefit and the extent of premium fuel conservation is dependent on their design. An optimum design approach for CAES is presented in this paper. It is based on decomposition of the overall CAES plant/utility grid system into three partially-decoupled sybsystems. Technical and economic models of the subsystems are used in a constrained optimization procedure. The constraints are imposed by the physical characteristics of the subsystems, by interaction among the subsystems and by the interfacing requirements imposed by the utility. To illustrate the concepts, models for the system comprising the compressor train, piping, and an aquifer reservoir have been used in the optimization procedure. Results from these studies show that substantial reductions in capital cost and total operating cost can be achieved using optimization techniques. © 1979.
Index Keywords: AQUIFERS - Mathematical Models; COMPRESSORS - Mathematical Models; ELECTRIC POWER PLANTS - Energy Storage; OPTIMIZATION - Applications; PIPING SYSTEMS - Mathematical Models; Compressed air

Title: Energy Storage and transmission by chemical heat pipe
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Authors: Smith G.C., Wiles L.E., Loscutoff W.V.
Title: Numerical analysis of temperature and flow effects in a dry, one-dimensional aquifer used for compressed air energy storage.
Authors with affiliations: Smith, G.C.; Wiles, L.E.; Loscutoff, W.V.
Abstract: A description of the method of analysis and the results obtained for an investigation of the hydrodynamic and thermodynamic response of a model of a dry porous media reservoir used for compressed air energy storage is presented. Results were obtained from a one-dimensional simulation of the cycling of heated air to and from a radial flow field surrounding a single well in a porous rock. The performance of the bulk of the reservoir was assumed to be characterized by the performance of a single well. (A)

Title: Physical and chemical stability of Galesville sandstone at elevated temperatures and pressures.
Source title: IN: PROC. 14TH INTERSOCIETY ENERGY CONVERSION ENGNG. CONF. (BOSTON, U.S.A., AUG. 5-10, 1979)
Volume: 1 . Washington D.C., Am. Chem. Soc., 1979, paper 799093
Authors with affiliations: Stottlemyre, J.A.; Erikson, R.L.
Abstract: This paper summarizes observations from a preliminary set of laboratory-scale autoclave experiments on Galesville sandstone, a potential Compressed Air Energy Storage reservoir rock. The sandstone cores were subjected to various combinations of the following independant variable magnitudes: temperature (50-300SUPC), pressure (60-120 bars), time (0.5-2.0 mo), oxygen content (0-21 percent), carbon dioxide content (0.0-0.1 percent), humidity (0-100 percent), and autoclave type and stirring frequency. Three humidity conditions were simulated: (1) dry air, (2) air-water vapor, and (3) air-vapor-liquid,. Pre- and post-test measurements were made for gas permeability, liquid permeability and friability. Temperature, humidity, and time were discovered to be the dominant independent variables. Dissolution of silica and carbonate cements is considered to be the primary contributor to observed friability and permeability increases in cores treated at elevated temperature in a liquid and/or vapor environment. The lack of confining stress and high liquid-to-solid volume ratios are also considered to be significant contributory factors. The average change for air and liquid permeabilities was approximately 30+ or !10 percent for all conditions tested. The average increase in the 'friability' index was 150 percent. (A)

Title: Transient thermal analysis of phase change material energy storage system.
Authors with affiliations: Yimer, B.
Abstract: An analytical model was developed to determine the temperature distribution and interface location of phase change material energy storage systems.

Title: Pneumatic pressure storage work - a new type of a power station for the production of electrical peak energy.
Authors with affiliations: Gutter, G.
Abstract: The essay deals with three different basic types of the .Pneumatic Pressure Storage Work' (PPSW). Here represented is the basic type .PPSW with gradient discharge and impulse type expansion'. This is shown by a rationalization study - 700 MW PPSW. Advantages of power economy are also discussed. (A)

Title: Development and testing of the sulfuric acid-water chemical heat pump/chemical energy storage system.
Source title: IN: PROC. 14TH INTERSOCIETY ENERGY CONVERSION ENGNG. CONF', (BOSTON, U.S.A.: AUG.5-10, 1979)
Volume: 1 , Washington D.C., U.S'A., Am. Chem. Soc., 1979, Paper 799104
Authors with affiliations: C'C. Hiller; Clark, E.C.
Abstract: funding which has been successfully demonstrated in a meaningful scale. The present paper discusses principles of operation, preliminary economics, and testing of a prototype unit of nominal 25,000 to 35,000 BTU/hr (7 to 10 KW) capacity. (A) The Sulfuric Acid-Water Chemical Heat pump/Chemical Energy Storage (CHP/CES) system is the first of several such solar heating and cooling systems being developed under U.S. Department of Energy (DOE)

Title: The effects of water on compressed air energy storage in porous rock reservoirs.
Authors with affiliations: Wiles, L.E.
Abstract: A computer code developed to define the hydrodynamic and thermodynamic response to simulated air mass cycling in a CAES dry porous rock reservoir is described. Analytical and numerical models and the analysis of the moisture parameters are presented. (from paper)

Title: Batteries with Gaseous Electrodes. [AKUMULATORY S PLYNOVYMI ELEKTRODAMI.]
Authors with affiliations: Smrcek, Karel
Abstract: The principles of operation and features of a variety of batteries are discussed. The present state-of-the-art is outlined of both research and development of new types of batteries which, due to their specific energy and power parameters and perhaps also due to their economic advantages, may be superior to existing types of classical storage batteries.
Index Keywords: Electric batteries, Secondary

Authors: Cobb J.H., Iwata S., Rahm D.C., Rehak P., Stumer I., Fabjan C.W., Harris M., Lindsay J., Mannelli I., Nakamura K., Nappi A., Struczinski W., Willis W.J., Kourkoumelis C., Lankford A.J.
Title: A large liquid-argon shower detector for an ISR experiment
Affiliations: Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY, United States; CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Yale University, New Haven, CT, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cobb, J.H., Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY, United States; Iwata, S., Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY, United States; Rahm, D.C., Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY, United States; Rehak, P., Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY, United States; Stumer, I., Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY, United States; Fabjan, C.W., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Harris, M., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Lindsay, J., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Mannelli, I., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Nakamura, K., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Nappi, A., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Struczinski, W., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Willis, W.J., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Kourkoumelis, C., Yale University, New Haven, CT, United States; Lankford, A.J., Yale University, New Haven, CT, United States
Abstract: A large liquid-argon shower detector system has been constructed for the detection of photons and electrons at the CERN ISR. The calorimeter system is built in a modular way such that eight modules would cover = 2 π azimuthally with a total solid angle of Ω = 8 sr. Each module consists of 1.5 mm thick lead plates, spaced 2 mm apart. Longitudinal grouping and transversal division into strip-like sections of the charge-collecting electrodes provide the required spatial resolution and hadron discrimination. Measurements on energy and space resolution and electron/hadron discrimination are described. The signal-processing system, designed to minimize electronics noise, can handle event rates up to 0.5 MHz and provides energy information for trigger purposes. The performance of this calorimeter system during two years of ISR operation is reported. © 1979 North-Holland Publishing Co.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS - Storage Rings; ELECTRONS - Energy Analyzers; RADIATION DETECTORS

Authors: Hammerli M., Butler J.P., Stevens W.H.
Title: Peak power and heavy water production from nuclear electrolytic H2 and O2 in Canada
Affiliations: Atomic Energy of Canada Ltd, Chalk River Nuclear Laboratories, Chalk River, Ont., Canada
Authors with affiliations: Hammerli, M., Atomic Energy of Canada Ltd, Chalk River Nuclear Laboratories, Chalk River, Ont., Canada; Butler, J.P., Atomic Energy of Canada Ltd, Chalk River Nuclear Laboratories, Chalk River, Ont., Canada; Stevens, W.H., Atomic Energy of Canada Ltd, Chalk River Nuclear Laboratories, Chalk River, Ont., Canada
Abstract: A combined energy storage-heavy water production system is presented. Off-peak nuclear energy is stored in the form of electrolytic H2 (and O2) from which a large fraction of the deuterium has been transferred to water in a deuterium exchange catalyst column. The main features and advantages of the Combined Electrolysis Catalytic Exchange-Heavy Water Process (CECE-HWP) are discussed. Significant quantities of D2O could be produced economically at reasonable peak to base power cost ratios. Thirty to forty per cent of the primary electric energy should be available for peak energy via either gas-steam turbines or fuel cells. © 1979.
Index Keywords: DEUTERIUM; HEAVY WATER - Manufacture; HYDROGEN - Energy Storage; NUCLEAR ENERGY

Title: Converters for Supplying Pulsed Power Loads
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN 55455, United States; U.S. Ameradcom, DRXFB-EA, Fort Belvoir, VA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mohan, N., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN 55455, United States, U.S. Ameradcom, DRXFB-EA, Fort Belvoir, VA, United States
Abstract: There is a growing need for supplying repetitive pulsed power loads of increasing magnitudes up to several hundred megawatts or more in areas ofradar, lasers, high-energy physics experiments and thermonuclear fusion. The nature of such loads can be expected to be as diverse as their applications. The pulsed power demands and corresponding reactive volt-amperes requirements are undesirable from the frequency and voltage fluctuation standpoint, even for the large utility power systems. Techniques for supplying large dc-pulsed loads from a relatively small size ac generator by means of inductive storage and the capacitor commutated converters are presented. A theoretical basis is provided for analyzing the converters which serve to minimize the effects of pulsed power and corresponding reactive volt-amperes. Energy transfer between the storage inductor and the pulsed load is permitted with minimal loss, at a readily controllable rate including the reversibility of power in case of inductive loads. Use of a simple control scheme is shown to provide a precise load voltage regulation which may be a requirement for certain applications. The greatest use of theseI circuits would be in supplying loads with pulse durations of a few milliseconds to many seconds or minutes. Copyright © 1979 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: CONTROL, ELECTRIC VARIABLES - Voltage; ELECTRIC CONVERTERS

Authors: Adolfson W.E., Mahan J.S., Schmid E.M., Weinstein K.D.
Title: Geologic issues related to underground pumped hydroelectric and compressed air energy storage.
Source title: IN: PROC. 14TH INTERSOCIETY ENERGY CONVERSION ENGNG. CONF. (BOSTON, U.S.A., AUG. 5-10, 1979)
Volume: 1 . Washington D.C., Am. Chem. Soc., 1979, paper 799094
Authors with affiliations: Adolfson, W.E.; Mahan, J.S.; Schmid, E.M.; Weinstein, K.D.
Abstract: Analysis of the geologic issues related to compressed air energy storage (CAES) and underground pumped hydroelectric storage (UPH) systems demonstrated that geologic conditions will have a very significant impact on site selection, design, construction, and cost of these two systems. While CAES and UPH have some common elements, the environments for which each is suitable are very different. Preliminary geologic investigations have indicated the existance of suitable sites for the construction of CAES chambers in three storage media over broad geographic areas of the United States. These include salt deposits, competent rock, and aquifers. Favourable locations for UPH can be found in many competent rock media. While it may be generally concluded that there are no overall identifiable geological conditions that will prevent the development of either C4ES or UPH, geologic conditions may restrict or prevent development at specific sites. (A)
Index Keywords: pumped; Storage

Title: Hydro electric and future power energy systems.
Source title: IN: III WORLD CONGRESS ON WATER RESOURCES,
Volume: 2 , Washington, D.C., U.S.A., Int. Water Resour. Assoc., no date, Subtheme 2
Authors with affiliations: Thapar, O.D.
Abstract: Role of hydro electric in the future power energy systems is discussed with reference to Northern Region of India. Growth of power demands up to year 2010 for the region and available hydro-electric potential is estimated. Effect of development of unconventional sources of energy on power demand patterns is studied. Utilization of low head canal falls to meet energy demands is suggested. Hydro thermal power system with large sized thermal units (nuclear or coal based) are envisaged. Need for planning hydro installation for average flows; utilizing all the available run off is established. Increasing use of pumped storage facility (surface and underground) to meet capacity requirements is brought out. Large unit size and special operating characteristics of the hydro units for the role envisaged are also suggested. (A)

Title: A review of alternative CAES concepts for the future.
Source title: IN: PROC. 1978 SYMP. ON COMPRESSED AIR ENERGY STORAGE, (PACIFIC GROVE, U.S.A.: MAY 15-18, 1978)
Volume: 2 , Washington, D.C., U.S.A., U.S. Dept. Energy, Jan. 1979, Session VIII, Advanced Concepts II, p.967-
Authors with affiliations: Driggs, C.L.; Hobson, M.J.
Abstract: The majority of proposed CAES plant concepts for the near term typically are large scale units (180 to 280 MW) requiring high grade distillate fuel, generally intended for application to large utility systems in plant sizes of 500 to 2,000 MW. A number of alternative concepts involving the use of compressed air storage, including concepts for electric power generation on a small scale (1 to 100 MW) are reviewed in this paper, with some projections of performance and costs. The system discussed involve the use of alternative energy sources such as coal, wood, waste heat, and solar, wind and tidal/wave energy. The small systems may be particularly suited to applications in developing countries, where capital is in short supply and large centalized loads are less common than dispersed distribution. (A)

Title: Magnetic bearing support study for a 10 kW-hr energy storage flywheel.
Authors with affiliations: Eusepi, M.W.; Wilcock, D.F.
Abstract: The design of a magnetic suspension system which fully supports a 10 kW-hr energy storage flywheel is presented. Included in the design presentation are discussions leading to the selection of the suspension type and the extension of the design to other storage levels ranging from a 1 kW-hr vehicular size to a large 100 kW-hr stationary system.

Title: The application of wind energy to a system with an inherent energy storage medium.
Source title: IN: PROC. 14TH INTERSOCIETY ENERGY CONVERSION ENGNG. CONF. (BOSTON, U.S.A., AUG.5-10, 1979)
Volume: 1 . Washington D.C., Am. Chem. Soc., 1979, paper 799070
Authors with affiliations: Kobylarz, T.; Al-Shehri, A.
Abstract: Economics has severely limited the exploitation of wind energy to a few special situations, thus wasting a valuable energy source. One of the most costly aspects of a wind energy system is that of energy storage. It is therefore suggested that wind energy be utilized by systems having an inherent storage medium. One such system is studied in this paper. This is a chlorine and caustic soda production facility from the electrolysis of brine. By using wind speed data for Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, and published data for the system components, yields of chemicals and for power are predicted. (A)

Title: Hydrogen embrittlement of metals (citations from the American Petroleum Institute data base)
Authors with affiliations: Reed, W.E.
Abstract: Research reports on hydrogen embrittlement of ferrous and nonferrous metals are cited. Studies relating to mechanical properties, corrosion, failure, testing, and inhibition are presented. Hydrogen embrittlement is described in pressure vessels, pipes, welds, and steels. Reports on materials used in pipeline, refinery, petrochemical, and energy storage service are included. (Contains 181 abstracts).

Title: Renewable energy.
Authors with affiliations: Srensen, B.
Abstract: Contents : Perspective; The Origin of renewable energy flows; The individual energy sources-solar, wind, ocean waves, tides, geothermal, biological; The energy conversion processes; Energy transport and storage; Energy Supply Systems; Socio-economic assessment of energy supply systems.

Title: Sun up to sun down.
Authors with affiliations: Buckley, S.
Abstract: Solar energy is explained in clear and simplified terms to a general audience. Fluid analogies are applied to thermal phenomena to avoid complicated mathematics. Concepts discussed range from thermal resistance, conduction and convection, radiation and transport, thermal storage and house heating to solar collector orientation, glazing and selective surfaces, and air-heating solar systems.

Title: Wind energy conversion and hydrogen production: a feasibility study for South Africa.
Source title: IN: PROC. INT. CONF. ON FUTURE ENERGY CONCEPTS, (LONDON, U.K.: JAN.30-FEB.1, 1979), LONDON, U.K., INST. ELECTR. ENGRS., 1979
Authors with affiliations: Harley, R.G.; Ben-Dov, E.
Abstract: A feasibility study was undertaken in South Africa to assess three different wind energy conversion schemes. One scheme generates a.c. power and is synchronized to an electric utility grid which has energy storage capacity such as pumped water storage. A variant of this system has no storage capacity. The third system uses wind generated d.c. power in an electrolysis mode to generate hydrogen. (A.M.T.)

Title: An evaluation of thermal energy storage for residential air conditions applications.
Authors with affiliations: Jones, J.W.; Small, T.S.
Abstract: The application of duty cycle thermal energy storage in residential air conditioning has significant potential for energy use management. The purpose of this study has been to evaluate the technical feasibility of two thermal storage systems and to determine the possible energy and economic benefits of their use. A computerized load analysis and system simulation procedure was used to determine the power requirements of both storage and conventional air conditioning system for a 1600-sq ft residence. The results obtained indicate that thermal storage could have a positive impact . on utility load profiles. It could also result in operating cost savings to homeowners under proposed time-of-day rate schedules, but the high initial cost makes storage systems a marginal investment at present. The results indicate that the impact on residential energy conservation ranges from negligible to somewhat negative. (A)

Title: Wind power, volume 1. Citations from the engineering index data base, progress report, 1970 to 1977.
Authors with affiliations: Hundemann, A.S.
Abstract: This bibliography contains 210 citations on windmill and wind power feasibility, use, and engineering. The use of wind power for electric power generation and wind turbine design and performance is considered. The use of wind power in developing countries and comparative analyses of wind power and alternative energy sources are included, as are studies on energy storage systems. (A)

Authors: Lustenader E.L., Edelfelt I.H., Jones D.W., Plunkett A.B., Richte E., Turnbull F.G.
Title: Regenerative flywheel energy storage system.
Source title: IN: PROC. 14TH INTERSOCIETY ENERGY CONVERSION ENGNG. CONF., (&OSTON, U.S.A.: AUG. 5-10, 1979)
Volume: 1 , Washington D.C., U.S.A., Am. Chem. Soc., 1979, Paper 977077
Authors with affiliations: Lustenader, E.L.; Edelfelt, I.H.; Jones, D.W.; Plunkett, A.B.; Richte, E.; Turnbull, F.G.
Abstract: This paper describes the current status of a program to develop and evaluate a regenerative flywheel energy storage system. The system has been designed for a battery/flywheel electric vehicle in the 3000 pound class. Planned laboratory tests will simulate this electric vehicle operating over the SAE J227a Schedule D driving cycle. The range improvement attributed to the use of the flywheel will be established. The flywheel energy storage system will consist of a solid rotor, synchronous inductor-type flywheel drive machine electrically coupled to a DC battery electric propulsion system through a load commutated inverter. The motor/alternator unit is coupled mechanically to a small steel flywheel which provides a portion of the vehicle's accelerating energy and regenerates the vehicle's braking energy. The laboratory simulation of the electric vehicle propulsion system will include a 108 volt lead-acid battery bank, a separately excited DC propulsion motor coupled to a flywheel which simulates the vehicle's inertia, and the flywheel energy storage system comprised of the motor/flywheel unit, the load commutated inverter and its control. (A)

Title: Novel flywheel energy storage system.
Source title: IN: PROC. 14TH INTERSOCIETY ENERGY CONVERSION ENGNG. CONF., (BOSTON, U.S.A.: AUG. 5-10, 1979)
Volume: 1 , Washington D.C., U.S.A., Am. Chem. Soc., 1979, Paper 799082
Authors with affiliations: Chicurel, R.
Abstract: This report describes a kinetic energy storage system in which a flywheel rotates inside an evacuated casing. Both the flywheel and the casing rotates about a horizontal axis, but the speed of the second is much lower than that of the first. This is governed by a fixed ratio mechanical drive also contained within the casing itself. The reaction torque required by the drive is provided by the action of gravity on a reaction member which is mounted in the manner of a pendulum. Three versions of the system are proposed. A prototype of one of these with a capacity of 25 watt-hours is being built. (A)

Title: Study of a wall heat storage for solar energy.
Source title: IN: CANCAM '79, PROC. SEVENTH CANADIAN CONGRESS OF APPLIED MECHANICS, (SHERBROOKE, CANADA: MAY 27-JUN.1, 1979), F. ELLYIN; K.
Volume: 2 , Sherbrooke, Canada, Proc. Seventh Canadian Congress Appl. Mech., 1979
Authors with affiliations: Bilgen, E.; Chaaban, M.
Abstract: This paper presents the theoretical studies relating the storage system of a modified Trombe wall collector.

Title: Superconducting magnetic energy storage for electric power'
Source title: IN: PROC' 14TH INTERSOCIETY ENERGY CONVERSION ENGNG' CONF., (BOSTON, U.S.A.: AUG.5-10, 1979)
Volume: 1 , Washington, D.C., U.S.AY, Am. Chem' Soc', 1979, Paper 799101
Authors with affiliations: Turner, R.D.
Abstract: A Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) system is being developed at the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory (LASL) for a dynamic stabilizer to be installed in the Bonneville Power Administration (EPA) power system at Tacoma, Washington, by 1982 . This unit will be an alternate stabilization method to the dc modulator now used to stabilize the 900 mile, ac intertie between BPA and Southern California. The generation control systems response to the constantly occuring, small-load and voltage changes can result in negatively damped, low-frequency power oscillations. The dc modulator provides stabilization by fast load control of the High-Voltage dc (HVDC). The SMES unit consists of a 30-MJ solenoid, a 10-MW convertor, a liquid helium dewar, and auxiliary systems which operate independent of the HVDC systems. The SMES dynamic stabilizer design is presented herein, and status information is given about the superconducting coil, the converter, and other components of the SMES dynamic stabilizer. (A)

Title: The desiccant/rock bed method of solar cooling with air collectors.
Source title: IN: PROC. 14TH INTERSOCIETY ENERGY CONVERSION ENGNG. CONF., (BOSTON, U.S.A.: AUG.5-10, 1979)
Volume: 1 , Washington D.C., U.S.A., Am. Chem. Soc., 1979, paper 799058
Authors with affiliations: Meredith, D.B.; Wilbur, P.J.
Abstract: A method of cooling buildings with solar energy is presented that incorporates a fixed desiccant bed, an evaporative cooler, associated controls and dampers, and conventional components and controls of a solar air heating system. All components are commercially available items and the three heating modes (direct heating with solar, solar heat to storage, and heating from storage) remain unchanged. The three additional operating modes pertaining to cooling (air conditioning, solar regeneration of the desiccant, and night regeneration of the rock bed) have been added. To investigate the thermal performance of the system under typical weather and insolation conditions, a transient simulation model was constructed using TRNSYS. The operating parameters assumed in the model are representative of the building and solar heating system of Solar House II at Colorado State University. The hourly weather values assumed were for a summer season in Washington, D.C. The predicted operating characteristics, thermal coefficient of performance and electrical Energy Efficiency Ratio (EEF) are discussed. (A)

Title: Wind power for domestic use in the United Kingdom.
Source title: IN: PROC. INT. CONF. ON FUTURE ENERGY CONCEPTS, (LONDON, U.K.: JAN.30-FEB.1, 1979), LONDON, U.K., INST. ELECTR. ENGRS., 1979
Authors with affiliations: Littler, J.G.F.; Thomas, R.B.
Abstract: The Cambridge autarkic housing project was designed to study the provision of electricity to houses with little or no network energy. The project has concentrated on the provision of 240V 50Hz domestic supplies by means of wind power. In addition to describing the wind turbine to be used at Cambridge, the authors summarise the approach used in optimising the division of expenditure on thermal storage and wind turbine size when considering the use of wind power for space and water heating. (from paper)

Authors: Molz F.J., Warman J.C., Meyer C.F.
Title: Aquifer storage of heated water: a step towards practical application.
Source title: IN: III WORLD CONGRESS ON WATER RESOURCES,
Volume: 2 , Washington, D.C., U.S.A., Int. Water Resour. Assoc., no date, Subtheme 2
Authors with affiliations: Molz, F.J.; Warman, J.C.; Meyer, C.F.
Abstract: Significant energy and cost savings can result from large-scale cogeneration of electricity and heat if a means is available for efficiently storing large amounts of heat at low cost and low loss for months at a time. Aquifer storage through the use of heat storage wells may provide the necessary storage requirements. To test the concept and to provide data for calibration of computer models, an aquifer injection, storage and recovery experiment was performed using warm water. Heat storage aquifers should have low natural pore velocities; care must be taken not to clog the injection well with solids or precipitated chemicals. Swelling of clays in the storage formation must be minimized, and excessive hydraulic pressures must be avoided. Mechanical and chemical clogging problems may be minimized by using formation water as influent to the heating system. For a 36-day storage of 21 million gallons, computer simulations predicted an energy recovery factor of 0.75; the measured value is 0.69.
Index Keywords: Energy storage

Title: Prediction of vehicle performance and its sensitivity to component improvements: applications to electric and H2-fueled vehicles.
Source title: IN: PROC. 14TH INTERSOCIETY ENERGY CONVERSION ENGNG. CONF., (BOSTON, U.S.A.: AUG. 5-10, 1979)
Volume: 1 , Washington D.C., U.S.A., Am. Chem. Soc., 1979, Paper 799076
Authors with affiliations: McAlevy, R.F.
Abstract: Simple, algebraic equations were used to relate vehicle mass, WT, and energy consumption, C, to parameters describing vehicle components characteristics. By differentiation, the sensitivity of WT and C to component improvements was determined and used to formulate a rational R & D investment policy. For H2-fueled vehicles and electric vehicles, EV's R & D investment in improving vehicle energy-storage device was predicted to produce greater decreases in WT and C than investment in the power-train. Using a published forecast of component characteristics, WT and C for both kinds of vehicles were projected into future time-frames. Numerical results are presented. (A)

Authors: Grandbois H., Sangster J., Paris J.R.
Title: A cycle life tester for the long-term stability of phase change materials for thermal energy storage.
Authors with affiliations: Grandbois, H.; Sangster, J.; Paris, J.R.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Sensitivity analysis of a community solar system using annual cycle thermal energy torage.
Authors with affiliations: Baylin, F.; Monte, R.
Abstract: The objective of this research is to assess the sensitivity of design parameters of a community solar heating system having annual thermal energy storage to factors including climate, building type, community size, collector type and inclination, and soil conditions. The system under consideration uses a large, water-filled concrete, constructed tank for providing space heating and DHW. Although a number of systems have been constructed in Canada (1,2) and Sweden (3) and designs for others are underway in Canada, Sweden (4), and France (5), no such systematic study has yet been performed. This presentation details the technical analysis:

Title: Dynamic design study of a hydrostatic transmission system for urban buses.
Source title: IN: PROC. 5TH WORLD CONGRESS ON THE THEORY OF MACHINES AND MECHANISMS, (MONTREAL, CANADA: JUL. 8-13, 1979)
Volume: 1 , New York, U.S.A., Am. Soc. Mech. Engrs, 1979
Authors with affiliations: Svoboda, J.
Abstract: The transmission system consists of a standard bus Diesel engine driving a double bent-axis variable-displacement pump which in turn powers two hub mounted high-torque low-speed ball motors. The driver-operated accelerator adjusts the setting of the engine speed governor. The pump displacement is automatically adjusted according to the engine speed and the system pressure in such a manner that an optimum engine loading is maintained. The displacement of the motors is halved by a pressure signal as soon as the vehicle reaches approximately half of the maximum velocity. The transmission is equ ipped with a hydraulic accumulator energy storage which assists the prime mover in accelerating the vehicle and allows for regenerative braking. According to the driving mode, i.e. whether the accelerator or the brake is activated, the accumulator is connected to the pump inlet or the motor outlet respectively. The system design was extensively aided by an analog computer model developed in three phases. The first phase dealt with simplified closed circuit transmission without control which was added to the model in the second phase. Finally, the accumulator with its control was incorporated in the third phase. The model was subjected to accelerator and brake step inputs and the bus performance predicted. 'Driving' of the system was manually operated accelerator/brake simulator clrified the system operation and hinted at possible system improvements. (A)

Title: On the economic assessment and optimization of energy storage systems
Affiliations: Energy Technology Assessment Group, National Center for Analysis of Energy Systems, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States
Authors with affiliations: Davitian, H., Energy Technology Assessment Group, National Center for Analysis of Energy Systems, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States; Leigh, R.W., Energy Technology Assessment Group, National Center for Analysis of Energy Systems, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States
Abstract: A method is described for the economic optimization and comparative evaluation of various energy storage systems in a given application. The method is particularly useful in examining the economics of devices with short lifetimes and can be employed whenever a device lifetime can be expressed as a function of physical parameters which are related to the manner in which the device is used. Given a detailed description of the pattern of use of the device in the application, the device lifetime can be calculated. The economic consequences of changes in lifetime result from the dependence of the capital recovery factor on device lifetime. It is shown how analyses can be made of changes in technical performance characteristics or changes in the pattern of use of the storage device to determine their effects upon the annual cost of energy storage and to determine minimum cost systems. © 1979.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY - Energy Storage; OPTIMIZATION - Applications; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: Evaluation of ammonium toluene sulphonate (ATS) and ammonium sulphamate (AMS) as catalysts for pigment prints
Affiliations: BTRA
Authors with affiliations: Varghese, J., BTRA; Gore, A.V., BTRA
Abstract: [No abstract available]
Index Keywords: AGEING (STORAGE); AMMONIUM SULPHAMATE; AMMONIUM TOLUENE SULPHONATE; CATALYSTS; COLOURFASTNESS; COLOURFASTNESS TESTING; CONCENTRATION; CROCKFASTNESS; CURING; DIAMMONIUM PHOSPHATE; ENERGY; FABRICS; PIGMENT PRINTING; POPLIN; PRINTING; PRINTING PASTES; SOLAR ENERGY; TEMPERATURE; TIME; WASHFASTNESS (COLOUR); WOVEN FABRICS

Title: Energy-storage systems.
Authors with affiliations: Kalhammer, F.R.
Abstract: Pumped storage energy abstraction from pumped storage hydropower schemes in the U.S. is detailed with the methods of energy storage in commercial and residential structures. The application of energy storage in solar energy systems over a range of sizes is then given.(AJP)

Title: Wind power, volume 2. Citations from the engineering index data base, progress report, 1978 to Apr.1979.
Authors with affiliations: Hundeman, A.S.
Abstract: Windmill and wind power feasibility, use, and engineering are discussed in these citations. Abstracts primarily cover the use of wind power for electric power generation and wind turbine design and performance. General studies dealing with the use of wind power in developing countries and comparative analyses of wind power and alternative energy sources are included, as are studies on energy storage systems. This updated bibliography contains 125 abstracts, 113 of which are new entries to the previous edition.

Title: Solar energy R&D projects in Denmark.
Authors with affiliations: Korsgaard, V.; Esbensen, T.V.
Abstract: Finance has been allocated for a five year R&D programme on solar heating and a low-energy housing project.
Index Keywords: and; development; district; Heating; Research; salt hydrates; Storage

Title: Commerical solar augmented heat pump system.
Authors with affiliations: Wilborn, J.
Abstract: Solar energy is collected from 600 square feet of solar collector panels which have been mounted on the roof. Buried tanks having a total capacity of 4,000 gallons store thermal energy. A complete and automated operation control system and instrumentation package have been included. The system features flexible operation and can operate in multiple modes. These modes of operation will allow testing with and without solar collectors and with and without thermal storage. The first concept to be evaluated in the test program is that of solar augmentation. Thermal energy collected by the solar panels is stored in the thermal storage tanks and used as required to supply source energy to the heat pumps. Afternoon heat of rejection from the heat pumps is stored until the following morning and used as the source energy during early morning building warmup. Data is recorded on magnetic tape at fifteen minute intervals. This data includes system temperatures, power consumption, liquid flowrates and weather parameters. A computer program processes the data and generates daily, monthly and yearly summaries. (Microfiche)

Authors: Petri R.J., Claar T.D., Marianowski L.G.
Title: Evaluation of molten carbonates as latent heat thermal energy storage materials.
Authors with affiliations: Petri, R.J.; Claar, T.D.; Marianowski, L.G.
