Abstract: Experimental results of comparative screening studies of candidate molten-carbonate salts as phase-change materials (PCM) for advanced solar thermal energy storage applications at 540SUP to 870SUP and Steam-Rankine electric generation at 400SUP to 540SUPC are presented.

Title: Drakensberg pumped storage scheme.
Authors with affiliations: Bowcock, J.
Abstract: The Drakensberg pumped storage scheme, presently under construction near Bergville in Natal, is an imaginative project. Not only will it be used to store surplus off-peak energy for the Electricity Supply Commission (Escom) but it will also be employed to pump water over the Drakensberg escarpment into the Vaal catchment on behalf of the Department of Water Af fairs. Construction of the underground works is now well advanced and more than 50 per cent of the excavations have been completed. (A)

Title: Status and prospects of local solar heating and cooling systems
Affiliations: Kuwait Institute for Scientific Research, P.O. Box 12009, Kuwait
Authors with affiliations: Puri, V.M., Kuwait Institute for Scientific Research, P.O. Box 12009, Kuwait
Abstract: In this paper, a state-of-the-art of solar heating and cooling systems is presented. Solar air heaters and different types of solar water collectors are discussed in detail. Storage systems including water, rocks, and heat-of-fusion salts are described as are space heating systems employing solar air heaters, in conjunction with rock or heat-of-fusion salt storage, and the use of water collectors plus hot water storage for space heating and domestic hot water. An indication of the commercialization of various space-heating systems and broad economic projections are presented. The three major solar cooling methods-absorption cooling, solar mechanical systems, and those involving humidification-dehumidification cycles-are also discussed in detail. Finally, an overview of solar heating and cooling activities in Kuwait is also given. © 1979.
Index Keywords: AIR CONDITIONING - Solar Energy Systems; BUILDINGS - Energy Conservation; HEATING

Authors: Kamimoto M., Tani T., Horigome T.
Title: SURVEY OF THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE FOR SOLAR THERMAL POWER PLANT.
Authors with affiliations: Kamimoto, M.; Tani, T.; Horigome, T.
Abstract: This paper surveys various concepts of thermal energy storage that have been proposed to enable solar thermal power systems to operate during momentary interruptions of sunlight and during night hours. The concepts, some of which are being tested on laboratory scales, are classified into sensible heat storage, latent heat storage and chemical energy storage. Technological and economic evaluation is given to each classified storage concept.
Index Keywords: Solar power plants

Title: Sizing phase-change energy storage units for air-based solar heating systems
Affiliations: Solar Energy Laboratory, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jurinak, J.J., Solar Energy Laboratory, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States; Abdel-Khalik, S.I., Solar Energy Laboratory, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States
Abstract: A simple method for sizing phase-change energy storage (PCES) units for air-based solar heating systems is presented. An effective heat capacity for the phase change unit is obtained as a function of its mass, latent heat, specific heat, and melting temperature. The effective heat capacity can then be used, along with any convenient design method for systems with sensible heat stores, such as the f-chart method, to estimate the thermal performance of the system utilizing PCES. © 1979.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SOLAR ENERGY; HEATING

Authors: Grimmer D.P., McFarland R.D., Balcomb J.D.
Title: Initial experimental tests on the use of small passive-solar test-boxes to model the thermal performance of passively solar-heated building designs
Affiliations: Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87544, United States
Authors with affiliations: Grimmer, D.P., Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87544, United States; McFarland, R.D., Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87544, United States; Balcomb, J.D., Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87544, United States
Abstract: Small passive-solar test-boxes can be a useful tool in the thermal-modelling of a passively solar-heated building designs. Several cubic-meter sized test-boxes have been constructed that incorporate basic elements of passive-solar design: glazings to admit solar radiation, good thermal insulation, and large thermal storage capacity within the insulation-envelope. The experimental thermal behavior of these text-boxes has been accurately computer simulated using weather and solar radiation data inputs, and correlated with the performance of large passive test rooms nearby. Similar small test boxes can be constructed to perform as thermal models of a particular passive-solar building design, by normalizing the appropriate thermal design parameters to one critical parameter, such as south-facting glazing area, or building floor area. Thus a thermal model will not resemble a scaled architectural model of the building, but will be distorted in appearance so as to exhibit thermal behavior similar to the real building. For a particular passive-solar building design to be located at a given site, a small thermal model of the building can be constructed and placed at the site to investigate possible micro-climate effects, such as a south-facing slope or nearby trees. The use of small passive-solar test-boxes complements simulation analyses of the influence of macro-climate and geometry on the performance of passive solar heated buildings. The accuracy and limitations of using small test-boxes to predict passive-solar building performance are discussed. © 1979.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Space Heating; ENERGY UTILIZATION; SOLAR ENERGY; HEATING

Title: Specific heat variations in oil energy storage media and their economic implications
Affiliations: Sandia Laboratories, Livermore, CA 94550, United States
Authors with affiliations: Carling, R.W., Sandia Laboratories, Livermore, CA 94550, United States; Radosevich, L.G., Sandia Laboratories, Livermore, CA 94550, United States
Abstract: [No abstract available]
Index Keywords: HYDROCARBONS; SOLAR ENERGY; HYDROCARBON OIL; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: Load-Commutated Inverter/Synchronous Motor Drive Without a Shaft Position Sensor
Affiliations: Power Electronics Laboratory, Corporate Research and Development Center, General Electric Company, Schenectady, NY 12301, United States
Authors with affiliations: Plunkett, A.B., Power Electronics Laboratory, Corporate Research and Development Center, General Electric Company, Schenectady, NY 12301, United States; Turnbull, F.G., Power Electronics Laboratory, Corporate Research and Development Center, General Electric Company, Schenectady, NY 12301, United States
Abstract: Synchronous motor drives are beginning to enjoy renewed popularity for certain applications such as flywheel energy storage. One of the reasons is that a synchronous motor drive can be made self-commutating so that the inverter becomes equivalent to a conventional phase-control bridge converter without large commutating components. The drive to be controlled consists of an inductor alternator coupled to a flywheel that will be used for temporary energy storage. The flywheel speed will vary over a two-to-one range;thus full performance can be achieved using a load-commutated inverter. A simple auxiliary commutating circuit is provided only for initial starting. The drive must operate both from a fixed dc voltage source (battery) and from a variable dc voltage source (dc motor), as it is intended for use in a battery-powered vehicle for load leveling. The load-commutated inverter consists of two bridges connected in parallel so as to provide two-way power flow by reversing the dc current. The control system described does not use shaft position sensing, but senses the motor terminal voltage and the ac line current to determine the motor internal operating conditions. This control method maintains the silicon-controlled rectifier (SCR) turn-off time as a constant percentage 1 of the period of the generated back electromotive force (EMF) as speed and current are varied during operation. The inverter turn-offtime is thus maintained by feedback control rather than the use of special function generators. A 20-kVA laboratory development drive system has been built and successfully tested using this control strategy. A hybrid computer simulation of the drive and control system hasbeen implemented, and the results are described. Copyright © 1979 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC MOTORS, SYNCHRONOUS; ELECTRIC DRIVE

Title: Sodium/Sulfur Battery - A Storage Device for Peakshaving and Electric Traction. [DIE NATRIUM/SCHWEFEL-BATTERIE - EIN SPEICHER FUER DEN SPITZENLASTAUSGLEICH UND DIE ELEKTROTRAKTION.]
Authors with affiliations: Fischer, W.
Abstract: A brief evaluation of the sodium/sulfur batteries is presented. When fully developed, these batteries are expected to store about four times more energy per unit of mass, to be cheaper and to have a longer life cycle than the lead acid batteries. Thanks to their high energy density, sodium/sulfur batteries will enable the construction of electric vehicles with a longer range than vehicles propelled by lead acid batteries. Another possible application is load leveling in electric networks.
Index Keywords: STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES; ELECTRIC VEHICLES; Electric batteries, Secondary

Title: Simulation of a Solar Heating System. [SIMULATION D'UN SYSTEME DE CHAUFFAGE SOLAIRE.]
Authors with affiliations: Canellias, M.; Javelas, R.
Abstract: Basic principles are presented for two flat solar heaters. One system has uniform temperature in storage tank while the other is designed to have stratified temperatures. Optimum angles for solar collectors are given, taking into consideration the effects of flow characteristics.
Index Keywords: Solar energy

Authors: Smith G.C., Wiles L.E., Loscutoff W.V.
Title: Numerical analysis of temperature and flow effects in a dry one-dimensional aquifer used for compressed air energy storage.
Authors with affiliations: Smith, G.C.; Wiles, L.E.; Loscutoff, W.V.
Abstract: A detailed description of the method of analysis and the results obtained for an investigation of the hydrodynamic and thermodynamic response of a model of a dry porous media reservoir used for compressed air energy storage (AES).

Authors: Weber M.E., Mujumdor A.S., Ashraf F.A.
Title: PCM thermal energy storage in cylindrical containers of various configurations.
Authors with affiliations: Weber, M.E.; Mujumdor, A.S.; Ashraf, F.A.
Abstract: [No abstract available]
Index Keywords: Phase change materials

Title: A parametric analysis of turbomachinery options for compressed air energy storage plants.
Source title: IN: PROC. 1978 COMPRESSED AIR ENERGY STORAGE SYMP., (PACIFIC GROVE, U.S.A.: MAY 15-18, 1978)
Volume: 1 , Washington D.C., U.S.A., U.S. Dept. Energy, 1979, Session VI, p.443-476. (Conf. 780599)
Authors with affiliations: Kim, C.S.; Kartsounes, G.T.
Abstract: A study of possible turbomachinery options for compressed air energy storage plants. The plant has four subsystems: a turbine system, compressor systrem, motor/generator, and an underground air storage reservoir. The turbine system comprises a high-pressure turbine, a low-pressure turbine, two combustors, and a recuperator. The compressor system comprises a low-pressure compressor, high-pressure compressor, booster compressor, intercoolers, and an aftercooler. A water-compensated mined cavern constitutes the underground air-storage reservoir. Plant performance is presented in terms of five parameters: specific air flow rate, specific heat rate, specific storage volume, specific compression rate, and plant efficiency. The capital and operating costs of the plant as a function of the turbo-machinery options are presented. Design variables of the turbomachinery are the reservoir pressure and inlet gas temperatures to the turbines. (A)

Authors: Willet D.C., Thompson S.N., Denham R.S.
Title: Site selection procedures for underground pumped hydro energy storage facilities.
Authors with affiliations: Willet, D.C.; Thompson, S.N.; Denham, R.S.
Abstract: A six-step methodology has been developed for the site selection of an underground pumped hydro (UPH) plant. The methodology is generic and, with minor modifications, considered applicable for any geographic region. The methodology is based on (a) technical factors that are considered to have the greatest economic impact on plant construction, and (b) evaluation of the environmental impacts expected during construction and plant operation. The methodology is structured to select the most preferred site(s) from within a large geographic region. The initial steps of the methodology are designed to systematically screen and eliminate areas withing the region of study considered totally unsuitable for UPH development. The later steps of the methodology involve the use of a technical and environmental index ranking system. (A)
Index Keywords: pumped storage

Authors: Schaetzle W.J., Fang L.R., Brett C.E., Grubbs D.M.
Title: A solar energy system with annual aquifier storage.
Authors with affiliations: Schaetzle, W.J.; Fang, L.R.; Brett, C.E.; Grubbs, D.M.
Abstract: By utilizing a sufficiently large thermal energy storage system, solar energy can be collected the year round and utilized during relatively short periods. Solar energy collected in the summer can be used in the winter. In some cases, over four times as much solar energy can be collected per month in the summer versus collection per month in the winter. The actual capital cost of the solar system for heating with storage can be reduced by over a factor of two where adequate aquifiers are available. Two examples are analyzed, one in Boston, Massachusetts and one in Birmingham, Alabama. The advantages of annual storage can decrease the capital costs appreciably. For heating in the northern parts of the continental United States collector areas can be reduced by over 75 percent. This reduction will result in a similar reduction in capital cost, thereby increasing the feasibility of solar systems. (A)

Title: Coal gas-fired compressed air energy storage.
Source title: IN: PROC. 1978, SYMP. ON COMPRESSED AIR ENERGY ENERGY STORAGE, (PACIFIC GROVE, U.S.A.: MAY 15-18, 1978)
Volume: 2 , Washington, D.C., U.S.A., U.S. Dept. Energy, Jan. 1979, Session VIII, Advanced Concepts II, p.897-
Authors with affiliations: Haydock, J.L.; Giramonti, A.J.
Abstract: Initially, Compressed Air Energy Storage ( CAES ) plants will be oil-fired. To the extent that their output replaces oil-fired generation in the utility power system, fuel oil consumption can be halved. The full potential of CAES for oil conservation will, however, not be realized until coal-fired CAES plants become available. Several different forms of air storage plant based on coal gasification are presented. Regenerative gas turbine and combined gas/steam power cycles are considered. A concept for self-contained coal burning CAES plant based on continuous coal gasification is described. In the limit, this type of plant is independent of energy to storage from electric power systems. (A)

Title: Survey of flue gas desulfurization systems: Lawrence Energy Center, Kansas Power and Light Co.
Authors with affiliations: Laseke, B.A.
Abstract: This report describes the results of a survey of operational flue gas desulfurization (FGD) systems on coal-fired utility boilers in the United States. The FGD systems installed on Units 4 and 5 at the Lawrence Energy Center of the Kansas Power and Light Company is described in terms of design and performance. The FGD system installed on each unit consists of two parallel two-stage scrubber modules, each of which includes a rectangular, variable-throat rod-deck venturi scrubber arranged in series with a spray tower absorber. Each system is also equipped with slurry-hold tanks, mist eliminators, and in-line reheaters, as well as isolation and bypass dampers. The two systems share a common limestone storage and preparation facility and waste-disposal facility. (A)

Title: Application and design studies of compressed-air energy storage for solar applications, final report.
Authors with affiliations: Flynn, G.T.; Nash-Webber, J.L.
Abstract: This report describes a study of adiabatic Compressed-Air Energy Storage (CAES), in which both the heat of compression and the compresed air are stored separately, and the applicability of this technology to solar power systems. The basic thermodynamics of ideal single- and two-stage adiabatic CAES is reviewed. Generic single-stage and two-stage types are discussed, and efficiency and mass flow rate as a function of storage pressure and stage pressure ratios are investigated. The performance and cost of available turbomachinery for the single- and two-stage adiabatic systems are given in detail as the basis for evaluating sixteen candidate near-term single-stage and two-stage designs. Both excavated caverns and abandoned mines are considered for storage reservoirs. Two scenarios are considered regarding joint application of CAES and Solar Thermal Energy (STE) systems. One is based on providing local CAES storage for STE systems, other on providing solar-augmentation to adiabatic CAES installations. Both solar-heated thermal storage and fuel firing are considered for provision of necessary backup during bad weather. Solar-heated heat-topping of adiabatic CAES is also considered, but rejected as an unattractive technology. The economics of all these systems is ranked on the basis of delivered busbar energy cost for three different charging energy costs. The adiabatic systems are compared to fired systems to determine the breakeven cost of fuel which yields the same busbar energy cost. An economic comparison with pumped hydro and peaking gas turbines is also given. Recommendations for future development of this technology are presented. (ERA citation 05.0085783).

Authors: Joon K., Sens P.F., van Koppen W.J.
Title: National solar heating and cooling program in the Netherlands.
Authors with affiliations: Joon, K.; Sens, P.F.; van Koppen, W.J.
Abstract: The Netherlands have a limited solar research programme, gas is relatively cheap in Holland, and the climate does not lend itself to a large application of solar energy. There is a four phase programme on solar domestic water heating, solar space heating, seasonal storage and solar cooling.

Authors: Schaetzle W.J., Brett E., Ansari J.M.
Title: Thermal energy storage in aquifiers for a solar power plant
Authors with affiliations: Schaetzle, W.J.; Brett, E.; Ansari, J.M.
Abstract: It is proposed to develop a thermal energy storage system in a confined aquifier which can be utilized with a solar power plant. The proposed operation temperature is 200 C. The transfer of thermal energy to the aquifer is made with pressurized water injection and withdrawal through a unique system which has been developed. (from paper)

Title: The selection of high-head pump-turbine equipment for underground pumped hydro energy storage application.
Authors with affiliations: Rodrique, P.
Abstract: For an underground pumped hydro energy storage plant, the lower reservoir is the most costly component. For economic reasons it is therefore desirable to maximize the plant head and hence, for a given storage capacity, reduce the size of the lower reservoir. This paper reviews various types of applicable high head pump-turbines and examines some of the considerations in selection of this equipment for an underground pumped hydro project. Some of the potential problems of extending pump-turbine head and capacity beyond current experience are also described. (A)
Index Keywords: pumped storage

Title: Advanced solar thermal storage medium test data and analysis.
Authors with affiliations: Saha, H.
Abstract: The primary objective of this paper is to present a comparative study of the experimental data of heat transfer and heat storage characteristics of a solar thermal energy storage bed utilizing containerized water, fused salt, and rocks as storage media. The test results and analysis thus far show that this type of storage device will be well suited for use with solar air systems for space and hot water heating in both active and passive systems. (from paper)

Title: Analysis of hybrid CAES systems using thermal storage.
Source title: IN: PROC. 1978 SYMP. ON COMPRESSED AIR ENERGY STORAGE, (PACIFIC GROVE, U.S.A.: MAY 15-18, 1978)
Volume: 2 , Washington, D.C., U.S.A., U.S. Dept. Energy, Jan. 1979, Session VII, Advanced Concepts (1), p.763-
Authors with affiliations: Kreid, D.K.; McKinnon, M.A.
Abstract: This paper summarizes the principal results and conclusions of an analysis of hybrid Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) systems that use Thermal Energy Storage (TES) for recovery of the heat of compression. The performance of the hybrid cycle is studied parametrically and compared with the performance of similar conventional cycles that use cooled compressors and exhaust heat recuperation. Preconceptual designs and cost estimates are provided for several TES systems that might be suitable for CAES applications. A ranking of these options according to costs indicates that pebble beds are likely to be most economical for CAES. The performance analysis indicates that the potential turbine fuel savings in a hybrid system with TES are minimal compared with a similar conventional cycle with recuperation. The conclusion is that the value of turbine fuel saved is unlikely to balance the anticipated additional cost of compression energy and the higher costs of the TES system. Thus, recovery of the heat of compression does not appear practical if fuel is available to fire the turbines.

Title: Water compensated CAES cavern design.
Source title: IN: PROC. 1978 SYMP. ON COMPRESSED AIR ENERGY STORAGE, (PACIFIC GROVE, U.S.A.: MAY 15-18)
Volume: 2 , Washington, D.C., U.S.A., U.S. Dept. Energy, Jan. 1979, Session VI, CAES in Hard Rock Caverns, p.5
Authors with affiliations: Gill, J.D.; Hobson, M.J.
Abstract: The physical configuratibn, shape and size for the excavation of a deep water compensated compressed air energy storage cavern is constrained by a number of important factors. With respect to configuration, these factors are orientation of principal joints in the rock mass, air leakage potential, wave propagation and carry-over of water into the air discharge pipe. The principal factors affecting cavern shape and size are rock strength. Young's modulus and joint frequency. Within the framework of these parameters, the economical construction of a cavern indicates the optimum cavern sizes and configuration. Due to these constraints, sensing and monitoring devices must also be incorporated into the design to monitor critical cavern functions as well as cavern integrity. This paper reviews these factors and suggests an approach to cavern design which attempts to satisfy these requirements. (A)

Authors: Eusepi M., Martin L., Ray A.
Title: Application of magnetic suspensions and fluid film bearings to energy storage flywheels. Technical report.
Authors with affiliations: Eusepi, M.; Martin, L.; Ray, A.
Abstract: The result of the study presented is the design of a suspension system for the support of a 10 kWh energy storage flywheel, with scaling equations and curves suitable for extending the 10 kWh design to other flywheel sizes up o 100 kWh. Included in the study is the design of a test vehicle suitable for evaluating the final suspension design. The first phase of this effort was a concept study in which fluid film bearings for both radial and axial load support and magnet suspensions were examined in several combinations to determine suitability. The concept study is described and includes discussions on flywheel sizing, journal and thrust bearing sizing, magnetic suspension sizing and geometric arrangements. (A)

Title: Energy Storage.
Abstract: A review is given of papers presented at the symposium (Southampton, 11 May, 1978) organized by the South coast section of the Institute of Energy in association with the Institution of Electrical Engineers and the Society of Chemical Industry . The papers included cover: Pumped water storage; Compressed air storage; Hot water storage; Density stratified fluids and latent heat storage; Battery storage; Electro-chemical storage, and Storage in superconducting magnets. (AP)

Title: Security assessment of power systems including energy storage and with the integration of wind energy. Progress report, July 1 - September 30, 1979.
Authors with affiliations: Carroll, D.P.; Krause, P.C.
Abstract: [No abstract available]
Index Keywords: Mod-1; Mod-2; Shackle; Stability

Title: The shallow solar pond: An alternative process hot water generator.
Authors with affiliations: Vineos, J.D.
Abstract: Rising energy prices have required investigation of alternative sources of hot water for manufacturing processes. One such alternative is the shallow solar pond (SSP) concept, which utilizes solar energy to provide large amounts of low to medium temperature hot water. A shallow solar pond is a relatively unsophisticated solar energy collector which can be configured as a simple open pond or a closed-type system with the capability of providing non-contaminated domestic quality hot water for process or domestic usage. Materials of construction are readily available as off-the-shelf items. This paper will deal with a closed-type system and will discuss the construction, materials, and system concept, including the filling, storage, and distribution systems. (A)

Authors: Ridgway S.L., Dooley J.L., Hammond R.P.
Title: Underground storage of off-peak power.
Source title: IN. PROC. INT. CONF. ON FUTURE ENERGY CONCEPTS, (LONDON, U.K.: JAN.30-FEB.1, 1979), LONDON, U.K., INST. ELECTR. ENGRS., 1979
Authors with affiliations: Ridgway, S.L.; Dooley, J.L.; Hammond, R.P.
Abstract: Storage of off-peak energy for later recovery using pressurized hot water storage, underground in low cost, large size storage vessels is examined. (C.Z.)

Title: An assessment of thermal energy storage in conjunction with heat pumps for residential heating and cooling
Affiliations: Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139, United States
Authors with affiliations: Packer, M.B., Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139, United States; Glicksman, L.R., Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139, United States
Abstract: The potential of thermal energy storage together with heat pumps to lower peak daytime residential electrical consumption and exploit off-peak rate reductions is examined. A computer simulation using New York City weather demonstrates that this approach, although technically successful, is economically infeasible for the foreseeable future. © 1979.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SIMULATION - Applications; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS - Applications; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; WATER TANKS AND TOWERS

Authors: Knutsen C.A., McKinnon M.A., Schulte S.C.
Title: Incremental cost analysis for advanced compressed air energy storage concepts.
Source title: IN: PROC. 14TH INTERSOCIETY ENERGY CONVERSION ENGNG. CONF. (BOSTON, U.S.A., AUG. 5-10, 1979)
Volume: 1 . Washington D.C., Am. Chem. Soc., 1979, paper 799090
Authors with affiliations: Knutsen, C.A.; McKinnon, M.A.; Schulte, S.C.
Abstract: Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) is a system for electric utility use, which takes the energy from excess base load electricity that becomes available during periods of low demand and stores it in the form of compressed air below ground. When the power is needed by the utility, the compressed air is fed to an aboveground gas turbine, where it is heated with petroleum-based fuels prior to expansion. Pacific Northwest Laboratory is investigating advanced CAES concepts that minimize or eliminate the use of petroleum-derived fuels by storing the compression heat in Thermal Energy Storage (TES) chambers and using that thermal energy to heat the air on its way to the turbine. Most of these concepts are technically possible. The purpose of this study was to determine under what conditions these concepts are economically competitive with conventional oil-fired CAES systems. The incremental costs of electricity for the advanced CAES systems are tested for their sensitivity to changes in base-case parametric values. The results of this sensitivity analysis show that the incremental costs are relatively insensitive to uncertainties in the additional capital costs for new or advanced design components in the TES systems. The incremental costs do, however, exhibit a marked sensitivity to the differential between compression energy and turbine fuel costs. In the event that this differential becomes large enough, as it might for utilities with excess low-cost base-load electricity and with continued rapid escalating fuel costs, it is concluded in this study that advanced CAES systems using TES can be economically competitive with conventional CAES systems. (A)

Authors: Hausz W., Anand R.K., LaMarche N.
Title: Electric utility applications of thermal energy storage and transport.
Source title: IN: PROC. 14TH INTERSOCIETY ENERGY CONVERSION ENGNG. CONF., (BOSTON, U.S'A.: AUG.5-10, 1979)
Volume: 1 , Washington, D.C., U'S.A., Am. Chem. Soc., 1979, Paper 799097
Authors with affiliations: Hausz, W.; Anand, R.K.; LaMarche, N.
Abstract: This paper reports on applications of thermal energy storage (TES) to conventional light water reactor and high sulfur coal generating plants. For thermal energy stored during off-peak periods, two applications considered were electric peak power generation, and thermal transport to serve process heat demands and district heating systems. An initial screening of many proposed concepts selected four for conceptual design as peaking power systems. Two were based on hot rock and oil as the dual storage media. The other two stored high temperature water (HTW) under pressure: a prestressed cast iron vessel (PCIV) was used in a feed water storage configuration and underground storage in an excavated cavern in a peaking turbine configuration. Levelized annual cost components of electric power with these TES systems were compared with baseline conventional plants used in a load following mode, and with cycling coal plants of comparable capacity' Transmission of thermal energy for up to 50 km was compared for HTW, hot oil, molten salt, and steam, over their applicable temperature ranges. The complementary advantages of thermal energy storage and transport included a high capacity factor on the transmission pipeline and separation of demand peaks by the user from the most economic dispatch of both electricity and thermal energy by the utility. (A)

Title: The application potential of hydro power
Affiliations: Energy International, London, England, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Jeffs, E.J., Energy International, London, England, United Kingdom
Abstract: Water is the only renewable energy source that has been exploited by man on a large scale and that has a well-developed technological base to support its continued exploitation. At present about 23% of the world's electricity supply is from hydro plants. Since all the new energy sources under development are mainly exploitable through electricity generation, it seems likely that the world will have to move increasingly to an electricity-based energy regime. To make an effective contribution to new energy supply patterns. hydro power could be exploited by the development of small generating units to meet local community needs, by the use of pumped storage to optimize operation of other energy sources, and by the development of the many remaining sites in remote areas and third world countries with high power potential including perhaps glacier-derived power. This last development could spawn a new energy trade which would require a transfer of manufacturing resources to the countries with hydro power. Political decisions and economic considerations will influence these developments. An effective electric power trade between countries requires an acceptable international code of practice. Ultimately the speed of development of these resources will depend upon the cost of energy delivered to the consumer compared with the cost of other energy sources closer to the load centre. © 1979.
Index Keywords: hydroelectric; ENERGY RESOURCES; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS

Title: [No title available]
Authors with affiliations: Takle, E.S.; Shaw, R.H.
Abstract: Daily values of solar and wind energy have been used (i) to study renewable energy availability at various times of year, (ii) to test the level of persistence for inferences about the practicality of energy storage and (iii) to examine the complementary behaviour of these two daily time series on both seasonal and daily bases. Results for the station studied (central Iowa) show a bimodal distribution for winter solar energy, whereas non-winter solar and wind (all seasons) show unimodal distributions. Wind and solar energy were observed to be highly complementary on an annual basis, but only slightly complementary on a daily basis. (A)

Authors: RYJ. Petri, Claar T.D., Marianowski L.G.
Title: Evaluation of molten carbonates as latent heat thermal energy storage materialsY
Source title: IN: PROC. 14TH INTERSOCIETY ENERGY CONVERSION ENGNG' CONF., (BOSTON, U.S.A.: AUG.5-10, 1979)
Volume: 1 , Washington, D.C., U.S'A., Am. Chem. Soc', 1979, Paper 799100
Authors with affiliations: RYJ. Petri; Claar, T.D.; Marianowski, L.G.
Abstract: of high-conductivity material to increase the heat flux through the layer of solidified salt was experimentally evaluated. Thermal cycling stability data for an 8 kWhr T.E.S. module containing LiKCOSUP3 and operated at 480SUP to 535SUPC for 5650 hours and 129 cycles are also presented. (A) Experimental results of comparative screening studies of candidate molten-carbonate salts as phase-change materials (PCM) for advanced solar thermal energy storage applications at 540SUP to 870SUP and Steam-Rankine electric generation at 400SUP to 540SUPC are presented. Alkali carbonates are attractive as latent-heat storage materials due to their relatively high storage capacity and thermal coductivity, low corrosiveness, moderate cost, and safe and simple handling requirements' Salts were tested in 0'1 kWhr lab-scale modules and evaluated on the basis of discharge heat flux, solidification temperature range, thermal cycling stability, and compatibility with containment materials. The feasibility of using a distributed network

Title: Design of the battery energy storage test facility
Source title: IEEE Transactions on Power Apparatus and Systems
Affiliations: Public Service Electric and Gas Company, 80 Park Place, Newark, New Jersey, United States
Authors with affiliations: Snow, R.V., Public Service Electric and Gas Company, 80 Park Place, Newark, New Jersey, United States
Abstract: The Battery Energy Storage test (BEST) Facility is being constructed for the Department of Energy (DOE) and the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI) by Public Service Electric and Gas (PSE&G) Company, The purpose of the facility, its general design philosophy, the proposed interactions of the facility with advanced batteries and AC/DC conversion equipment, and the layout of the facilty are described in this paper. The BEST Facility is one in a series of projects to encourage commercialization of battery energy storage systems. Through its particular design and implementation, advanced battery systems will be brought from the laboratory to application on a utility system. This step will provide significant information for both manufacturers and utilities on the characteristics of battery energy storage system. Copyright © 1979 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY - Research; ELECTRIC CONVERTERS, POWER TYPE - Research; ELECTRIC UTILITIES

Title: Energy storage efficiency for the ammonia/hydrogen‐nitrogen thermochemical energy transfer system
Affiliations: Department of Engineering Physics, Research School of Physical Sciences, Australian National University, Canberra, Australian Capital Territory, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Williams, O.M., Department of Engineering Physics, Research School of Physical Sciences, Australian National University, Canberra, Australian Capital Territory, Australia; Carden, P.O., Department of Engineering Physics, Research School of Physical Sciences, Australian National University, Canberra, Australian Capital Territory, Australia
Abstract: Energy storage efficiency is calculated for the solar thermochemical energy transfer system based on ammonia/hydrogen‐nitrogen. the calculation for this system involves generation of thermodynamic data not available in the literature by a method in which use is made of the available phase equilibrium measurements together with application of the criterion that the correct value of separation work for a two‐phase mixture must be generated internally by degradation of mixing heat. Energy storage efficiencies for ammonia/hydrogen‐nitrogen are derived from the generated thermodynamic data and are shown to increase towards unity as the endothermic reaction approaches completion, with efficiencies greater than 0.90 being obtained for reaction extents exceeding 0.60. the validity of the analysis has been tested successfully by comparison between the thermodynamic predictions and experimental data in the form of measurements of the waste heat rejected from a counterflow heat exchanger operated with liquid ammonia feed and ammonia/hydrogen‐nitrogen output. Copyright © 1979 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.
Author Keywords: Ammonia/hydrogen‐nitrogen system; Energy storage efficiency; Thermochemical energy transfer
Index Keywords: AMMONIA; HYDROGEN; NITROGEN; THERMODYNAMICS; THERMOCHEMICAL ENERGY TRANSFER; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: Minimum energy problem for discrete linear admissible control systems
Affiliations: Division of Electrical Engineering, National Research Council, Ottawa, ON, K1A 0R8, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Abdelmalek, N.N., Division of Electrical Engineering, National Research Council, Ottawa, ON, K1A 0R8, Canada
Abstract: The minimum energy problem for discrete linear admissible control system is solved as a quadratic programming problem for bounded variables. In this method, the optimal solution for the minimum energy problem of the non-admissible system is taken as the initial solution for the present problem. Minimum computer storage is required and no conditions are imposed on the matrix of the constraints. Numerical results indicate that the algorithm is a fast one. © 1979 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Index Keywords: CONTROL SYSTEMS, DISCRETE TIME - Theory; CONTROL SYSTEMS, LINEAR

Title: A general design method for closed-loop solar energy systems
Affiliations: Solar Energy Laboratory University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI 53706, United States
Authors with affiliations: Klein, S.A., Solar Energy Laboratory University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI 53706, United States; Beckman, W.A., Solar Energy Laboratory University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI 53706, United States
Abstract: A general design method is presented for closed loop energy systems consisting of solar collectors, sensible energy storage and a closed-loop flow circuit in which thermal energy is supplied (through heat exchange) to a load above a specified minimum temperature. It is assumed that the energy supplied to the load is used at a constant thermal efficiency. Computer simulations were used to estimate the long-term thermal performance of these systems, and correlations between the system performance and the system design parameters, such as the collector characteristics, load size, climatic data, and the minimum useful temperature, are presented. © 1979.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SIMULATION; ENERGY STORAGE; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; THERMAL EFFICIENCY; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: Flammability and ignitability
Affiliations: School of Mechanical Engineering, Cranfield Institute of Technology, Cranfield, Bedford M K43 0AL, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Goodger, E.M., School of Mechanical Engineering, Cranfield Institute of Technology, Cranfield, Bedford M K43 0AL, United Kingdom
Abstract: A clear distinction emerges between the properties 'flammability' and 'ignitability' by defining them in terms of temperature. The light hydrocarbon fuels, for example, are seen to produce flammable mixtures at near ambient temperatures and thus, for fire safety, require protection from sparks, flames and other localised sources of energy within the vicinity of storage. The heavier fuels, and lubricants, on the other hand, are not flammable in this way, but would ignite spontaneously if subjected to general overheating. © 1979.
Index Keywords: FUELS

Authors: Freeman T.L., Mitchell J.W., Audit T.E.
Title: Performance of combined solar-heat pump systems
Affiliations: Solar Energy Laboratory, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI 53706, United States
Authors with affiliations: Freeman, T.L., Solar Energy Laboratory, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI 53706, United States; Mitchell, J.W., Solar Energy Laboratory, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI 53706, United States; Audit, T.E., Solar Energy Laboratory, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI 53706, United States
Abstract: A comparative study of the performance of combined solar heat pump systems for residential space and domestic hot water heating has been undertaken. Simulations have been made with TRNSYS[1] of three basic combined configurations, as well as conventional solar and conventional heat pump systems, in two different climates, Madison, Wisconsin, and Albuquerque, New Mexico. The three combined systems are the series system in which the solar storage is used as the source for the heat pump, the parallel system in which ambient air is used as the source for the heat pump, and the dual source system in which the storage or ambient is used as the source depending on which source yields the lowest work input. The influence of collector area, number of glazings, main storage volume to collector area ratio, and heat pump coefficient of performance were determined. The results indicate that the parallel combined system is probably the most practical solar-heat pump configuration. The thermal performance at a given collector area is consistently superior to both the series or the dual source systems over the heating season. Costs and the extent to which summer cooling is a requirement determine the relative merit of the conventional heat pump, conventional heat pump, conventional solar, and parallel systems. © 1979.
Index Keywords: HEATING - Solar; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SOLAR ENERGY; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; SOLAR HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS

Title: A mathematical simulation of a solar assisted heat pump system using the ground for energy storage
Affiliations: Refrigeration Laboratory, Technical University of Denmark, Building 402, DK2800 Lyngby, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Schlosser, K., Refrigeration Laboratory, Technical University of Denmark, Building 402, DK2800 Lyngby, Denmark; Teislev, B., Refrigeration Laboratory, Technical University of Denmark, Building 402, DK2800 Lyngby, Denmark
Abstract: A residential heating system utilizing a combination of a solar collector, a heat pump and an energy storage in the ground is described and some simulation results are presented. It is concluded that for ground heat-pump systems without a solar collector the best positioning of the heat absorbing tubes are horizontal, whereas the vertical tube configuration seems to be superior when a solar collector is included in the system. Finally it is observed that the use of a heat storage consisting of vertical tubes buried under the house appears to be a rather attractive solution. © 1979.
Index Keywords: HEATING - Solar; HOUSES - Space Heating; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS

Title: Proposal of a High-Power Microwave Pulse Source Utilizing a Superconducting Cavity for Energy Storage
Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Graduate School of Energy Science, Tokyo Institute of Technology, Tokyo 152, Tokyo, Japan; National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Tokyo, 300-32, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Minami, K., Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Graduate School of Energy Science, Tokyo Institute of Technology, Tokyo 152, Tokyo, Japan; Hosoyama, K., National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Tokyo, 300-32, Japan
Abstract: A new principle for a high-power microwave pulse source utilizing a superconducting cavity for energy storage is described. Since quality factors of about 1011 and electric field strengths of up to 60 MV/m are presently attainable in superconducting cavities, microwaves with energy density up to 16 kJ/m3 can be stored. The stored energy can be released, in a short time, by increasing the coupling factor between the cavity and a waveguide circuit rapidly. The technical possibilities are discussed in some detail. It is emphasized that, although the economical feasibility is not assured at this stage of development of technology, the present method may be used to produce high-power microwave pulses which are not available in usual microwave oscillators. © 1979 The Japan Society of Applied Physics.
Index Keywords: SUPERCONDUCTING DEVICES; MICROWAVES

Authors: Shitzer A., Kalmanoviz D., Zvirin Y., Grossman G.
Title: Experiments with a flat plate solar water heating system in thermosyphonic flow
Affiliations: Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Technion-Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Shitzer, A., Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Technion-Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa, Israel; Kalmanoviz, D., Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Technion-Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa, Israel; Zvirin, Y., Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Technion-Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa, Israel; Grossman, G., Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Technion-Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa, Israel
Abstract: A typical Israeli water heating system in thermosyphonic-flow was tested. The system consisted of two flat plate collectors painted matt black connected in parallel and a 140 l. storage tank. Total surface area of the collectors, employing the parallel flow pattern, was about 3 m2 and they were tilted about 35° relative to the horizon. All collector pipes and connecting tubes were made of galvanized steel. The underside collector plate, collector tubes and storage tank were equipped with thermo-couples. A specially designed flow meter was used to measure water flow rate. Results show relatively linear temperature distributions both along the collectors and in the storage tank when no water consumption was allowed. Water flow rate was found to essentially follow solar radiation and reached a maximum of about 950 cm3/min. This value was found to be about 33 per cent smaller than the one predicted by an analytical model developed by the authors. It was also observed that shutting the system off during the afternoon hours, when losses to the environment are enhanced, might increase system efficiency. © 1979.
Index Keywords: SOLAR ENERGY; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; THERMOCOUPLES; FLAT RATE SOLAR COLLECTORS; THERMOSYPHONIC FLOW; WATER HEATERS

Title: Practical cryostats for laboratory courses in superconductivity
Affiliations: Physikalisches Institut der Universität, D-6000 Frankfurt, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Hoenig, H.E., Physikalisches Institut der Universität, D-6000 Frankfurt, Germany
Abstract: Three simple cryostats are described which may be used to demonstrate three principal facts of superconductivity: persistent currents, the Meissner effect, and the energy gap in a tunnelling experiment on top of or within a helium storage dewar which avoids the transfer of helium. In the first two cases, the superconductor can be approached with permanent magnets at room temperature to less than a few millimeters. Because of the simplicity of the experimental setup the three experiments can be part of a regular physics laboratory course. © 1979.
Index Keywords: CRYOSTATS

Title: Kinetics of the Fischer-Tropsch Reaction over Iron
Source title: Industrial and Engineering Chemistry Process Design and Development
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Connecticut, Storrs, Connecticut 06268, United States
Authors with affiliations: Atwood, H.E., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Connecticut, Storrs, Connecticut 06268, United States; Bennett, C.O., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Connecticut, Storrs, Connecticut 06268, United States
Abstract: Product distributions and reaction rates were measured for the reaction of a mixture of 66.7% H2-33.3% CO over a commercial promoted, fused iron catalyst. Data are presented for a pressure of 2.0 MPa, over the temperature range 523-588 K, for a range of conversion up to 70%. The results are used for the preliminary design of an energy storage system based on the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. Product distributions over a cobalt-silica catalyst are also presented. © 1979, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: CATALYSTS; CHEMICAL REACTIONS - Reaction Kinetics; ENERGY STORAGE; FISCHER-TROPSCH REACTION; ELECTRIC POWER PLANTS

Title: Prediction of the performance of solar heating systems utilizing annual storage
Affiliations: Center for the Environment and Man, Inc., 275 Windsor Street, Hartford, CT 06120, U.S.A. Present affiliation: Hartford Graduate Center (same address).
Authors with affiliations: Lunde, P.J., Center for the Environment and Man, Inc., 275 Windsor Street, Hartford, CT 06120, U.S.A. Present affiliation: Hartford Graduate Center (same address).
Abstract: Integrated performance equations which incorporate effects of finite storage are derived for solar heating systems such as those using annual storage in which the well-mixed storage temperature rises or falls monotonically. These equations accurately predict in a single step the performance of ordinary systems over an entire day, and annual storage systems over an entire month. Over a year, monthly application of the integrated equations predicted annual performance within about two per cent relative to an hourly simulation. © 1979.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; ENERGY UTILIZATION; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SOLAR ENERGY; HEATING

Title: Melt time and heat flux for a simple PCM body
Affiliations: Mathematics and Statistics Research Department, Computer Sciences Division, Union Carbide Corporation, Oak Ridge, TN 37830, United States
Authors with affiliations: Solomon, A.D., Mathematics and Statistics Research Department, Computer Sciences Division, Union Carbide Corporation, Oak Ridge, TN 37830, United States
Abstract: Using data derived from computer calculations, exact solutions and quasi-stationary approximations, relations for the total melt time and average surface heat flux are given for a lump of phase change material (PCM) subject to a constant temperature at its boundary, and initially at critical temperature. © 1979.
Index Keywords: MATERIALS - Thermal Conductivity; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SOLAR ENERGY; HEAT FLUX; PHASE CHANGE MATERIALS; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; ENERGY STORAGE

Authors: Savinell R.F., Galasco R.T., Chiang S.H.
Title: Discharge Characteristics of a Soluble Iron-Titanium Battery System
Affiliations: Diamond Shamrock Corporation, Research Center, Cleveland, Ohio, United States; Department of Chemical and Petroleum Engineering, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania 15261, United States; Department of Chemistry, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania 15261, United States
Authors with affiliations: Savinell, R.F., Diamond Shamrock Corporation, Research Center, Cleveland, Ohio, United States, Department of Chemical and Petroleum Engineering, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania 15261, United States, Department of Chemistry, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania 15261, United States; Galasco, R.T., Department of Chemical and Petroleum Engineering, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania 15261, United States; Chiang, S.H., Department of Chemical and Petroleum Engineering, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania 15261, United States
Abstract: Constant-load and constant-current discharge data are presented for a soluble iron-titanium electrochemical system. Output performance is limited mainly by activation polarization in the anodic reaction, Ti(III) - e- → Ti(IV). The influence of different electrode materials, including platinum, graphite foil, and titanium-base electrodes, and of temperature was investigated. © 1979, The Electrochemical Society, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: battery; energy storage; membrane
Index Keywords: ELECTRODES - Iron Titanium Alloys; MEMBRANES; ELECTRIC BATTERIES

Title: Heat Transfer in Geothermal Systems
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Hawaii, Honolulu, Hawaii 96822, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cheng, P., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Hawaii, Honolulu, Hawaii 96822, United States
Abstract: This chapter discusses the mathematical formulation of the problems of convective heat transfer in geothermal systems. Geothermal reservoirs may have numerous near-vertical faults and relatively impermeable intrusive interspersed in the aquifers. Both theoretical and experimental investigations of heat transfer in geothermal systems are reviewed. A qualitative understanding of the large-scale convection processes in a geothermal reservoir and the prediction of reservoir behavior under production can be obtained by idealizing it as a saturated porous medium. The identification of a viable geothermal reservoir and the estimation of its capacity remain major problems in the utilization of geothermal resources. Thermal anomalies in geothermal areas can be detected by surface manifestations, aerial infrared surveys, geochemical analyses, or exploratory drillings. Many of the analyses are applicable to a wide range of engineering problems whenever they can be idealized as convection in a porous medium. These include the problems of the secondary recovery of oil by thermal methods, the use of fibrous materials for thermal insulations, the design of aquifers as an energy storage system, and the deposition of mineral ore in the subsurface formation. Results from short-duration well testing are used to determine reservoir characteristics. © 1978, Academic Press Inc.
Index Keywords: GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HEAT TRANSFER

Title: Superconductive magnetic energy storage
Affiliations: University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States
Authors with affiliations: Boom, R.W., University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States; Van Sciver, S.W., University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States
Abstract: Technical and economic aspects of large scale superconductive magnetic energy storage are discussed. This paper is a review of a program which has been under way at the University of Wisconsin since 1970. Early work between 1970 and 1976 was primarily involved in proving economic and technical feasibility of the concept The present program deals with component development and detailed design ultimately leading to construction of a large superconducting magnet capable of storing 1000-10,000 MWh. The magnet is a single-layered segmented solenoid of approx. 100 m radius. Energy containment is achieved economically by burying the magnet underground in bedrock tunnels. Magnetic loads are transmitted from the conductor to bedrock through glass fiber reinforced composite struts. The conductor consists of a composite of aluminum and NbTi and is designed for full cryogenic stability in 1.8 K superfluid helium. The dewar-conductor assembly will be rippled in a l m radius of curvature to reduce the hoop stress tension. A Graetz bridge is required to convert the d.c. superconducting current into a.c. current in the three-phase power system. Economic analysis indicates that superconductive magnetic energy storage is competitive with alternative large scale storage schemes for units greater than 1000 MWh size. © 1979.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC INVERTERS - Applications; INDUSTRIAL ECONOMICS - Analysis; SUPERCONDUCTING CABLES - Applications; GRAETZ BRIDGE; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS

Authors: Abdel-Wahed R.M., Emerson P.F., Blackshear Jr. P.L., Riaz M.
Title: Effects on thermal storage efficiencies of modifying heat-transport properties of indigenous sandstones
Affiliations: Faculty of Engineering, University of Alexandria, Egypt; Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN 55455, United States; Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN 55455, United States
Authors with affiliations: Abdel-Wahed, R.M., Faculty of Engineering, University of Alexandria, Egypt; Emerson, P.F., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN 55455, United States; Blackshear Jr., P.L., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN 55455, United States; Riaz, M., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN 55455, United States
Abstract: For conditions encountered in much of the Midwest, an extensive layer of dry sandstones protected by an impermeable limestone roof is accessible for long-term (six-month), high-temperature (T > 100 °C) thermal energy storage. The performance of such storage beds is examined when the thermal properties of sandstones are modified so as to adjust the permeability towards an optimum in order to reduce pumping power. The thermal properties of consolidated St. Peter sandstone, dispersed St. Peter sand, and pelletized St. Peter sand are measured by several techniques. A nondimensional computer model for beds bounded by a constant temperature water table is employed to estimate the influence of thermal property manipulation of storage system performance. Disrupting the sandstone permits a substantial increase in the volume efficiency and first and second law efficiencies. Pelletizing sand into particles of approx. 1 mm diameter permits marginal further increases in performance. Disruption of the consolidated sandstone reduces the thermal diffusivity and increases the permeability. Both effects improve performance. © 1979.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SIMULATION - Applications; HEAT TRANSFER - Granular Materials; ROCK - Thermal Properties; SANDSTONES; SAND AND GRAVEL

Title: Polyelectrolyte electrets for electrical energy storage
Affiliations: Bioengineering Program, University Illinois at Chicago Circle, Chicago, IL 60680, United States
Authors with affiliations: Miller, I.F., Bioengineering Program, University Illinois at Chicago Circle, Chicago, IL 60680, United States
Abstract: Membrane electrets composed of mixtures of polyelectrolyte salts and hydrogen bonding materials have been studied to determine their electric charge and electrical energy-storage characteristics. It has been found that membranes containing salts of polystyrenesulfonic acid, plus polyvinyl alcohol, show excellent promise for such electrical storage purposes. The electrets are formed by heating the membrane to above its glass-transition temperature (typically 60-90 °C), placing it in an electric field (in our case, by use of a 22.5 V dry cell battery) and cooling the membrane back to room temperature within the field. It is found that the membrane, typically 0.005-0.010 cm thick, will retain a potential difference of about 2.5 V. These membranes differ from the usual electrets in that they are not really dielectrics. Whereas typical dielectric electrets might have conductivities of the order of 1014 (Ω-cm)-1, the polyelectrolyte electrets have conductivities of the order of 10-9 (Ω-cm)-1 or even higher. The charge is stored by orientation of dipoles within divergence elements, probably of a semi-crystalline nature, scattered throughout the membrane. The charge storage is stable and, if the membrane is stored with the faces shorted, will last indefinitely. The electret can be discharged by connecting the two faces to an external circuit and heating the membrane to above the charging temperature. Alternatively, electrets can be discharged by use of ultraviolet light, though we have not attempted this method as yet. Using thermal discharge, we have measured charge storage capacities of the order of 1 C/g. Using our present system, we foresee no difficulty in increasing charge storage capacity by an order of magnitude or more, thus making the system comparable to lead-acid or mercury storage batteries. © 1979.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC CONDUCTIVITY - Measurements; ELECTRIC MEASUREMENTS - Charge; MEMBRANES - Applications; POLYELECTROLYTES - Energy Storage; POLYELECTROLYTE ELECTRETS; ELECTRETS

Title: Synchrotron light and its uses
Affiliations: Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, New York 11973, United States
Authors with affiliations: Blewett, J.P., Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, New York 11973, United States
Abstract: It has been known for a century that charged particles radiate when accelerated and that relativistic electrons in the energy range between 100 MeV and several GeV and constrained to travel in circular orbits emit concentrated, intense beams with broad continuous spectra that can cover the electromagnetic spectrum from infrared through hard X-rays. Recently the possible applications of this radiation have been appreciated and electron synchrotrons and electron storage rings are now being used in many centers for studies of the properties of matter in the solid, liquid and gaseous states. Copyright © 1978 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS, ELECTRON RING; X-RAYS; ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON

Title: A high speed trigger system for total deposited energy measurement in a liquid argon calorimeter
Affiliations: Stanford Linear Accelerator Center Stanford University, Stanford, California 94305, United States
Authors with affiliations: Grund, J.E., Stanford Linear Accelerator Center Stanford University, Stanford, California 94305, United States
Abstract: A system to produce trigger signals.measuring the total energy deposited in the liquid argon/lead shower counters of the SPEAR Mark II Detector at the Stanford Linear Accelerator Center is described. The trigger signals are developed by summing, filtering, and discriminating the signals from several thousand preamplifiers connected to the liquid argon detector strips. The system requirement of trigger information 430 ns after a particle has entered the shower counter led to a special filter design in which a leading edge sampling technique was utilized. A filtered signal representing the total deposited energy is measured by a fast level discriminator that is strobed in synchronization with the e+e− beam crossings of the SPEAR storage ring. This sampling of the filtered waveform produces a digital output that is delivered to the trigger logic. Copyright © 1978 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: ARGON; LIQUID ARGON CALORIMETER; TRIGGER SYSTEM; CALORIMETERS

Authors: Vogel J.M., Cline J.W., Harrison J.F., Ulloa G.A., McDonald R.J.
Title: Microcomputer based dual energy photon absorptiometric bone mineral analyzer (VCH)
Affiliations: Dominican Santa Cruz Hospital, United States; Crocker Nuclear Lab. U.C.D., United States
Authors with affiliations: Vogel, J.M., Dominican Santa Cruz Hospital, United States; Cline, J.W., Crocker Nuclear Lab. U.C.D., United States; Harrison, J.F., Crocker Nuclear Lab. U.C.D., United States; Ulloa, G.A., Crocker Nuclear Lab. U.C.D., United States; McDonald, R.J., Crocker Nuclear Lab. U.C.D., United States
Abstract: Measurement of mineral content in trabecular bone with reproducible precision can have significant effect on patient management with osteopenic conditions. Commercial instruments measure single cross sections of the upper extremity which, unless uniform bone sections are measured, produce large errors. Forearm bones, that are primarily cortical and therefore less reflective of rapid bone turnover, are usually measured. Utilizing experience gained with rectilinear scanning for large area mineral estimation on Apollo and Skylab astronauts, we designed hardware and software that is compact, can use single or dual photon sources in a rectilinear fashion with precise repositioning, scan in a vertical or horizontal plane, perform on-line data storage and reduction, and provide continuous visual evaluation of the data profile. Copyright © 1978 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: BIOLOGICAL MATERIALS - Bone; COMPUTERS, MINIATURE; PHOTONS; BONE MINERAL ANALYZER; NUCLEAR MEDICINE

Authors: Hassenzahl W.V., Rogers J.D., Boenig H.J., Bronson J.C., Colyer D.B., Turner R.D., Schermer R.I.
Title: 30-MJ Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (Smes) Unit For Stabilizing An Electric Transmission System
Affiliations: U. S. Department of Energy, Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory of the University of California, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hassenzahl, W.V., U. S. Department of Energy, Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory of the University of California, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Rogers, J.D., U. S. Department of Energy, Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory of the University of California, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Boenig, H.J., U. S. Department of Energy, Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory of the University of California, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Bronson, J.C., U. S. Department of Energy, Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory of the University of California, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Colyer, D.B., U. S. Department of Energy, Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory of the University of California, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Turner, R.D., U. S. Department of Energy, Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory of the University of California, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Schermer, R.I., U. S. Department of Energy, Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory of the University of California, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States
Abstract: Electric power systems that have major loads and generation centers separated by large distances may experience low-frequency power oscillations. This type of oscillation has occurred on the Pacific AC Intertie that connects southern California and the Pacific Northwest. A separate, almost parallel, dc-transmission line also connects these areas. The Bonneville Power Administration, which operates this transmission system, has overcome the instability by controlling the power transmitted on the dc-transmission line. A 30-MU (8.4-kWh) superconducting magnetic energy storage unit with a 10-MW converter could also provide damping for this instability. The conceptual design of the 30-MJ coil and the cryogenic and electrical components of the system are described. The system is to operate at a maximum current of 5 kA and will modulate the AC Intertie at 0.35 Hz. Discharge will be controlled to retain a minimum stored energy of 20 MJ to limit cyclic strains in the coil and ac losses in the conductor. The conductor will be made of multistrand-copper and copper-matrix, multifilament NbTi superconducting wires on a stainless steel mandrel. © 1979 IEEE
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER TRANSMISSION - Oscillations; Superconducting magnets; Electric lines

Title: Two Superconducting Storage Rings-Isabelle — Rings-Isabelle
Affiliations: Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sanford, J.R., Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States
Abstract: At Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island the Department of Energy has under construction a high-energy, proton-proton colliding beam research facility called ISABELLE. Located in the northwest corner of the existing Brookhaven site (Fig. 1), two rings of magnets are contained within a common tunnel more than two miles in circumference. These two rings of magnets carry beams in opposite rotations, crisscrossing at six positions around the periphery. At these locations, head-on collisions occur between the proton beams, leading to center-of-mass energies up to 800 GeV. This paper summarizes the general features of the design and the status of the project at the present time. It brings up to date the results reported at the National Particle Accelerator Conference in March 1977. The most significant change since that time has been an upgrading of the energy of the overall facility, and acceptance of the project by the Department of Energy. © 1979 IEEE
Index Keywords: SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS; SUPERCONDUCTING STORAGE RINGS; ACCELERATORS

Authors: Otavka M., Alcorn J., Purcell J., Chen W., Toffolo W.
Title: General Atomic's Superconducting High Field Test Facility and Initial Performance
Affiliations: Department of Energy, Contract EY-76-C-03-0167, PA 38, United States; General Atomic Company, PO Sox 81608, San Diego,California 92 138, United States
Authors with affiliations: Otavka, M., Department of Energy, Contract EY-76-C-03-0167, PA 38, United States; Alcorn, J., Department of Energy, Contract EY-76-C-03-0167, PA 38, United States; Purcell, J., Department of Energy, Contract EY-76-C-03-0167, PA 38, United States; Chen, W., Department of Energy, Contract EY-76-C-03-0167, PA 38, United States; Toffolo, W., General Atomic Company, PO Sox 81608, San Diego,California 92 138, United States
Abstract: General Atomic has established a high field test facility whose primary mission is to investigate the J-B-T and stability performance margins of commercial NbTi superconductor in the 10 tesla, 4.2 K region. This work is part of the overall DOE/MFE/MAGNETIC SYSTEMS effort to provide an adequate technological base for construction of superconducting toroidal field coils for the next generation of large tokamak fusion devices. The principal components of the facility are the coil/cryostat assembly, the helium refrigerator-liquefier/compressor system, and the gaseous helium recovery and storage system. The epoxy impregnated, layer wound main background field coil generates 8 teals within its 40 cm diameter bore. The insert background field coil was layer wound with cooling channels provided by “barber pole” mylar conductor insulation. Ten tesla is generated within its 22 cm bore. The initial performance of the facility will be discussed. Future testing calls for operating test coils with implanted heating elements to simulate mechanically induced perturbations. The normal zone growth and recovery behavior will be observed for various disturbance energies. This data will then be compared with results obtained from the transient recovery analysis developed at General Atomic. © 1979 IEEE
Index Keywords: SUPERCONDUCTING MATERIALS; TOKAMAK DEVICES; SUPERCONDUCTING DEVICES

Authors: Thullen P., Lindsay J.D.G., Weldon D.M., Vogel H.F.
Title: Superconducting Ohmic-Heating Coil Simulation
Affiliations: Department of Energy, Scientific Laboratory, P.O. Box 1663, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States
Authors with affiliations: Thullen, P., Department of Energy, Scientific Laboratory, P.O. Box 1663, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Lindsay, J.D.G., Department of Energy, Scientific Laboratory, P.O. Box 1663, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Weldon, D.M., Department of Energy, Scientific Laboratory, P.O. Box 1663, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Vogel, H.F., Department of Energy, Scientific Laboratory, P.O. Box 1663, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States
Abstract: Superconducting coils have been proposed for use as ohmic-heating coils in the conceptual designs of most tokamak and reverse field pinch fusion reactors because of their high energy efficiency Lack of detailed knowledge about the behavior of superconducting coils performing the required bipolar flux swings may delay their application in future fusion reactors. The Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory has undertaken a study to show how such coils can be constructed. This program includes both theoretical and experimental phases. The work is based to a large extent on the experience gained during the fast discharge (1 ms) magnetic energy transfer and storage (METS) program. A series of experiments in which a typical ohmic-heating current waveform is simulated have been undertaken using the 300-kJ, 10-kA METS superconducting coil, a 500-kW, 250-V, 2-kA dc motor generator set used as a capacitor, and a rectifier power supply. The coil has undergone full bipolar flux swings to greater than rated current (+ 12-kA, 430 kJ) and remained superconducting. The commutator dc machine has functioned successfully as a capacitor up to 12 kA. We describe the test circuits and discuss the components. Terminal characteristics are presented. Coil energy losses are presented as a function of the terminal current. These tests support the viability of bipolar pulsed superconducting coils for use in tokamaks and other fusion concepts.). © 1979 IEEE
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC COILS; NUCLEAR ENERGY - Fusion Reactions; TOKAMAK DEVICES; OHMIC-HEATING COILS; SUPERCONDUCTING COILS; SUPERCONDUCTING DEVICES

Authors: Hilal M.A., Stone L., Van Scive S.W.
Title: Helium Requirements For A Superconducting Power Network
Affiliations: Michigan Technological University, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Houghton, MI 49931, United States; University of Wisconsin, 531 ERB, 1500 Johnson Drive, Madison, WI 53706, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hilal, M.A., Michigan Technological University, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Houghton, MI 49931, United States; Stone, L., University of Wisconsin, 531 ERB, 1500 Johnson Drive, Madison, WI 53706, United States; Van Scive, S.W., University of Wisconsin, 531 ERB, 1500 Johnson Drive, Madison, WI 53706, United States
Abstract: A review of the helium requirements for future superconductive energy technologies is presented. The first section of the paper includes a survey of commercial sized units of five energy related devices: superconductive magnetic energy storage, magnetically confined fusion reactors, superconducting power transmission lines, magnetohydrodynamic units,and superconducting ac generators. Results of the survey are discussed in terms of requirements for typical size units on a per unit power basis. Estimates are based on published system studies and private information provided by various workers in the field. © 1979 IEEE
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER TRANSMISSION; SUPERCONDUCTING CABLES - Cooling; SUPERCONDUCTING DEVICES - Cooling; ELECTRIC LINES
