Authors: Gaines G.L., Jr., Behnken P.E., Valenty2 S.J.
Title: Monolayer Films of Surfactant Ester Derivatives of Tris(2,2'-bipyridine)ruthenium(II)2+
Source title: Journal of the American Chemical Society
Affiliations: General Electric Company Corporate Research Development, Schenectady, New York 12301, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gaines, G.L., Jr., General Electric Company Corporate Research Development, Schenectady, New York 12301, United States; Behnken, P.E., General Electric Company Corporate Research Development, Schenectady, New York 12301, United States; Valenty2, S.J., General Electric Company Corporate Research Development, Schenectady, New York 12301, United States
Abstract: Surfactant ruthenium complexes are attracting attention as potential photoinduced electron-transfer reagents, especially for possible light energy storage schemes. The ester derivatives {(bpy)2RuII[bpy(COOR1)(COOR2)]}2+ (where bpy = 2,2'-bipyridine, the carboxy substituents are in the 4,4' positions, and R1 = R2 = C18H37 (I); R1 = C18H37, R2 = H (111); and R1 = C18H37, R2 = C2H5 (IV)) have been prepared and characterized. The alkaline hydrolysis of I to octadecanol and II (R1 = R2 = H), with III as an intermediate product, proceeds more rapidly in monolayers and in 50% aqueous THF than does that of the water-soluble analogue V (R1 = R2 = C2H5) in aqueous solution. Both the surface pressure-area characteristics and luminescence of monolayers of the surfactant compounds spread on aqueous subphases depends strongly on dissolved anions; even traces of strongly interacting anions such as perchlorate lead to condensation of the films, while luminescence is ~20-fold more intense in the presence of perchlorate as compared with chloride. When the monolayers are transferred to glass slides, the pretreatment of the glass affects the extent of dark ester hydrolysis. Prolonged photolysis of monolayer assemblies on glass in contact with water leads to a slow (quantum yield, ~5 x 10-6) nonhydrolytic degradation of the complex, but to no detectable water dissociation (quantum yield for H2 production, ≤1 X 10-4). © 1978, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.

Authors: Böhm A., Van Dalen G., Kernan A., Layter J., Shen B., Ceradini F., Muller F., Naroska B., Nussbaum M., Orkin-Lecourtois A., Rubbia C., DiBitonto D., Irion J., Schinzel D., Seebrunner H., Staude A., Tirler R., Voss R., Zupančič Č., Block M.
Title: Meson-resonance production in p-p interactions at 53-GeV (c.m.) energy
Affiliations: III. Physikalisches Institut, Technischen Hochschule Aachen, Aachen, Germany; University of California, Riverside, CA 92502, United States; CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Harvard University, Cambridge, MA 02138, United States; Sektion Physik der Universität, Munich, Germany; Northwestern University, Evanston, IL 60201, United States; Physics Department, University of Cincinnai, Cincinnati, OH, United States; Harvard University, Cambridge, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Böhm, A., III. Physikalisches Institut, Technischen Hochschule Aachen, Aachen, Germany; Van Dalen, G., University of California, Riverside, CA 92502, United States; Kernan, A., University of California, Riverside, CA 92502, United States; Layter, J., University of California, Riverside, CA 92502, United States; Shen, B., University of California, Riverside, CA 92502, United States; Ceradini, F., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Muller, F., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Naroska, B., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Nussbaum, M., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland, Physics Department, University of Cincinnai, Cincinnati, OH, United States; Orkin-Lecourtois, A., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Rubbia, C., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA, United States; DiBitonto, D., Harvard University, Cambridge, MA 02138, United States; Irion, J., Sektion Physik der Universität, Munich, Germany; Schinzel, D., Sektion Physik der Universität, Munich, Germany; Seebrunner, H., Sektion Physik der Universität, Munich, Germany; Staude, A., Sektion Physik der Universität, Munich, Germany; Tirler, R., Sektion Physik der Universität, Munich, Germany; Voss, R., Sektion Physik der Universität, Munich, Germany; Zupančič, Č., Sektion Physik der Universität, Munich, Germany; Block, M., Northwestern University, Evanston, IL 60201, United States
Abstract: At the CERN intersecting storage ring the inclusive differential cross section [dd]y=1 has been measured for f0, g0, K*0(1420), and K»*0(1420) production: We obtain 0.58 0.05 mb, 0.09 0.05 mb, 38 15 b, and 26 13 b, respectively. The corresponding total inclusive cross sections are estimated to be 2.62 0.26 mb, 0.40 0.22 mb, 154 60 b, and 107 52 b, respectively. The magnitude of the K* cross section implies a cross section of approximately 5 b for production of a charmed DD» pair. © 1978 The American Physical Society.

Title: Photoproduction of vector mesons at high energies and Compton scattering by nucleons
Affiliations: Institute of Physics, A/105 Saheed Nagar, Bhubaneswar-751007, India
Authors with affiliations: Misra, S.P., Institute of Physics, A/105 Saheed Nagar, Bhubaneswar-751007, India; Maharana, L., Institute of Physics, A/105 Saheed Nagar, Bhubaneswar-751007, India
Abstract: We consider photoproduction of vector mesons and Compton scattering at high energies. Coupling of the electromagnetic current to neutral vector mesons as given theoretically in quark models and experimentally in storage-ring experiments is assumed. This gives a reasonable theory for ρ, ω, φ, ψ, and ψ′ photoproduction processes in a unified manner with appropriate energy dependence for (dσdt)0 for φ, ψ, and ψ′, as well as for the slope parameter while approaching the high-energy limit. The correct total Compton-scattering cross section by nucleons in the high-energy limit is obtained. It appears that one is able to understand in a qualitative manner the success of vector-dominance models in the context of the quark model, without assuming vector dominance in a conventional form and without any field-current identity. © 1978 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Lutz H.M., Schmitt R., Steffens F.
Title: A high-temperature, high-pressure microbalance for the determination of the hydrogen sorption characteristics of metal hydrides
Affiliations: Battelle-Geneva Research Centre, CH-1227 Carouge, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Lutz, H.M., Battelle-Geneva Research Centre, CH-1227 Carouge, Switzerland; Schmitt, R., Battelle-Geneva Research Centre, CH-1227 Carouge, Switzerland; Steffens, F., Battelle-Geneva Research Centre, CH-1227 Carouge, Switzerland
Abstract: The use of hydrogen as a future complementary energy vector is essentially linked to the problem of its storage and transport. Apart from conventional techniques, the storage of hydrogen in metal hydrides is considered of interest for a number of applications. To make a metal hydride a suitable hydrogen storage material, it must exhibit certain characteristics concerning in particular: (i) the hydrogen storage capacity, (ii) the dissociation pressure-temperature relationship, (iii) the heat of reaction, and (iv) the kinetics of hydrogen absorption/desorption. All these data can be determined using a microbalance capable of operating at high temperatures and pressures. The principal item of the thermogravimetric installation developed at Battelle-Geneva consists of a Sartorius balance type 4406 equipped with a heatable autoclave. The attached pressure and temperature control systems allow measurements under conditions of constant pressure (10-5 Torr to 60 bar) and temperature (15 to 600°C), as well as the execution of pressure and temperature cycling programs at various scanning speeds. The performance and versatility of the instrument is illustrated by measuring various hydrogen sorption characteristics of the known magnesium nickel hydride and iron titanium hydride. © 1978.

Authors: KE P.J., LINKE B.A., ACKMAN R.G.
Title: ACCELERATION OF LIPID OXIDATION IN FROZEN MACKEREL FILLET BY PRETREATMENT WITH MICROWAVE HEATING
Affiliations: Dept. of Fisheries and the Environment, Fisheries and Marine Service Halifax Lab, 1707 Lower Water St, Halifax, Nova Scotia, B3J 2R3, Canada
Authors with affiliations: KE, P.J., Dept. of Fisheries and the Environment, Fisheries and Marine Service Halifax Lab, 1707 Lower Water St, Halifax, Nova Scotia, B3J 2R3, Canada; LINKE, B.A., Dept. of Fisheries and the Environment, Fisheries and Marine Service Halifax Lab, 1707 Lower Water St, Halifax, Nova Scotia, B3J 2R3, Canada; ACKMAN, R.G., Dept. of Fisheries and the Environment, Fisheries and Marine Service Halifax Lab, 1707 Lower Water St, Halifax, Nova Scotia, B3J 2R3, Canada
Abstract: Fresh mackerel fillets with skin on were pretreated, before frozen storage at –15°C by microwave heating at 2450 MHz for 5, 10 and 20 sec. During 6 months, the lipids of the skin and meat of the fillets were separately examined for quality variations by chemical methods such as TBA, POV and FFA. Pro‐oxidant effects on lipids in mackerel fillets pretreated for 20 sec were shown by an increase of TBA molar value of 200% and 100% in the skin and meats, respectively, after 6 wk of frozen storage at –15°C. In fillets stored for 6 months, the rate of increase in POV in the pretreated sample was twice that in the control. According to the RIM quality evaluation system, the life in frozen storage of mackerel fillets pretreated with microwave heating decreased proportionately with the time of pretreatment. The loss of storage life was as much as 60% (from 16 to 7 wk) compared with the control samples. It is suggested that the promotion of lipid oxidation in the fish pretreated with microwave energy should be considered as a particularly important factor affecting the quality during frozen preservation. Copyright © 1978, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Authors: Adam M.Y., Wuilleumier F., Sandner N., Krummacher S., Schmidt V., Mehlhorn W.
Title: New Determination of Partial Subshell Photoionization Cross Sections in Argon and Xenon
Affiliations: Universität Freiburg, Freiburg im Breisgau, D-7800, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Adam, M.Y., Universität Freiburg, Freiburg im Breisgau, D-7800, Germany; Wuilleumier, F., Universität Freiburg, Freiburg im Breisgau, D-7800, Germany; Sandner, N., Universität Freiburg, Freiburg im Breisgau, D-7800, Germany; Krummacher, S., Universität Freiburg, Freiburg im Breisgau, D-7800, Germany; Schmidt, V., Universität Freiburg, Freiburg im Breisgau, D-7800, Germany; Mehlhorn, W., Universität Freiburg, Freiburg im Breisgau, D-7800, Germany
Abstract: Absolute photoionization cross sections of the 3s-3p subshells of argon and of the 5s-5p-4d subshells of xenon have been redetermined in the 30–110 eV photon energy range. The synchrotron radiation emitted by the ACO storage ring was used to determine the relative contribution of the various ionization processes leaving the residual positive ion in its ground state or in an excited state. The amount of multiple ionization and the total photoabsorption cross section have been taken from other recent experiments and tabulations. The results are presented in graphic form and compared with theoretical calculations. They show there is still a need for more accurate determinations of the total photoabsorption cross section. © 1978 The Japan Society of Applied Physics.
Index Keywords: SPECTROSCOPY, X-RAY; XENON - Ionization; ARGON

Authors: Edsinger R.W., Warren A.W., Gordon L.H.
Title: SIMWEST: a simulation model for wind energy storage systems.
Source title: IN: PROC. 13TH INTERSOCIETY ENERGY CONVERSION ENGINEERING CONF., (SAN DEIGO, U.S.A.: AUG.20-25, 1978)
Volume: 3 , Warrendale, U.S.A., Soc. Automot. Engrs. Inc., 1978
Authors with affiliations: Edsinger, R.W.; Warren, A.W.; Gordon, L.H.
Abstract: This paper describes a computer program for the modelling of wind energy systems with storage. It was developed under the sponsorship of the Department of Energy, under the direction of the NASA/Lewis Research Lab and under contract to Boeing Computer Services . The level of detail of SIMWEST is consistent with evaluating the economic feasibility as well as the general performance of wind energy sysetms with energy storage options. The software package consists of two basic programs and a library of system, environmental, and control components. The first program is precompiler which allows the library components to be put together in building block form. The second program performs the techno-economic system analysis with the required input/output, and the integration of system dynamics. An example of the application of the SIMWEST program to a current 100 kW wind energy storage system is given. (A)

Title: Performance optimization of a hydraulic hybrid vehicular drive.
Source title: IN: PROC. FIFTH INT. FLUID POWER SYMP., (DURHAM UNIV., U.K.: SEO.13-15,1978)
Volume: 1 , Cranfield, U.K., BHRA Fluid Engng., 1978, Paper B4
Authors with affiliations: Svoboda, J.V.; Sankar, S.
Abstract: This paper is concerned with the performance optimization of a hydraulic hybrid vehicular drive. The drive uses a small IC-engine prime mover, a hydraulic transmission, and a hydraulic accumulator as a small energy storage. The system aims to achieve a high overall efficiency by utilizing the hydraulic accumulator to maintain optimal loading of the prime mover and to provide regenerative braking. The system design was conceived and designed with the aid of both the analog and digital modelling techniques. Based on the preliminary design of the hybrid vehicle drive, this paper presents the selection of optimal controller gains and time constants using multiparameter optimization. An optimization algorithm called the complex method is used, which is a modification of the sequential simplex method. The objective of the optimization was to minimize the fuel consumption without any loss of drive performance. A comparison between the drive performance before and after optimization is presented and discussed. (A)

Title: Mechanochemical properties of membranes
Source title: Current Topics in Membranes and Transport
Affiliations: Department of Biomedical Engineering, Duke University, Durham, NC, United States; Department of Chemical Engineering, Washington University, St. Louis, MI, United States
Authors with affiliations: Evans, E.A., Department of Biomedical Engineering, Duke University, Durham, NC, United States; Hochmuth, R.M., Department of Chemical Engineering, Washington University, St. Louis, MI, United States
Abstract: Thin biological membranes are most simply characterized by four independent elastic moduli and two coefficients of surface viscosity. The elastic constants include: (1) an elastic modulus for volume compressibility, ∼ 10 10-1011 dyn/cm2; (2) an elastic modulus for area compressibility (at constant volume), ∼ 102 dyn/cm; (3) a surface elastic shear modulus for recoverable extension (at constant area), ∼ 10-2 dyn/cm for the red cell membrane and ∼0 for lipid bilayer membranes; and (4) a curvature or bending elastic modulus, ∼ 10 -13-10-12 dyn-cm (erg). Assumed to be volumetrically incompressible, membranes also exhibit a very large resistance to fractional changes in area per molecule or membrane thickness. On the contrary, red cell membranes have a low resistance to shear or extensional deformations, and these membranes are capable of large elastic extensions. Even though red cell membrane shear rigidity is small, the red cell membrane is a solid material for shear resultants less than the yield shear, 2-8 × 10-2 dyn/cm; above the yield point, red cell membranes begin plastic flow, resulting in permanent deformation. The lipid bilayer, however, has no shear rigidity (above the transition temperature) and thus is a two-dimensional liquid. The red cell membrane shear elastic energy storage is in general much greater than the curvature or bending energy. However, for a lipid bilayer and in situations in which membrane force resultants contribute neglibibly, bending rigidity can determine the mechanical stability. The coefficients of viscosity for tlie membrane represent: (1) the energy dissipation produced by finite rates of membrane area expansion or condensation, ∼ 10-7 dyn-sec/cm (estimate); and (2) the energy dissipation resulting from finite rates of extension or shear in the membrane plane, ∼10-4-10-2 dyn-sec/cm for the red cell membrane and ∼10-5-10-3 dyn-sec/cm for lipid bilayer membranes. Associated structural material, e.g., red cell membrane spectrin, or connective tissue strongly influences the membrane dynamic behavior in extension or shear deformation. Continuum mechanical properties are related to the molecular structure and therefore provide direct assessment of the material arrangement. In conjunction with thermodynamic considerations, mechanochemical equations of state and material thermodynamic relations can be investigated. The major difficulties are associated with the mechanical experiments and analyses. In many cases, forces on the order of 10-9-10-6 dyn have to be produced, controlled, and detected; also, observation of the experiment is often limited by microscope resolution or can only be indirectly performed. On top of this, mathematical complexity can obscure the "physics" and make the analysis almost intractable. Experiments must be carefully designed to measure the independent material properties of the membrane. It is clear from Tables I-IV that there is a significant requirement for more experimental data.

Authors: Carrigan R.A., Strauss B.P., Giacomelli G.
Title: Search for magnetic monopoles at the CERN intersecting storage rings
Affiliations: Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, Batavia, IL 60510, United States; Istituto di Fisica, Universita di Bologna, INFN, Bologna, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Carrigan, R.A., Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, Batavia, IL 60510, United States; Strauss, B.P., Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, Batavia, IL 60510, United States; Giacomelli, G., Istituto di Fisica, Universita di Bologna, INFN, Bologna, Italy
Abstract: In a search for magnetic monopoles produced in high-energy pp collisions, a series of metallic collectors was exposed at an intersection region of the CERN Intersecting Storage Rings to an integrated luminosity Lt7.2×1037 cm-2. The search was sensitive to poles with a mass mg 30 GeV. For mg<20 GeV, the search yielded an upper-limit cross section of σ<1.3×10-37 cm2 (95% confidence level) for 0.2 g 1.2 Dirac magnetic charges; for 1.2<g<24 the limit is σ 4×10-37 cm2. © 1978 The American Physical Society.

Title: Why change gaits? Recruitment of muscles and muscle fibers as a function of speed and gait
Affiliations: Museum of Comparative Zoology, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA 02138, United States
Authors with affiliations: Richard Taylor, C., Museum of Comparative Zoology, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA 02138, United States
Abstract: Muscles shorten, stay the same length and are stretched while they are active during normal modes of terrestrial locomotion. The relative importance of these different types of muscular activity changes as animals change gait. Energy is conserved during a walk by an alternate storage and recovery of gravitational potential energy within each stride, as in an inverted pendulum. In order for this transfer of energy to take place, muscular activity is required to hold the limb rigid while the animal rotates over it. Energy is conserved by a spring mechanism during running, trotting, galloping, and hopping. Energy is stored when active muscles and their tendons are stretched and recovered as they subsequently shorten. The recruitment patterns of motor units as a function of speed therefore, depends on the type of muscular activity as well as the force exerted. Discontinuities in the cross sectional area of active fibers with increasing speed have been observed at the trot-gallop transition. It is suggested that at this point the trunk is recruited as an additional spring enabling more energy to be stored elastically. It is concluded that we must consider what muscles are doing during normal modes of locomotion before we become too involved in designing schemes of motor unit recruitment. © 1978 by the American Society of Zoologists.

Title: Extracting energy from warm seawater
Authors with affiliations: Marland, G.
Abstract: While the phrase energy crisis is widely used in the context of the rising cost and diminishing availability of fossil fuels, there is in fact no lack of energy from alternative sources. The present situation has led to much more intensive investigation of these, which has revealed formidable-but certainly not insuperable-technological and economic obstacles to their exploitation. This article reviews the prospects for generating power on a large scale from the warm surface waters of the ocean, which represent a massive energy storage system. © 1979.

Title: The integrative role of lecithin-.cholesterol acyl transferase in triglyceride clearance
Source title: Scandinavian Journal of Clinical and Laboratory Investigation
Affiliations: Dept. of Chemical Pathology, Royal Free Hospital, London, United Kingdom; University College Hospital, London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Cramp, D.G., Dept. of Chemical Pathology, Royal Free Hospital, London, United Kingdom; Tickner, T.R., University College Hospital, London, United Kingdom
Abstract: There is evidence that not only lipoprotein lipase (LPL) but also lecithin: cholesterol acyl transferase (LCAT) are involved in the directional flow of triglyceride (TG) from endogenous very low density lipoproteins (VLDL) and chylomicrons as part of a general energy storage pathway. Evidence is given to suggest that LCAT plays an integrative role in this process. © 1978 Informa UK Ltd All rights reserved: reproduction in whole or part not permitted.

Authors: Coates T.J., Jeffery R.W., Wing R.R.
Title: The relationship between person's relative body weights and the quality and quantity of food stored in their homes
Affiliations: Stanford University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Coates, T.J., Stanford University, United States; Jeffery, R.W., Stanford University, United States; Wing, R.R., Stanford University, United States
Abstract: This study assessed, in a non-clinical community sample, the relationship between persons' weights and the quantity and quality of foods stored in their homes. Observers visited 65 randomly selected middle class suburban homes and recorded all food out in the house or visible in food storage areas. They also measured and weighed each family member. Foods were classified by type and by caloric content per serving. A generalizability analysis indicated that the data collection system yielded relatively precise estimates of each variable. Nevertheless, there was little relationship between body weight and the quantity and quality of food stored in these families' homes. Possible differences might emerge if more deviant samples were surveyed. © 1978.
Index Keywords: food storage; human cell; obesity; Body Height; Body Weight; Energy Intake; Family Characteristics; Food Habits; Food Supply; Obesity

Title: Minimizing radioactivity and other features of elemental and isotopic tailoring of materials for fusion reactors
Affiliations: Fus. Res. Program, Nucl. Engin. Dept., Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, Wis. 53706, United States
Authors with affiliations: Conn, R.W., Fus. Res. Program, Nucl. Engin. Dept., Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, Wis. 53706, United States; Okula, K., Fus. Res. Program, Nucl. Engin. Dept., Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, Wis. 53706, United States
Abstract: The levels of induced radioactivity in fusion devices can be controlled by appropriate selection of elements in a structural alloy and, in principle, by the selection of specific isotopes of a particular element. Three general rules are developed by which long-term induced radioactivity can be minimized. These rules are then applied to two specific alloy systems - stainless steels and the molybdenum alloy, TZM. A particular steel, Tenelon, containing neither nickel nor molybdenum, is especially attractive. It is found that the principles of both elemental substitution and isotopic tailoring can reduce the long-term radioactivity levels by orders of magnitude compared to normal Type 316 stainless steel. A comparison of long-term activity levels in such systems as the liquid-metal fast breeder reactor, fusion with standard structural alloys, and fusion with steel alloys designed for low activity quantitatively shows the potential advantage of fusion in this area. The influence of isotopic tailoring on gas production rates is also discussed. The calculations on radioactivity indicate that with proper attention to the choice of materials and isotopes, long-term radioactivity in fusion devices can be made so low as to either eliminate concern over long-term storage or allow recycling within a few human generations.
Index Keywords: nuclear energy; nuclear material; prevention

Title: Utilization of stored elastic energy in leg extensor muscles by men and women
Affiliations: Kinesiology Laboratory, Department of Biology of Physical Activity, University of Jyväskylä, Jyväskylä, FIN-40100, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Komi, P.V., Kinesiology Laboratory, Department of Biology of Physical Activity, University of Jyväskylä, Jyväskylä, FIN-40100, Finland; Bosco, C., Kinesiology Laboratory, Department of Biology of Physical Activity, University of Jyväskylä, Jyväskylä, FIN-40100, Finland
Abstract: KOMI, PAAVO V., AND CARMELO BOSCO. Utilization of stored elastic energy in leg extensor muscles by men and women. Med. Sci. Sports. Vol. 10, No. 4, pp. 261-265, 1978. An alternating cycle of eccentric-concentric contractions in locomotion represents a sequence when storage and utilization of elastic energy takes place. It is possible that this storage capacity and its utilization depends on the imposed stretch loads in activated muscles, and that sex differences may be present in these phenomena. To investigate these assumed differences, subjects from both sexes and of good physical condition performed vertical jumps on the force-platform from the following experimental conditions: squatting jump (SJ) from a static starting position; counter-movement jump (CMJ) from a free standing position and with a preparatory counter-movement; drop jumps (DJ) from the various heights (20 to 100 cm) on to the platform followed immediately by a vertical jump. In all subjects the SJ, in which condition no appreciable storage of elastic energy takes place, produced the lowest height of rise of the whole body center of gravity (C.G.). The stretch load (drop height) influenced the performance so that height of rise of C. of G. increased when the drop height increased from 26 up to 62 cm (males) and from 20 to 50 cm (females). In all jumping conditions the men jumped higher than the women. However, examination of the utilization of elastic energy indicated that in CMJ the female subjects were able to utilize most (~90%) of the energy produced in the prestretching phase. Similarly, in DJ the overall change in positive energy over SJ condition was higher in women as compared to men. Thus the results suggest that although the leg extensor muscles of the men subjects could sustain much higher stretch loads, the females may be able to utilize a greater portion of the stored elastic energy in jumping activities. © 1978 The American College of Sports Medicine.
Author Keywords: Elastic energy; Muscle mechanics; Positive and negative work
Index Keywords: elasticity; extensor muscle; human cell; leg muscle; muscle; normal human; Adult; Biomechanics; Comparative Study; Energy Metabolism; Female; Human; Leg; Male; Mathematics; Muscle Contraction; Posture

Title: Carbohydrate storage in man: Speculations and some quantitative considerations
Affiliations: Clinical Metabolic Laboratory, Department of Medicine I, Sahlgren's Hospital, University of Gothenburg, Gothenburg, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Björntorp, P., Clinical Metabolic Laboratory, Department of Medicine I, Sahlgren's Hospital, University of Gothenburg, Gothenburg, Sweden; Sjöström, L., Clinical Metabolic Laboratory, Department of Medicine I, Sahlgren's Hospital, University of Gothenburg, Gothenburg, Sweden
Abstract: Recent information indicates that the capacity of man to store carbohydrate energy by transformation into fatty acids synthetized de novo is very limited in adipose tissue as well as in liver and intestine. This seems to be in contrast to other species such as the rat where de novo fatty acid synthesis can be induced to a high capacity of glucose removal. This leaves man with a limited capacity to store excess carbohydrate. The remaining possibilities are both the main glycogen stores in liver and in muscle. The latter is by far the largest. The capacity of muscle to assimilate glucose is dependent on its glycogen content that in turn is dependent on previous glycogen depletion to supply energy for muscle contraction. Man might, thus, be uniquely limited in the capacity to dispose of extra carbohydrate in the sedentary state. This might speculatively be thought to be an explanation for a carbohydrate excess syndrome in the sedentary state that may well increase the risk for obesity, hyperinsulinemia, and diabetes mellitus. The logical treatment for such a syndrome then is either a decreased intake of energy as carbohydrate or an increased disposal of carbohydrate energy by exercise. Exercise has, indeed, been shown to have such effects both after physical training programs and, perhaps more pertinent to the question, during a few days after a single exercise bout that has consumed a large amount of muscle glycogen. © 1978, Grune & Stratton, Inc.. All rights reserved.

Title: Remote sensing of some forest damaged plants by false colour photography, spectroradiometry visible and near IR.
Source title: Proc. international symposium on remote sensing for observation and inventory of earth resources and the endangered environment, Freiburg, July 1978. Vol. 1

Sciences, Mont-Saint-Aignan, France., France; Anthore, N., Laboratoire d'Optique Physique, Institut Scientifique de Haute Normandie et U.E.R. Sciences, Mont-Saint-Aignan, France., France
Abstract: This paper discusses: 1) the data collected by means of false colour aerial photography in order to detect and to evaluate damage in the Roumare forest; 2) measurements of the relative spectral distribution of reflected energy by oak, birch, beech and bracken leaves; 3) a prototype of a ten spectral band spectroradiometer with short time storage of data which can be taken on board a helicopter. -from Authors false colour aerial photography damage Roumare forest helicopter

Title: Myocardial metabolism for the toxicologist
Affiliations: Dept. Anesthesiol., Univ. Rochester Med. Cent., Rochester, N.Y. 14642, United States
Authors with affiliations: Merin, R.G., Dept. Anesthesiol., Univ. Rochester Med. Cent., Rochester, N.Y. 14642, United States
Abstract: Drug effects on myocardial contractile function are obviously of considerable practical importance for the toxicologist. The basic mechanism of such actions must reside at some point in the metabolism of cardiac muscle. Interference in the liberation of energy from the fuels that the heart uses may be implicated. It is possible that drugs may interfere with the storage (conservation) of that energy as the high energy phosphates (ATP and CP). Finally, the utilization of that stored energy by the contractile proteins themselves may be altered. The latter process is highly dependent on intracellular calcium ion kinetics. Anesthetic drugs, which produce reversible depression of myocardial contractile function in a dose-dependent fashion, have been shown to interfere to some extent with all three processes. However, the most important mechanism probably involves utilization of energy and intracellular calcium ion movement. A basic knowledge of the biochemistry of cardiac muscle is necessary for the understanding of drug action and toxicity at the subcellular level.

Title: Energy Budget and Monthly Evaporation Estimates for Lake Superior, 1973
Affiliations: Applied Research Division, Canada Centre for Inland Waters, Burlington, Ontario, L7R 4A6, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Schertzer, W.M., Applied Research Division, Canada Centre for Inland Waters, Burlington, Ontario, L7R 4A6, Canada
Abstract: Thermal energy budget components and monthly evaporation estimates are computed for Lake Superior, 1973. Temperature surveys were available from which monthly heat storage change could be evaluated. Other budget parameters were estimated partly from existing basin meteorological network data and partly from empirical relationships. Monthly evaporation estimates computed as a residual from the energy budget were compared to estimates given by the mass transfer and water budget methods. Agreement with the water budget results is within 1 cm for most months. Correspondence with the mass transfer values is less impressive. Large discrepancies occur in summer for situations when the boundary layer is stable and the mass transfer approach overestimates condensation. © 1978, International Association for Great Lakes Research. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: EVAPORATION; TEMPERATURE MEASUREMENT; ENERGY BUDGET; LAKES

Title: Physiologic regulation of body energy storage
Affiliations: Department of Physiology, School of Medicine, University of Virginia, Charlottesville, VA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pitts, G.C., Department of Physiology, School of Medicine, University of Virginia, Charlottesville, VA, United States
Abstract: Both new and published data (rats, mice, and human beings) on three parameters-fat mass, fat-free body mass (FFBM), and total body mass in some cases-are evaluated. Steady state values of the parameters are analyzed for changes in response to specific perturbing agents and for their frequency distributions. Temporal sequences of values on individuals are examined for evidence of regulatory responses. The results lead to the hypothesis that the FFBM is regulated, but probably not as a unit, and that mass of fat is regulated with a high priority near the range extremes but with a much lower priority in the mid-range. Properties and advantages of such a mechanism are discussed. © 1978.

Authors: Miyairi S., Sugiura M., Fukui S.
Title: Immobilization of β-glucosidase in fibroin membrane
Affiliations: National ChemicalLaboratory for Industry, Hiratsuka, 254, United States; The Institute of Applied Microbiology, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, 113, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Miyairi, S., National ChemicalLaboratory for Industry, Hiratsuka, 254, United States; Sugiura, M., National ChemicalLaboratory for Industry, Hiratsuka, 254, United States; Fukui, S., The Institute of Applied Microbiology, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, 113, Japan
Abstract: Fibroin membrane was used as a support for immobilized β-glucosidase. The immobilized enzyme was prepared by drying fibroin-enzyme solution on a horizontal plate, followed by ethyl alcohol treatment which was an essential process for immobilization. The immobilized β-glucosidase was characterized enzymatically compared with soluble enzyme, using ρ-nitrophenyl-β-D-glucopyranoside as a substrate. The immobilized enzyme showed 47% of the activity of soluble enzyme and little decrease of the activity was observed both on re-use and storage. There were no significant differences in pH dependency between immobilized and soluble enzyme activity. Activation energy was slightly larger with immobilized enzyme than soluble enzyme. The enzyme was considerably enhanced by immobilization in stabilities against heating, electrodialysis and protease treatment. Apparent affinity for the substrate decreased as membrane thickness increased. Enzyme affinity for substrate in the membrane was discussed. © 1978 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Index Keywords: beta glucosidase; enzyme; animal experiment; arthropod; fibrosis; higher plant; membrane

Title: Relationships of adenine nucleotide metabolism to platelet-collagen adhesion
Affiliations: Dept. Pathol., Harbor Gen. Hosp., UCLA Sch. Med., Torrance, Calif. 90509, United States
Authors with affiliations: Morin, R.J., Dept. Pathol., Harbor Gen. Hosp., UCLA Sch. Med., Torrance, Calif. 90509, United States; Chen, A.F.T., Dept. Pathol., Harbor Gen. Hosp., UCLA Sch. Med., Torrance, Calif. 90509, United States
Abstract: Adhesion of platelets to collagen fibrils in a stirred system was inhibited by preincubation of platelets with combinations of 2-deoxy-D-glucose and oligomycin or antimycin. The inhibition of adhesion was associated with a decrease in metabolic ATP to 6% of control levels. Without metabolic inhibitors, platelets adherent to collagen fibrils were found to have catabolized approximately 57% of their metabolic ATP, and converted a major part of this to IMP. Storage pool ATP and ADP contents were also diminished in the adherent platelets. Pretreatment with imipramine resulted in 76% inhibition of the release reaction, but only 5% inhibition of adhesion. Imipramine-treated platelets that were adherent to collagen showed significant depletion of metabolic ATP, but markedly diminished conversion of ATP to IMP as compared to control adherent platelets. Inhibition of deamination of platelet AMP by coformycin or erythro-9-(2-hydroxy-3-nonyl) adenine (EHNA) did not inhibit adhesion, although platelets adherent to collagen after treatment with these agents showed depletion of metabolic ATP. These studies suggest that adhesion is an energy dependent process, occurring independently of release, and not associated with conversion of ATP to IMP. The energy dependent portions of the adhesion process are probably disc to sphere transformation and pseudopod formation, the ATP threshold requirement is relatively low, and the ATP utilized can probably be regenerated during the adhesion process via glycolysis and oxidative phosphorylation.
Index Keywords: adenine nucleotide; collagen; blood and hemopoietic system; histology; in vitro study; thrombocyte adhesiveness

Authors: Charles J.M., Abou-Donia M.B., Menzel D.B.
Title: Absorption of paraquat and diquat from the airways of the perfused rat lung
Affiliations: Departments of Physiology, Pharmacology and Medicine, Duke University Medical Center, Durham, NC 27710, United States
Authors with affiliations: Charles, J.M., Departments of Physiology, Pharmacology and Medicine, Duke University Medical Center, Durham, NC 27710, United States; Abou-Donia, M.B., Departments of Physiology, Pharmacology and Medicine, Duke University Medical Center, Durham, NC 27710, United States; Menzel, D.B., Departments of Physiology, Pharmacology and Medicine, Duke University Medical Center, Durham, NC 27710, United States
Abstract: The uptake of paraquat dichloride (bis-N-[14C]methyl-4,4′-bipyridilium chloride) and diquat dibromide (N,N′-ethylene-U-14C] 2,2′-bipyridilium dibromide monohydrate) from the airways and by the vasculature of the isolated and perfused rat lung (IPL) were studied. A semilogarithmic plot of the percent unabsorbed with time revealed a bi-exponential decay, suggesting at least two phases of removal of paraquat and diquat from the airways. The rapid initial process was similar for both herbicides. The slow component had a t1 2 of 355.98 min for paraquat and 75.03 min for diquat. This second process may represent the storage pool associated with the pulmonary toxicity of paraquat. When paraquat or diquat was presented to the capillary side of the lung, long-term storage was not evident. Uptake by the lung occured from the pulmonary circulation with similar velocity. These data suggest that the energy-dependent uptake observed with lung slices probably represents airway transport and may be associated with cell membranes lining the alveolus. © 1978.

Authors with affiliations: Kattlove, H.E., Dept. Med., Harbor-UCLA Med. Cent., Torrance, Calif., United States; Tanaka, K.R., Dept. Med., Harbor-UCLA Med. Cent., Torrance, Calif., United States
Abstract: Data indicate that the platelet glycolytic enzymes are stable during conditions normally used to preserve platelets for transfusion. However, it must be pointed out that these data only indicate that the enzyme activities are preserved as assayed in platelet extracts. This does not necessarily indicate that glycolysis in stored platelets is normal since a critical mechanism for regulating glycolysis, adenylate energy charge, is apparently affected by storage.

Authors: Service F.J., Veneziale C.M., Nelson R.A., Ellefson R.D., Go V.L.W.
Title: Combined deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase and fructose-1,6-diphosphatase. Studies of glucagon secretion and fuel utilization
Authors with affiliations: Service, F.J.; Veneziale, C.M.; Nelson, R.A.; Ellefson, R.D.; Go, V.L.W.
Abstract: An adult woman with hypoglycemia, hyperlactatemia, hyperuricemia, hypertriglyceridemia, hyperketonemia and inability to make new glucose from galactose, fructose, glycerol and alanine was found to have no hepatic glucose-6-phosphatase and deficient fructose-1,6-diphosphatase. Nonautonomous hyperglucagonemia was demonstrated and shown to contribute to the hyperlactatemia and hyperketonemia. A paradoxic hyperlactatemic response to glucose and galactose was observed. Studies of substrate utilization showed prompt adaptation to changes in dietary supply of energy which probably accounted for her never having experienced symptoms of hypoglycemia. © 1978.

Title: Direct-Contact Heat Exchanger - Storage System in Residential Solar Heating. [DIREKT-KONTAKT-WAERMEAUSTAUSCHER-SPEICHER IN SONNENHAEUSSERN.]
Authors with affiliations: Loss, Walter
Abstract: A pilot plant direct-contact-heat-exchanger-storage-system has been tested with three collector liquids. These liquids were heavier than water. Heat transfer and fluid dynamics were studied as these liquids streamed through a perforated plate at the top of the unit and passed down through a column of water. A full scale direct contact heat exchanger has been constructed and is presently being tested with Colorado State University Solar Houses.
Index Keywords: HEATING - Solar; Solar energy

Title: Opitimal control of on-board and station flywheel storage for rail transit systems
Source title: Journal of Dynamic Systems, Measurement and Control, Transactions of the ASME
Affiliations: Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ, 08540, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sweet, L.M., Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ, 08540, United States; Keane, M.J., Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ, 08540, United States
Abstract: The energy efficiency of rail transit systems using regenerative braking is enhanced by flywheel storage elements used to store energy not accepted by the wayside power rail. In this paper three storage system control concepts are examined: armature and field (onlrol of on-board flywheels, and field control of a station-based storage device. The energy recovery efficiency and performance characteristics of each system are determined subject to optimal control laws derived to minimize energy loss. The resulting control systems are bilinear, due to the use of separately excited DC traction and flywheel motors as continuously variable transmissions. The three systems yield similar energy recovery efficiencies for deceleration, with the advantages of each for practical applications discussed. © 1978 ASME.
Index Keywords: CONTROL SYSTEMS - Testing; ELECTRIC TRACTION - Flywheel Propulsion; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; FLYWHEEL ENERGY STORAGE; REGENERATIVE BRAKING; RAPID TRANSIT

Title: Cosmic ray induced errors in MOS memory cells
Affiliations: Rockwell International, Electronics Research Center, 3370 Miraloma Avenue, Anaheim, California 92803, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pickel, J.C., Rockwell International, Electronics Research Center, 3370 Miraloma Avenue, Anaheim, California 92803, United States; Blandford, J.T., Jr., Rockwell International, Electronics Research Center, 3370 Miraloma Avenue, Anaheim, California 92803, United States
Abstract: A model for estimating the cosmic ray induced bit error rate in dynamic MOS RAMs is developed and used to calculate the bit error rate in NMOS dynamic RAMs used in an operating satellite system. The calculated error rate agrees sufficiently well with the observed error rate to conclude that cosmic ray ionization is a likely cause of observed satellite bit errors. The susceptibility of MOS RAMs to cosmic ray induced error is a result of the small charge (sub-picocoulomb) typically stored on a MOS gate to represent a data bit. Relatively small energy deposition (a few MeV) can discharge a storage node, resulting in a bit error. The heavy ion particles present in galactic cosmic rays can provide this energy, resulting in a significant bit error rate for large memory systems in satellites. The dynamic RAM operational factors and design factors affecting ionization-induced bit error rates are discussed. Copyright © 1978 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: COMMUNICATION SATELLITES; COSMIC RAYS; SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES, MIS; MOS RAM; RANDOM-ACCESS MEMORIES; DATA STORAGE, SEMICONDUCTOR

Title: Energy assessments in pathological gait
Affiliations: Dept. Kinesiol., Fac. Hum. Kinet. Leisure Stud., Univ. Waterloo, Ontario, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Winter, D.A., Dept. Kinesiol., Fac. Hum. Kinet. Leisure Stud., Univ. Waterloo, Ontario, Canada
Abstract: The inefficiency of pathological gait has been the continuous concern of therapists. Unfortunately, quantitative measures of efficiency are impossible to obtain directly, and difficult to calculate even with sophisticated measurement and analysis equipment. The aim of this paper is to detail the magnitude of the problem of measurement of efficiency and to try to clarify certain anomalies and misconceptions that are apparent at this time. In order to give an overview, it is necessary to discuss the basic concepts involved in the term 'efficiency of gait'. To achieve this goal the paper has been subdivided into four specific topic areas: 1) a review of the basic theory of mechanical energy generation, absorption, storage, and transfer within the human body; 2) a description of the causes of loss of energy in gait, therapy identifying causes of inefficiency; 3) a description of the techniques used to analyze the energy of gait, and the interpretation of these analyses; and 4) a presentation of three case studies that demonstrate these techniques.
Index Keywords: biomechanics; case report; central nervous system; gait; hemiplegia; hip exarticulation; muscle; musculoskeletal system; normal human; total knee replacement

Title: Asymptotic behaviour as a guide to the long term performance of solar water heating systems
Affiliations: Solar Energy Unit, University College, Cardiff, Wales, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Brinkworth, B.J., Solar Energy Unit, University College, Cardiff, Wales, United Kingdom
Abstract: It is shown that good predictions of the long-term performance of solar water heating systems may be obtained from the asymptotic behaviour as the storage mass becomes indefinitely large. This can be evaluated with very little labour, enabling quick estimates to be made of optimum design parameters, and narrowing the range of conditions which need to be covered by more accurate but more costly methods. © 1978.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SOLAR ENERGY; SOLAR WATER HEATING SYSTEMS; WATER HEATERS

Title: Operational changes improve treatment at Philadelphia's Northeast WPC plant
Source title: Water Pollution Control Federation Deeds and Data for Wastewater Collection and Treatment
Affiliations: Philadelphia Water Dept., Philadelphia, Pa., United States
Authors with affiliations: DiMenna, R.A., Philadelphia Water Dept., Philadelphia, Pa., United States; Wankoff, W., Philadelphia Water Dept., Philadelphia, Pa., United States
Abstract: Many wastewater treatment plant operations can be improved without the expense and time necessary for major plant additions or modifications. More stringent effluent requirements and increasing energy costs make such optimization increasingly desirable. Although the operational changes described herein were made at one particular plant with its own unique design features, there are often operational changes, that can be made to improve the plant performance in almost any wastewater treatment facility. Maintaining a lower SRT in warm-weather months can be done in any activated sludge plant and can reduce power costs substantially. Maintaining a constant instantaneous F:M may improve treatment in some plants. Any plant which pumps raw wastewater has some storage capacity available for flow equalization. These are only a few areas where a plant operator can try innovative ideas. Sometimes pilot testing may be possible to evaluate a new idea, but more often the trial-and-error approach must be used. Extra effort may be needed to try a new procedure, but the outcome may be well worth the effort.
Index Keywords: sewage treatment; therapy; waste water treatment plant

Title: Waste heat utilization technology
Authors with affiliations: Hakuta, T.
Abstract: Approximately 50% of all energy consumed in Japan is released into the atmosphere, rivers, etc. as waste heat. Of the total energy consumed, close to 60% is used in the industrial sector. Taking these facts into consideration it can be seen that effective recovery and utilization of waste heat from energy intensive industries can contribute to massive energy conservation during the present era of high energy costs. All of the industries covered by this research and development are energy intensive. They include iron and steel, aluminum, cement, chemicals and pulp paper industries. Design of a series of technologies which will provide effective methods for recovery, exchange, storage, transportation and utilization of waste heat are covered by this research and development work. The technologies are innovative and will be widely used in many industrial fields. Research and development on waste heat utilization technology is in progress at three National Laboratories and many companies under government sponsored programs.
Index Keywords: heat; prevention; therapy

Authors: Weaver K.E., Barone G.J., Fewell T.R.
Title: Selection of technique factors for mobile capacitor energy storage X-ray equipment
Affiliations: Dept. Radiol., George Washington Univ. Med. Cent., Washington, D.C. 20037, United States
Authors with affiliations: Weaver, K.E., Dept. Radiol., George Washington Univ. Med. Cent., Washington, D.C. 20037, United States; Barone, G.J., Dept. Radiol., George Washington Univ. Med. Cent., Washington, D.C. 20037, United States; Fewell, T.R., Dept. Radiol., George Washington Univ. Med. Cent., Washington, D.C. 20037, United States
Abstract: The technique factors of capacitor energy storage x-ray equipment influence the x-ray beam quality and quantity differently than those encountered with conventional single-phase or constant potential equipment. This is due to the nature of the high voltage waveform applied to the x-ray tube in capacitor energy storage systems. A lack of understanding of this difference can lead to excess patient exposure through inappropriate selection of technique factors by either the manufacturers of these systems or uninformed technologists using them. From analysis of exposure measurements made with a Masonite phantom, a method has been developed for determining whether a selected technique may result in unnecessary patient exposure. In addition, the distinction between technique factors for conventional high tension transformer and capacitor energy storage systems is reviewed.
Index Keywords: methodology; radiography; roentgen equipment

Authors: Ninnemann J.L., Fisher J.C., Frank H.A.
Title: Clinical skin banking: A simplified system for processing, storage, and retrieval of human allografts
Source title: Journal of Trauma - Injury, Infection and Critical Care
Affiliations: The Division of Plastic Surgery, Regional Burn Treatment Center, University of California, San Diego, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ninnemann, J.L., The Division of Plastic Surgery, Regional Burn Treatment Center, University of California, San Diego, United States; Fisher, J.C., The Division of Plastic Surgery, Regional Burn Treatment Center, University of California, San Diego, United States; Frank, H.A., The Division of Plastic Surgery, Regional Burn Treatment Center, University of California, San Diego, United States
Abstract: A simplified procedure for the harvest and preservation of human allograft skin for burn treatment is outlined. In establishing a skin bank to serve the San Diego County Regional Burn Treatment Center, our primary goals were to deliver a low-cost product, monitored to be free of significant bacterial contamination. Our own innovations include the use of Falcon 2070 tubes as packaging material, and the use of microwave energy for the safe, rapid thawing of liquid nitrogen stored tissue. © 1978 by The Williams and Wilkins Co.

Title: STABILITY OF COCAINE IN AQUEOUS SOLUTION
Source title: Journal of Clinical Pharmacy and Therapeutics
Affiliations: Heriot-Watt University, Pharmacy Department, 79 Grassmarket, Edinburgh, EM 2HJ, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Murray, J.B., Heriot-Watt University, Pharmacy Department, 79 Grassmarket, Edinburgh, EM 2HJ, United Kingdom; Al‐Shora, H.I., Heriot-Watt University, Pharmacy Department, 79 Grassmarket, Edinburgh, EM 2HJ, United Kingdom
Abstract: The effect of pH on the rate of hydrolysis of cocaine was investigated. Ionic strength had a negligible effect while the concentrations of the various buffers had a significant effect on the rate of hydrolysis. The pH rate profile in buffer showed a minimum at 1.95. The energies of activation were determined to be 95.9, 107.3 and 97.9 kJ mol‐1 respectively at pH 6.8, 5J0 and 2.2. The stability on storage of sterilized solutions of cocaine prepared by various methods and formulae was compared with the stability predicted from the results of the accelerated tests. Copyright © 1978, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Title: Active Thermal Insulation by House Wall Solar Heating System. [AKTIVE WAERMEDAEMMUNG DURCH EIN IN DIE HAUSWAND INTEGRIERBARES, SOLARES NIEDERTEMPERATURHEIZSYSTEM.]
Authors with affiliations: Koerner, Wolf
Abstract: A compact heating system is developed by integration of collector and night storage heating in the walls of a house, which in comparison to passive heat insulation transfers the energy striking the outer wall to the inner wall. Under optimum conditions, an average inner wall temperature of 25 degree C in winter is expected. The energy requirements of fully insulated dwelling units could be reduced by 40%. The results of the technical-economical optimization and initial experiments are presented.
Index Keywords: SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; Heating

Title: Hydro-electric power generation and pumped storage schemes utilizing the sea
Affiliations: Sir Alexander Gibb and Partners, Earley House, 427 London Road, Earley, Reading, RG6 1BL, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Back, P.A.A., Sir Alexander Gibb and Partners, Earley House, 427 London Road, Earley, Reading, RG6 1BL, United Kingdom
Abstract: A large potential for a pumped storage hydro power is available around the shores of the United Kingdom, making use of the sea as the lower basin. There are also limited applications for pumped storage using the sea as the upper basin and disused mines for the lower basin. In this paper the general requirements for initial selection, feasibility analysis and planning of such projects are discussed with special emphasis on the major environmental constraints such as ground water pollution which must be satisfactorily resolved in each case before a scheme can be considered acceptable. A brief description is given of the coastal regions of the U.K. where topography and regional geology is favourable to pumped storage installations and an assessment is made of the overall capacity which might be available from such sources. © 1978.
Index Keywords: ENERGY CONSERVATION; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS

Title: The use of nuclear energy for district heating
Affiliations: AB Atomenergi, Studsvik, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Margen, P., AB Atomenergi, Studsvik, Sweden
Abstract: So far only one reactor-the Ågesta reactor, south of Stockholm has been used to supply a sizeable district heating scheme. For 10 years this pilot scheme delivered 10 MW of electricity to the grid and initially 50 later 70 MW of heat to the suburb 'Farsta' of Stockholm, with a very good reliability record. As yet it has had no successors anywhere in the world. Ågesta was of course too small to give good economics, but it gave valuable experience. As the citizens of Farsta had become accustomed to the smokeless nuclear heat, there were many protests from the public when Ågesta was shut down to allow the nuclear effort in Sweden to be concentrated on bigger units. Since the oil crisis, nuclear district heating schemes have, however, been studied with increasing effort in a number of countries as one of the possible ways of achieving lower heat costs, conserving the limited oil and natural gas resources, and reducing air pollution. In this article the author describes the basis for assessing the performance and economics of such schemes. To do this it has been necessary to treat not merely the nuclear plants but also the entire system of transport distribution and storage of heat. Many of the numerical examples in this area have been taken from the Swedish scene with which the author is best acquainted but also many comments on conditions in other countries are included. Also the institutional obstacles which often stand in the way of a wider use-and the manner in which they are starting to be tackled by several countries-are discussed. The subject is treated in a manner which it is hoped will be useful also to those without previous experience of district heating. © 1978.
Index Keywords: NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS; NUCLEAR REACTORS; AGESTA REACTOR; HEATING

Authors: Gruen D.M., Schreiner F., Sheft I.
Title: A thermodynamic analysis of HYCSOS, a hydrogen conversion and storage system
Affiliations: Chemistry Division, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gruen, D.M., Chemistry Division, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL, United States; Schreiner, F., Chemistry Division, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL, United States; Sheft, I., Chemistry Division, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL, United States
Abstract: A two metal hydride system for the storage, retrieval and conversion of thermal energy is described. The system functions-heating, cooling and power production-are discussed for solar energy applications. A thermodynamic analysis particularly of the conversion cycle is presented. It is concluded that solar concentrators providing heat transfer fluid temperatures of 140°C could give conversion efficiencies of 16.5%. © 1978.
Index Keywords: HYDROGEN; THERMODYNAMICS; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: The hydrogen/hydride energy concept
Affiliations: Daimler-Benz AG, Postfach 202, 7000 Stuttgart-60/BRD, Department of Research and Development, Stuttgart, Federal Republic of Germany, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Buchner, H., Daimler-Benz AG, Postfach 202, 7000 Stuttgart-60/BRD, Department of Research and Development, Stuttgart, Federal Republic of Germany, Germany
Abstract: With technology at its present stage, hydrogen is a very convenient secondary energy source (fuel, propellant) at the end of the oil era, as hydrogen (given the necessary primary energy, e.g. coal, nuclear energy for hydrogen production) is available in water in practically inexhaustible quantities and its distribution in the form of pure hydrogen or part-hydrogen gas mixtures (town gas) presents no fundamental technical problems. Hydrogen technology brought about as a result of the dwindling reserves of mineral oil offers particularly favourable advantages in that hydrogen, like oil, can be applied universally as an energy source not only for domestic and industrial use, but also for motor vehicles. The storage of hydrogen for mobile (vehicle) and stationary (domestic) applications is best undertaken by the aid of suitable metal hydrides. Hydride research at Daimler-Benz not only produced the world's first combination hydride vehicles, it also led to the discovery and further development of a series of possible applications for hydrides. This work shows, that hydrogen out of metal hydrides is not only environmentally acceptable and offers independence of petroleum supplies, metal hydrides also permit optimum primary energy utilization by means of waste heat recovery from all combustion processes, heating and cooling of houses and cars without consuming primary energy and a reduction in energy consumption during the production of inexpensive D2O for natural uranium reactors. © 1978.
Index Keywords: AUTOMOTIVE FUELS - Research; HYDROGEN INORGANIC COMPOUNDS; METAL HYDRIDES; HYDROGEN FUELS

Title: Storage of Thermal Energy. [LE STOCKAGE THERMIQUE DE L'ENERGIE.]
Authors with affiliations: Coeytaux, M.
Abstract: A survey is presented of current methods proposed and applied in storage of thermal energy from solar radiation. The fluids considered include pressurized water organic fluids, molten salts, liquid metals, nitrates, carbonates, sulfates, chlorides, and fluorides.
Index Keywords: Solar energy

Title: A compact shallow solar pond hot water heater
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, Ben Gurion University of the Negev, Beer-Sheva, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Kudish, A.I., Department of Chemical Engineering, Ben Gurion University of the Negev, Beer-Sheva, Israel; Wolf, D., Department of Chemical Engineering, Ben Gurion University of the Negev, Beer-Sheva, Israel
Abstract: The concept of the shallow or convecting solar pond has been discussed in the literature in great detail but with regard to large scale installations only. It is also possible to consider the use of portable, compact SSPs in reacreation (i.e. camping) and military sites. We have constructed and tested such a prototype unit. It consisted of a clear PVC pond placed within an insulated wooden container equipped with a hinged cover. The upper glazing was a 0.1 mm tedlar film. The container cover served a dual purpose. During the day it performed as a solar reflector by means of an aluminized mylar film affixed to the inner site, and it was thermally insulated so as to enable the overnight storage of the heated water. © 1978.
Index Keywords: ENERGY UTILIZATION; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; SOLAR PONDS; SOLAR REFLECTORS; WATER HEATERS

Authors: GEBHART W., LASSMANN H., NIEBAUER G.
Title: Demonstration of Specific Storage Material within Cutaneous Nerves in Metachromatic Leukodystrophy
Affiliations: Universitäts-Hautklinik, University of Vienna, Vienna, Austria; Neurological Institute, Institute for Micromorphology and Electronmicroscopy, University of Vienna, Vienna, Austria
Authors with affiliations: GEBHART, W., Universitäts-Hautklinik, University of Vienna, Vienna, Austria; LASSMANN, H., Neurological Institute, Institute for Micromorphology and Electronmicroscopy, University of Vienna, Vienna, Austria; NIEBAUER, G., Universitäts-Hautklinik, University of Vienna, Vienna, Austria
Abstract: Biopsies of clinically unaltered skin from a 5‐year‐old girl with metachromatic leukodystrophy were studied by light, fluorescence and analytical electron microscopy. Investigation of hematoxy‐lin‐eosin‐stained sections revealed no pathologic changes, but a brown metachromatic material was found within cutaneous nerves after acetic acid cresyl violet staining of frozen sections. In semithin Epon sections small dermal nerve fascicles contained endoneural deposits, which proved to correspond with the typical prismatic, dense or Tuffstein bodies described in other organs of patients suffering from MLD. The inclusions were located mainly within Schwann cells and exhibited a bright orange fluorescence after trypaflavine‐phosphotungstic acid‐treatment as well as a high electron density in serial ultrathin sections. Energy dispersive X‐ray microanalysis revealed a high sulfur content in the membrane bound granules. These findings demonstrate the presence of the specific storage material also within cutaneous nerves in MLD and thus suggest skin biopsies as an additional and simple diagnostic aid in this disease. Copyright © 1978, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Authors: Ohkubo H., Musha H., Okuda K.
Title: Effects of caloric restriction on the kinetics of indocyanine green in patients with liver diseases and in the rat
Source title: The American Journal of Digestive Diseases
Affiliations: First Department of Medicine, Chiba University School of Medicine, Chiba, 280, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ohkubo, H., First Department of Medicine, Chiba University School of Medicine, Chiba, 280, Japan; Musha, H., First Department of Medicine, Chiba University School of Medicine, Chiba, 280, Japan; Okuda, K., First Department of Medicine, Chiba University School of Medicine, Chiba, 280, Japan
Abstract: The effect of caloric restriction on the hepatic uptake and excretion of indocyanine green (ICG) was studied in man as well as in rats. It was demonstrated that following a 72-hr caloric restriction in man, the plasma clearance rate for ICG was increased significantly at the low dose of 0.5 mg/kg, and transport maximum was increased without a significant change of storage capacity. In rats, the maximal biliary excretion was significantly increased after 48-hr fast, but neither maximal hepatic uptake (Vmax) nor hepatic ICG content was altered. The evidence is consistent with the view that fasting increases the ICG plasma clearance at low doses by enhancement of excretory steps at the bile canalicular membrane. © 1978 Digestive Disease Systems, Inc.

Title: Medium-Power 100-1000 kWe Solar Plants. [LES CENTRALES SOLAIRES DE MOYENNE PUISSANCE A COLLECTEURS DISTRIBUES 100 A 1,000 kWe.]
Authors with affiliations: Boy-Marcotte, J.L.
Abstract: A study of a system of medium-power (100 to 1000 kWe) solar energy plants was made with a view to reducing the cost of the kWe produced. Development of the components led to the construction and testing of prototype solar modules and a pilot storage and turbine plant; the results of the tests were successfully compared with the theoretical estimates of performances. Two direct by-products of this project appear promising: the solar modules and storage plant together constitute a medium-temperature heat generator (100-250 degree C) which ought to find interesting applications in the production of industrial heat, for example, for agricultural and food factories; in addition, the thermal machine can be used not only with solar heat but also with heat recovered from factories with excess calories in the range of 100-250 degree C.
Index Keywords: Solar power plants

Title: Conversion of Chemical Energy into Work or Electrical Energy. [PASSAGE DE L'ENERGIE CHIMIQUE AU TRAVAIL OU A L'ENERGIE ELECTRIQUE.]
Authors with affiliations: Serruys, Max
Abstract: The problem of utilizing chemically reactive systems to generate caloric energy and, most of all, mechanical or electric energy is considered, showing that the difference between the reaction enthalpy and the maximum work, in applying the available energy concept of Gouy in the latter case, is not always positive, and appears more or less directly linked with the change in the number of molecules which accompanies the reaction. This, in turn, is applicable to problems in thermal energy storage (nuclear origin e. g. ), in breaking down water molecules to produce hydrogen and oxygen, particularly problems in choosing between the electrolytic process and the numerous possibilities of producing hydrogen through adequate endothermic reaction chains.
Index Keywords: Power generation

Authors: Leshuk J.P., Zaworski R.J., Styris D.L., Harling O.K.
Title: Solar pond stability experiments
Affiliations: P.O. Box 12833, Salem, OR 97309, U.S.A.; Department of Mechanical Engineering, Oregon State University, Corvallis, OR 97331, United States; Battelle-Northwest Laboratories, P.O. Box 999, Richland, WA 99352, United States
Authors with affiliations: Leshuk, J.P., P.O. Box 12833, Salem, OR 97309, U.S.A.; Zaworski, R.J., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Oregon State University, Corvallis, OR 97331, United States; Styris, D.L., Battelle-Northwest Laboratories, P.O. Box 999, Richland, WA 99352, United States; Harling, O.K., Battelle-Northwest Laboratories, P.O. Box 999, Richland, WA 99352, United States
Abstract: Questions about the long term stability of salinity gradients necessary for the proper operation of nonconvecting salt pond solar collector/storage systems have been raised in earlier feasibility studies. A cooperative experimental effort was established between Battelle-Northwest Laboratories and Oregon State University to investigate some of these questions. The results of a year long experimental study are reported with conclusions drawn to date from partial data reduction. Although severe modeling problems were encountered, generally encouraging observations about the stability of these thermo-haline systems were made. Maximum bottom temperatures of 76°C were obtained as a result of insolation levels below those occurring in field installations. Stable temperature gradients ranging from 150-300°C/m were observed. Slow top and bottom mixing layer growth was the only failure mode noted despite attempts to introduce instabilities at intermediate levels. © 1978.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SOLAR ENERGY; SOLAR PONDS; SOLAR RADIATION

Title: Cross regulation in a two-output DC-To-DC converter with application to testing of energy-storage transformers
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Bell Laboratories, Whippany, NJ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wilson, T.G., Jr., Bell Laboratories, Whippany, NJ, United States
Abstract: Cross regulation is a technique for providing multiple regulated output voltages from an energystorage dc-To-dc converter where only one of the outputs is actually sensed by the controller and regulated to the desired value. The regulation of the remaining output voltages depends on the magnetic coupling between the multiple secondary windings of the energy-storage transformer. This paper extends the analysis of [l] by examining the cross regulation performance of a two-output voltage step-up/current step-up dc-To-dc converter operating in the continuous mmf mode under constant-frequency control. The analysis is shown to be a useful tool for generating test specifications for screening energy-storage transformers to guarantee that the leakage flux associated with the transformers does not prevent the converter from providing adequate cross regulation. © 1978 IEEE.
Index Keywords: DC transformers; Electric transformer testing; Energy storage; Magnetic couplings; Magnetic storage; Power converters; Transformer windings; ELECTRIC TRANSFORMERS - Testing; Constant frequency; Cross regulation; DC-to-DC converters; Leakage flux; Output voltages; Secondary windings; Test specifications; DC-DC converters; ELECTRIC CONVERTERS, POWER TYPE

Title: Properties optimization for phase-change energy storage in air-based solar heating systems
Affiliations: Solar Energy Laboratory, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI 53706, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jurinak, J.J., Solar Energy Laboratory, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI 53706, United States; Abdel-Khalik, S.I., Solar Energy Laboratory, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI 53706, United States
Abstract: A parametric study has been conducted to determine the optimum physical properties of phase-change energy storage materials for solar air-heating systems. Simulation techniques are used to determine the system performance over the entire heating season. Variations of the solar fraction of the load with melting temperature, latent heat, load characteristics, and control strategy have been determined. Air-heating systems with a wide range of hot water and space heating loads have been examined. The effect of semicongruent melting of the phase change material on system performance has also been investigated. © 1978.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; OPTIMIZATION; SOLAR ENERGY; HEATING

Authors: Fischer W., Gels H.B., Gross F., Liemert K., Rohr F.J.
Title: Economic prospects for the application of new electric energy storage devices
Affiliations: Brown, Boveri and Cie AG, Central Research Laboratory, Heidelberg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Fischer, W., Brown, Boveri and Cie AG, Central Research Laboratory, Heidelberg, Germany; Gels, H.B., Brown, Boveri and Cie AG, Central Research Laboratory, Heidelberg, Germany; Gross, F., Brown, Boveri and Cie AG, Central Research Laboratory, Heidelberg, Germany; Liemert, K., Brown, Boveri and Cie AG, Central Research Laboratory, Heidelberg, Germany; Rohr, F.J., Brown, Boveri and Cie AG, Central Research Laboratory, Heidelberg, Germany
Abstract: The technical and economic properties of new storage devices for electric energy such as batteries, hydrogen storage systems, flywheels, steam storage plants and compressed air storage facilities are compared with conventional peak power plants such as gas turbines and hydroelectric storage systems. The analysis shows that batteries, steam storage plants and compressed air storage facilities may be economically competitive with conventional peak power devices. Batteries are especially appropriate for dispersed energy storage systems. Utilization of storage devices instead of gas turbines results in substitution of oil or natural gas by coal or nuclear fuel. © 1978.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY - Applications; ELECTRIC ENERGY, STORAGE

Authors: Mathers J.P., Boquist C.W., Olszanski T.W.
Title: Powder Electrode Separators for High Temperature Lithium-Aluminum/Iron Sulfide Batteries
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Maryland, Baltimore, Maryland 21200, United States; Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, Illinois 60439, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mathers, J.P., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Maryland, Baltimore, Maryland 21200, United States; Boquist, C.W., Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, Illinois 60439, United States; Olszanski, T.W., Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, Illinois 60439, United States
Abstract: The feasibility of using ceramic powders for electrode separators in lithium-aluminum/iron sulfide cells was evaluated. Test cells of two different designs were constructed and operated for periods of 1000 and 2000 hr. Thus, the powder separator appears to be a good candidate for use in commercial cells. The advantages and limitations of this type of separator are discussed, and a comparison is made with fibrous separators which are also being developed for these cells. © 1978, The Electrochemical Society, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: battery; ceramics; fused salts; insulator
Index Keywords: CERAMIC MATERIALS; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; ELECTRODES, ELECTROCHEMICAL; ENERGY STORAGE; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES; ELECTRODE SEPARATORS; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Title: Modeling energy and power requirements of electric vehicles
Affiliations: School of Public and Urban Policy, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Blair, P.D., School of Public and Urban Policy, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA, United States
Abstract: In this paper we present a model of electric vehicle performance that can be used to estimate energy and power requirements of vehicles in various driving environments. The model is developed from basic vehicle parameters and, when coupled with a simple model of battery performance, is used to examine effective ranges and per-mile traveled energy requirements of electric vehicles as compared with internal combustion powered vehicles under similar driving conditions. A number of classes of vehicles are discussed, each of which is identified by characteristic values of the model's vehicle and driving pattern parameters. A simplified driving cycle is adopted and range calculations are made on each of the vehicle classes using a simple model of battery performance for a typical lead-acid battery and for a theoretical high-performance battery. The relationships developed here not only provide a simple estimating model of vehicle performance, but also lay the groundwork for a more comprehensive simulation model, the development of which is currently in progress. The simplified model has a number of restrictions on modeling alternative driving patterns. These restrictions are discussed along with logical extensions to the model that address the restrictions. The preliminary results of the model indicate that electric vehicles, employing either current technology or high-performance batteries, may be energy efficient in urban environments. However, in inter-city applications, where internal combustion engines are most efficient, the comparative energy efficiency of electrics is minimal. © 1978.
Author Keywords: Electric vehicles; Energy models
Index Keywords: STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES

Title: Energy storage: Economics and fuel conservation
Affiliations: ECN-Netherlands Energy Research Foundation, Research Centre, 3 Westerduinweg, Petten (NH), Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: De Boer, A.A., ECN-Netherlands Energy Research Foundation, Research Centre, 3 Westerduinweg, Petten (NH), Netherlands; Smit, J., ECN-Netherlands Energy Research Foundation, Research Centre, 3 Westerduinweg, Petten (NH), Netherlands
Abstract: This article presents an analysis of the economic aspects of energy storage for an electric utility. It is shown that it is possible to optimize the storage economics. A relation between the efficiency of an energy storage device and the possible fuel saving is derived. Fuel savings are only obtainable with high efficiency energy storage systems. © 1978.
Author Keywords: Economics; Efficiency; Energy conservation; Energy storage; Public utilities
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION

Title: Model systems in photoelectrochemical energy conversion
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, University of Oklahoma, Norman, OK 73019, United States
Authors with affiliations: Murphy, G.W., Department of Chemistry, University of Oklahoma, Norman, OK 73019, United States
Abstract: Several model photoelectrochemical energy conversion systems are devised and analyzed, based on properties of liquid junction-solid state semi-conductor photoactive "membranes". The systems are classified in terms of the following output objectives: electric power, short term chemical energy storage, desalted water from a saline source, acid-base production from a saline source, and hydrogen and oxygen from water.
