Multicompartment photoelectrochemical cells designed to achieve these objectives are made from various combinations of the photoactive component and ion selective membranes. All of the objectives are projected as technically feasible, but only the electric power and desalting are projected as economically feasible based on state-of-the-art technology. The properties of conceptual new solid state membranes needed to meet economic objectives in the other cases are analyzed. © 1978.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; MEMBRANES; SOLAR CELLS; SOLAR ENERGY; ENERGY CONVERSION; PHOTOELECTROCHEMICAL CELLS; ENERGY RESOURCES

Title: Energy storage and solar power: An exaggerated problem
Authors with affiliations: Metz, W.D.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Switching Mechanism in Amorphous Silver Metaphosphate Memory Cell with Low Switching Field Strength. [SCHALTMECHANISMEN AMORPHER SILBERMETAPHOSPHAT-SPEICHERELEMENTE MIT NIEDRIGER SCHALTFELDSTAERKE.]
Authors with affiliations: Kaes, H.H.; Herwig, H.
Abstract: The memory cycle of an amorphous silver metaphosphate memory cell with low switching field strength has been measured using rectangular pulses. The results can be interpreted by assuming phase separated regions in the semiconductor, an energy controlled 'on-off' and a mixed electronic and thermal 'off-on' switching process.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE UNITS - Switching; Data storage, Semiconductor

Authors: Tanaka T., Sakuta K., Kamimoto M., Tani T., Sawata S., Horigome T.
Title: Solar thermal energy storage using heat of dilution: Analysis of heat generation in multistage mixing column
Affiliations: Electrotechnical Laboratory, Tanashi, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tanaka, T., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Tanashi, Tokyo, Japan; Sakuta, K., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Tanashi, Tokyo, Japan; Kamimoto, M., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Tanashi, Tokyo, Japan; Tani, T., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Tanashi, Tokyo, Japan; Sawata, S., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Tanashi, Tokyo, Japan; Horigome, T., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Tanashi, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Storage of solar energy is important for the future success of solar energy utilization systems such as solar thermal power plants. Various papers have described the storage methods for storing solar energy. Because of the results of assessing the storage methods proposed in these papers, the method based on heat of dilution was selected by reasons of the ease of heat transfer, the controllability of reaction and the recovery of heat stored. The effectiveness of heat recovered from heat of dilution in the case of storing solar energy in the form of heat of dilution was considered in this paper. Sulfuric acid and water solution used as the typical example of heat of dilution, since its thermodynamic properties were well known. Two liquids were mixed in two different systems of multistage mixing column, and an application of heat of dilution to multipurpose energy utilization was analyzed. The utility of heat of dilution was explained from the results of thermal characteristics of each system. © 1978.
Author Keywords: Energy storage; Heat of dilution; Solar energy storage; Thermochemical energy storage
Index Keywords: SOLAR POWER PLANTS - Energy Storage; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: Factors contributing to the multiple rate of piano tone decay
Source title: Journal of the Acoustical Society of America
Affiliations: General Electric Co., Appliance Park 35 1101, Louisville, KY 40225, United States; Formerly at the Seismological Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, United States; Baldwin Piano and Organ Company, Cincinnati, Ohio 45202, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hundley, T.C., General Electric Co., Appliance Park 35 1101, Louisville, KY 40225, United States, Formerly at the Seismological Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, United States, Baldwin Piano and Organ Company, Cincinnati, Ohio 45202, United States
Abstract: Causes for the decrease in rate of piano tone decay with time of tone duration were investigated, including the following: different rates for different vibration modes or groups of modes, nonlinear transformation of mechanical energy to acoustical energy, storage of mechanical energy for subsequent acoustical radiation, transfer of energy between string modes perpendicular and parallel to the bridge, interference among strings that are almost exactly in tune, and change in rate of energy transfer from the multiple-string source to the bridge during the transition from an initial in-phase condition to a later out-of-phase condition. The last two closely related factors were found to control the rate change in most cases. © 1978, Acoustical Society of America. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: PIANOS; MUSICAL INSTRUMENTS

Title: Wire Mesh Floor Heating Systems
Affiliations: Ontario Hydro, ON, P1B 8L4, North Bay, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Armstrong, T.B., Ontario Hydro, ON, P1B 8L4, North Bay, Canada
Abstract: The use of wire mesh floor heating systems to store heat developed from low-cost electrical energy during off-peak hours was investigated for large resource industries. These systems have the double function of heating and reinforcing. As current increases in the steel magnetic wire, resistance decreases due to skin effect. Current follows the shortest path along the longitudinal wires with relatively little flow in the transverse wires. The resistance of the mesh electrical leads must be low to avoid making them heaters. The mesh heat output is regulated by voltage which varies directly as circuit length. Copyright © 1978 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; HEATING

Title: Recombination enhanced defect reactions
Affiliations: Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kimerling, L.C., Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States
Abstract: The energy liberated during an electronic transition may take the form of photons (luminescence), secondary electronic excitations (Auger), or phonons. In the case of phonon production, the vibrational excitation is localized at the recombination center (defect) before it dissipates to raise the temperature of the host lattice. A defect in an excited vibrational state may undergo simple solid state reactions such as diffusion, dissociation and annihilation which would not proceed under the Boltzmann distribution of energies determined by the temperature of the quiescent host lattice. The phenomenology of electronic enhancement is reviewed with emphasis on the roles of defect charge state, recombination and electric fields. The application of unimolecular reaction rate theory to the characterization of recombination enhanced reaction kinetics is discussed conceptually. Implications concerning the structural and chemical nature of host materials, recombination centers and reactant products is outlined. The role of recombination enhanced phenomena in device degradation is discussed and some useful applications of REDR in the selective programming of logic arrays and high definition electron beam data storage are presented. © 1978.
Index Keywords: SEMICONDUCTOR MATERIALS

Title: Two thermodynamic optima in the design of sensible heat units for energy storage
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Colorado, Boulder, CO, 80309, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bejan, A., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Colorado, Boulder, CO, 80309, United States
Abstract: The paper presents a treatment of sensible heat energy storage units as systems intended to store useful work. An analysis of the thermodynamic irreversibilities associated with storing energy from a hot gas source as sensible heat in huge liquid baths points out two important trade-offs: 1. There exists an optimum, well-defined quantity of hot gas to be used in order to maximize the useful work stored in the liquid bath. Using more than this optimum quantity in the hope of maximizing the amount of thermal energy stored as sensible heat leads to severe thermodynamics losses. 2. There exists an optimum relationship among the gas-liquid heat exchanger design parameters which minimizes the system irreversibility while maximizing its capability of storing useful work. This relationship provides a procedure for estimating the heat exchanger optimum number of transfer units (Ntu). Increasing the Ntu above the optimum in order to upgrade the heat exchanger effectiveness and the thermal energy storage capability leads to prohibitive losses due to fluid friction in the heat exchanger channels. The existence of the two optima demonstrates that designing sensible heat units for maximum thermal energy storage does not necessarily amount to thermodynamically optimizing such systems. © 1978 by ASME.
Index Keywords: HEAT EXCHANGERS - Design; HEATING - Heat Storage; THERMODYNAMICS; LIQUID BATHS; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: Energy storage requirements for spacecraft
Affiliations: Electrical Power Systems, Space Systems Division, Lockheed Missiles, Sunnyvale, CA 94086, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gandel, M.G., Electrical Power Systems, Space Systems Division, Lockheed Missiles, Sunnyvale, CA 94086, United States
Abstract: The demands for electrical power on a spacecraft are reviewed. These requirements affect the choice of prime power source and energy storage devices, which must be selected as a system. The design of the electrical system is addressed by describing current hardware characteristics and how these interact. Particular attention is given to batteries for energy storage. © 1978.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY - Design; SPACECRAFT

Title: Offshore Natural Gas Liquefaction Plants. [OFFSHORE-ERDGASVERFLUESSIGUNGSANLAGEN.]
Source title: Erdoel Kohle Erdgas Petrochem Ver Brennst Chem
Authors with affiliations: Berger, Eginhard
Abstract: Gas recovery from small offshore fields through LNG (liquefied natural gas) production, intermediate storage and loading on floating or stationary offshore platforms is discussed in terms of its advantages over the pipeline transport of gas. Offshore LNG plants would be particularly suitable for use in marginal offshore gas fields such as found in the North Sea, and in those fields which continue to flare the associated gas and thus waste a valuable energy resource. Further, these plants would prove advantageous in offshore areas plagued by harsh weather, and would be environmentally compatible in densely populated coastal regions.
Index Keywords: Natural gas, Liquefied; Offshore structures; Production platforms; SEMISUBMERSIBLE PLATFORMS; Natural gas

Authors: Giramonti A.J., Lessard R.D., Blecher W.A., Smith E.B.
Title: Conceptual design of compressed air energy storage electric power systems
Affiliations: United Technologies Research Center, East Hartford, CT 06108, United States
Authors with affiliations: Giramonti, A.J., United Technologies Research Center, East Hartford, CT 06108, United States; Lessard, R.D., United Technologies Research Center, East Hartford, CT 06108, United States; Blecher, W.A., United Technologies Research Center, East Hartford, CT 06108, United States; Smith, E.B., United Technologies Research Center, East Hartford, CT 06108, United States
Abstract: Conceptual design studies have been conducted to identify Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) systems which are technically feasible and potentially attractive for future electric utility load-levelling applications. The CAES concept consists of compressing air during off-peak periods and storing it in underground facilities for later use. During peak-load periods the air would be withdrawn, heated by recuperation and combustion and expanded through turbines to generate power. By using off-peak electricity for compression and stored air for peak-load generation, the resulting oil consumption would be about 40 per cent of that consumed by conventional gas-turbine peaking plants. The turbomachinery requirements for this type of system could be met using existing equipment with relatively modest modifications. Although the study discussed herein focused on the storage of air in hydraulically compensated, mined, hard-rock caverns, the compressed air could also be stored in underground aquifers or leached-out salt cavities. Conventional underground excavation technology could be used to construct these storage caverns. A geological survey of the north-central and north-east regions of the United States indicated that sufficient siting opportunities exist such that a prudently designed CAES plant should have little long-term adverse impact on the environment. The competitive position of CAES relative to conventional generation alternatives is highly dependent on utility-specific factors. The cost of electric energy from CAES is generally competitive with costs from conventional peak-shaving systems such as gas turbines and will improve as low-cost off-peak energy from nuclear plants becomes available. © 1978.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION; ENERGY STORAGE; COMPRESSED AIR; nuclear power station

Title: The efficiencies of thermochemical energy transfer
Affiliations: Department of Engineering Physics, Research School of Physical Sciences, the Australian National University, Canberra, Australian Capital Territory, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Carden, P.O., Department of Engineering Physics, Research School of Physical Sciences, the Australian National University, Canberra, Australian Capital Territory, Australia; Williams, O.M., Department of Engineering Physics, Research School of Physical Sciences, the Australian National University, Canberra, Australian Capital Territory, Australia
Abstract: A general thermodynamic study of thermochemical energy transfer and work production processes is presented. Both gaseous systems in which the effluent of each reactor is not separated into the reactant and product species, and liquid/gas systems in which the effluent separates spontaneously into liquid and gas phases, are treated. the study extends to consideration of non‐isothermal reactors, to the individual roles of reactor and heat exchanger in the work production processes and to the significance of the intrinsic work of phase separation. the overall system efficiency is derived as the product of two efficiencies: the energy storage efficiency which defines the fraction of the input energy passed in chemical form to storage and the work recovery efficiency which defines the fraction of this stored energy available as output work. the fundamental thermodynamic processes underlying the derivation of these efficiencies are examined from the point of view of optimization of the design and operation of individual system components. In particular, it is shown that the available work from a thermochemical energy transfer system approaches the maximum value given by the Gibbs' free energy change when the temperature profile of the exothermic reactor is suitably tailored. The work of separation has formed the basis of the analysis of specific system components and has given a useful insight into the understanding of energy storage efficiency. Work recovery efficiencies are calculated for the ammonia/hydrogen‐nitrogen system and the paper concludes with a discussion of some practical considerations relating to the recovery of work and the performance that one might ultimately expect from this system. Copyright © 1978 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.
Author Keywords: Ammonia/hydrogen‐nitrogen system; Thermochernical energy transfer; Thermodynamics
Index Keywords: AMMONIA - Thermodynamic Properties; HEAT EXCHANGERS - Applications; HYDROGEN; NITROGEN; WASTE HEAT UTILIZATION - Applications; DISSOCIATION; THERMOCHEMICAL ENERGY TRANSFER; ENERGY STORAGE

Authors: Babin L., Clausse D., Sifrini I., Broto F., Clausse M.
Title: Nucleation by the Borax of Dispersed Sodium Sulfate, Possible Application in Heat Storage. [NUCLEATION PAR LE BORAX DU SULFATE DE SODIUM DISPERSE. APPLICATION POSSIBLE AU STOCKAGE THERMIQUE.]
Authors with affiliations: Babin, L.; Clausse, D.; Sifrini, I.; Broto, F.; Clausse, M.
Abstract: The crystallization of droplets of aqueous solutions of Na//2SO//4 (0. 9 mole Na//2SO//4; 10 moles (H//2O) and an excess of solid Na//2B//4O//7 10 H//2O, dispersed within an emulsifying medium has been studied by differential scanning calorimetry. Two maxima of crystallization are observed at plus 7 degree C and minus 2. 5 degree C (without borax, the crystallization occurs around minus 41 degree C). Between the first and thirtieth cooling and heating cycles, an increase of about 15% of the calorific energy released during the crystallization has been found. This type of nucleation process could be of interest in the field of heat storage.
Index Keywords: CALORIMETERS - Measurements; Sodium compounds

Title: Deep ground coil evaporators for heat pumps
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering, Queens' University, Ashby Institute, Stranmillis Road, Belfast, Northern Ireland, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Goulburn, J.R., Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering, Queens' University, Ashby Institute, Stranmillis Road, Belfast, Northern Ireland, United Kingdom; Fearon, J., Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering, Queens' University, Ashby Institute, Stranmillis Road, Belfast, Northern Ireland, United Kingdom
Abstract: [No abstract available]
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS; SOLAR ENERGY; EVAPORATORS

Title: Failure Mechanisms and Reliability of Low‐Noise GaAs FETs
Authors with affiliations: Irvin, J.C.; Loya, A.
Abstract: The degradation and failure of low‐noise GaAs FETs have been accelerated by various stress‐aging techniques including storage at elevated temperatures with and without bias, exposure to humid atmospheres with and without bias, and temperature cycling. Several time‐temperature‐bias‐induced catastrophic failure mechanisms have been observed, all involving the Al gate metallization. These mechanisms are Au‐Al phase formation, Al electromigration, and electrolytic corrosion. Each of these processes results ultimately in an open gate. Accelerated aging also produces gradual, long‐term degradation in both dc and rf characteristics, though the two are not always correlated. In fact, contrary to some expectations, contact resistance may increase almost two orders of magnitude without significant degradation in the noise figure or gain of a low‐noise transistor. Besides contact resistance, other mechanisms such as traps in the channel are thought to play a role in the degradation of rf properties. It was found that all the important degradation mechanisms are bias‐sensitive and that aging without bias gives erroneously long lifetime projections. The cumulative failure distributions for the mechanisms observed approximate a log‐normal relation with standard deviations between 0.6 and 1.4. The relevant degradation or failure processes have activation energies near 1.0 eV, which give rise to projected median lifetimes at 60°C (channel temperature) over 107 hours and corresponding failure rates (excepting infant mortality) under 40 FITs (40 per 109 device‐hours) at 20 years of service. © 1978 The Bell System Technical Journal
Index Keywords: TRANSISTORS - Testing; TRANSISTORS, FIELD EFFECT

Title: Future Possibilities of Heat Supply by Nuclear Energy. [KUENFTIGE MOEGLICHKEITEN DER WAERMEVERSORGUNG DURCH KERNENERGIE.]
Authors with affiliations: Barnert, H.
Abstract: The market for thermal energy is presently supplied chiefly by products based on oil and natural gas. In the Federal Republic of Germany these two sources make up 75% of the thermal energy market. However, oil and natural gas will not be available in sufficient quantities in the long run and will thus have to be substituted, e. g. , by nuclear energy and coal. According to forecasts of the long term development of the primary energy requirement in the world the relative percentage fractions of oil and natural gas will decrease and will be replaced by nuclear energy and coal. The thermal energy market has a multi-faceted structure with respect to the production of sources of secondary energy, transport, distribution, storage and, finally, application as well as with regard to the utilization of capabilities and unit sizes of generation and thus offers possibilities of substitution in a variety of ways. There are numerous processes under development, which are technically feasible, to generate sources of secondary energy from nuclear energy to supply the thermal energy market, and in the long run sufficient varieties will be available to suit all users. Here are some of these methods and sources of secondary energy, respectively: electricity for the thermal energy market; district heat and process steam from nuclear power plants operated in the coupled heat-power mode; nuclear coal gasification; nuclear district energy; nuclear hydrogen generation from water. The conversion of coal into an easy-to-use source of energy, which is possible by means of nuclear energy and is also economically attractive, opens up new applications of coal and thus contributes to a more efficient utilization of this source of energy which is so abundant worldwide and also in the Federal Republic of Germany. According to the market and economic study included in the Nuclear Process Heat Prototype Plant Project (PNP) the theoretical potential of using substitute natural gas from nuclear coal gasification in 2025 will be some 100 million TCE/a.
Index Keywords: Nuclear power plants; Nuclear reactors

Title: Power from glaciers: the hydropower potential of Greenland's glacial waters
Affiliations: IIASA, International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis, A-2361 Laxenburg, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Partl, R., IIASA, International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis, A-2361 Laxenburg, Austria
Abstract: In the southern parts of Greenland, large quantities of water melting every summer from the ice shield 1000 m above sea level and more, within a short distance from the coast, offer favorable conditions for a large-scale hydropower development. General ideas on such a development have been published by several authors. This report tries to go a step further by providing an assessment of available resources, an analysis of technical problems for the utilization of this resource and its integration into a global energy system, and a preliminary estimate of construction needs and costs. The estimate of available resources is based on published climatological data for Greenland and other arctic stations, and on a cautious selection of effective solar radiation and albedo values. 210-360 km3 of water is expected to be available during the summer months at an average altitude of 1000 m, corresponding to an energy generation of 460-800 TWh. Continuous generation all-year-round, however, requires storage reservoirs with a total volume of 100-180 km3. In southwest Greenland, numerous large lakes will provide sufficient storage volumes. In the east, storage is a problem, and power generation might be restricted to the summer months. Some 12 to 15 sites have been identified on the maps where power schemes can be developed with a total installed capacity of 60-120 GW; hence, the estimated hydropower resources of Greenland come close to the 1974 total consumption of electric energy in the interconnected grid system of Western Europe which, according to the statistics of UCPTE, was 724 TWh with a peak load of 118 GW. Technologies for hydropower development are well established and already in progress towards the order of magnitude needed for Greenland; however, methods of collecting water melting from large ice surfaces have still to be studied and tested. The problem of bulk energy transport over great distances is common to all future global energy supply options, and not unique to Greenland energy. Carriers envisaged in the report are EHV sea cables and transmission lines on land, hydrogen gas pipelines across sea and land, and tankers for liquid hydrogen or ammonia. Preliminary cost comparisons show each of these carriers to be competitive under specific production and market conditions. The report gives a tentative model for the full development of Greenland's glacier power comprising all these options. Construction cost of the power schemes is estimated at 775-320 US-dollars per installed kilowatt, but another 220-430 US$/kW have to be invested in transport facilities such as EHV links or H2 gas pipelines. The use of liquid H2 as an energy carrier requires lower investments but involves higher energy losses. The integration of Greenland's glacier power into a global energy system is analyzed according to the criteria adopted for IIASA's Energy Program. No need of fundamental innovation and no serious constraints have been identified for a full development, scheme by scheme, over a projected construction period of e.g. 40 years, starting after an initial testing, planning, and design period of e.g. 10 years. A tentative study program is suggested comprising the collection of basic scientific data, as well as preparatory technical investigations and tests to ascertain the technical feasibility of the development. © 1978.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER TRANSMISSION, EHV - Costs; ENERGY RESOURCES - Greenland; GLACIERS - Greenland; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS

Title: Ranges of Application for Short-Time Heat Storage Units in the District Heating Supply. [EINSATZBEREICHE VON KURZZEIT-WAERMESPEICHERN IN DER FERNWAERMEVERSORGUNG.]
Authors with affiliations: Sparr, Uwe
Abstract: The author explains, in viewing the basic methods of operation, under which conditions short-time heat storage units can be used in the district heating supply. Statements are laid down on the economy of storage operation and on the possibility to save primary energy, which were arrived at within the frame of model calculations in a study of the Federal Ministry for Research and Technology in the Federal Republic of Germany.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Space Heating; HEAT STORAGE; Heating

Title: New energy-storage DC-DC converter with multiple outputs
Affiliations: Department of Electronics, Nagasaki University, Nagasaki 852, Japan; Department of Electronics, Kyushu University, Fukuoka 812, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Matsuo, H., Department of Electronics, Nagasaki University, Nagasaki 852, Japan; Harada, K., Department of Electronics, Kyushu University, Fukuoka 812, Japan
Abstract: New energy-storage dc-dc power converter is presented which provides multiple regulated and isolated dc output voltages. The conventional converter circuits have some defects. In the step-up-down type circuit, the operation is easy to be unstable when the feedback loop gain and/or the total output power grows larger. Meanwhile, although the operation of the step-down type circuit is stable, the extraordinary phenomena arise when the magnetomotive force of the energy-storage reactor is discontinuous for the light-load. These phenomena may be eliminated by the use of a dummy load or the reactor of sufficiently large inductance, but it makes the efficiency lower or the size and weight of the reactor larger. In the converter circuit presented here, the operation is stable and the extraordinary phenomena are eliminated by using the magnetic coupling among the multiple windings of the reactor. Hence, the dummy load can be removed and the inductance of the reactor can be made smaller. © 1978 IEEE
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC CONVERTERS, POWER TYPE; DC-TO-DC CONVERTERS; ELECTRONIC CIRCUITS, POWER SUPPLY

Authors: Fischer P., Hälg W., Schlapbach L., Stucki F., Andresen A.F.
Title: Deuterium storage in FeTi. Measurement of desorption isotherms and structural studies by means of neutron diffraction
Affiliations: Institut für Reaktortechnik ETH, CH-5303 Würenlingen, Switzerland; Laboratorium für Festkörperphysik ETH, CH-8093 Zürich, Switzerland; Institutt for Atomenergi Kjeller, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Fischer, P., Institut für Reaktortechnik ETH, CH-5303 Würenlingen, Switzerland; Hälg, W., Institut für Reaktortechnik ETH, CH-5303 Würenlingen, Switzerland; Schlapbach, L., Laboratorium für Festkörperphysik ETH, CH-8093 Zürich, Switzerland; Stucki, F., Laboratorium für Festkörperphysik ETH, CH-8093 Zürich, Switzerland; Andresen, A.F., Institutt for Atomenergi Kjeller, Norway
Abstract: Activation of pure stoichiometric FeTi turned out to be difficult and deactivation processes due to gas impurities limit the hydrogen storage capability. Isotherms of deuterium desorption are reported for the temperature range T = (25÷70)°C. At room temperature the crystal structures of FeTiDx (x = 0÷1.74) and FeTiH0.78D0.22 were investigated by means of neutron diffraction at D2-pressures up to 84 bar. Deuterium absorption in FeTi yields ternary deuterides and is associated with symmetry reduction corresponding to considerable distortions of the CsCl-type metal structure. In FeTiD deuterium occupies octahedral sites with two iron and four titanium atoms as nearest neighbour coordination (space group P2221 or P2 c). Hydrogenation does not change essentially the order parameter of FeTi. © 1978.
Index Keywords: CRYSTALS - Structure; DEUTERIUM - Absorption; ENERGY STORAGE

Authors: Abel E., Mahtani J.L., Rhodes R.G.
Title: Linear machine power requirements and system comparisons
Affiliations: Department of Engineering, University of Warwick, Coventry, CV4 7AL, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Abel, E., Department of Engineering, University of Warwick, Coventry, CV4 7AL, United Kingdom; Mahtani, J.L., Department of Engineering, University of Warwick, Coventry, CV4 7AL, United Kingdom; Rhodes, R.G., Department of Engineering, University of Warwick, Coventry, CV4 7AL, United Kingdom
Abstract: The revenue vehicle designs of the two German Maglev groups are analysed and the complex power requirements at the trackside substation calculated. The two systems are the Electromagnetic System (EMS) with either linear induction motor (LIM) or long stator motor propulsion, and the Electrodynamic System (EDS) with linear synchronous motor (LSM) propulsion. The operational conditions considered were 400 and 500 km/h velocities either at steady state cruise or with a grade or headwind additional loading. It is found that the LSM of the EDS system is the most suitable form of propulsion for these operating conditions, the long stator motor for the EMS having apparently reasonable characteristics at 400 km/h, but becoming degraded at 500 km/h, and the LIM's studied being unsuited to the high speed range. These results highlight the necessity to compare not only the active power supplied to a vehicle, but also the complex power at wayside substations to be able to indicate the overall efficiencies and power factors of the competing systems. The German, the Canadian and the Philco-Ford EDS designs are also compared by weight make-up and specific energy intensity. These results show that the advantage gained from a lightweight aircraft-type construction, coupled with the relatively longer body, is lost in the German design because of the extra dead weight of the wheel sets required for running on conventional duo-rail with the resultant heavier body structure. The respective machine power factors are included in the intensity calculations to link in reactive power storage. © 1978 IEEE
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC MOTORS, LINEAR; MAGNETIC LEVITATION

Title: A general method for the evaluation of possible systems for electric generation with solar energy
Source title: IEEE Transactions on Power Apparatus and Systems
Affiliations: Oak Ridge, Tennessee, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pollard, W.G., Oak Ridge, Tennessee, United States
Abstract: The purpose of this paper is the development of an easily applied general method of analysis of any type of potential system for electric generation with solar energy. It assumes that data for the site of the potential solar-electric plant collected over a period of ten or more years are available. The most important such data for this analysis are the mean annual insolation per unit area, I, in Btu per square foot (Btu/ft2), and the peak rate of solar insolation, P, in Btu/ft2 hr. Secondary site data include the mean number of hours of sunshine on the site per year, measures of the seasonal variation between summer and winter, and the frequency of damaging storms. For the proposed solar-electric generating plant, only two characteristics are required: the gross heat rate, H, in Btu of solar radiation received on the collectors per kilowatt hour (kWhr) of electricity delivered in usable form, and the amount and efficiency of energy storage included in the plant. The heat rate for the system depends on a series of efficiencies or losses as the received solar radiation passes through successive stages of the system to its electrical output. For fully engineered systems it can be estimated within fairly narrow limits. For speculative systems which might materialize as a result of future research and development, an assumed value can be chosen on the basis of what is hoped to be achieved. Copyright © 1978 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: SOLAR CELLS - Arrays; SOLAR RADIATION - Concentrators; SOLAR POWER PLANTS

Authors: Miura Y., Kawakami S., Sakai S.
Title: An analysis of the write performance on thin film head
Affiliations: Fujitsu Laboratories, Kawasaki, 211, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Miura, Y., Fujitsu Laboratories, Kawasaki, 211, Japan; Kawakami, S., Fujitsu Laboratories, Kawasaki, 211, Japan; Sakai, S., Fujitsu Laboratories, Kawasaki, 211, Japan
Abstract: The write/read performance of a thin-film head was studied by using simple single-turn stepped head. Yoke length and pole-face length are varied from 30 µm to 120 µm and from 3 µm to 6 µm, respectively. The read efficiency was well explained by the transmission line model. It was clarified that the magnetomotive force for saturation magnetic recording is expressed by a formula which consists of a constant term and a term proportional to the yoke length. The former term is corresponding to the minimum field to saturate a recording media, while latter is determined by the reluctance of the yoke. For more detailed analysis, the field produced by the head having a yoke semi-infinite in length is numerically calculated from the magnetization distribution determined so as to minimize the total magnetic energy. The result of the calculation explains the pole-face length dependence of the magnetomotive force for saturation recording. © 1978 IEEE
Index Keywords: THIN-FILM MAGNETIC HEADS; DATA STORAGE, MAGNETIC

Title: Hot Water from the Waste Heat of Refrigerating Plant. [WAERMERUECKGEWINNUNG IM GEWERBE - WARMES WASSER AUS DER ABWAERME VON KAELTEANLAGEN.]
Authors with affiliations: Stienen, R.
Abstract: The production, preparation and storage of meat and sausages in a butcher's shop requires hot water and adequate refrigerating facilities. These two factors, namely, refrigeration with its unavoidable yield of waste heat and the large amount of hot water required, furnished the reason for studying how the waste heat can be recovered and used for heating water. The solution arrived at was a storage heat exchanger which is arranged between the compressor and the air-cooled condenser and uses the heat of condensation for water-heating. The first pilot installations have shown that hot water is now available without any additional consumption of energy, the quantity being dependent on the capacity of the refrigerating machine and the time it is kept in operation.
Index Keywords: REFRIGERATION - Waste Heat Utilization; BUTCHER SHOPS; Heat pump systems

Title: Milk Cooling with Heat Recovery. [MILCHKUEHLUNG MIT WAERMERUECKGEWINNUNG ZUR BRAUCHWASSERERWAERMUNG.]
Authors with affiliations: Hermes, M.
Abstract: All major manufacturers of milk cooling equipment have recently been offering their products with facilities for heat recovery for water heating. Depending on make, the condenser used as heat exchanger is accommodated inside a water storage tank or attached to its wall or arranged in an intermediate tank. Service water temperatures of from 50 to 55 degree C are achieved in this way without any additional consumption of energy. In actual operating practice the cooling of one liter of milk can on average heat one liter of water to a temperature of 50 degree C. Heat recovery for water heating can be expected to be economic when the milk from about 30 cows and more has to be cooled. This applies in particular when oil-fired equipment has to be replaced.
Index Keywords: Heat pump systems; Dairies

Title: Head to head polymers IX: The rheological behavior of H‐H and H‐T atactic polystyrenes
Affiliations: Polymer Science and Engineering Department, Materials Research Laboratory, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, Massachusetts, 01003, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jacovic, M., Polymer Science and Engineering Department, Materials Research Laboratory, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, Massachusetts, 01003, United States; Vogl, O., Polymer Science and Engineering Department, Materials Research Laboratory, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, Massachusetts, 01003, United States
Abstract: The rheological behavior of a sample of H‐H polystyrene of Mn of 41,000 and a Mw/Mn of 2 was compared at 160 and 190°C with a sample of H‐T atactic polystyrene of similar molecular weight. The melt viscosity of H‐H polymer (unlike the H‐T polymer) was non‐Newtonian at low stresses and decreased more rapidly with stress. This observation seems to indicate a stiffer polymer chain for the H‐H polystyrene. The flow activation energy (E*) of H‐H polystyrene was found to be dependent on the dynamic shear stress and decreased with increasing dynamic shear stress. The dynamic shear storage modulus of the H‐H polymer has a smaller increase of G′ with ω than that of the H‐T polystyrene. Copyright © 1978 Society of Plastics Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: RHEOLOGY; THERMODYNAMICS; VISCOSITY; POLYSTYRENES

Title: Structural design for a 10-GWh SMES vacuum vessel
Source title: Journal of Pressure Vessel Technology, Transactions of the ASME
Affiliations: Group Q-13, Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM, 87545, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bennett, J.G., Group Q-13, Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM, 87545, United States; Anderson, C.A., Group Q-13, Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM, 87545, United States
Abstract: An approximate solution to the problem of the nonlinear elastic deformation of a periodically point-supported cylindrical shell is obtained. This solution is used to investigate the structural design of the vacuum vesssel for Die large underground SMES concept. Vacuum vessel designs are evaluated by varying such parameters as shell thickness, support spacing, material properties and physical configuration to keep the amount of material used and construction cost to a minimum. © 1978 by ASME.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; STRUCTURAL DESIGN; VACUUM TECHNOLOGY

Title: Operating record and reliability of pressurized water reactors
Affiliations: Kraftwerk Union AG, D-8520 Erlangen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Steinert, C., Kraftwerk Union AG, D-8520 Erlangen, Germany
Abstract: Although it was possible to prevent an imminent moratorium of nuclear energy in the Federal Republic of Germany, a noticeable stagnation has been observed in the domestic market because in addition to the present situation of the whole economy further building permits for nuclear power stations are linked to a solution of the problem concerning the location of the German nuclear waste disposal and storage center. For this reason, the export success achieved by the German reactor industry in Brazil, Iran and Spain was all the more important. One of the reasons for this success is that the operational results of the German plants are generally good.
Index Keywords: OPERATIONS RECORD; Nuclear reactors, Pressurized water; nuclear reactor; radioactive contamination

Title: High temperature lithium/sulphur batteries: a preliminary investigation of a zeolite-sulphur cathode
Affiliations: National Physical Research Laboratory, CSIR, PO Box 395, Pretoria, 0001, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Coetzer, J., National Physical Research Laboratory, CSIR, PO Box 395, Pretoria, 0001, South Africa
Abstract: A reversible lithium/sulphur high temperature cell is described in which the cathode consists of elemental sulphur absorbed in a zeolite 4A matrix. A lithium-aluminium alloy is used for the anode and the electrolyte is a molten ionic salt consisting of a LiI-KI eutectic (m.p. 260°). The cell was operated at 300° and underwent more than 70 continuous charge/discharge cycles (800 h) without significant loss in efficiency. The coulombic efficiency was more than 90% and the energy density 404 Wh/kg (based on the masses of active electrode materials, viz lithium metal and zeolite 4A-sulphur). The cell showed an open circuit voltage of 1.80 V, a short-circuit cd of about 1.1 A/cm2 and a maximum power of about 0.5 W/cm2. The internal resistance was 0.54 Ω (cathode surface area ∼ 3 cm2). © 1978.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Title: Available, usable, and stored radiant energy in relation to marine photosynthesis
Affiliations: Laboratoire de Physique et Chimie Marines, Station Marine de Villefranche-sur-Mer, 06230 Villefranche sur Mer, France
Authors with affiliations: Morel, A., Laboratoire de Physique et Chimie Marines, Station Marine de Villefranche-sur-Mer, 06230 Villefranche sur Mer, France
Abstract: At 32 stations covering a wide variety of phytoplankton biomass, results have been obtained for in situ production, daily irradiation, photosynthetically available radiation (PAR), and spectral composition of submarine radiant energy. PAR is compared to the photosynthetically stored radiant energy (PSR), and a dimensionless quantity, ε{lunate}, describing the efficiency of the energy storage, is calculated. ε{lunate} varies from less than 0.01% to about 0.1% between the surface and the base of the euphotic layer in oligotrophic waters (Sargasso Sea). The corresponding values for productive waters (Mauritanian upwelling area) range between 0.1 and 0.8%. On average, for the whole productive column, about 3% (±1.5%) of the total incident energy (including infra-red) is stored by photosynthesis per unit area of ocean per unit of chlorophyll (1 g Chl-a m-2), despite the variability of biomass (0.003 to 0.3 g Chl-a m-2). The photosynthetically usable radiant energy (PUR), i.e. the part of PAR that can be absorbed by algae, is evaluated. Comparison of PSR and PUR allows the estimation of the quantum yield φ and its variation with depth. The exact calculation of PUR requires the introduction of an effective absorption coefficient, aeff, for the living phytoplankton in its actual environment. The coefficient aeff must take into account both the algal absorption and the spectral composition of the remnant light. Low values obtained for PUR and the consequent excessive values for φ emphasize the necessity for chromatic adaptation, especially for an increase in accessory pigments absorbing green-yellow light. © 1978.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL REACTIONS - Photosynthesis; SOLAR RADIATION; MARINE PHOTOSYNTHESIS; PHYTOPLANKTON; MARINE BIOLOGY

Authors: Hilal M.A., Stone E.L., Van Sciver S.W., McIntosh G.E.
Title: Unit helium requirements for superconductive energy applications in the USA
Affiliations: University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, United States; Cryenco Division, CTI, Denver, CO, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hilal, M.A., University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, United States; Stone, E.L.; Van Sciver, S.W.; McIntosh, G.E., Cryenco Division, CTI, Denver, CO, United States
Abstract: Estimates of the helium requirements for superconductive magnetic energy storage, magnetically confined fusion reactors, superconducting power transmission lines, magnetohydrodynamic units, superconducting motors and generators, and particle accelerators are presented. The approach entails surveying estimates from system studies, then developing simple scaling laws to calculate helium inventories. Helium loss rates are discussed and applied to estimate annual helium makeup. © 1978.
Index Keywords: CRYOGENICS; SUPERCONDUCTING DEVICES

Title: Analytical method of capacitor allocation on distribution primary feeders
Source title: IEEE Transactions on Power Apparatus and Systems
Affiliations: Portland General Electric Company, Portland, Oregon, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bae, Y.G., Portland General Electric Company, Portland, Oregon, United States
Abstract: This paper reports the development of an analytical method to determine the best capacitor locations, reactive compensation level, and yearly loss reductions under a wide range of annual reactive load conditions for use 1n distribution system design. The results show that, not only 1s more than 80 percent yearly loss reduction possible with non-switched capacitor banks, but also optimum reactive-compensation level and maximum yearly loss reduction can be expressed 1n a simple mathematical equation. Copyright © 1978 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: CAPACITORS - Energy Storage; ELECTRIC NETWORKS - Reactive Power; CAPACITOR-BANK ALLOCATION; ELECTRIC POWER DISTRIBUTION

Title: Effects of Calcium, Potassium, and Iron Ions on Degradation of β″-Alumina
Affiliations: Institute of Industrial Science, University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Department of Materials Engineering, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Troy, New York 12181, United States
Authors with affiliations: Yasui, I., Institute of Industrial Science, University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan, Department of Materials Engineering, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Troy, New York 12181, United States
Abstract: The influence of calcium, potassium, and iron impurities in sodium-sulfur cells on β″-alumina electrolytes were studied. Sections of the ceramic were analyzed with the electron microprobe after cyclic electrolysis of the cells. No degradation by iron was detected. The distribution of potassium in the β″-alumina became more uniform as electrolysis proceeded, and the cell impedance increased by factors of two or three. Calcium was the most damaging impurity; even in small concentrations it caused large increases in cell impedance and calcium concentrated in the grain boundaries of the β″-alumina. © 1978, The Electrochemical Society, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: cell; ceramics; cracking; energy storage
Index Keywords: ALUMINA; FUEL CELLS

Title: Reduction in Minority Carrier Storage Effect by Fluorine Ion Implantation Damage
Affiliations: Fundamental Technology Section, Production Engineering Department, IC Division, Nippon Electric Company, Ltd., Nakahara-Ku, Kawasaki, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kanamori, A.R., Fundamental Technology Section, Production Engineering Department, IC Division, Nippon Electric Company, Ltd., Nakahara-Ku, Kawasaki, Japan
Abstract: Damage is produced in p-n diodes by fluorine ion implantation to reduce minority carrier storage effect. The switching time, reverse leakage current, and l-V characteristics were investigated for annealing temperature between 450Â°C and 650Â°C. The accelation energy is 130 keV and doses are 1013-1015/cm2. Annealing causes restoration in switching time, but leakage current increases with annealing temperature rise for doses more than 1 X 1014/cm2. The best diodes indicate 1.5-order reduction in switching time and 10 nA in reverse leakage current. These properties, caused by implantation damage, are retained after long-cycle annealing at 450Â°C and are expected to be stable under practical use. These diodes can be obtained by annealing at 450Â°C and they furnish satisfactory diode performance. Copyright © 1978 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: SEMICONDUCTOR MATERIALS - Ion Implantation; SEMICONDUCTOR DIODES

Title: Mixing fixed-speed pumps to variable flows
Source title: Journal of the Water Pollution Control Federation
Affiliations: M.M. Dillon Ltd, London, Ont., Canada
Authors with affiliations: Goldschmidt, G., M.M. Dillon Ltd, London, Ont., Canada
Abstract: Fixed-speed pumps may be effectively used in wastewater lift stations to match the pumping capacity over a wide range of inflows. Matching the pumping rate to the inflow substantially reduces pump on-off cycling, energy consumtpion, pump wear, shock loading to downstream treatment facilities, and the required storage volume for any number of pumps working side by side is presented and analyzed in detail. The basic equations account for the variation of the pumping capacity with respect to the changing water levels in the collection chamber. The solutions of the basic equations are completely general and allow any number of fixed-speed pumps of any desired capacity and head versus flow characteristics to draw from the collection chamber.The author describes how fixed-speed pumps may be effectively used in wastewater lift stations to match the pumping capacity over a wide range of inflows. Matching the pumping rate to the inflow substantially reduces pump on-off cycling, energy consumption, pump wear, shock loading to downstream treatment facilities, and the required storage volume for any number of pumps working side by side is presented and analyzed in detail. The basic equations account for the variation of the pumping capacity with respect to the changing water levels in the collection chamber.
Index Keywords: Mathematical models; PUMPS - Selection; Wastewater; FLOW PUMPS; Pumping plants; flow measurement; pump; sewage collection; sewage treatment; therapy

Title: The safe management of radioactive wastes. Ontario hydro demonstrates the safe management of radioactive waste, a key factor in gaining public acceptance of nuclear-electric generation
Authors with affiliations: Vivian, G.A.
Abstract: The fissioning of uranium in a nuclear power reactor results in the production of two broad categories of solid radioactive materials: the high-level radioactivity of the irradiated fuel, and the low-to-intermediate radioactivity of miscellaneous reactor wastes. The latter includes the concentrates from various process systems that ensure that only minute amounts of radioactivity are emitted into the environment of the generating station site. For more than ten years, Ontario Hydro has been operating a centralized program for the management of miscellaneous reactor wastes at its Bruce Nuclear Power Development, between Kincardine and Port Elgin. The site facilities include both shallow in-ground and above-ground storage structures tailored to different types of wastes and a radioactive waste volume reduction facility consisting of a radioactive waste incinerator and a mechanical compactor.In the ten years of operating the reactor waste storage facilities there has never been a site or transportation situation which posed a radiological hazard to the public. Radioactivity emissions from the site have been two to three orders of magnitude below the regulatory limits with significant contributors being atomic bomb fallout and natural radioactivity such as potassium 40. Routine monitoring of the bedrock aquifer, which is separated from the storage structures by 5.2 to 10.7 meters of dense glacial till, confirms no radioactivity has reached this water from storage operations as would be expected from analysis of the small amounts of water from the underdrainage system. The unit volume costs of the three facilities described here are significant, $ 1100, $ 8400 and $ 7100 per m3 for trenches, tile holes, and quadricells respectively, but are a very small contributor to the total unit cost of nuclear electric energy. They are directly charged against the station generating the waste. In 1977 they contributed less than 0.1 mills/kWh to the total unit energy cost of 9.27/mills kWh at the Pickering Generating Station. This total unit energy cost approaches one half of that at comparable coal fired units.
Index Keywords: HAZARDOUS MATERIALS - Storage; MATERIALS - Safe Handling; RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS - Management; Nuclear reactors; radioisotope; prevention; radioactive waste; therapy; waste management

Authors: Anderson K.A., Kane S.R., Primbsch J.H., Weitzmann R.H.
Title: X-Ray Spectrometer Experiment Aboard the ISEE-C (Heliocentric) Spacecraft
Affiliations: Space Sciences Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, University of California, Los Alamos, NM 87544, United States
Authors with affiliations: Anderson, K.A., Space Sciences Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States, Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, University of California, Los Alamos, NM 87544, United States; Kane, S.R., Space Sciences Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States, Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, University of California, Los Alamos, NM 87544, United States; Primbsch, J.H., Space Sciences Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States, Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, University of California, Los Alamos, NM 87544, United States; Weitzmann, R.H., Space Sciences Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Abstract: This experiment is designed to provide continuous coverage of solar flare X-ray bursts and transient cosmic gamma-ray bursts. A proportional counter and a scintillation detector together cover the energy range from 5 to 228 keV with good sensitivity, large dynamic range, and high temporal resolution. This experiment provides data storage capability and good absolute timing so that in conjunction with similar experiments on other spacecraft, accurate source locations can be obtained for cosmic gamma-ray bursts. Copyright © 1978 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: SOLAR RADIATION - Instruments; SPECTROMETERS, X-RAY; SPACECRAFT

Authors: Anderson K.A., Lin R.P., Potter D.W., Heetderks H.D.
Title: An Experiment to Measure Interplanetary and Solar Electrons
Affiliations: Space Sciences Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Authors with affiliations: Anderson, K.A., Space Sciences Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Lin, R.P., Space Sciences Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Potter, D.W., Space Sciences Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Heetderks, H.D., Space Sciences Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Abstract: This experiment is designed to study interplanetary and solar electrons in the energy range between solar wind and galactic cosmic rays. Between these two particle populations the energy spectrum, anisotropy, and propagation characteristics of the particles change drastically from bulk plasma to single particle characteristics. These low energy particles are particularly sensitive to the amount of matter traversed in terms of energy loss. Thus they can be used as probes of electron acceleration, storage, and propagation processes in the solar corona and interplanetary medium. In addition, these particles generate both plasma waves and electromagnetic radiation as they pass through the ambient medium. The instrumentation is designed to identify and measure electron fluxes with high energy resolution and high sensitivity from ∼2 keV to ⩾1 MeV. The angular distributions of the electrons will also be obtained. In addition measurements of energetic ions above ∼50 keV will be made. Copyright © 1978 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: COSMIC RAYS - Measurement; SOLAR RADIATION - Measurements; SPACE PROBES - Interplanetary; SPACE RESEARCH

Title: A Heat Pump Driven Optimal Heating System
Affiliations: Diamond Shamrock Chemical Company, Cleveland, OH 44114, United States; Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Toledo, Toledo, OH 43606, United States
Authors with affiliations: Harpster, H.E., Diamond Shamrock Chemical Company, Cleveland, OH 44114, United States; Eltimsahy, A.H., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Toledo, Toledo, OH 43606, United States
Abstract: Optimizing a heat pump driven forced-air domestic heating system utilizing solar/thermal energy storage and off-peak storage from the electric power network is discussed. The system proposed is modeled and simulated on the digital computer. An optimal controller is then developed to maximize comfort and minimize conventional energy consumption. The controller is then simulated with the heating system for the University of Toledo experimental electric/solar house, Toledo, OH, and shown to be truly optimal and able to control the system in a desirable manner. © 1978 IEEE
Index Keywords: ENERGY CONSERVATION; SOLAR ENERGY; HEATING

Title: The formation of high-density z-pinches
Affiliations: Blackett Laboratory, Imperial College, London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Potter, D., Blackett Laboratory, Imperial College, London, United Kingdom
Abstract: Three regimes in the formation of a simple pinch are delineated. For a rapidly rising current, the formation of the pinch by a strong shock is first considered. A slug model is developed which, unlike the snowplough model, describes the radial structure between piston and shock. The final equilibrium pinch is described and radial profiles of density and temperature are obtained. Under the conditions of a strong shock, a weakly compressed pinch is formed in which the pinch radius is related to the wall radius and is independent of the current applied. By programming the current in time, regimes of singular compression and adiabatic compression can be obtained. A much more highly compressed plasma is produced. Such a current profile can readily be produced by a line storage energy source. © 1978 IOP Publishing Ltd.
Index Keywords: PLASMAS

Title: Experimentally Supported Simulation of a Lead Battery as Energy Storage for Electric Vehicles. [EINE EXPERIMENTELL GESTUETZTE SIMULATION DER BLEIBATTERIE ALS ENERGIESPEICHER FUER ELEKTROFAHRZEUGE.]
Authors with affiliations: Heldt, Joachim; Canders, Wolf Ruediger
Abstract: A calculation model for the lead battery is presented which is adapted for the purpose and has experimental backing, and simulates the nonlinear operational behavior during discharge, recovery and, for the first time, during regenerative braking. By the introduction of a load-dependent evaluation of the discharge it is possible to follow the actual state of charge of the battery, and from this to calculate the range which can be achieved by a vehicle with electric storage, on any desired test cycle. The results of calculation are compared with experimental measurements on a VW-E-Transporter.
Index Keywords: STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES; Electric batteries, Secondary

Authors: Rao R.P., Rao D.R., Banerjee H.D.
Title: Studies on the TL and decay of BaS:Cu phosphors
Affiliations: Materials Science Centre Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, 721302, India
Authors with affiliations: Rao, R.P., Materials Science Centre Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, 721302, India; Rao, D.R., Materials Science Centre Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, 721302, India; Banerjee, H.D., Materials Science Centre Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, 721302, India
Abstract: Thermoluminescence (TL) and phosphorescence of BaS:Cu phosphors have been studied in this investigation of exciting at 28°C by low energy electrons, X-rays and UV light. While by UV light only one TL glow peak around 80°C can be observed, by X-ray and electron irradiation additional glow peaks at 187°C, 287°C and 427°C have been produced. The TL output diminishes with the time of storage in darkness. Considering the color of fluorescence, TL emission and the nature of decay (afterglow and TL), the traps involved in this system may be associated with Cu centers located either near S-- ion vacancy or with halogen ions in their neighborhood. © 1978.
Index Keywords: THERMOLUMINESCENCE; PHOSPHORS

Title: HYDROGEN STORAGE AND TRANSMISSION.
Authors with affiliations: Suzuki, Akira
Abstract: Three basic methods for the storage and transmission of hydrogen are discussed. These methods are designed for gaseous hydrogen, liquid hydrogen and metal hydrides. Gaseous storage and transmission have not received much attention because of safety problems associated with high-pressure containers and container weight. Liquid storage and transmission are also plagued by various problems, including those of liquefication energy, boiling off, ortho-para transition etc. The liquid hydrogen storage method holds best promise for future large-scale storage. Recent studies on various hydrides show that these hydrogen absorbing alloys are also promising for energy storage.
Index Keywords: HYDROGEN - Transportation; Hydrogen fuels

Title: The ZnHg excimer: Optical and kinetic properties
Affiliations: Laser Physics Branch, Optical Sciences Division, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States
Authors with affiliations: Eden, J.G., Laser Physics Branch, Optical Sciences Division, Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States
Abstract: The optical and collisional properties of the ZnHg excimer have been examined by optically pumping the Zn (41S0→ 43P1) resonance line in Zn-Hg vapor mixtures. The stimulated emission cross-section determined for ZnHg* (2.3 × 10-19 cm2) and the excimer's low rate of quenching by Hg (5.5 × 10-15 cm3 s-1) make it attractive for future energy-storage laser research. © 1978.
Index Keywords: ZINC COMPOUNDS

Title: New Additives for Heavy Oil Fuel: Gamlenol Regular H. D. and Gamapol S. A. S..
Authors with affiliations: Rouet, Jean; Coron, Andre
Abstract: The crisis created by the divergences over petroleum supply has resulted in a progression towards heavier industrial fuels which tend to have higher asphaltene content and higher viscosity. Asphaltenes are solid particles, insoluble in fuel oils, which burn less easily than liquid hydrocarbons do. These asphaltenes lump together to form agglomerates which, as they decant, settle in the bottom of storage tanks. Their presence makes it impossible to use that part of the fuel oil, and can cause pluggage of the filters. Higher fuel viscosities mean that, in order to achieve good combustion, the fuel has to be heated up to temperatures which some installations are not equipped to accommodate. Under these conditions it is very difficult for small and medium-sized boilers to comply with French legislation on particulate emissions (the French legislation is the strictest so far in Europe). Two new fuel oil additives can prevent asphaltenes from forming into agglomerates and act as catalysts to improve fuel combustion. Use of these additives reduces air pollution and saves energy.
Index Keywords: BOILER FIRING - Oil Fuel; Oil fuel

Authors: Jones S.R., Thompson M.J., Allison J., Ormondroyd R.F.
Title: Relaxation processes in memory and threshold chalcogenide switches
Affiliations: Department of Electronic and Electrical Engineering, The University of Sheffield, Mappin Street, Sheffield, S1 3JD, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Jones, S.R., Department of Electronic and Electrical Engineering, The University of Sheffield, Mappin Street, Sheffield, S1 3JD, United Kingdom; Thompson, M.J., Department of Electronic and Electrical Engineering, The University of Sheffield, Mappin Street, Sheffield, S1 3JD, United Kingdom; Allison, J., Department of Electronic and Electrical Engineering, The University of Sheffield, Mappin Street, Sheffield, S1 3JD, United Kingdom; Ormondroyd, R.F., Department of Electronic and Electrical Engineering, The University of Sheffield, Mappin Street, Sheffield, S1 3JD, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper concerns the relaxation processes that occur during and following switching in amorphous threshold and commercial memory devices. Relaxation with time of the conduction activation energy in the low-field OFF state following switching events, has been measured for a large number of materials. The results can be explained by assuming that the switching operation creates a severe thermal cycling process which influences the localized structure and thus the electronic properties of the glass. © 1978.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE UNITS - Switching; GLASS

Title: Solar Refrigeration for Air Conditioning Installations. [SOLAR-KUEHLUNG IN DER KLIMATECHNIK.]
Authors with affiliations: Loewer, Harold
Abstract: In principle all types of refrigerating machines which can be operated with conventional, thermal or mechanical energy, can also be considered for the operation with solar energy. As the most economical and reliable method, the absorption refrigerating machine offers itself for applications. The special problems of solar cooling will have to be accounted for, viz. , energy storage, type and size of applied collector, and the individual operational method of the particular components of the absorption machine. Economical results can be achieved by combined heat and cooling installations with heat pump arrangement of the absorption machine.
Index Keywords: REFRIGERATING MACHINERY - Absorption; REFRIGERATION - Solar; Air conditioning

Title: RECENT PROGRESS IN BATTERIES - 2.
Source title: Natl Tech Rep Matsushita Electr Ind
Authors with affiliations: Fukuda, Masataro
Abstract: During this decade the demand has increased for maintenance-free batteries of high energy density, high power density, high reliability, and low environmental pollution. In order to meet these demands, many efforts have been made to improve ordinary battery characteristics and to develop new types of batteries. The practical use of the lithium battery has been achieved as a primary battery, and studies of secondary batteries and fuel cells for electric vehicles, storage of electricity and on-site electric power generation are progressing. This report chiefly describes the progress and trends of new types of batteries.
Index Keywords: Electric batteries

Title: Energy conservation options for residential water heaters
Affiliations: Arthur D. Little, Inc., Acorn Park, Cambridge, MA 02140, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wilson Jr., R.P., Arthur D. Little, Inc., Acorn Park, Cambridge, MA 02140, United States
Abstract: Current designs of gas-fired and electric water heaters present a substantial opportunity for energy conservation through reductions in jacket losses, pilot losses and flue-gas losses. A systematic analysis and comparison of alternative energy-conserving designs has been carried out. Promising options for gas-fired water heaters include increased insulation, thermostat setback, forced-draft burners with intermittent ignition and flue closure, and instantaneous (low storage) designs. High efficiency electric water heaters incorporate increased insulation, thermostat setback, solar preheat, and heat pump operation. The evolution and market penetration of these alternative designs, some of which are commercially available at this writing, can reduce the energy usage for residential water heating in the U.S. by approx. 0.3 quads in the near-term, and up to 1.0 quads in the long-term as advanced designs achieve widespread saturation. © 1978.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC APPLIANCES - Energy Conservation; GAS APPLIANCES - Energy Conservation; HEAT INSULATING MATERIALS - Applications; SOLAR ENERGY - Applications; WATER HEATERS

Title: A duplex chemical system for the storage and container transport of heat for district heating
Affiliations: Swiss Fed. Inst. Reactor Res., CH-5303 Wurenlingen, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Taube, M., Swiss Fed. Inst. Reactor Res., CH-5303 Wurenlingen, Switzerland
Abstract: A system of two-component chemical agents is proposed for transforming heat with T approximately equals 450 plus or minus 50 K into chemical energy, as a means of storage and transportation. The system is called SALAMO (for Salt/Ammonia), and the following boundary conditions have been arbitrarily chosen.A system of 2 component chemical agents is proposed for transforming heat with T ≃ 450 ± 50 K into chemical energy, as a means of storage and transportation. The system is called Salamo (for Salt/Ammonia), and the following boundary conditions have been arbitrarily chosen: The primary source of heat is a light water reactor (LWR), with temperatures of T(max)=530 K and T(optim)=400±20 K. The heat energy bounded in chemical form is transported in railway wagons, in pressureless containers, at a near-ambient temperature.
Index Keywords: HEATING - District; Nuclear reactors, Water cooled; HEAT STORAGE; Nuclear power plants; radioisotope; methodology; nuclear reactor; thermogenesis

Title: Diffusion parameters of hot holes created by ionizing radiation in NaCl(Ag)
Affiliations: Institute of Physics, Academy of Sciences of the Estonian Ssr, Tartu
Authors with affiliations: Kadchenko, V.N., Institute of Physics, Academy of Sciences of the Estonian Ssr, Tartu; Elango, M., Institute of Physics, Academy of Sciences of the Estonian Ssr, Tartu
Abstract: Using the dependence of the thermoluminescence light sum storage efficiency in NaCl(Ag) on the energy of exciting ultrasoft X‐rays (180 to 240 eV) at 80 K the phenomenological diffusion parameters of hot holes in NaCl are estimated. The next averaged values are obtained: diffusion length LOP ≈ 720 Å, free mean path lp ≈ 180 Å, relaxation time τrp ≈ 5 × 10−14 s, thermalization time τOP ≈ 2.3 × 10−12 s, diffusion coefficient Dp ≈ 20 cm2s−1, mobility μp ≈ 40 cm2 V−1 s−1, capture cross section on Ag+ centres σAp ≈ 1.5 × 10−15 cm2. Copyright © 1978 WILEY‐VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA
Index Keywords: SODIUM CHLORIDE

Authors: Ito T., Sung S.K., Fukazawa T.
Title: Change of Acto-Heavy Meromyosin ATPase of Rabbit Skeletal Muscle during Postmortem Storage
Source title: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
Affiliations: Laboratory of Chemistry and Technology of Animal Products, Faculty of Agriculture, Kyushu University, Fukuoka 812, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ito, T., Laboratory of Chemistry and Technology of Animal Products, Faculty of Agriculture, Kyushu University, Fukuoka 812, Japan; Sung, S.K., Laboratory of Chemistry and Technology of Animal Products, Faculty of Agriculture, Kyushu University, Fukuoka 812, Japan; Fukazawa, T., Laboratory of Chemistry and Technology of Animal Products, Faculty of Agriculture, Kyushu University, Fukuoka 812, Japan
Abstract: Actin-activated heavy meromyosin (HMM) ATPase of at time of death and postmortem muscles has been investigated. The maximum velocity of acto-HMM ATPase was the highest at time of death and decreased with time in postmortem muscles. The affinity of actin for myosin was the greatest in 168-h postmortem muscle and least in at time of death muscle. The study of the cross-reaction between actin and HMM suggests that the properties of both actin and myosin are altered during postmortem storage of muscles. The apparent activation energy of myosin ATPase was decreased with postmortem time, while the polymerization rate of actin was increased. © 1978, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: adenosine triphosphatase; myosin subfragment; animal; article; cadaver; rabbit; tissue preservation; Adenosinetriphosphatase; Animal; Myosin Subfragments; Postmortem Changes; Rabbits; Tissue Preservation

Title: Optimal control of flywheel hybrid transmissions
Source title: Journal of Dynamic Systems, Measurement and Control, Transactions of the ASME
Affiliations: Department of Aerospace and Mechanical Sciences, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ, United States; USAF Weapons Laboratory, Kirtland AFB, Albuquerque, NM, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sweet, L.M., Department of Aerospace and Mechanical Sciences, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ, United States, USAF Weapons Laboratory, Kirtland AFB, Albuquerque, NM, United States; Anhalt, D.A., Department of Aerospace and Mechanical Sciences, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ, United States, USAF Weapons Laboratory, Kirtland AFB, Albuquerque, NM, United States
Abstract: Selection of variable transmission ratio in a vehicle with a flywheel energy storage element to maximize the kinetic energy transfer for specified vehicle accelerations is formulated as an optimal control problem. Models for single and parallel power-flow path configurations are presented as generic hybrid propulsion system types. For both systems variation of the ratio of the continuously variable transmission results in inherently nonlinear control, with velocity trajectories found by the solution of twopoint boundary value problems. For the single power-flow path system a closed loop controller is synthesized which tracks acceleration command. For the parallel path system, which is representative of conventional power split transmissions, the open loop control yields useful information, indicating tradeoffs between system energy recovery efficiency and component design parameters. Maximum energy recovery during regenerative braking is achieved by minimizing power losses to vehicle drag and transmission elements. Planetary gear geometry is shown to have the strongest influence on efficiency, maximum transmission component loading, and CVT ratio range. © 1978 ASME.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC TRACTION - Flywheel Propulsion; POWER TRANSMISSION - Mathematical Models; FLYWHEELS

Title: Weld Joints Made Between Type AlMgSi0. 5 Alloy and Type X5CrNi18 9 Alloy for the Vacuum System of a High Energy Catalizer. [SCHWEISSVERBINDUNGEN ZWISCHEN AlMgSiO, 5 UND X5CrNi 18 9 FUER DAS VAKUUMSYSTEM VON HOCHENERGIEBESCHLEUNIGERN.]
Authors with affiliations: Hartwig, Heinrich; Kouptsidis, Johannes
Abstract: The manufacturing problems that arise during the welding of joints between Type AlMgSi0. 5 aluminium alloy and Type X 5 CrNi 18 9 chromium nickel steel for the vacuum system of an electron storage ring are discussed. Of the jointing processes investigated tungsten inert gas welding and friction welding proved to be the most effective whereas explosion welding and shield gas brazing proved to be unsatisfactory from the point of view of fabrication largely due to the high costs involved.
Index Keywords: Welding

Authors: Jones II G., Reinhardt T.E., Bergmark W.R.
Title: Photon energy storage in organic materials- The case of linked anthracenes
Affiliations: Departments of Chemistry, Boston University, Boston, MA 02215, U.S.A. and Ithaca College, Ithaca, NY 14850, U.S.A.
Authors with affiliations: Jones II, G., Departments of Chemistry, Boston University, Boston, MA 02215, U.S.A. and Ithaca College, Ithaca, NY 14850, U.S.A.; Reinhardt, T.E., Departments of Chemistry, Boston University, Boston, MA 02215, U.S.A. and Ithaca College, Ithaca, NY 14850, U.S.A.; Bergmark, W.R., Departments of Chemistry, Boston University, Boston, MA 02215, U.S.A. and Ithaca College, Ithaca, NY 14850, U.S.A.
Abstract: Criteria for the photochemical conversion of solar energy are reviewed in terms of utilization of photoactive organic materials. Endoergic valence isomerizations which may be driven by visible light are proposed for study. These isomerizations store electronic excitation energy as chemical potential energy. Products of the proposed photoreactions are kinetically stable for energy storage over controllable periods. Stored energy is retrieved by thermal or catalytic recycling to the original photoactive substance. Such organic materials are potentially useful as additives to working fluids of conventional solar-thermal conversion units. Photon energy storage is illustrated in several examples which utilize 300-500 nm radiation for isomerizations with storage capacities of about 400 J/g (about 100 cal/g). New data including quantum efficiencies, storage capacities and conditions for recycling are presented for a series of linked anthracenes. A photocalorimeter capable of direct measurement of storage enthalpies is described. The economic and physical requirements of a photochemical storage material are outlined, and several systems for the conversion of solar energy on an appropriate scale are suggested. © 1978.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL REACTIONS - Reaction Kinetics; PHOTONS; ENERGY CONVERSION; PHOTOCHEMISTRY; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: PVSS-A photovoltaic system simulation program
Affiliations: Sandia Laboratories, Division 2113, Albuquerque, NM 87115, United States
Authors with affiliations: Goldstein, L.H., Sandia Laboratories, Division 2113, Albuquerque, NM 87115, United States; Case, G.R., Sandia Laboratories, Division 2113, Albuquerque, NM 87115, United States
Abstract: A computer program has been developed to accurately simulate the performance of a photovoltaic system. Sixteen configurations can be simulated, including systems with combinations of battery storage, inverters, d.c.-voltage regulators and maximum power point trackers. Models are presented for system components, and sample runs illustrating various aspects of program performance are described. © 1978.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SIMULATION; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PHOTOVOLTAIC EFFECTS; SOLAR ENERGY; ENERGY RESOURCES

Title: Thermochemical energy transport costs for a distributed solar power plant
Affiliations: Department of Engineering Physics, Research School of Physical Sciences, The Australian National University, Canberra, A.C.T. 2600, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Williams, O.M., Department of Engineering Physics, Research School of Physical Sciences, The Australian National University, Canberra, A.C.T. 2600, Australia
Abstract: Thermochemical energy transport costs are calculated for a solar thermal power plant based on a distributed network of para-boloidal collectors. The optimum pipe size distribution within the fluid transport network has been generated subject to requirements of minimum cost and pressure drop equality across parallel conduction paths. The optimization procedure includes the installed capital cost of pipework together with the effective cost of pumping power. An analytical expression for the overall thermochemical energy transport cost has been derived, based on a Black and Veatch pipe cost survey in which conventional pipelaying technology is assumed. Thermochemical energy transport costs are calculated for systems based on ammonia, methanol, water-methane and sulphur trioxide. The derived costs are dominated by the pipe installation component whereas other parameters such as choice of system, operating pressure, reaction enthalpy and degree of reaction are of secondary importance. Larger collectors favour a lower installed cost per unit energy while increases in network area and hence in plant output capacity lead to slow increases in unit cost. Typical thermochemical energy transport costs for a solar thermal power plant operating only during sunlight hours and based on large collectors are estimated at $20 kWt-1 (1974 U.S. dollars).
