Title: Measurements of the behaviour of adsorbent energy storage beds
Affiliations: Department of Civil and Systems Engineering, James Cook University of North Queensland, Townsville, QLD, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Pryor, T.L., Department of Civil and Systems Engineering, James Cook University of North Queensland, Townsville, QLD, Australia; Close, D.J., Department of Civil and Systems Engineering, James Cook University of North Queensland, Townsville, QLD, Australia
Abstract: This paper presents data from measurements made on an adsorbent energy storage bed. Comparisons between air outlet states predicted by a numerical model with constant system properties and the data show good agreement when the system is operated in a charge-discharge mode similar to the situation in a solar system. However, the agreement is not so satisfactory for the classical single blow case, and the discrepancy is attributed to the assumption of constant system properties. The long term storage ability of these beds is demonstrated by first charging the test bed, allowing it to cool to around 21°C and then extracting energy by admitting air to the bed at temperatures between 25 and 30°C. © 1978.
Index Keywords: MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SOLAR ENERGY; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: Wind energy statistics for large arrays of wind turbines (New England and Central U.S. Regions)
Affiliations: School of Aerospace Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA 30332, United States
Authors with affiliations: Justus, C.G., School of Aerospace Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA 30332, United States
Abstract: The performance characteristics have been simulated for large dispersed arrays of 500-1500 kW wind turbines producing power and feeding it directly into the New England or Central U.S. utility distribution grids. These studies, based on design power performance curves, indicate that in good wind environments the 500 kW generators can average (on an annual basis) up to 240 kW mean power output, and the 1500 kW generators can average up to 350 kW mean power output. Higher mean power output (averaging up to 470 kW) is indicated, however from a hypothetical 1125 kW rated power unit designed to operate at wind speeds near those observed throughout the study area, rather than the higher design operating wind speed of the 1500 kW unit. The beneficial effect of operating large disperse arrays of wind turbines is that available power output can be increased-if winds are not blowing over one part of the array, chances are they will over some other part of the array. These studies indicate that wind power availability levels of 200 kW per 1125 kW generator were 77-93 per cent, depending on season. Reasonably steady high wind power in winter and high afternoon peak wind power in summer (corresponding to peak air conditioning load) means that significant peak load displacement can be achieved without the use of storage. © 1978.
Index Keywords: ENERGY RESOURCES; TURBOMACHINERY; WIND TURBINES; WIND POWER

Authors: Furuhama S., Hiruma M., Enomoto Y.
Title: Development of a liquid hydrogen car
Affiliations: Musashi Institute of Technology, Setagaya-ku, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Furuhama, S., Musashi Institute of Technology, Setagaya-ku, Tokyo, Japan; Hiruma, M., Musashi Institute of Technology, Setagaya-ku, Tokyo, Japan; Enomoto, Y., Musashi Institute of Technology, Setagaya-ku, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Due to stricter emission control standards and the higher cost of fossil fuels, hydrogen is considered to be of great promise as a future automotive fuel. However, the problem of on-board storage has yet to be solved. At present, storage of the hydrogen as a liquid is the only method in practice. In order to participate in the SEED Rally held in the U.S.A. in 1975, a Datsun B-210 passenger car with a 1.4 liter engine was converted to a hydrogen fueled car using the liquid storage method. This was accomplished within the short space of 4 months. Since the car had to travel at least 650 km (400 miles) between fuelings, it was equipped with a tank which could contain 230 l (61 gal) of liquid hydrogen at 5 atm. gage (71 psig). Because cooler hydrogen gas induces better engine performance, the fuel line from the rear tank to the front engine was a vacuum insulated pipe. Fuel was injected intermittently into the intake port by a mechanical valve. This car successfully completed the Rally, 2800 km (1730 miles), and proved that the liquid hydrogen car has a bright future with regard to energy economy, performance, emissions, and safety. © 1978.
Index Keywords: AUTOMOBILE ENGINES - Design; AUTOMOBILES - Fuel Tanks; AUTOMOTIVE FUELS - Storage; HYDROGEN FUELS

Authors: Valette P., Valette L., Siebker M., Leclercq J.
Title: Analysis of a delphi study on hydrogen
Affiliations: S.C.I.E.N.C.E. sprl, Brussels, Belgium S.C.I.E.N.C.E.: Société de Consultants Indépendants et Neutres de la Communauté Europénne. Av. de Tervueren 98-1040 Brussels.
Authors with affiliations: Valette, P., S.C.I.E.N.C.E. sprl, Brussels, Belgium S.C.I.E.N.C.E.: Société de Consultants Indépendants et Neutres de la Communauté Europénne. Av. de Tervueren 98-1040 Brussels.; Valette, L., S.C.I.E.N.C.E. sprl, Brussels, Belgium S.C.I.E.N.C.E.: Société de Consultants Indépendants et Neutres de la Communauté Europénne. Av. de Tervueren 98-1040 Brussels.; Siebker, M., S.C.I.E.N.C.E. sprl, Brussels, Belgium S.C.I.E.N.C.E.: Société de Consultants Indépendants et Neutres de la Communauté Europénne. Av. de Tervueren 98-1040 Brussels.; Leclercq, J., S.C.I.E.N.C.E. sprl, Brussels, Belgium S.C.I.E.N.C.E.: Société de Consultants Indépendants et Neutres de la Communauté Europénne. Av. de Tervueren 98-1040 Brussels.
Abstract: Eighty-six experts of thirteen countries have participated in a Delphi study started in July 1974 and terminated in March 1975. This study has found a consensus on many different technical and economical features and on the consumption of hydrogen in 1985 and 2000. Most of these features have been investigated in a comprehensive forecasting effort on a world-wide basis. The study emphasized three specific areas production, transportation and consumption. Production Relative importance of different primary energy sources for hydrogen production in 1985 and 2000. Relative importance of the various hydrogen production processes in 1985 and 2000. Production costs efficiency of the different production processes. Transportation and storage Relative importance of the different techniques for large scale hydrogen transportation and storage. Hydrogen storage in air, sea and ground vehicles. Consumption Share of hydrogen in the total energy market in 1985 and 2000 and relative importance in different economical sectors Permissible overcost due to environmental advantages. © 1978.
Index Keywords: HYDROGEN - Applications; HYDROGEN FUELS

Title: Spool motors-compact storage of a stretched elastic medium
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, The University of Western Ontario, London, Ont. N6A 5B9, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Dewdney, A.K., Department of Computer Science, The University of Western Ontario, London, Ont. N6A 5B9, Canada
Abstract: A class of mechanical energy storage devices called Spool Motors, is described and analysed. Such motors consist of two parallel spools linked by gears or a belt. An elastic medium, wound spirally on one spool, is taken up by the second spool and, due either to size differential or gear differential, becomes stretched in the process. The energy put into the motors in thus winding the elastic medium onto the second spool is available when the process is reversed. Since the medium is wound and since stress, rather than strain, is used to store energy, such motors can be much shorter than linear devices like helical springs and lighter than coil spring motors. © 1978.
Index Keywords: ELASTIC MATERIALS; MECHANICAL ENERGY STORAGE; SPOOL MOTORS; MECHANICAL DRIVE

Authors: Gray H.R., Nelson H.G., Johnson R.E., McPherson W.B., Howard F.S., Swisher J.H.
Title: Potential structural material problems in a hydrogen energy system
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, OH, United States; NASA Ames Research Center, Moffett Field, CA, United States; NASA Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center, Houston, TX, United States; NASA George C. Marshall Space Flight Center, AL, United States; NASA John F. Kennedy Space Center, Kennedy Space Center, FL, United States; ERDA, Washington, DC, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gray, H.R., NASA Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, OH, United States; Nelson, H.G., NASA Ames Research Center, Moffett Field, CA, United States; Johnson, R.E., NASA Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center, Houston, TX, United States; McPherson, W.B., NASA George C. Marshall Space Flight Center, AL, United States; Howard, F.S., NASA John F. Kennedy Space Center, Kennedy Space Center, FL, United States; Swisher, J.H., ERDA, Washington, DC, United States
Abstract: Potential structural material problems that may be encountered in the three components of a hydrogen energy system-production, transmission/storage, and utilization-have been identified. Hydrogen embrittlement, corrosion, oxidation, and erosion may occur during the production of hydrogen. Hydrogen embrittlement is of major concern during both transmission and utilization of hydrogen. Specific materials research and development programs necessary to support a hydrogen energy system are described. An awareness of probable shortages of strategic materials has been maintained in these suggested programs. © 1978.
Index Keywords: METALS AND ALLOYS - Embrittlement; HYDROGEN EMBRITTLEMENT; HYDROGEN FUELS

Title: A hydrogen-powered mass transit system
Affiliations: Billings Energy Corporation, Provo, UT 84601, United States
Authors with affiliations: Billings, R.E., Billings Energy Corporation, Provo, UT 84601, United States
Abstract: Hydrogen's application to mass transit systems is considered. A 21-passenger bus is converted to hydrogen using a Dodge engine which has been modified for high compression operation. Backfiring and nitric oxide pollution formation are controlled by a water injection technique. Hydrogen fuel storage for the experimental prototype is accomplished by two metal hydride containers using an iron-titanium alloy. Data are presented regarding equipment conversion and design, energy resource utilization, economics, and safety. © 1978.
Index Keywords: AUTOMOTIVE FUELS; MOTOR BUSES - Fuel Economy; MASS TRANSIT SYSTEMS; HYDROGEN FUELS

Authors: Ward D.S., Löf G.O.G., Uesaki T.
Title: Cooling subsystem design in CSU solar house III
Affiliations: Solar Energy Applications Laboratory, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, CO 80523, United States; Yazaki Parts Company, Umeda, 390 Kosai-shi, Shizuoka-ken, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ward, D.S., Solar Energy Applications Laboratory, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, CO 80523, United States; Löf, G.O.G., Solar Energy Applications Laboratory, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, CO 80523, United States; Uesaki, T., Yazaki Parts Company, Umeda, 390 Kosai-shi, Shizuoka-ken, Japan
Abstract: The use of cool storage in conjunction with residential lithium bromide absorption chillers allows for improved operating conditions of the cooling subsystem. Significant performance degradation in the absorption cooling capacity is evident whenever the chiller cycles on and off during periods of low cooling demand. The capability of providing storage for the chiller out-put prevents short-term cycling of the absorption machine and significantly improves the seasonal average coefficient of performance of the cooling system. Cool storage can also be utilized to allow for a lower cooling capacity of the absorption unit (lower tonnage), without decreasing the ability of the subsystem to meet the cooling demands of the building. The size of cool storage can, in fact, be optimized by evaluating the ability of the cool storage component to minimize cycling of the absorption machine and in meeting the cooling demands on a smaller tonnage chiller. © 1978.
Index Keywords: SOLAR ENERGY; COOLING SUBSYSTEM DESIGN; SOLAR HOUSES; AIR CONDITIONING

Title: Comparisons of deep well and insulated shallow earth storage of solar heat
Affiliations: Department of Civil Engineering, University of Delaware, Newark, DE 19711, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nicholls, R.L., Department of Civil Engineering, University of Delaware, Newark, DE 19711, United States
Abstract: Four techniques for storing solar heat in earth are described and their costs are compared by a hypothetical example. They include heat storage by: (a) deep well; (b) deep well with a storage membrane; (c) insulated shallow earth heat exchange bed; and (d) insulated shallow earth tube exchanger. The cost comparison obtains optimal design parameters for each storage method and optimal surface area for an attached solar collector. Heat loss equations for insulated shallow earth storage are obtained by electrolytic tank models. Heat loss for deep well storage is derived by superposition of radial flow of water and diffusion of heat. © 1978.
Index Keywords: HEATING - Solar; SOLAR ENERGY; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: Measurement of the effect of write-erase cycling on noise in mnos memory transistors
Affiliations: Laboratoire Physique des Composants à Semiconducteurs, ERA CNRS 659, E.N.S.E.R., 38031 Grenoble-Cadex, France
Authors with affiliations: Gentll, P., Laboratoire Physique des Composants à Semiconducteurs, ERA CNRS 659, E.N.S.E.R., 38031 Grenoble-Cadex, France; Chausse, S., Laboratoire Physique des Composants à Semiconducteurs, ERA CNRS 659, E.N.S.E.R., 38031 Grenoble-Cadex, France
Abstract: p-channel MNOS memory transistors with 25-Å oxide, 550-Å nitride are investigated. Changes in memory characteristics such as high-conductivity and low-conductivity threshold voltages are examined as a function of the number of write-erase cycles taking the amplitude and the duration of the pulses as parameters, Simultareous measurements of the channel carrier mobility and low-fiequency noise spectrum give new information. Changes in noise properties after cycling depend on the amplitude and duration of the write-erase pulses. Beyond about 106 write-erase cycles the memory window decays, the channel carrier mobility drops, while the noise exhibits a 1/f2 spectrum in the lowest frequency region. Experimental results are interpreted by the formation, during cycling, of a high density of hole traps distributed in energy and located inside the insulators near the oxide-nitride interface. Copyright © 1978 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, SEMICONDUCTORS; TRANSISTORS - Noise; SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES, MIS; computer analysis; computer memory; mos semiconductor

Title: Interface states and memory decay in mnos capacitors
Affiliations: Philips Laboratories, Briarcliff Manor, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Arnold, E., Philips Laboratories, Briarcliff Manor, NY, United States; Murau, P.C., Philips Laboratories, Briarcliff Manor, NY, United States
Abstract: A method for measuring the density and energy distribution of interface states at the silicon-silicon dioxide interface in MNOS capacitors is described. Application of this method to capacitors fabricated on n-type substrates obtains a logarithmic dependence of the decay rate for stored holes on the interface state density generated during write-erase cycling. The slope of this relationship is strongly dependent on sample preparation. No dependence of the decay rate of electrons on interface state density was observed. Copyright © 1978 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: CAPACITORS; DATA STORAGE, SEMICONDUCTOR; SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES, MIS; computer analysis; computer memory; mos semiconductor

Title: Closed loop chemical systems for energy storage and transmission (chemical heat pipe).
Authors with affiliations: Vakil, H.B.; Flock, J.W.
Abstract: This work documents the analysis of closed loop chemical systems for energy storage and transmission, commonly referred to as the Chemical Heat Pipe (CHP). The concept has been expanded in this work beyond the original scope of heat transmission to provide district heating, as proposed by the West Germans, to uses such as high temperature process steam delivery, distributed peak generation of electricity, and co-generation of electricity and steam. A market analysis shows that substitution for more than 1 million barrels per oil equivalent of prime fossil fuels could be accomplished by the use of this concept. Among the various chemical reactions systems and sources investigated, the two best systems were determined to be the high temperature methane/steam reforming reaction (HTCHP) coupled to a Very High Temperature Gas Cooled Reactor (VHTR) and the lower temperature, cyclohexane dehydrogenation reaction (LTCHP) coupled to existing sources such as coal or light water reactors. Solar and other developing technologies can best be coupled to the LTCHP. (Microfiche)

Authors: Ashbury J., Caruso J., Giese R., Mueller R., Akridge L., Heitner K., Molando A., Moritz P.
Title: Assessment of energy storage technologies and systems. Phase 2: heat pump and solar energy applications.
Authors with affiliations: Ashbury, J.; Caruso, J.; Giese, R.; Mueller, R.; Akridge, L.; Heitner, K.; Molando, A.; Moritz, P.
Abstract: This report describes an analysis of the cost-effectiveness of thermal energy storage (TES) systems in heat pump, solar energy, and competing-system applications. The energy storage technologies evaluated interface with conventional electricity utility supply systems. In winter-peaking service areas, storage and bivalent heat pump and resistance heating technologies were found to offer substantial savings relative to conventional heat pump and direct resistance heating systems. In summer-peaking service areas, a hybrid heat pump-diurnal ice storage system is the most efficient technology for year-round space conditioning. The TES commercialization program recommended here includes: design and implementation of economically efficient electric rates, field demonstrations to establish technical and economic viability of TES systems in U.S. markets, appliance performance-safety certification, and improved TES performance through development of advanced TES concepts. Development of phase change material (PCM) storage appears to hold substantial promise for reducing the cost of residential heating and cooling. Accordingly, a strong research effort to develop and validate PCM storage is recommended. (A)(Microfiche)

Title: Energy from wind - old idea with new potential.
Issue: 7 , Jul. 1978 (Abstract of paper presented at the Circum-Pacific Energy and Mineral Resources Conf., J
Authors with affiliations: Dubey, M.
Abstract: Wind energy is a significant alternative resource for generating electricity, heat or hydrogen fuel. If exploited to its full potential in the United States, wind can provide almost 19% of the electrical energy demand forecast for the year 1995. That is equivalent to conserving 2.1 billion bbl of oil. Further, wind-energy conversion to electricity is nonpolluting, environmentally inert, and nonhazardrous, and wind-energy is continually replenished. The most likely opportunity for wide-scale exploitation is in the generation of electricity by utilities, as a supplement to fossil steam and hydroelectric power plants. Storage for satisfying peak demand or for periods without wind is provided by the unburned fuel or retained water conserved whenever the wind turbines operate. Thus, the economic tradeoff between the cost of fuel necessary to produce a kilowatt hour of energy and the cost of owning and operating a wind-turbine generater allocated per kilowatt determines whether or not wind energy is competitive. In many regions of the United States and the world, fuel costs already have escalated beyond the equivalent energy costs of wind, and if they should continue to rise as they have since 1973, it is likely to make acceptance of wind energy or other alternative energy sources more imperative. In the Circum-Pacific community, wind turbines can be used effectively to supplement diesel, or gas-turbine power plants to conserve fuel, or to operate synergetically with hydroelectric facilities as a totally independent self-sufficient energy supply. Recent studies of wind data show an abundance of good wind sites. The technology for developing large wind turbines, with rotor diameters of 80 m or more, is well in hand. What is needed to trigger the availability of commercial systems, is the materializaton of market demand and commitment from public and private utilities, communities, and goverment agencies to acquire these systems. (A)

Authors: Potter I.C., Percy L.R., Youson J.H.
Title: A Proposal for the Adaptive Significance of the Development of the Lamprey Fat Column
Affiliations: School of Environmental and Life Sciences, Murdoch University, Western Australia, 6153, Australia; Department of Zoology, University of Newcastle-Upon-Tyne, Newcastle-Upon-Tyne, NE17 RU, United Kingdom; Department of Zoology, Scarborough College, University of Toronto, West Hill, Ontario, M1C 1A4, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Potter, I.C., School of Environmental and Life Sciences, Murdoch University, Western Australia, 6153, Australia, Department of Zoology, University of Newcastle-Upon-Tyne, Newcastle-Upon-Tyne, NE17 RU, United Kingdom, Department of Zoology, Scarborough College, University of Toronto, West Hill, Ontario, M1C 1A4, Canada; Percy, L.R., School of Environmental and Life Sciences, Murdoch University, Western Australia, 6153, Australia, Department of Zoology, University of Newcastle-Upon-Tyne, Newcastle-Upon-Tyne, NE17 RU, United Kingdom, Department of Zoology, Scarborough College, University of Toronto, West Hill, Ontario, M1C 1A4, Canada; Youson, J.H., School of Environmental and Life Sciences, Murdoch University, Western Australia, 6153, Australia, Department of Zoology, University of Newcastle-Upon-Tyne, Newcastle-Upon-Tyne, NE17 RU, United Kingdom, Department of Zoology, Scarborough College, University of Toronto, West Hill, Ontario, M1C 1A4, Canada
Abstract: Abstract Lampreys differ from the other extant agnathan group, the hagfishes, in possessing a fat column above the nerve cord. It is suggested that this region of fat is just one of many sites of lipid storage that have been developed to provide energy reserves for the lengthy non‐trophic periods found during the life cycle of lampreys. The incorporation of this fat within an extension of the nerve cord sheath suggests that it could act as a protective dorsal cushion for the nerve cord, which would otherwise be more exposed due to the absence of complete vertebral arches. The development of the fat column as the principal blood cell forming structure in the adult can apparently be related to certain changes that take place during metamorphosis, particularly in the circulatory system. 1978 The Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences

Authors: Bontius G.H., Manders A.H.E., Th. Stoop
Title: Implications of large scalg introduction of power from large wind energy conversion systems into the existing electric power supply system in the Netherlands.
Source title: IN: SECOND INT. SYMP. ON WIND ENERGY SYSTEMS, (AMSTERDAM, THE NETHERLANDS: OCT. 3-6, 1978)
Volume: 1 , Cranfield, U.K., BHRA Fluid Engng., 1978, Paper G3
Authors with affiliations: Bontius, G.H.; Manders, A.H.E.; Th. Stoop
Abstract: The National Program on Wind Energy in the Netherlands includes a basic study of the consequences for the national electric power supply system if a large portion of the electric energy produced were derived from large wind energy conversion systems (WECS). Use of the existing power system has the advantage of avoiding storage systems in one or other form. From the present day estimates which can be given of the annual average amount of energy produced by a wind turbine, it appears that compared to conventional production units a considerable amount of rated power must be installed in order to produce a given amount of energy because of the low utilisation factor of the wind-turbine. An energy production of 10-15% of the total electricity production as an annual average, implies that at high wind speeds the power produced is in the same order of magnitude as that of the actual load of the system. Even in a densely populated country with a dense electricity infrastructure the existing medium voltage distribution grid (10-20 kV) will not be sufficient to absorb the power from arrays or parks of wind turbines. With help of examples it can be shown that only transmission networks and substations with voltages from 50 kV upwards can be used. General criteria are discussed for the conversion of the mechanical power into electric power with suitable characteristics. Some economic considerations are given. Introduction of wind turbines into the existing system does not lead to savings with regard to the necessary power to be installed in the form of conventional plant. (A)

Title: Thermal inactivation of hepatitis B surface antigen
Affiliations: Inst. Hyg., Univ. Genoa, Italy
Authors with affiliations: De Flora, S., Inst. Hyg., Univ. Genoa, Italy
Abstract: Thermal inactivation of hepatitis B surface antigen (HB(s) Ag) was investigated under various experimental conditions by means of a quantitative radioimmunoassay. No decrease of HB(s) Ag immunologic reactivity could be detected at -80°C, up to 24 months of storage, whereas at -20 and 4°C survival of serum HB(s) Ag after 6 months was 71.4 and 48.7%, respectively. Freezing and thawing of serum affected the activity of the antigen slightly (60.6% after 26 cycles in 6 months). The loss of activity of purified HB(s) Ag in phosphate buffer at 20, 37, 44, 56, 70, and 98°C was linear with respect to time, and the half-life of inactivation ranged from 6 min at 98°C to 52 days, 18 hr, and 12 min at 20°C. Over this range of temperature, the velocity constants for inactivation (k) showed a linear relationship with the reciprocal of absolute temperature, and the energy (ΔH) and the entropy (ΔS) of activation of the process were 23.382 kcal/mole and -8.468 cal/mole/deg, respectively. No residual activity was detected after 15 min at 121°C (1 Atm). At neutral pH an increasing protective effect was afforded by deionized water, 0.15 M NaCl, 0.067 phosphate mixture, 0.1 M citric acid-0.2 M sodium phosphate dibasic buffer and human serum. Heat-stability of HB(s) Ag was significantly reduced by modifying the pH of the medium whereas addition of 1 M MgCl2 had a considerable stabilizing effect. Survival of HB(s) Ag was affected by contamination with a variety of microbial stains. Traces of the antigen dried on a glass surface could be recovered after 3 and 4 weeks of exposure at room temperature (21 ± 2°C) to ambient air. Subtypes adw and ayw were destroyed to the same extent by heat exposure, and no selective inactivation of a, d, and y subdeterminants was observed.
Index Keywords: hepatitis b surface antigen; hepatitis b virus; in vitro study; methodology; microorganism; theoretical study; virus inactivation; Heat; Hepatitis B Surface Antigens

Title: Evaluation of the operating internal resistance, inductance, and capacitance of intact damped sine wave defibrillators
Affiliations: Biomed. Engin. Cent., Purdue Univ., West Lafayette, Ind. 47907, United States
Authors with affiliations: Babbs, C.F., Biomed. Engin. Cent., Purdue Univ., West Lafayette, Ind. 47907, United States; Whistler, S.J., Biomed. Engin. Cent., Purdue Univ., West Lafayette, Ind. 47907, United States
Abstract: A method is developed for determining actual values of circuit elements in a damped sine wave (Lown waveform) defibrillator solely from measurements of the output, using two or more power resistors and a storage oscilloscope. If a defibrillator containing capacitance C, inductance L, and internal resistance Ri, is discharged into increasing 5- to 100-ohm resistive loads R, it is shown for underdamped output waveforms that ȧ = Ri/2L + R/2L and ċ = CRi + CR, where ȧ = π/[t2tan(πt1/t2)], ċ = 2ȧ/[ȧ2+(π/t2)2], t1 = time from onset to peak, and t2 = time from onset to first zero crossing of the output waveform on the oscilloscope trace. Linear plots of ȧ vs R are constructed for seven defibrillators, and values of Ri and L computed as intercept/slope and 1/(2 slope) respectively. C is given by the slope of a linear plot of ċ vs R. Delivered energy is accurately predicted as stored energy x R/(Ri + R).A method is developed for determining actual values of circuit elements in a damped sine wave (Lown waveform) defibrillator solely from measurements of the output, using two or more power resistors and a storage oscilloscope. The technique permits investigators to characterize damped sine wave defibrillators used in experimental studies. All too often, reports of defibrillation studies do not allow the reader to reconstruct the waveform of the stimulus applied to experimental subjects. Since there is no agreement at present as to the essential property of the electrical stimulus that causes defibrillation, the lack of exact descriptions of the voltage and current waveforms employed in experimental studies seriously compromises the future utility and comparability of much hard-won experimental data.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC EQUIPMENT - Testing; ELECTRIC MEASUREMENTS - Applications; DAMPED-SINEWAVE DEFIBRILLATORS; BIOMEDICAL EQUIPMENT; defibrillation; heart; therapy; Electric Conductivity; Electric Countershock; Evaluation Studies; Methods

Title: Performance of a hydraulic air compressor for use in compressed air energy storage power systems.
Authors with affiliations: Berghmans, J.A.; Ahrens, F.W.
Abstract: A fluid mechanical analysis of a hydraulic air compression system for Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) application is presented. With this compression concept, air is charged into an underground reservoir, for later use in power generation, by entraining bubbles into a downward flow of water from a surface reservoir. Upon releasing the air in the underground reservoir, the water is pumped back to the surface. The analytical model delineated in the paper is used to predict the hydraulic compressor performance characteristics (pumping power, pump head, compression efficiency) as a function of water flow rate and system geometrical parameters. The results indicate that, although large water pumps are needed, efficiencies as high as 90% (relative to ideal isothermal compression) can be expected. This should result in lower compression power than for conventional compressor systems, while eliminating the need for the usual intercoolers and aftercooler. (A)

Authors: Edsinger R.W., Warren A.W., Gordon L.H., Chang G.C.
Title: SIMWEST: A simulation model for wind energy storage systems.
Authors with affiliations: Edsinger, R.W.; Warren, A.W.; Gordon, L.H.; Chang, G.C.
Abstract: A comprehensive and efficient computer program for the modelling of wind energy systems with storage is described. It was developed under the sponsorship (1000,000) of the Department of Energy , under the direction of the NASA/Lewis Research Lab and under contract to Boeing Computer Services . The level of detail of SIMWEST is consistent with evaluating the economic feasibility as well as the general performance of wind energy systems with energy storage options. The software package consists of two basic programs and a library of system, environmental, and control components. The first program is a precompiler which allows the library components to be put together in building block form. The second program performs the techno-economic system analysis with the required input- output, and the integration of system dynamics. An example of the application of the SIMWEST program to a current 100 KW wind energy storage system is given. (A)

Title: New possibilities for utilising wind energy.
Authors with affiliations: Zuliani, G.
Abstract: A brief review of wind powered motors is given, considering the effect of different numbers of sails or blades, the problems of orientation of the machine and the advantages of a vertical axis design (the use of which has been largely restricted to irrigation pumping.) Modern design has tended to employ a two-blade system which offers higher power, better aerodynamic efficiency, higher speed of rotation and lower cost and weight. Such motors are often directly coupled to an electric generator via a clutch. An alternative is the wind turbine, which distributes an air flow accelerated by the Venturi effect to the turbine blades. Such machines may be mounted on a turntable to take advantage of changing wind direction. A novel solution to the storage of wind energy is proposed, whereby electricity produced from a combination of solar panels and wind power is used for the electrolysis of water; hydrogen and oxygen thus produced are then used to power a gas turbine and a conventional generator. Other alternative energy possibilities such as the use of fuel cells ofr molten salt (the latter for energy storage as heat), are also mentioned. (C.C.B.)

Title: A review of current R and D in thermal energy storage and heat exchange in solar applications.
Authors with affiliations: Michaels, A.I.
Abstract: A survey of current research and development methods used for storing and transferring thermal energy is presented. The thermal energy storage and heat transfer methods discussed are innovative heat exchange and transport, advanced concept sensible heat storage in water, rock, Earth or a combination of these, for either short term or for annual storage periods, heat storge in the energy of phase change, and heat storage in the energy of reversible chemical reactions.

Title: Storing solar BTU: new Technologies show promise but cost effectiveness is the key.
Authors with affiliations: Lawn, J.
Abstract: Phase-change materials are reviewed in regard to their application to latent-heat storage of solar energy. While water and rocks are suitable for thermal storage, they require costly insulated containers and large stortage spaces. Salt-hydrates are considered low-cost phase-change materials. Sodium sulfate decahydrate (Glauber's salt) has a heat-storage capacity of about 360 joules/cmSUB3 but has a lower melting point than may be optimum for a heat source and has problems of incongruent melting. Sodium thiosulfate has a higher melting point. (40SUPC) but has supercooling problems. Methods for reducing crystal precipitation in Glauber's salt include the utilization of additives (which suspend the salt and create a closed-cell honey-comb structure). Several applications of phase-change materials for potential marketing include: the development of a system which stores latent heat in three temperature ranges; eutectic salts in conjunction with an immiscible heat-transfer fluid; and a two-tank unit incorporating 380 litres of sodium hydroxide and 190 litres of water. (A)

Title: The regulation of an electricity supply system including wind energy generators.
Source title: IN: SECOND INT. SYMP. ON WIND ENERGY SYSTEMS, (AMSTERDAM, THE NETHERLANDS: OCT.3-6, 1978)
Volume: 1 , Cranfield, U.K., BHRA Fluid Engng., 1978, Paper G1
Authors with affiliations: Sorensen, B.
Abstract: Simulations are performed, of a system consisting of a number of fuel based power generation units, plus wind energy generators without energy storage facilities. A simple wind forecasting technique, based on crude extrapolations, is used to predict the amount of base and intermediate load, that wind generators are expected to be able to replace. Decisions to start or stop fuel based units are made on the basis of these predictions. If the predictions turn out to be in error, beyond the regulating capacity of the intermediate load fuel fired units already in operation, use of peak load units or unplanned import is required. On the basis of hour by hour simulations throughout a year, the optimum share of wind generators in such a model system is discussed. (A)

Authors: Smith G.C., Stottlemyre J.A., Wiles L.E., Loscutoff W.V., Pincus H.J.
Title: Stability and design criteria studies for compressed air energy storage reservoirs. (FY-1977 Progress Report)
Authors with affiliations: Smith, G.C.; Stottlemyre, J.A.; Wiles, L.E.; Loscutoff, W.V.; Pincus, H.J.
Abstract: A summary of the progress made during FY-1977 in establishing design criteria to ensure the successful operation and long-term stability of Compressed Air Energy Storage reservoirs in underground porous media, such as aquifers. (from paper)

Title: Chemical heat-pump-energy storage device and its applications.
Abstract: Describes the results of a one-year feasibility study on a chemical heat-pump-energy storage device. The study had two components: the practical demonstration of a chemical heat-pump device and a theoretical investigation of suitable applications. A prototype heat-pump has been constructed and operated at the Rutherford Laboratory. The prototype uses sulphuric acid and water as the chemical pair and has achieved a power output of 3.5 kW (this with malfunctioning heat exchangers). A preliminary assessment of performance shows it to operate as theory predicts.

Title: Compressed air energy storage turbo-machinery.
Authors with affiliations: Berman, P.A.
Abstract: This paper presents some of the aspects involved in the selection of the thermodynamic cycle for CAES power generating systems. It also presents several of the considerations involved in fitting turbomachinery to the cycle, including arrangement and operation. A typical set of economic criteria is used to illustrate a method of cycle optimization. (A)
Index Keywords: 1978; Power generation

Title: Computer simulation model of water and power studies.
Authors with affiliations: Kapila, I.P.; Shishodia, B.S.
Abstract: The paper describes a computer programme formulated for replacing manual water and power studies for the integrated operation of reservoirs on the Sutlej, Beas and Ravi Rivers in India. For any given requirements of the several irrigation canals of the interlinked system, the objective is to generate the maximum possible firm power from the hydroelectric grid of the region. The programme for operating the reservoirs is based on the rationale that the energy potential of the system, after meeting the irrigation requirements during any segment of time, sHould be as high as possible. The sequence of withdrawals from storage at each of the three storage reservoirs is thus determined according to the effective generating head for the corresponding subsystem of powerhouses. Reservoirs which have a higher energy potential are called upon to supply water for irrigation only when the lower-head subsystems cannot meet the canal requirements in any interval of time. A flow chart for the computation is presented in the paper, and the results obtained from the computer programme formulated on this basis are compared with those obtained from a manual study to establish the credibility of the simulation model. (A)
Index Keywords: Beas River; Sutley River

Title: Wind turbine data acquisition and analysis system.
Authors with affiliations: Stiefeld, B.
Abstract: Under Department of Energy sponsorship, Sandia Laboratories has implemented a programme to develop vertical axis wind turbine systems. One aspect of this programme has been the development of an instrumented test site adjacent to Sandia Laboratories' Technical Area I on Kirtland Air Force Base . Three vertical axis turbines are now in operation on this test site. This paper describes the data acquisition and analyses system develops to meet the needs of the vertical axis turbine test site. The system employs a 16 bit word length minicomputer as the major element in a stand-alone configuration. A variety of peripheral devices perform the required data acquisition functions and provide for data display and analysis. Included is a disk based software operating system that supports a mass storage file system, high level language, and auxillary soft water procedures. (A) (microfiche)

Title: Operating experience with a gas absorption heat pump.
Source title: LONDON, U.K., BRITISH GAS CORP., 1984, 11P. (TRANSL. NO. T6302/BG/WH765-84) (TRANSL. FROM GERMAN: GAS & WASSERFACH - GAS ERDG
Authors with affiliations: Diessner, E.
Abstract: This paper describes a project to examine the performance of a gas absorption heat pump. The boiler room of a building was chosen for the test site. It contained a large sanitary hot water installation for the staff of the works. The heat pump is designed to preheat water in a tank to 30 DEGREE C for 11 m SUP 3 capacity for shower baths. The warm waste air from the water storage heater and boiler room and part of the sensible heat of the flue gases are used. An absorption refrigerator RKH 10/20 made by Ruckelhausen (10-5 kw) and an air heat exchanger (air capacity 2400 m SUP 3/h) have been converted into a heat pump. For the sake of economy, the cold water pump and the fan motor are also switched off. All heat carrying pipes are insulated. The energy input in the form of natural gas is determined by a gas meter (pressure/temperature). An electricity meter is also included. Useful energy retrieved is shown on a commercial heat meter. It is not applicable to domestic water heating but has great potential in the technology applied to swimming pools. (R.A.H.)
Index Keywords: appropriate technology; Energy conservation

Title: Survey of solar thermal energy storage subsystems for thermal/electric applications.
Authors with affiliations: Segaser, C.L.
Abstract: This report presents a survey of the current technology and estimated costs of subsystems for storing the thermal energy produced by solar collectors. The systems considered were capable of producing both electricity and space conditioning for three types of loads: a single-family detached residence, an apartment complex of 100 units, and a city of 30,000 residents, containing both single-family residences and apartments.

Title: Heat and mass flow analysis of packed-bed thermal regenerators.
Authors with affiliations: Hamilton, N.I.
Abstract: This report describes a heat and mass flow analysis of a packed bed for thermal-energy storage including examination of the pressure drop across the bed, flow regime, and a parametric analysis. A cycling analysis that considers a variety of charge/discharge modes which might be required in an energy-storage system is also included. Problems such as radiation, heat losses, condensation, and bed irreversibility are treated as seperate subjects. (A)(Microfiche)

Title: Thermochemical energy storage systems: a review.
Authors with affiliations: Mar, R.W.; Bramlette, T.T.
Abstract: This report reviews the characteristics of thermochemical storage systems, analyzes the present state-of-the-art of the relevant technical disciplines, and presents some potential solar storage applications. (A) (Microfiche)

Title: A cAMP-induced increase in the motility of demembranated bull sperm models
Affiliations: Department of Biological Sciences Oakland University Rochester, MI 48063, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lindemann, C.B., Department of Biological Sciences Oakland University Rochester, MI 48063, United States
Abstract: cAMP is shown to be directly involved in activating the motile apparatus of bull sperm. Triton X-100-extracted, demembranated (modeled) bull sperm are motile in the presence of ATP. Addition of cAMP to motile demembranated preparations of sperm produced a measured increase in motility. Maximal stimulation was obtained with 8-30 μM cAMP present in the mixture. The stimulation is of the same relative magnitude as obtained by addition of theophylline or caffeine to intact (membrane-bound) sperm. Modeled sperm show no sensitivity to theophylline. The response of the modeled sperm to the addition of cAMP was dependent upon the length of storage of the sperm and the condition of the sperm prior to modeling. Although modeled sperm show no sensitivity to theophylline, theophylline treatment of sperm prior to modeling increases the motility of the models produced and eliminates the sensitivity of the models to cAMP. Inhibiting the energy metabolism of the sperm prior to modeling greatly enhanced the sensitivity of the models to cAMP. We conclude that the effect of cAMP on modeled bull sperm reflects a naturally occurring balance which controls the motility of bull sperm, and that cAMP exerts its stimulatory action directly on the motile apparatus. © 1978.
Index Keywords: adenosine triphosphate; bucladesine; caffeine; cyclic amp; cyclic gmp; deoxyglucose; potassium cyanide; theophylline; animal experiment; cattle; dose response; drug comparison; drug response; drug sensitivity; energy transfer; in vitro study; spermatozoon motility; Adenosine Monophosphate; Animal; Bucladesine; Cattle; Cell Survival; Cyanides; Cyclic AMP; Cyclic GMP; Deoxyglucose; Male; Sperm Motility; Spermatozoa; Support, U.S. Gov't, Non-P.H.S.; Theophylline

Title: Biology, Physiology and Biochemistry of Hyphomicrobia
Affiliations: Departments of Microbiology, The Universities of Groningen, The Netherlands, and Sheffield, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Harder, W., Departments of Microbiology, The Universities of Groningen, The Netherlands, and Sheffield, United Kingdom; Attwood, M.M., Departments of Microbiology, The Universities of Groningen, The Netherlands, and Sheffield, United Kingdom
Abstract: Hyphomicrobia are stalked bacteria that reproduce by a budding process. These organisms have been recognized for a long period and were observed originally in enrichment cultures for nitrifying bacteria. This chapter reviews the genus Hyphomicrobium, the group of organisms that consists of either rod-shaped cells with pointed ends or oval- or bean-shaped cells and produce mono- or bipolar filamentous outgrowths of varying length. The length of these filaments depends upon the environmental conditions but the diameter remains approximately constant. Multiplication occurs by the formation of a bud or daughter cell at the tip of the filament. All Hyphomicrobium spp. are chemo-organotrophs with a limited range of carbon and energy sources for growth. They can all utilize a range of one-carbon compounds and, in addition, a number of strains can grow on some two-carbon compounds. They can be considered obligate methylotrophs or restricted facultative methylotrophs depending upon their ability to utilize two- and four-carbon compounds. Hyphomicrobium spp. form polyhydroxybutyrate as storage material. © 1978 Academic Press Inc. (London)Ltd.
Index Keywords: carbon; cytochrome; methanol; pyruvic acid derivative; article; bacterial phenomena and functions; bacterium; ecology; genetic polymorphism; growth, development and aging; metabolism; species difference; ultrastructure; Bacteria; Bacterial Physiology; Carbon; Cytochromes; Ecology; Methanol; Polymorphism (Genetics); Pyruvates; Species Specificity

Authors: Hoffman H.W., Kedl R.J., Duscha R.A.
Title: Thermal energy-storage for industrial waste heat recovery.
Authors with affiliations: Hoffman, H.W.; Kedl, R.J.; Duscha, R.A.
Abstract: The United States Department of Energy-Division of Energy Storage Systems - has contracted with several industrial teams to examine the potential for waste heat recovery and reuse through thermal energy storage in five specific industrial categories: primary aluminium, cement, food processing, paper and pulp, and iron and steel. Preliminary results from Phase 1 feasibility studies suggest energy savings through fossil fuel displacement approaching 0.1 quad/yr in the 1985 period. Early implementation of recovery technologies with minimal development appears likely in the food processing and paper and pulp industries; development of the other three categories, though equally desirable, will probably require a greater investment in time and dollars. (A)(Microfiche)

Title: Tenth world energy conference.
Authors with affiliations: Shaw, T.L.
Abstract: Escalating fuel prices have brought an upsurge of interest in exploiting renewable energy sources. Since only water power is well proven, this can be exPected to come in for rapid expansion. The Author provides a brief review and discussion of hydrogeneration and cites some more unconventional resources. (A)
Index Keywords: Financial Aspects; Hydroelectric; Pumped Storage

Title: A parametric study of hot water storage for peak power generation.
Authors with affiliations: Li, K.W.
Abstract: In recent years the need for energy storage in utility systems has been increasingly recognized. At present the energy storage systems under consideration are hydrogen production and storage, superconducting magnet, bulk storage battery, flywheel energy storage, high-temperature water storage, and compressed-air storage. In this paper the focus of attention will be on a use of high-temperature water storage in steam-turbine power plants. Fig 1 shows a schematic diagram for a typical power plant with hot-water storage. At the time when the power demand is low, a greater than normal water flow is sent through the feedwater heater train. This would result in an increase of st eam extracted from the turbine and also in a reduction of turbine output. The excess feedwater is then directed to the storage tank. During the peaking period the heated feedwater will be recalled from the storage and returned to the power-plant system. At the same time the bala nce of required water is passed through the feedwater heater train. Because of less demand on the steam extraction, the turbine will generate more than normal output. In this arrangement the steam generator is operated at a constant load. This paper is intended to present a parametric study of a steam-turbine power plant with hot-water storage. The study will identify the parameters affecting the plant performance and its economic acceptance. Also, fuel cost and storage size are estimated for peak power generation. (A)

Authors: Blecher W.A., Giramonti A.J., Smith E.B.
Title: The champagne effect in hyrdaulically compensated compressed air energy storage systems.
Source title: U.S. DEPT. ENERGY, JAN. 1979, SESSION VI, CAES IN HARD ROCK CAVERNS
Authors with affiliations: Blecher, W.A.; Giramonti, A.J.; Smith, E.B.
Abstract: The presence of rapidly rising air bubbles, the so-called champagne effect, is caused by the solubility of air in water used for hydraulic compensation of CAES systems. During charging, water rises in the compensating shaft. AS it rises, hydrostatic pressure is reduced and dissolved air is released. The presence of air bubbles reduces the hydrostatic head of the water column by as much as 10 percent. The resultant pressure imbalance could cause the water to accelerate to a potentially dangerous velocity. Also, since the outflow will continue even if charging is stopped, all the water could be lost with concomitant loss of stored air. Since the occurrence of the champagne phenomenon could result in potentially severe consequences, any consideration of hydraulically compensated CAES systems must include a detailed analysis of the two-phase flow system in the compensating shaft. An analysis of transient performance was made, and means of preventing or controlling the problem were examined. The alternatices considered were oversizing of the cavern and incorporating a U-bend water seal below the cavern. Other alternatices include increasing water flow resistance and purging of the saturated water. Preliminary estimates show that these methods could add as much as 10 percent to the total storage system cost.

Title: Selection and application of pasted plate lead-acid batteries for wind and solar power energy storage.
Authors with affiliations: Ruhlmann, T.E.
Abstract: [No abstract available]
Index Keywords: Wind power

Title: Solar/electric district heating via cases.
Source title: IN: IECEC 80, PROC. 15TH INTERSOC. ENERGY CONVERSION ENGNG. CONF. ON ENERGY TO THE 21ST CENTURY, (SEATTLE, U.S.A.: AUG. 18-22
Volume: 2 , New York, U.S.A., Am. Inst. Aeronaut. & Astronaut., 1980, Paper No. 801978
Authors with affiliations: Powell, W.R.
Abstract: A district heating and cooling system using solar energy and surplus heat from large community buildings instead of power plant waste heat is described. The Community Annual Storage Energy System (CASES) is a thermal utility plan designed to save precious fossil fuels. CASES is based on water-source heat pumps, warm and cold water pipelines, and seasonal storage of thermal energy. Winter's chill and summer's heat are collected, saved, and returned months later for more efficient and economical heating and cooling. Cogeneration district heating plants require reduced efficiency in electrical generation and function best in northern climates with prolonged heating demand. CASES is designed for a warmer climate, where cooling demands cannot be ignored. CASES is also compatible with existing American regulatory institutions and the historic utility goal of generating electric power with the highest possible efficiency. CASES offers economic means for both diurnal load management and seasonal transfer of electric power demands.

Title: Problems of monitoring radioactive effluents
Source title: International Atomic Energy Agency Proceeding Series
Affiliations: Chalk River Nucl. Lab., Atom. Energy Canada Ltd, Chalk River, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Grummitt, W.E., Chalk River Nucl. Lab., Atom. Energy Canada Ltd, Chalk River, Canada; Lahaie, G., Chalk River Nucl. Lab., Atom. Energy Canada Ltd, Chalk River, Canada
Abstract: The technical aspects of monitoring effluent wastes from a nuclear establishment are described. The errors in specific procedures from inadequate sampling, non-uniform mixing and retention on walls of vessels during storage and sample preparation, have been investigated. Procedures which reduce losses and errors to a minimum are outlined. Water outfalls at the Chalk River Nuclear Laboratories (CRNL) of Atomic Energy of Canada Limited (AECL) are sampled before release to the Ottawa River, either with an auto-sampling device that collects a sample proportional to flow rate, or by an operator who collects a sample manually. Loss of radioactivity occurs on the walls of the auto-sampler and the storage bottle as well as in most methods of sample concentration. These losses have been investigated, and results are given for a range of fission products and neutron capture nuclides. Losses resulting from evaporation and ashing are large, more than half of the nuclide being retained on the walls in some cases. The effects of surface treatment and aqueous pH on the stability of radioactive solutions have been investigated. Treatment of the vessel walls with aqua regia before use substantially reduces losses. Reduction of sample volume by evaporation and by ion exchange has been considered in detail. Methods are outlined whih give >99% recovery for all nuclides of interest.
Index Keywords: radioisotope; effluent; monitoring; radioactivity

Authors: Doukas A.G., Aton B., Callender R.H., Ebrey T.G.
Title: Resonance Raman Studies of Bovine Metarhodopsin I and Metarhodopsin II
Affiliations: Physics Department, City College of City, University of New York, New York. New York 10031, United States; Department of Physiology Biophysics, University of Illinois, Urbana, Illinois, United States
Authors with affiliations: Doukas, A.G., Physics Department, City College of City, University of New York, New York. New York 10031, United States; Aton, B., Physics Department, City College of City, University of New York, New York. New York 10031, United States; Callender, R.H., Physics Department, City College of City, University of New York, New York. New York 10031, United States; Ebrey, T.G., Department of Physiology Biophysics, University of Illinois, Urbana, Illinois, United States
Abstract: The resonance Raman spectra of bovine metarhodopsin I and metarhodopsin II have been measured. The spectra are compared with model chromophore resonance Raman data. It was found that metarhodopsin I is linked to opsin via a protonated Schiff base linkage, whereas metarhodopsin II is linked by an unprotonated Schiff base. A recent suggestion that the chromophore of metarhodopsin II is retinal is explicitly disproved. The chromophores of both metarhodopsins are found to have an essentially all-trans conformation. The basic mechanism for color regulation in both forms appears to be electron derealization. The data tend to support the model of cis trans isomerization as the primary mechanism for vision. Also, the conclusions and inferences of this work on energy uses and storage by rhodopsin in neural generation are discussed. © 1978, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: rhodopsin; animal experiment; cattle

Title: Surface science
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, University of California, Berkeley, CA, United States; Materials and Molecular Research Division, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Authors with affiliations: Somorjai, G.A., Department of Chemistry, University of California, Berkeley, CA, United States, Materials and Molecular Research Division, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Abstract: During the past 15 years, surfaces have been increasingly studied on the atomic scale. As a result, their atomic structure and composition and the dynamics of gas-surface interactions are much better understood. Modem surface science is beginning to have an impact on many technologies. Techniques are readily available to study solid-vacuum and solid-gas interfaces. Studies of solid-liquid and solid-solid interfaces are difficult and appear to be challenging frontier areas of research. Surface science is at the heart of most research and development problems in energy conversion and storage. Copyright © 1978 AAAS.
Index Keywords: short survey; surface property

Title: USERDA effluent data collection and reporting program
Source title: International Atomic Energy Agency Proceeding Series
Affiliations: US Energy Res. Developm. Adm., Div. Operat. Environm. Safety, Washington, D.C., United States
Authors with affiliations: Elle, D.R., US Energy Res. Developm. Adm., Div. Operat. Environm. Safety, Washington, D.C., United States; Schoen, A.A., US Energy Res. Developm. Adm., Div. Operat. Environm. Safety, Washington, D.C., United States
Abstract: Effluent and environmental monitoring has been conducted at United States Energy Research and Development Administration (formerly United States Atomic Energy Commission) facilities and sites virtually since the inception of atomic energy research and development. In 1971, computer systems were developed that permitted storage of information and data characterizing each effluent and onsite discharge point and relevant information on sources, effluent treatment and control systems, and discharge data, and serve as ERDA's computer-based management information systems for compiling waste discharge control and monitoring data on radioactivity released as airborne or liquid effluents or liquid discharges to onsite retention basins at ERDA facilities. The information systems and associated data outputs have proved to be an effective internal management tool for identifying effluent control problem areas and for surveying an agencywide Radioactive Effluent Reduction Program. The trend data facilitate the detection of gradual changes in the effectiveness of waste treatment systems, and errors or oversights in monitoring and data handling. Other computer outputs are useful for identifying effluent release points that have significantly higher or lower concentrations or quantities in the discharge stream than were measured the previous year. The year-to-year trend reports and the extensive computer edit and error checks have improved the reliability of the reported effluent data. Adoption of a uniform, centralized reporting system has improved the understanding and credibility of effluent data, and has allowed management to evaluate the effectiveness of effluent control practices at ERDA facilities.
Index Keywords: radioisotope; computer; effluent; geographic distribution; methodology; monitoring; nuclear power plant; radioactivity; United States

Authors: WAGNER G., HARTMANN R., OESTERHELT D.
Title: Potassium Uniport and ATP Synthesis in Halobacterium halobium
Affiliations: Institut für Botanik und Pharmazeutische Biologie, Friedrich‐Alexander‐Universität zu Erlangen‐Nürnberg, Schloßgarten 4, Erlangen, D-8520, Germany; Institut Für Biochemie Der Julius-Maximilians-Universität Würzburg, Rontgenring 11, Würzburg, D-8700, Germany
Authors with affiliations: WAGNER, G., Institut für Botanik und Pharmazeutische Biologie, Friedrich‐Alexander‐Universität zu Erlangen‐Nürnberg, Schloßgarten 4, Erlangen, D-8520, Germany; HARTMANN, R., Institut Für Biochemie Der Julius-Maximilians-Universität Würzburg, Rontgenring 11, Würzburg, D-8700, Germany; OESTERHELT, D., Institut Für Biochemie Der Julius-Maximilians-Universität Würzburg, Rontgenring 11, Würzburg, D-8700, Germany
Abstract: Light‐driven potassium ion uptake in Halobacterium halobium is mediated by bacteriorhodopsin. This uptake is charge‐balanced by sodium ions and not by proton release. Light‐induced shifts in concentrations of divalent cations were found to be negligible. The transient changes in extracellular pH (alkaline overshoot) can be understood by the concomitant processes of ATP synthesis, proton/sodium exchange and potassium uptake. The driving force of potassium ion uptake is the membrane potential, no ATP‐dependent potassium transport process is found. Fluorescence measurements indicate a high permeability of the membrane to potassium ions compared to sodium ions. Therefore the potassium ion diffusion potential contributes to the membrane potential (about 30 mV/decade) and thereby influences the ATP level. Sudden enhancement of the diffusion potential by the potassium ionophore monactin leads to the expected transient increase in cellular ATP level. Due to the large size (up to 100‐fold) of the potassium ion gradient and its high capacity (intracellular concentration up to 3 M) the potassium ion gradient can well serve the cell as a long term storage form of energy. Copyright © 1978, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved
Index Keywords: adenosine triphosphate; potassium; animal experiment; halobacterium halobium; in vitro study; ion transport; Adenosine Diphosphate; Adenosine Triphosphate; Biological Transport, Active; Halobacterium; Hydrogen-Ion Concentration; Kinetics; Light; Photophosphorylation; Potassium; Sodium; Spectrometry, Fluorescence

Authors: Bombi F., Ciscato D., Congiu S., Noll P., Zimmermann D.
Title: The jet control and data acquisition system
Affiliations: JET Design Team Culham Laboratory, Abingdon, Oxon, United Kingdom; University of Padova, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Bombi, F., JET Design Team Culham Laboratory, Abingdon, Oxon, United Kingdom, University of Padova, Italy; Ciscato, D., JET Design Team Culham Laboratory, Abingdon, Oxon, United Kingdom; Congiu, S., JET Design Team Culham Laboratory, Abingdon, Oxon, United Kingdom; Noll, P., JET Design Team Culham Laboratory, Abingdon, Oxon, United Kingdom; Zimmermann, D., JET Design Team Culham Laboratory, Abingdon, Oxon, United Kingdom
Abstract: JET-The Joint European Torus - will be a major step in the European Community's fusion program. The principal objective of the experiment is to obtain and study a plasma in conditions and dimensions approaching those needed in a thermonuclear reactor. The size and complexity of the experiment demands an integrated computerized control and data acquisition system. CODAS comprises machine monitoring and control, acquisition of plasma and machine data, data analysis and storage. It is divided into several almost self contained subsystems, each of which is controlled and serviced by a minicomputer. The various local units of each subsystem are interfaced through CAMAC. The communication between the centralized control and the subsystems is obtained through 3 communication paths, the computer communication, the timing and the interlock system. The experiment as a whole is operated from two consoles, the machine console and the experiment console. One computer with large storage capacity is foreseen for the filing of all data, for automatic data processing between two pulses and for further analysis programs. © 1978 IEEE
Index Keywords: NUCLEAR ENERGY - Fusion Reactions; DATA PROCESSING

Title: Characterization of charge-coupled analog memories for nuclear data acquisition
Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, California 94720, United States; Technical University of Istanbul, Istanbul, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Yazgan, E., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, California 94720, United States, Technical University of Istanbul, Istanbul, Turkey; Kirsten, F., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, California 94720, United States
Abstract: Analog memory charge-coupled devices (CCDs) have potential use in instrumentation for nuclear data acquisition, particularly for large detectors for high-energy physics experiments. Some measurements aimed at characterizing the Fairchild 321 for this application have been made. This includes measurements on linearity, noise, dark current and transfer inefficiency. The results are given together with the measurement techniques used. © 1978 IEEE
Index Keywords: DATA PROCESSING - Data Acquisition; PHYSICS - High Energy; SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES, CHARGE COUPLED - Applications; DATA STORAGE, SEMICONDUCTOR

Authors: Melamud M., Shamir N., Shaked H.
Title: Magnetic form factor measurements by inelastic neutron scattering
Source title: Journal of Magnetism and Magnetic Materials
Affiliations: Nuclear Research Centre-Negev, Beer-Sheva, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Melamud, M., Nuclear Research Centre-Negev, Beer-Sheva, Israel; Shamir, N., Nuclear Research Centre-Negev, Beer-Sheva, Israel; Shaked, H., Nuclear Research Centre-Negev, Beer-Sheva, Israel
Abstract: The thermal neutron cross section for scattering by crystalline-electric field (CEF) levels is d2 σ/dΩdω = A x f2 (Q), where A includes physical and instrumental parameters, and f(Q) is the magnetic from factor of the ion being measured. The intensity of a neutron energy transfer peak resulting from a CEF level, measured at any Q value, is proportionl to f2 (Q) when all quantities in A are kept constant. The Q dependence of the form factor can therefore be derived from an energy analysis of the neutrons scattered from a powder sample, at several Q values. This method is suitable for paramagnetic ions having defined CEF levels (especially the rare earth ions). The method was utilizedby the authors for measuring the form factor of Pr3+ in PrF3, Ho3+ in HoCrO3 and U4+ in UPd3. The measurements were carried out on the triple axis neutron spectrometer KANDI III at the NRCN. The results agree with those found in the literature. © 1978.
Index Keywords: ELECTROACOUSTIC TRANSDUCERS; MAGNETIC TAPE; DATA STORAGE, MAGNETIC

Title: Fermi-motion corrections for deuterium targets
Affiliations: Department of Applied Mathematics and Theoretical Physics, University of Cambridge, Cambridge , CB3 9EW, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Landshoff, P.V., Department of Applied Mathematics and Theoretical Physics, University of Cambridge, Cambridge , CB3 9EW, United Kingdom; Polkinghorne, J.C., Department of Applied Mathematics and Theoretical Physics, University of Cambridge, Cambridge , CB3 9EW, United Kingdom
Abstract: A covariant analysis is given of the smearing effects of the Fermi motion of the nucleons in a deuterium target, in the impulse approximation. It is concluded that when the nucleon cross sections σp and σn are constant, the smearing correction vanishes: σd=σp+σn. More generally, in a relativistic theory the correction may be expanded in powers of (εM)12, where ε and M are the binding energy and the mass of the deuteron. However, present knowledge of the structure of the deuteron does not allow an evaluation of the coefficients in this expansion, so that the very sizable correction necessary in, for example, deep-inelastic lepton scattering on deuterium cannot be reliably determined. To rectify this situation, we urge a study of the momentum distribution of the spectator nucleon in hadronic reactions with a deuteron beam, or with a deuteron storage ring. © 1978 The American Physical Society.

Title: Viscoelastic properties of dilute polymer solutions
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, University of Wisconsin, Madison, Wisconsin, 53706, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ferry, J.D., Department of Chemistry, University of Wisconsin, Madison, Wisconsin, 53706, United States
Abstract: The frequency dependences of the intrinsic storage and loss shear moduli can be predicted from molecular theories for flexible random coil polymers (bead-spring models) and for rigid elongated macromolecules. Comparison with various experimental data extrapolated to infinite dilution shows good agreement with both these extreme types. For semi-rigid helical macromolecules, and for highly charged polyelectrolytes, experimental data correspond to hybrid relaxation spectra which are attributed to rigid-body rotation together with certain internal motionsprobably flexural modes for the helices, configurational rearrangements for the polyelectrolytes. At high frequencies or in high-viscosity solvents, additional energy dissipation mechanisms appear in random coil polymers, whose nature is still conjectural. © IUPAC

Authors: Hayes D.M., Kenyon G.L., Kollman P.A.
Title: Theoretical Calculations of the Hydrolysis Energies of Some “High-Energy” Molecules. 2. A Survey of Some Biologically Important Hydrolytic Reactions
Source title: Journal of the American Chemical Society
Affiliations: Department of Pharmaceutical Chemistry, School of Pharmacy, Department of Biochemistry and Biophysics, School of Medicine, University of California, San Francisco, California 94143, United States; Department of Chemistry, Union College, Schenectady, New York 12308, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hayes, D.M., Department of Pharmaceutical Chemistry, School of Pharmacy, Department of Biochemistry and Biophysics, School of Medicine, University of California, San Francisco, California 94143, United States; Kenyon, G.L., Department of Chemistry, Union College, Schenectady, New York 12308, United States; Kollman, P.A., Department of Chemistry, Union College, Schenectady, New York 12308, United States
Abstract: We present ab initio calculations on most of the major classes of hydrolytic reactions of high-energy molecules of importance in biological processes. Although intramolecular (opposing resonance and electrostatic) effects play an important role in determining the energy of hydrolysis in some of these reactions, it is concluded that in those hydrolyses of most importance in energy storage and transduction (ATP→ADP+orthophosphate and phosphocreatine+ADP creatine+ATP), relative solvation energies of reactants and products are by far the most important factors in determining these energies. We applied simple reaction field equations to estimate solvation energies. By doing so, we are able to reproduce the fact that phos-phoguanidinium and pyrophosphate ions have similar free energies of hydrolysis in H2O. despite the huge calculated difference between the corresponding energies of hydrolysis in the gas phase. © 1978, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.

Authors: Stoika A.D., Strelkov A.V., Hetzelt M.
Title: Upscattering detected as the main reason for anomalous loss of ultra-cold neutrons in neutron storage experiments
Source title: Zeitschrift für Physik B Condensed Matter and Quanta
Affiliations: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Dubna; Institut Max von Laue-Paul Langevin, 156X Centre de Tri, Grenoble Cedex, F-38042, France

Abstract: Neutron bottles have been surrounded with an outer detection system in an attempt to detect neutrons which possibly leave the neutron bottle through the walls. Results give evidence that neutrons, undergoing inelastic processes at the inner surface, leave the bottle with energies of ≈ 10 meV. About 75 % of all neutrons captured in the bottle are lost in this way. This result is in contradiction with the results of several previous works. © 1978 Springer-Verlag.

Authors: Maestri M., Infelta P.P., Grätzel M.
Title: Kinetics of fast light-induced redox processes in micellar systems: Intramicellar electron transfer
Affiliations: Institu de Chimie Physique, Ecole Polytechnique Fédérale, Lausanne, Switzerland; Istituto Chimico G. Ciamician, Università di Bologna, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Maestri, M., Institu de Chimie Physique, Ecole Polytechnique Fédérale, Lausanne, Switzerland, Istituto Chimico G. Ciamician, Università di Bologna, Italy; Infelta, P.P., Institu de Chimie Physique, Ecole Polytechnique Fédérale, Lausanne, Switzerland; Grätzel, M., Institu de Chimie Physique, Ecole Polytechnique Fédérale, Lausanne, Switzerland
Abstract: A phenomenological model is developed describing the kinetics of fast intramicellar redox reactions induced by light. It takes into account the influence of compartmentation as well as statistical distribution of reactants which lead to kinetic equations that differ from the rate laws in homogeneous kinetics. The theoretical predictions are experimentally tested by laser photolysis studies with solutions containing tetradecyltrioxyethylene sulfate as the micelle forming agent, N-methyl-phenothiazine (MPTH) as an electron donor, and tris(2,2-bipyridine)-ruthenium(II) [Ru(bipy)32+], as an electron acceptor. The intramicellar electron transfer from MPTH to excited state Ru(bipy)32+ occurs with a specific rate of 3 × 106 s-1. This reaction is followed by a back electron transfer occuring with a specific rate of 6 × 106 s-1. Possible ways to intercept the back reaction and to achieve light energy storage effects are indicated. © 1978 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Bulow F.J., Coburn C.B., Jr., Cobb C.S.
Title: Comparisons of Two Bluegill Populations by Means of the RNA-DNA Ratio and Liver-Somatic Index
Source title: Transactions of the American Fisheries Society
Affiliations: Department of Biology Tennessee Technological University, Cookeville, TN, 38501, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bulow, F.J., Department of Biology Tennessee Technological University, Cookeville, TN, 38501, United States; Coburn, C.B., Jr., Department of Biology Tennessee Technological University, Cookeville, TN, 38501, United States; Cobb, C.S., Department of Biology Tennessee Technological University, Cookeville, TN, 38501, United States
Abstract: Bluegills (Lepomis macrochirus Rafinesque) from two central Tennessee lakes revealed monthly and seasonal variations of liver RNA-DNA ratios (liver RNA/DNA) and liver-somatic indexes (LSI’s) that were associated with gonad maturation, spawning, and temperature. Liver RNA/DNA indicated a longer summer growth depression in fish collected from the smaller, shallower lake. Although LSI’s were consistently higher in the smaller, shallower lake, liver RNA/DNA and scale analyses showed faster growth rate in the larger, deeper lake. Thus the LSI may be a useful indicator of relative food intake-energy storage levels within a single lake, but it does not necessarily reflect absolute growth rate of the fish. Liver RNA/DNA provided an indication of immediate or short-term growth rates. © 1978 by the American Fisheries Society.
