H3A 2T8, Canada; Shahbazian, K., McGill University, Montreal, Que. H3A 2T8, Canada; Stairs, D.G., McGill University, Montreal, Que. H3A 2T8, Canada; Trischuk, J., McGill University, Montreal, Que. H3A 2T8, Canada; Faissler, W., Northeastern University, Boston, MA 02115, United States; Gettner, M., Northeastern University, Boston, MA 02115, United States; Johnson, J.R., Northeastern University, Boston, MA 02115, United States, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States; Kephart, T., Northeastern University, Boston, MA 02115, United States; Pothier, E., Northeastern University, Boston, MA 02115, United States; Potter, D., Northeastern University, Boston, MA 02115, United States, Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ 08903, United States; Tautz, M., Northeastern University, Boston, MA 02115, United States; Baranov, P., Lebedev Physical Institute, Moscow, Russian Federation; Rusakov, S., Lebedev Physical Institute, Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: Proton-proton elastic scattering has been measured in the region 4.9<|t|<12.1 GeV2 at a beam momentum of 201 GeV/c. If the form exp(At) is fitted to the data, the exponent A gradually changes from 1.5 to 0.9 GeV-2 over our t range. The data are consistent with the form exp(-6.6p). A comparison with intersecting storage ring results shows that in this kinematical region the slopes are about the same, but dσdt at fixed t is still dropping with energy. © 1977 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Mehlman G., Ederer D.L., Saloman E.B.
Title: The photoabsorption cross section of O2 from 55-350 Å
Affiliations: Synchrotron Ultraviolet Radiation Facility, Optical Physics Division, National Bureau of Standards, Washington, DC 20234, United States; L.I.M.H.P.-C.N.R.S., Villetaneuse, France
Authors with affiliations: Mehlman, G., Synchrotron Ultraviolet Radiation Facility, Optical Physics Division, National Bureau of Standards, Washington, DC 20234, United States, L.I.M.H.P.-C.N.R.S., Villetaneuse, France; Ederer, D.L., Synchrotron Ultraviolet Radiation Facility, Optical Physics Division, National Bureau of Standards, Washington, DC 20234, United States; Saloman, E.B., Synchrotron Ultraviolet Radiation Facility, Optical Physics Division, National Bureau of Standards, Washington, DC 20234, United States
Abstract: The photoabsorption cross section of O2 was measured photoelectrically in the wavelength range 55-350 Å . The 250 MeV storage ring at the National Bureau of Standards provided the background continuum. The absolute accuracy of the measurements is ±3% between 55-140 and 170-300 Å and ±5% in the wavelength range 140-170 and 300-350 Å. The cross section decreased monotonically with increasing photon energy. No thresholds or new structure was observed in the total cross section. © 1978 American Institute of Physics.

Title: Detecting heavy neutral leptons in electron-positron collisions
Affiliations: Institute for Theoretical Physics, State University of New York at Stony Brook, Stony Brook, NY 11794, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bletzacker, F., Institute for Theoretical Physics, State University of New York at Stony Brook, Stony Brook, NY 11794, United States; Nieh, H.T., Institute for Theoretical Physics, State University of New York at Stony Brook, Stony Brook, NY 11794, United States
Abstract: We present a detailed study of a μe signal for detecting heavy neutral leptons in electron-positron colliding-beam experiments with the new e+e- storage rings, which are now under construction. Potential backgrounds are also discussed. We conclude that with a judicial choice of the acceptance criteria there should be a viable μe signal for heavy neutral leptons with masses up to 10 GeV, at the projected maximum beam energy of 20 + 20 GeV of these new storage-ring accelerators. © 1977 The American Physical Society.

Title: Battery development makes good progress
Abstract: Improvements to conventional lead-acid types, new varieties with high capacity for energy storage described at ERDA-sponsored conference.

Title: Fuel Cycle Alternatives for Nuclear Power Reactors
Affiliations: Department of Nuclear Engineering, University of California, Berkeley, California 94720, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pigford, T.H., Department of Nuclear Engineering, University of California, Berkeley, California 94720, United States
Abstract: Annual and lifetime requirements of uranium and thorium resources for light-water and heavy-water nuclear reactors, a gas-cooled reactor, and a fast-breeder reactor have been calculated for alternate uranium and thorium fuel cycles. Recycling uranium and plutonium In a light-water reactor reduces the lifetime ore requirement by 40%. Compared to a uranium-plutonium recycle water reactor generating the same electrical energy, the lifetime uranium ore consumption is 37% less for a heavy-water reactor with plutonium recycle, 18% less for the U-Th fueled gas-cooled reactor with uranium recycle, and 82% less for the first-generation fast breeder reactor. The theoretical ingestion toxicity of stored discharge fuel or of high-level radioactive wastes is greatest during the first 600 years when dominated by fission products. For longer storage times it is comparable to the theoretical toxicity of the uranium ore originally mined to fuel the nuclear powr plant. © 1977, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.

Title: Quenching and Quenching Reversal of Tris(2'2-bipyridine)ruthenium(II) Emission in Poly electrolyte Solutions
Source title: Journal of the American Chemical Society
Affiliations: Chemistry Division, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, Illinois 60439, United States
Authors with affiliations: Meisel, D., Chemistry Division, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, Illinois 60439, United States; Matheson, M.S., Chemistry Division, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, Illinois 60439, United States
Abstract: The emission from the lowest charge transfer excited state of Ru(bpy)32+is very efficiently quenched by low concentrations of Cu2+ions when polyvinylsulfate (PVS) is present in the solution. Stern-Volmer constants 2 X 103higher than in the absence of PVS can be easily obtained. This efficient quenching completely vanishes and the emission is nearly totally restored when higher concentrations of the same quencher, or of inert cations, are added. The efficient quenching results from Cu2+and Ru(bpy)32+residing in the potential field of the same polymer. However, as soon as the quencher (or the inert cation) displaces Ru(bpy)32+from the polyelectrolyte, quenching reversal is observed. Quantitative results regarding the number of available sites and the relative binding constants of Cu2+and Ru(bpy)32+can be deduced from the minima and the quenching reversal portions of the quenching curves. Possible utilization of this or similar systems in solar energy conversion and storage is indicated. © 1977, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.

Authors: Hahn H., Month M., Rau R.R.
Title: Proton-proton intersecting storage accelerator facility ISABELLE at the Brookhaven National Laboratory
Affiliations: Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hahn, H., Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States; Month, M., Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States; Rau, R.R., Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States
Abstract: The intersecting storage accelerator facility ISABELLE proposed for construction at the Brookhaven National Laboratory is reviewed. ISABELLE would permit the exploration of proton-proton collisions at center-of-mass energies continuously variable from 60 to 400 GeV and with luminosities of 1032-1033 cm-2s-1 over the entire energy range. The facility would consist of two interlaced rings of superconducting magnets, operating at 40 kG, in a common tunnel about 2.6 km in circumference. The proton beams would collide at six intersection regions where particle detecting systems would be located. Protons of about 30 GeV from the AGS will be accumulated in each ring to obtain the design current of 10 A prior to their acceleration to the final energy. In this paper the design philosophy underlying the principal design choices, as well as a brief description of the major accelerator systems and the conventional structures, is presented. An overview of the physics potential provided by ISABELLE is then given. The large extension of the center-of-mass energy range combined with the very high luminosity would provide unique possibilities for the investigation of the questions of greatest current interest in particle physics. Arguments, based on the available data and reasonable theoretical concepts, are presented that suggest strongly that the intermediate vector bosons required for a unified weak and electromagnetic field theory should be discovered. They should be studied in detail. The hadron production at high transverse momentum, the energy dependence of the strong interactions, and the possible search for new, massive particles are also discussed. The paper concludes with a detailed beam analysis, the various limitations on beam current, the procedures followed in optimizing the luminosity, and a justification of the projected performance levels. © 1977 American Physical Society.

Authors: Luban M., Shtrikman S., Isaacson J.
Title: Director field and lifetime of the cholesteric storage mode
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Bar-Ilan University, Ramat-Gan, Israel; Department of Electronics, Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Luban, M., Department of Physics, Bar-Ilan University, Ramat-Gan, Israel, Department of Electronics, Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, Israel; Shtrikman, S., Department of Electronics, Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, Israel; Isaacson, J., Department of Physics, Bar-Ilan University, Ramat-Gan, Israel, Department of Electronics, Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, Israel
Abstract: The detailed spatial dependence of the director field n→(r→) for the metastable cholesteric storage mode is calculated as a function of plate spacing and surface energy coefficient. These calculations are first performed subject to the constraint that n→ is confined to a plane perpendicular to the plates. Upon waiving the planarity constraint and solving the complete Euler-Lagrange equations, we find that the departure of n→ from the plane is less than 7°with the largest values occurring in the immediate vicinity of the plates. Employing our results for n→(r→), we calculate the dependence of the electrical capacitance on plate spacing. We also propose a mechanism for the decay of the storage mode as well as a simple semiphenomenological expression for its lifetime. For a suitable choice of parameters our theoretical expressions are in reasonably good agreement with the capacitance and lifetime measurements of Hulin for variable plate spacing. © 1977 The American Physical Society.

Title: A mathematical model of the closure problem and permanent operation for tidal power studies.
Source title: IN: PROC. SEVENTEENTH CONGRESS OF THE INTERNATIONAL ASSOCIATION FOR HYDRAULIC RESEARCH, HYDRAULIC ENGINEERING FOR IMPROVED WA
Volume: 4 , Subject C - Improved design criteria for hydraulic structures, IAHR, 1977, Paper C1
Authors with affiliations: Kluth, D.J.; Ackers, P.
Abstract: The closure problem is the selection of a practicable and economic method and sequence of building an impounding structure across an existing tidal channel. The tidal flow and velocity depend on the waterway area, energy losses, sea level, basin storage and upland inflow to the basin. Incremental closure of the channel when building the impounding structure affects the waterway area, changes the flow and velocity and promotes a differential water level across the structure. These hydraulic effects can influence the choice of building method (e.g. in situ construction or floated-in caissons, rockfill or sandfill). The correct choice of building sequence minimises adverse hydraulic effects. A mathematical model is essential in studying alternative methods and sequences of closure for the wide ranges of tidal levels and waterway openings likely to be involved. Such a model was used for the study of a tidal power scheme at Secure Bay, Western Australia. The program outputs include flows and velocities through each available opening, water levels and (where appropriate) energy generation. (A)

Title: Tidal power.
Source title: IN: OFFSHORE AND UNDERGROUND POWER PLANTS, R. NOYES (ED.), PARK RIDGE, U.S.A., NOYES DATA CORP., 1977, CHAPTER 9
Abstract: Chapter contents: Introduction; Past and present tidal power projects; Tidal power plant systems; Economic considerations; Bibliography.
Index Keywords: Bay of Fundy; energy; pumped storage; Storage

Title: Solar desalination: status and potential.
Authors with affiliations: Mustacchi, C.; Cena, V.
Abstract: Freshwater can be produced by means of solar energy at a cost of 1 to 1.7 DOLLARS/cu m with a margin of the order of 5% towards fossil-fired operation. This concerns plants having a nominal production of at least 50 cu m/hr and the multistage flash evaporator concept. For much smaller capacities, basin stills, at a cost of 2 DOLLARS/cu m , are a convenient low technology solution. These margins will increase to 30% within the next ten years, and can even lead to better prospects provided that priority is given to the present bottlenecks of this technology; namely increasing lifetime and reliability, designing an appropriate heat storage system, improving the dynamics of startup and shutdown for the plants. (A)

Authors: Zinner H., Schott W., Daniel H.
Title: A storage device for relativistic electrons consisting of a phase-free cavity resonator and two magnetic mirrors
Affiliations: Physik-Department der Technischen Universität München, Munich, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Zinner, H., Physik-Department der Technischen Universität München, Munich, Germany; Schott, W., Physik-Department der Technischen Universität München, Munich, Germany; Daniel, H., Physik-Department der Technischen Universität München, Munich, Germany
Abstract: Several electron storage devices with a rectangular cavity, two magnetic mirrors with homogeneous fields and quadropole magnets are discussed. Advantage is taken of the fact that particles are accelerated when they pass the cavity close to the axis in positive z- or negative z-direction, as confirmed experimentally. Directly measured energy gain values of 20 keV electrons and energy gain values at 20 keV and 6 MeV calculated using either measured cavity fields or approximated field distributions are presented. Using an input power gain of 50 W the time-averaged energy gain values at 20 keV and 6 MeV are about 50 eV and 5 eV, respectively, in both z-directions. In one example of a storage device which was considered in more detail, the range of possible particle momenta devided by the particle momentum at injection amounts to be Δp p1 = 0.27. Δp is limited by rf- knock-out resonances. If the energy spread at injection is 10-3, the stored current is about 300 times larger than the injected current for the same density in phase space. A very high electron current (of the order of kA) should be feasible if this density is increased by the emission of synchrotron radiation. © 1977.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS

Title: Hydroblok pile driving hammer to the sea bottom.
Authors with affiliations: van Hussen, G.
Abstract: The Netherlands Hydroblock is a pile driving hammer that allows piles to be driven under water. The hammer uses a hydraulic drive that is fed by a hydraulic power pack through flexible hoses. Variations in oil pressure permit changes in nitrogen pressure within the cylinder that drives the impact head. The specifications (in terms of drive energy hammer weight, blow rate per minute) of commercially available models are given together wtih details of applications of the hammer. These include fixing of ocean platforms, mooring systems, submarine storage tanks and other underwater structures.
Index Keywords: oilhydraulic

Authors: Koch E.E., Kunz C., Sonntag B.
Title: Electronic states in solids investigated by means of synchrotron radiation
Affiliations: Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron DESY, Notkestieg 1, 2000 Hamburg 52, Germany; II. Institut für Experimentalphysik, Universität Hamburg, Luruper Chaussee 149, 2000 Hamburg 50, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Koch, E.E., Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron DESY, Notkestieg 1, 2000 Hamburg 52, Germany; Kunz, C., Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron DESY, Notkestieg 1, 2000 Hamburg 52, Germany; Sonntag, B., II. Institut für Experimentalphysik, Universität Hamburg, Luruper Chaussee 149, 2000 Hamburg 50, Germany
Abstract: Recent progress is reviewed in the investigation of deep valence and core states in solids by means of continuous and intense vacuum ultraviolet radiation from electron synchrotons and storage rings. The basic theoretical concepts involved in the interpretation of spectroscopic data for the range from the ultraviolet to the X-ray region are outlined and a short account is given of the experimental aspects of work with synchrotron radiation. In addition to optical reflectivity and absorption measurements the advantages are pointed out of investigating photoelectric yield, energy distributions of photoemitted electrons and luminescence excitation spectra with a tunable light source. A selection of more recent experimental results is given in order to illustrate the following topics concerned with the electronic structure of solids: band structure effects, localized excitations such as excitons, decay processes of elementary excitations, unoccupied surface states, surface excitons and electronic states of adsorbates, and many-body effects. The common origin and close correspondence of many features of inner-shell absorption spectra from atoms, molecules and solids is pointed out. © 1977.

Title: Potential of Chemical Preservation and Improvement of Forages
Affiliations: U. S. Department of Agriculture, Agricultural Research Service, Nutrition Institute, Ruminant Nutrition Laboratory, Beltsville, Maryland, 20705, United States
Authors with affiliations: Waldo, D.R., U. S. Department of Agriculture, Agricultural Research Service, Nutrition Institute, Ruminant Nutrition Laboratory, Beltsville, Maryland, 20705, United States
Abstract: Wilted hay-crop silages are difficult to manage for ensiling at an optimum dry matter. Even at optimum dry matter, protein degradation is considerable. If the forage becomes too dry, additional protein becomes indigestible from heat damage. Untreated direct-cut silages have low recoveries of energy and nitrogen. Protein degradation is extensive during storage. Low intake, partial feed conversion, daily animal production, and animal production per ton or hectare result. Formic acid may be used to desiccate standing forage in an effort to control dry matter, but adding formic acid to direct-cut forage at the silo is probably as beneficial. Formic acid alone, formic acid-formaldehyde, or formaldehyde alone eliminate many of the problems of direct-cut silage. Amounts of formaldehyde, when used alone, may be too critical for farm use. Formic acid also improves the quality and animal responses with wilted silages. Propionic acid controls the heat damage in wilted silages where the forage becomes too dry before ensiling. Sodium, calcium, and ammonium hydroxides increase the digestibility and intake of crop residues enough to make them more valuable feedstuffs for ruminants. © 1977, American Dairy Science Association. All rights reserved.

Title: Modelling of a solar-operated absorption air conditioner system with refrigerant storage
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Queensland., Brisbane, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Grassie, S.L., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Queensland., Brisbane, Australia; Sheridan, N.R., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Queensland., Brisbane, Australia
Abstract: A detailed dynamic model of a solar air conditioning system is reported. The model, including the solar collector and cooling tower, is described in terms of design parameters. Ambient wet and dry bulb temperatures and solar radiation are the required inputs. System temperatures, energy flows and coefficient of performance can be predicted. Careful attention is given to the evaporator model and the control of refrigerant flow. Typical performance results are discussed. Finally several recommendations for future investigations are made. © 1977.
Index Keywords: COOLING TOWERS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; REFRIGERANTS - Flow; SOLAR ENERGY; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; REFRIGERANT STORAGE; AIR CONDITIONING

Title: Solar power systems
Affiliations: Energy Associates, P.O. Box 355, Belton, TX 76513, United States
Authors with affiliations: Denton, J.C., Energy Associates, P.O. Box 355, Belton, TX 76513, United States
Abstract: A review of the principal solar power systems is presented. The nature of the solar energy source is discussed starting from the energy output of the sun and covering briefly the important atmospheric effects to characterize the available solar energy on the earth's surface. The various methods for capturing solar energy are presented: flat-plate, concentrating, photovoltaic, and other collectors. Energy storage methods are presented briefly for thermal, chemical, electrical, and mechanical storage approaches. An application of solar power systems in interaction with a conventional electrical utility system is presented in terms of mode of operation (base, intermediate, and peaking), reliability, capacity displacement, and energy displacement. An economic evaluation of selected solar power systems compared to conventional electrical generation plants is presented. Conclusions are drawn as to the conditions under which solar power systems may become economically competitive. A preliminary indication of market capture potential is discussed. © 1977.
Author Keywords: Chemical energy storage; Concentrating collectors; Flat-plate collectors; Photovoltaic collectors; Solar electric power; Solar energy source; Solar power economics; Solar power systems; Thermal energy storage
Index Keywords: SOLAR ENERGY - Energy Utilization; SOLAR POWER PLANTS

Title: Flywheel energy storage-II. Magnetically suspended superflywheel
Affiliations: Mechanical Engineering Department, University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20742, United States; Goddard Space Flight Center, Electromechanical Branch, Greenbelt, MD 20771, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kirk, J.A., Mechanical Engineering Department, University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20742, United States; Studer, P.A., Goddard Space Flight Center, Electromechanical Branch, Greenbelt, MD 20771, United States
Abstract: This article, the second of a two part paper, describes the general design requirements for a flywheel energy storage system. A new superflywheel energy storage system, using a spokeless, magnetically suspended, composite material pierced disk rotor is proposed. The new system is configured around a permanent magnet ("flux biased") magnetic suspension system with active control in the radial direction and passive control in the axial direction. The storage ring is used as a moving rotor and electronic commutation of stationary armature coils is proposed. There is no mechanical contact with the rotating ring and long life and low run down losses are projected. A discussion of major components for a 10 kwh system is presented. © 1977.
Index Keywords: FLYWHEELS

Authors: Hill J.E., Kelly G.E., Peavy B.A.
Title: A method of testing for rating thermal storage devices based on thermal performance
Affiliations: Center for Building Technology, National Bureau of Standards, Washington, DC 20234, U.S.A., United States
Authors with affiliations: Hill, J.E., Center for Building Technology, National Bureau of Standards, Washington, DC 20234, U.S.A., United States; Kelly, G.E., Center for Building Technology, National Bureau of Standards, Washington, DC 20234, U.S.A., United States; Peavy, B.A., Center for Building Technology, National Bureau of Standards, Washington, DC 20234, U.S.A., United States
Abstract: This paper describes a proposed test method for determining the "effective capacity" and heat loss characteristics of thermal storage devices. The prescribed series of tests should provide useful data for the rating of thermal storage devices based on thermal performance. The apparatuses and major components used in the tests have been prescribed so a liquid or air can be used as the transfer fluid. The series of tests to be conducted consist of one steady-state test to determine the heat loss characteristics and eight transient tests to determine the "effective capacity" for both heat storage and heat removal. During the transient tests, the entering fluid temperature is changed in a step-wise manner and amount of energy either stored or removed over a specified test time is determined. Sample experimental data are given in the paper to demonstrate the concept of the transient tests. © 1977.
Index Keywords: AIR CONDITIONING - Solar Energy Systems; HEATING - Solar; SOLAR ENERGY; THERMAL STORAGE; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: Enteral Nutrition by Tube
Affiliations: Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Cornell University Medical College, New York, New York 10021, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shils, M.E., Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Cornell University Medical College, New York, New York 10021, United States
Abstract: When p.o. intake is unsatisfactory or contraindicated, maintenance of nutrition by tube feeding is an alternative to the i.v. route. A number of factors will enter into the decision as to which alternative is better. In general, it is desirable to utilize the alimentary tract if it is functioning adequately. The potential hazard of aspiration and problems in inserting the tube into the appropriate part of the tract may offset advantages of tube feeding. The composition of the formula to be administered will depend upon the functional state of the gastrointestinal tract and the metabolic needs of the patient. Defined-formula diets have become commercially available for p.o. and tube feeding. These are both a boon and a problem to patient, physician, and dietitian. They simplify ordering, storage, preparation, and administration, but they have drawbacks related to their fixed composition. The large number of diverse formulations require expertise for their proper use. Entry of food into the alimentary tract is a stimulus to maintenance of structure and function of that tract and to hyperplasia when resection of bowel has occurred. Special formulations and modifications in route and rate of feeding may be beneficial in meeting the needs of patients with pancreatic insufficiency, malabsorption of various etiology, fistulas, and organ failures that modify nutritional requirements. Consideration should be given to adjunctive chemotherapy during nutritional rehabilitation of patients with known or suspected tumor. © 1977, American Association for Cancer Research. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: cancer; major clinical study; nutrition; therapy; Adult; Animal; Antineoplastic Agents; Case Report; Cervix Neoplasms; Diet; Energy Intake; Enteral Nutrition; Esophagus; Female; Gastrostomy; Human; Intestinal Fistula; Intestinal Mucosa; Intestines; Jejunum; Malabsorption Syndromes; Nasopharynx; Neoplasms; Neoplasms, Experimental; Nutrition; Pancreas; Rats

Title: A simplified technique for determining the boundary layer voltage loss in MHD generators
Affiliations: Naval Postgraduate School, Monterey, CA 93940, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dolson, R.C., Naval Postgraduate School, Monterey, CA 93940, United States; Biblarz, O., Naval Postgraduate School, Monterey, CA 93940, United States
Abstract: MHD generator performance predictions require an accurate determination of the voltage losses in the channel; however, most techniques for determining these losses need substantial calculations and/or computer storage space. This paper proposes a simplified method for calculating the ohmic boundary layer contribution to the overall voltage losses. Voltage drop regions are discussed and a description of the turbulent boundary layer contribution is derived. Appropriate simplifying assumptions on the basic transport and MHD concepts are used to express the conductivity as a function of temperature only. Weighting functions for averaging the resistivity in turbulent boundary layers are determined and the nature of these functions is presented. Our results are compared with more precise descriptions and with experimental results. © 1977.
Author Keywords: Electrohydrodynamics; Energy conversion; Magnetohydrodynamics; Plasma physics
Index Keywords: MAGNETOHYDRODYNAMIC CONVERTERS

Title: Structural materials use in a hydrogen energy economy
Affiliations: Science Center, Rockwell International Thousand Oaks, CA 91360, United States
Authors with affiliations: Thompson, A.W., Science Center, Rockwell International Thousand Oaks, CA 91360, United States
Abstract: Many common structural alloys are subject to gross embrittlement by hydrogen. Since hydrogen-induced fracture in such cases can result in catastrophic failures of equipment, it is very important to consider appropriate design measures and alternative materials choices for hydrogen service. There are two areas of concern for hydrogen energy applications: systems to generate hydrogen or hydrogen-bearing gases at high temperatures and pressures, and high pressure hydrogen transmission and storage systems. It appears possible in each area to identify the desirable classes of structural materials for hydrogen service. © 1977.
Index Keywords: HYDROGEN FUELS; STEEL - Structural; HYDROGEN EMBRITTLEMENT; METALS AND ALLOYS

Authors: Cricchi J.R., Barth D.A., Oehler H.G., Lyman R.C., Shipley J.M., Ahlport B.
Title: Radiation hardened CMNOS/SOS mask programmable ROM and general processor unit
Affiliations: Westinghouse Electric Corporation, Baltimore, Maryland 21203, United States; Northrop Corporation, Hawthorne, California 90250, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cricchi, J.R., Westinghouse Electric Corporation, Baltimore, Maryland 21203, United States; Barth, D.A., Westinghouse Electric Corporation, Baltimore, Maryland 21203, United States; Oehler, H.G., Westinghouse Electric Corporation, Baltimore, Maryland 21203, United States; Lyman, R.C., Westinghouse Electric Corporation, Baltimore, Maryland 21203, United States; Shipley, J.M., Westinghouse Electric Corporation, Baltimore, Maryland 21203, United States; Ahlport, B., Northrop Corporation, Hawthorne, California 90250, United States
Abstract: A low temperature CMOS/SOS process has been developed to minimize threshold voltage shifts and back channel leakage currents caused by radiation and temperature-bias stress conditions. Dual dielectric gate structures using CVD nitride 1300A thick on thermally grown SiO2 100A thick have been used to minimize the oxidation time at high temperatures. The dual dielectric structure has been combined with a multiple boron ion implant, φ = 3.5 × 1012 cm-2 at implant energies of 180 keV and 80 keV to produce n-channel enhancement devices with a graded boron profile with a maximum near the Al2O3-Si interface. This process has been utilized to fabricate a 1024 bit mask-programmable ROM (MP/ROM) and general processor unit (GPU). This paper will discuss the organization and fabrication of the MP/ROM and GPU and present data for radiation hardness tests to both accumulated total dose and transient upset radiation environments at levels of 1 × 106 rad (Si) and > 1010 rad (Si)/sec (narrow pulse), respectively. Temperature bias stress data is presented which demonstrates device stability. © 1977, IEEE. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, SEMICONDUCTOR - Radiation Effects; RADIATION-HARDENED SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES; SILICON ON SAPPHIRE SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES; SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES

Title: Some Aspects of the Solar Case Study Austria Illustrated by the Example of Hybrid Power Plants. [QUELQUES ASPECTS DE L'ETUDE SUR L'ENERGIE SOLAIRE EN AUTRICHE, ILLUSTRES PAR L'EXEMPLE DES CENTRALES D'ENERGIE HYBRIDES.]
Authors with affiliations: Weyss, Norbert
Abstract: A hybrid thermal power plant is described which can alternately utilize fossil fuels (during the time periods when solar energy is not available), or solar energy for heating the working fluid (production of steam) to yield favorable cost effectiveness of the power plant operation. The hybrid operation for meeting the base-load requirements has the advantage that the frequently posed questions of energy storage need not be considered. In Austria, for example, a solar energy utilizing hybrid plant producing about 8000 hours per year with a nominal performance rating of 50 MW (e) (and substantial energy storage facility such as pumped-up water) would require a surface area of about 5. 2 km**2. A power plant utilizing only the available solar insolation (sunny periods with about 2000 hours per year) with an intermittent 50 MW (e) performance during periods of sunshine (and moderate internal energy storage) would require only 1. 3 km**2. A nomograph permitting calculation of solar energy conversion economy is presented.
Index Keywords: Solar energy; Steam power plants; HYBRID POWER PLANTS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; Solar power plants

Title: Optimal proportioning of an insulated earth cylinder for storage of solar heat
Affiliations: Department of Civil Engineering, University of Delaware, Newark, DE 19711, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nicholls, R.L., Department of Civil Engineering, University of Delaware, Newark, DE 19711, United States
Abstract: A technique is illustrated, by means of an example, for optimally proportioning the insulated boundaries of a partially-insulated volume of earth for solar heat storage. The required equations for heat loss rates are determined from electrolytic tank models. © 1977.
Index Keywords: MATHEMATICAL MODELS; OPTIMIZATION; SOLAR ENERGY; INSULATED EARTH CYLINDERS; ENERGY STORAGE

Authors: Avenhaus R., Häfele W., McGrath P.E.
Title: Considerations on the large-scale deployment of the nuclear-fuel cycle
Affiliations: IIASA, Schloss Laxenburg, A-2361 Austria, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Avenhaus, R., IIASA, Schloss Laxenburg, A-2361 Austria, Austria; Häfele, W., IIASA, Schloss Laxenburg, A-2361 Austria, Austria; McGrath, P.E., IIASA, Schloss Laxenburg, A-2361 Austria, Austria
Abstract: In papers by Häfele, Manne and Schikorr, strategies for a transition from fossil to nuclear fuels are considered for a model society of 250 M people with an asymptotic energy consumption of 10 kW thermal per capita. In the final state, a purely nuclear energy production system, based on only two reactor types, was assumed to cover all electric and non-electrical energy demands of the model society. It is the purpose of this paper to evaluate the whole nuclear fuel cycle belonging to the asymptotic nuclear energy-production system. In order to achieve this, all normal operational and accidental risks connected with the nuclear material throughputs are analyzed. Thus, an idea of the relative importance of the different hazards is obtained; furthermore, the basis for a comparison of the nuclear option with alternative options (which is the subject of forthcoming work) is given. With this purpose in mind, only orders of magnitude are considered throughout the paper; in addition, the argumentation is restricted to the level of expected values. Following the introduction, the mass flows of nuclear material through the nuclear fuel cycle are analyzed. The methodology used is then developed. The normal operation releases of radioactivity are considered and possible modes of accidental radioactive releases are analyzed; the problem of a final waste storage is treated separately because of its unique nature. Different kinds of sabotage and blackmail, including the construction of a nuclear explosive device, are next analyzed; finally, all calculations are summarized. In conclusion, a number of decision-oriented assessments are identified that must be made when the large-scale deployment of nuclear energy is considered. © 1977.
Index Keywords: NUCLEAR REACTORS - Safeguard Systems; RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS - Safe Handling; NUCLEAR FUELS

Authors: Rhode E.A., Peterson T.M., Elsner R.W.
Title: Pressure-volume characteristics of the aortae of harbor seals, Phoca vitulina
Affiliations: Univ. California, Davis, Cal. 95616, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rhode, E.A., Univ. California, Davis, Cal. 95616, United States; Peterson, T.M., Univ. California, Davis, Cal. 95616, United States; Elsner, R.W., Univ. California, Davis, Cal. 95616, United States
Abstract: The functional significance of the dilated aortic bulb of diving marine mammals was studied on 15 excised aortae of harbor seals by pressure-volume records from the aortic bulb and thoracic aorta, 0-200 mm Hg pressure range, and passive length-tension measurements of whole thickness aortic strips. Aortic strips from the bulb and lower thoracic aorta had similar length-tension characteristics and the length-tension relationship is nearly linear over a range of length from resting length to 1 1/2 times resting length. The aortic bulb was more distensible than the lower thoracic segment. It held a larger volume and at pressures from 75-120 mm Hg large increments in volume were associated with small increments in distending pressure. The dilated aortic bulb appears to serve as a reservoir for volume and pressure energy storage in the vascular system. It appears that the geometry of the structures rather than the properties of the arterial wall accounts for the differences in the pressure-volume relationships.
Index Keywords: aorta; blood pressure; in vitro study; mammal; theoretical study; thoracic aorta

Title: Report on an international atomic energy agency inventory verification
Affiliations: Argonne Nat. Lab., Nondestructive Assay Sect., Spec. Materials Div., Argonne, Ill. 60439, United States
Authors with affiliations: Winslow, G.H., Argonne Nat. Lab., Nondestructive Assay Sect., Spec. Materials Div., Argonne, Ill. 60439, United States; Harkness, A.L., Argonne Nat. Lab., Nondestructive Assay Sect., Spec. Materials Div., Argonne, Ill. 60439, United States
Abstract: A five-member team from the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna conducted a plutonium inventory verification at Argonne National Laboratory in February 1976. The presence of 45.706 kg of total plutonium, 88.184% fissile, was demonstrated as a substitute for Japanese-owned plutonium held in almost inaccessible storage by Westinghouse. An attributes check made by gamma counting and a variables check made calorimetrically verified to 95% certainty that the inventory was not smaller than the book value by 2.4% or more. It was estimated that 200 man hours went into the effort. There were only a few minor snags, and those involved found it an interesting and instructive experience.
Index Keywords: radioisotope; methodology; nuclear energy; nuclear safety

Title: Proposal for the production and seasonal storage of hot water to heat a city
Affiliations: Centro Informazioni Studi Esperienze, Segrate, Milano, Italy and Istituto di Fisica dell'Università di Milano, Italy; Ditta ing. F. Poggi, Via Casoretto 4623, Milano, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Cavalleri, G., Centro Informazioni Studi Esperienze, Segrate, Milano, Italy and Istituto di Fisica dell'Università di Milano, Italy; Foligno, G., Ditta ing. F. Poggi, Via Casoretto 4623, Milano, Italy
Abstract: It is proposed to use an artficial lake, thermally insulated in the upper part only, to be filled during the spring, summer and autumn with hot water at 98°C, as a big storage of heat. Both the lake and the solar collectors should be placed in the mountains in order to exploit the low cost of the land and the higher solar radiation. An aqueduct with a low cost thermal insulation and with a negligible temperature drop even with 100 km length, can heat a city with more than 1 million people. In order to extract the maximum heat from the water, the aqueduct first feeds usual heaters then, in cascade, radiating panels and finally warm air conditioners equipped with a heat pump so that the discharged water is at 5°C. Convenient solar collectors to be placed in the mountains and for large production of hot water are the ones with concentration by fixed cylindrical mirrors. The design of the relevant moving tubular boiler is presented. The estimated cost per person is half of the cost required by a conventional heating system. © 1977.
Index Keywords: HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS; HEATING - Hot Water Systems; SOLAR ENERGY; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; TUBULAR BOILERS; ENERGY STORAGE

Authors: Kutal C., Schwendiman D.P., Grutsch P.
Title: Use of transition metal compounds to sensitize a photochemical energy storage reaction
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, University of Georgia, Athens, GA 30602, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kutal, C., Department of Chemistry, University of Georgia, Athens, GA 30602, United States; Schwendiman, D.P., Department of Chemistry, University of Georgia, Athens, GA 30602, United States; Grutsch, P., Department of Chemistry, University of Georgia, Athens, GA 30602, United States
Abstract: A solar energy storage system based upon the valence isomerization of norbornadiene to quadricyclene possesses several attractive features, including high specific energy storage capacity, kinetic stability of the energy rich photo-product in the absence of suitable catalysts, and relatively inexpensive reactants. An inherent difficulty with the system is the lack of absorption of solar energy by norbornadiene. Attempts to overcome this shortcoming have focused upon the use of transition metal compounds to sensitize the desired energy storage step. Results to date indicate that complexation of norbornadiene to the metal provides a potentially useful route to sensitization. Several copper(I) compounds have thus far been found to be effective. The facors which affect the ability of a transition metal compound to function as a sensitizer via a complexation mechanism are discussed. © 1977.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; PHYSICAL CHEMISTRY; PHOTOCHEMISTRY; TRANSITION METAL COMPOUNDS; SOLAR ENERGY

Abstract: 1. 1. ATP and CP levels were measured in brain slices from golden hamster and guinea pig after varying periods of cold storage and subsequent incubation at 37°C in the presence and absence of K+ salts. 2. 2. ATP and CP levels were maintained at higher levels in hamster tissue. 3. 3. The results are discussed in relation to the ability of a hibernator to transform and transport chemical energy at low temperatures. © 1977.

Affiliations: Department of Applied Science, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, N. Y., 11973 U.S.A., United States; Direct Energy Conversions Program, General Electric Company, Wilmington, MA 01887, United States

Abstract: Electrolysis of HCl and storage of hydrogen and chlorine is proposed as a means for energy storage for the electric utility industry. An economic evaluation is presented which shows that the system has a clear advantage over the hydrogen-air storage system and is comparable in cost to gas turbines. The system is flexible, allowing both energy storage and hydrogen production for industrial purposes, and lends itself easily to scale-up. Assuming that the R&D goals of this new system are met, it will compete successfully with all other electric energy storage devices presently considered. © 1977.

Title: A Kinetic Study of Calcium Transport by Heart Mitochondria
Affiliations: Pharmakologisches Institut, Universität Düsseldorf, Moorenstraße 5, Düsseldorf, D-4000, Germany
Authors with affiliations: NOACK, E.A., Pharmakologisches Institut, Universität Düsseldorf, Moorenstraße 5, Düsseldorf, D-4000, Germany; HEINEN, E.M., Pharmakologisches Institut, Universität Düsseldorf, Moorenstraße 5, Düsseldorf, D-4000, Germany
Abstract: Initial velocities of energy‐dependent Ca2+ uptake in cardiac mitochondria were measured with the ethyleneglycol bis(2‐aminoethylether)‐N,N,N′,N′‐tetraacetic acid/ruthenium red quenching technique. Accurate concentrations of free Ca2+ between 1 and 15μM were generated with ATP as a Ca2+ buffer system. Using the method of iterative approximation, the accurate value of the initial velocity of ATP‐driven 45Ca uptake, and the time (t0.5) for half‐maximal uptake can be calculated. The rate of initial Ca2+ uptake increased in response to the rising free Ca2+ concentrations in the medium (in the presence of 0.6–5.0 mM ATP). A maximal rate was obtained between 10 and 15 μM of free Ca2+. For different ATP concentrations (0.6–5.0 mM), the half‐maximal rate of Ca2+ transport (Km) was observed between 4.1 and 7.4 μM Ca2+ (with a mean Km of 5.6 ± 0.6 μ Ca2+; n= 5). Hill plots of the data yield straight lines with an average slope n, of 1.93 ± 0.29, indicating the existence of two binding sites for Ca2+ in the transmembrane transport system. Keeping the free Ca2+ concentration on a constant level (6 μM), the rate of initial Ca2+ uptake also increased continually with rising ATP concentrations (maximum velocity v= 7.1 nmol of Ca2+× mg protein−1× s−1). From energy‐independent calcium‐ion binding studies with cardiac mitochondria, a dissociation constant (Kd) of 26.8 × 10−6M and a total number of external binding sites n of 12.6 nmol of Ca2+/mg of protein was obtained. The data are discussed with regard to the physiological role which cardiac mitochondria may play as a reversible storage site during the contraction relaxation cycle of the heart. Copyright © 1977, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Title: Auditory/vibratory perception of syllabic structure in words by profoundly hearing-impaired children
Source title: Journal of Speech and Hearing Research
Affiliations: Cent. Inst. Deaf, St. Louis, Mo., United States
Authors with affiliations: Zeiser, M.L., Cent. Inst. Deaf, St. Louis, Mo., United States; Erber, N.P., Cent. Inst. Deaf, St. Louis, Mo., United States
Abstract: Sixty monosyllabic, disyllabic, and trisyllabic words were recorded and presented at different times through earphones and vibrators to 20 normal-hearing adults and to 20 profoundly hearing-impaired children to evaluate their perception of number of syllables. Vibratory perception by the profoundly hearing-impaired and normal-hearing subjects and auditory perception by the profoundly hearing-impaired subjects all were similar. Their responses could be predicted by counting the number of prominent energy bursts displayed on the screen of a storage oscilloscope. The subjects' responses obtained under these conditions differed considerably from normal auditory perception, which could be predicted by 'dictionary criteria' for syllabification. These findings suggest the need for a special perceptual viewpoint in teaching stress or prosody to profoundly hearing-impaired children.
Index Keywords: child; hearing impairment; speech perception; theoretical study; vibration

Title: Depletion of platelet amine storage granules by the antithrombotic agent, suloctidil
Affiliations: Thromb. Res. Cent., Temple Univ. Hosp., Philadelphia, Pa. 19140, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mills, D.C.B., Thromb. Res. Cent., Temple Univ. Hosp., Philadelphia, Pa. 19140, United States; MacFarlane, D.E., Thromb. Res. Cent., Temple Univ. Hosp., Philadelphia, Pa. 19140, United States
Abstract: Suloctidil, a compound with antithrombotic properties in animal models, causes depletion of human platelet serotonin stores during 1-5 hr incubation with platelet-rich plasma in vitro. This effect is not attended by leakage of cytoplasmic nucleotides or by alterations in cyclic AMP metabolism, malondialdehyde production or energy balance. 5HT uptake was also inhibited but uptake of adenine was not. 5HT released by suloctidil appeared in the supernatant as oxidation products, though the amine also accumulated when re-uptake was blocked by imipramine.

Title: Regulation of food intake in fatty and lean growing Zucker rats
Abstract: In the fatty strain of Zucker rats, obesity is inherited due to an autosomal recessive gene. The rats carrying one or two normal alleles Fafa or FaFa, lean rats) are normal in appearance and in body composition, whereas in homozygous recessive individuals (fafa, fatty rats), the fatty trait is noticeable by 3 wk of age. When the food intake of fatty Zucker rats is restricted to that consumed by lean littermates, their rate of growth is reduced but their body composition continues to be abnormal. The pair-fed fatty animals retained an increased fraction of the ingested calories, and had a preferential storage of calories in lipids, the rate of fat deposition being 50% greater than in lean rats. Hyperphagia alone can, therefore, not alone explain the abnormal lipid deposition in the fatty strain. Fatty and lean female Zucker rats weaned at 24 days of age, to receive then until the 34th day of age a commercial pelleted diet, were at that stage divided into groups, and fed on one of 6 diets. Fatty and lean rats differed markedly in body composition at 24 and 34 days. At day 34, the carcass lipid content of fatty animals was almost 4 times that of lean counterparts. Body protein content was the same, however, for the 2 phenotypes at both the time points. When food was given to satisfy appetite, the rate of protein deposition was the same for the 2 types of animals on all the diets and at the time points, but the lipid and energy deposition, were much greater in the fatty rats. Food intake of these animals was also much greater on all the diets except on the 4% protein diet, which both groups ate poorly. Food restriction for the fatty animals led to significant reduction in protein deposition, but these pair-fed animals continued to deposit twice as much lipid and energy. The intake of metabolizable energy (ME) in the lean rats was maximum on a 15% protein diet to remain almost constant at higher protein concentrations. The fatty animals showed maximum intake of ME on a 30% protein diet, and a fall at higher concentrations. Thus maximum differences between the two phenotypes with regard to ME intake, weight gain and lipid deposition were apparent on a 30% protein diet. Protein deposition in both types of animals reached a peak on a 15% protein diet. Nitrogen retention/intake of apparently digestible nitrogen, was significantly higher for the lean rats. Energy retention/ME intake was very much higher for the fatty animals. Heat production (ME intake-energy retention) of the 2 phenotypes eating ad lib was similar. These observations confirm that the obesity in these rats is not simply due to hyperphagia. That the mechanism for appetite control is not lost in the fatty animals is suggested by the observations that these animals show a markedly reduced appetite on low protein diets or an absolute zinc deficiency. These animals spent a lot of time in searching through their food as if they were looking for specific nutrients. It is suggested that the food intake in the congenitally obese Zucker rats is regulated by the need for adequate protein deposition.
Index Keywords: ethnic or racial aspects; etiology; fat intake; food intake; genetics; methodology; obesity; protein deficiency; rat; theoretical study

Title: Lightweight thermal storage for solar heated buildings
Affiliations: Department of Architecture, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139, United States
Authors with affiliations: Johnson, T.E., Department of Architecture, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139, United States
Abstract: A new building element is introduced that greatly improves the thermal and architectural peformance of passively heated structures. Insolated ceiling tiles charged with thin layers of phase change material are used to stabilize room temperatures and store large quantities of heat without using weighty materials which are expensive to support in multiple story structures. Experimental and analytical results are presented which detail the tile performance. © 1977.

Affiliations: The Aerospace Corporation, P.O. Box 92957, Los Angeles, CA 90009, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lapin, E.E., The Aerospace Corporation, P.O. Box 92957, Los Angeles, CA 90009, United States
Abstract: The conditions under which windmills become competitive with the generation of electric power from fossil fuels are examined. The influence of cost of construction, financing arrangements, and the future cost of fuels is shown. Energy storage and network arrangements for mills are considered briefly, as are alternate uses for mills, e.g. the utilization of mill output directly for heating or for the production of a fuel. © 1977.

Abstract: Solar panels are used for direct conversion of solar radiation into electrical energy. Based on ten years experience in space and terrestrial projects the BPX47A has been developed to meet stringent requirements imposed by humid, arid, tropical, subtropical, continental and arctic climates. This paper describes operation of the solar panel in combination with storage batteries, design considerations, solar radiation on the earth's surface, optimum design of a power station and an example of a realized project. © 1977.

Title: Flywheel energy storage-I. Basic concepts
Affiliations: Mechanical Engineering Department, University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20742, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kirk, J.A., Mechanical Engineering Department, University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20742, United States
Abstract: The basic concepts of flywheel energy storage systems are described in the first part of a two part paper. General equations for the charging and discharging characteristics of flywheel systems are developed and energy density formulas for flywheel rotors are discussed. It is shown that a suspended pierced disk flywheel is competitive with the super-flywheel designs currently being suggested in the literature. In Part II the details of a magnetically levitated spokeless ring flywheel design are provided. © 1977.

Authors: Meckoni V., Catlin R.J., Bennett L.L.
Title: Regional nuclear fuel cycle centres. IAEA study project

Authors with affiliations: Meckoni, V., The authors are with the International Atomic Energy Agency, PO Box 590, A-1011 Vienna, Austria; Catlin, R.J., The authors are with the International Atomic Energy Agency, PO Box 590, A-1011 Vienna, Austria; Bennett, L.L., The authors are with the International Atomic Energy Agency, PO Box 590, A-1011 Vienna, Austria
Abstract: A study project on regional nuclear fuel cycle centres was initiated by the International Atomic Energy Agency in 1975 to examine the economic, safety, safeguards and security aspects of a multinational approach to the planning and establishment of nuclear fuel cycle facilities. The study has concentrated on the 'back end' of the fuel cycle, covering transport, storage, processing and recycling activities. The results of this study would help any group of interested member states to develop alternative strategies for their present and projected nuclear fuel cycle needs, as well as evolve institutional, legal and other appropriate arrangements for establishing fuel cycle centres on a multinational cooperative basis. © 1977.

Authors: Cheema L.S., Camara Torres C.D., Lobo P.C.
Title: Prospects of power generation from solar plants in the north east of Brazil.
Source title: Solar Energy. Proc. symposium, Geneva, 1976, (World Meteorological Organization, Geneva, WMO-477)
Authors with affiliations: Cheema, L.S.; Camara Torres, C.D.; Lobo, P.C.
Abstract: The prospects for the utilization of solar power plants in the north east of Brazil, are studied for small communities removed from the power grid. The number of units that would be economically feasible depends on the price of plant per unit of installed capacity and the possibility of energy storage and subsidiary functions (distillation, pumping) performed by the plant. Some solutions that may reduce the cost of plant and price targets that appear to be viable in the near future are considered. Based on the electricity power grid in the north east of Brazil, the maximum demand for small solar power plants given two different selling prices per unit of installed capacity is estimated. Areas in the north east of Brazil where the installation of solar power plants is considered possible are indicated. -from STAR 16(19) 1978

Title: Iceberg utilization.
Authors with affiliations: Job, J.
Abstract: The prospect of transporting icebergs to South Australia for use as a fresh water source is examined. It is speculated that an iceberg of some 5 sq km in top surface could be towed from the Amery Ice Shelf area to the southern coast of Australia in about 2 months, with about half of its original mass remaining for conversion to water. This would contain enough water to supply a city of the size of Adelaide for 2 yr. The chief requirement would be an appropriate towing force. A comparison of the energy needs of iceberg towing and seawater desalination indicates that icebergs promise to be a much more economic source of water. The water would be suitable for domestic and industrial supplies, and perhaps for garden food crops. Feasible methods for protecting and towing the icebergs, and for converting them into water in storage are as yet undeveloped.-from Current Antarctic Literature
Index Keywords: Adelaide; Amery Ice Shelf; South Australia; towing technology (icebergs); water source

Authors: Roberts A.M., Coulston D.J., Bates T.H.
Title: Confirmation of in vivo uranium in chest survey by analysis of autopsy specimens
Affiliations: Brit. Nucl. Fuels Ltd. Risley, Warrington, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Roberts, A.M., Brit. Nucl. Fuels Ltd. Risley, Warrington, United Kingdom; Coulston, D.J., Brit. Nucl. Fuels Ltd. Risley, Warrington, United Kingdom; Bates, T.H., Brit. Nucl. Fuels Ltd. Risley, Warrington, United Kingdom
Abstract: At the ERDA (Energy Research and Development Administration) Conference on the Occupational Health Aspects of Working with Uranium at Arlington, Va, in April 1975, frequent mention was made of the lack of any recent autopsy data to supplement the results of in vivo chest counting. These authors can report one such case. The man had worked with uranium dioxide (UO2) powder for 22 mth when a routine in vivo uranium-in-chest count was carried out; 3 mth later he died suddenly from a coronary thrombosis, but from the time of monitoring until his death he had been transferred to another department (no UO2 contact). At autopsy one lung, the mediastinum, samples of kidney, liver, sternum, rib and vertebrae were available for study. The chest survey was carried out in the Whole Body Counter at British Nuclear Fuels Limited (BNFL) Windscale, where U is detected by means of the 90 and 185 keV gamma photons emitted by mixed U isotopes together with emissions from associated daughter products. A 120 mm diameter, 100 mm thick sodium iodide (thallium activated) crystal is employed, a side shield of 25 mm thick aged lead being incorporated to reduce the level of Compton Scatter effects. Measurements are made with the detector viewing the subject's back and chest sequentially. Pulse height analysis is performed with a multi-channel analyser which allows correction for normal room background (obtained by the observation of a water filled phantom) and presents the data in a form suitable for isotopic analysis. Because the sensitivity of the counting system is dependent on the degree of 235U enrichment, analyses of the subject's fecal voidings (provided during the week prior to measurement) were used to determine the mean storage of U in the lungs, and also the radiologic significance of this value with regard to the more dominant 234U isotope arising from its high specific activity. In this case, before chemical analysis, a lung was placed in a standard man phantom to test the validity of the previous in vivo measurement. The results of these analyses show that the Whole Body Counter system has a measurement capability of the order of 50% of the maximum permissible level as derived from ICRP (dependent upon isotopic composition and subject to chest wall thickness). Radiochemical analyses of the autopsy tissues were also carried out in the Bioanalytical Laboratories, BNFL, Windscale. In other subjects, it has been observed that the biologic half-life in lung of UO2 is significantly longer than the period between the original in vivo measurement and the analysis of the autopsy samples, such that the relative change in the lung content would be less than 10%. On this basis a table is presented in which the assessments of uranium in the lung are presented. The mediastinal tissue includes the tracheobronchial lymph nodes and if the U should reside essentially in these, and if the mass lymph nodes would be similar to that described by Pochin then they would contain about 1 μg U/g. This is at variance with earlier measurements that these are critical tissues regardless of the physicochemical form and atmospheric concentration of UO2 and other oxides, but in agreement with the conclusions of Donoghue et al. (1972). The relative concentrations of U in tissues other than lung (e.g. kidney vs liver, kidney vs bone) were in reasonable agreement with those reported by Donoghue although their subject had been exposed mainly to U3O8. The authors conclude that the results from organs taken at autopsy broadly confirm the in vivo chest survey result.
Index Keywords: radioisotope; uranium; uranium dioxide; uranium; autopsy; body burden; coronary artery thrombosis; major clinical study; methodology; radiology; article; autopsy; environmental exposure; half life time; human; lung; male; mediastinum; radiation monitoring; Autopsy; Environmental Exposure; Half-Life; Human; Lung; Male; Mediastinum; Radiation Monitoring; Uranium

Title: Effect of X-irradiation in utero on glucose and lactate content of rabbit in the course of the brain development
Source title: FOLIA MED. FAC. MED. UNIV. SARAVIENSIS
Affiliations: Dept. Physiol. Biochem. Dr Aleksandar Sabovljev, Med. Fac., Univ. Sarajevo
Authors with affiliations: Vranesic, M., Dept. Physiol. Biochem. Dr Aleksandar Sabovljev, Med. Fac., Univ. Sarajevo
Abstract: Glucose and lactate concentrations were estimated in brains of control and experimental rabbits in utero irradiated at fifteenth day of the gestational period. The quantities of the absorbed X-irradiation doses in the fetus amounted to: 22.5; 74.5 and 154.5 rad. In the course of the post-natal development glucose and lactate concentrations were estimated in brains of animals which had been sacrificed on the 3rd, 5th, 10th, 18th and 33rd day after birth. The glucose content in the course of initial 10 days of life in the irradiated rabbits displayed the appearance of progressive decrease. This occurrence developed earlier and had a more intensive course in rabbits irradiated with 74.5 and 154.5 rad in relation to the control animals. The lactate content in irradiated animals demonstrated a characteristic course over the period in which marked glucose decrease in brain manifests a considerable lactate increase. After the initial 18 days of post-natal development, both parameters, glucose concentration and lactate concentration had the appearance of relative stabilization. The noted dynamic changes of the energetic metabolic processes in newborn animals after exposure to radiation of various sources and energies were proved by glycogen, glucose and lactate findings in brains of control and irradiated animals. Intensive glucose absorption in brain tissue with a high utilization rate maintaining reactivity and chemical composition of the nervous tissue was established. The central role of glucose in the energy metabolism of brain was also proved by the 'tracer' method. These investigations have shown that glucose metabolism in nervous tissue varies considerably compared to other tissues. Whereas in other tissues, 14C labelled glucose was converted mainly into glycogen, lactate and CO2, in nervous tissue 14C labelled glucose appeared after one minute in more considerable amounts in aminoacids, as e.g. glutamic, asparagin, glutamine, gamma-aminobutyric acid and, to a lesser extent, in alanine and glycine. The relative activity values of enzymes in brain which conform to recent data on the organization of glucose metabolism as well as the results of radio-active precursors provide a firm biochemical basis for the unique part of glucose in brain metabolism. The majority of functional and biochemical changes in the course of brain development does not merely comprise a quantitative increase of enzyme activity. A specific structural organization of the metabolic pathway arises and gives rise to glucose utilization predominantly by route of glycosis in the cycle of tricarboxyl-acids. These biochemical changes correspond, owing to time, to electrophysiological manifestations of brain development. Imbalance of metabolism and metabolites due to low irradiation doses exhibits correlation with changes in enzyme activity; thus, data on the check up of these reactions in a certain metabolic direction with an altered metabolic route may be obtained. Data furnished by numerous authors demonstrate the nervous tissue to accumulate glycogen either when injured mechanically or by irradiation. The data on the changes of the content of carbohydrates and their metabolism in tissues following irradiation, even in case of almost identical doses exhibits correlation with changes in enzyme activity. The assumption that glycogenolysis drop due to irradiation, plays a significant part in glycogen storage following brain irradiation, seems likely.
Index Keywords: glucose; glycogen; lactic acid; radioisotope; animal experiment; brain; central nervous system; female genital system; fetus; pregnancy; X ray

Title: Some effects of variation in carbohydrate and nitrogen intakes on the chemical composition of mixed rumen bacteria from young steers
Affiliations: National Institute for Research, Shinfield, Reading RG2 9AT, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Mcallan, A.B., National Institute for Research, Shinfield, Reading RG2 9AT, Australia; Smith, R.H., National Institute for Research, Shinfield, Reading RG2 9AT, Australia
Abstract: Samples of rumen digesta were taken at different times after giving calves various dried forage or hay and cereal diets and mixed bacteria were separated. 2. For calves receiving dried forage only, the carbohydrate content of mixed bacteria varied with time after feeding, reaching a maximum of approximately 140 g/kg dry matter (dm) after 0.5-1 h, decreasing to about 60 g/kg DM after 4 h. 3, Replacement of part of the dried forage with glucose to give a similar metabolizable energy intake but approximately half as much nitrogen, produced a similar pattern of change with time after feeding but resulted in a markedly increased maximum bacterial carbohydrate content (approximately 230 g/kg dm). Addition of urea to this diet reduced the bacterial accumulation of carbohydrate to approximately the same level as was found in samples from calves receiving forage only diets. For the forage diets the carbohydrate content fell to 60–100 g/kg dm 4 h after feeding. For the hay and cereal diet the value was 170 g/kg DM at this time. 4. Changes in bacterial carbohydrate content were largely a result of changes in storage polysaccharide (a-dextran) content. 5. Crude protein (N × 6.25) and ash contents of mixed bacteria decreased after feeding with all-forage diets, but returned to approximately fasting levels within 4 h. At this time samples from calves receiving dried forage and glucose diets contained less CP and more ash (approximately 450 and 220 g/kg dm respectively) than those from calves given diets of dried forage osly (approximately 525 and 180 g/kg dm respectively). 6. CP, total carbohydrate and ash content of mixed rumen bacteria contributed approximately o.8o g/g DM. 7. Sodium, potassium, calcium, magnesium and phosphate accounted for approximately 0•50 g/g bacterial ash. © 1977, The Nutrition Society. All rights reserved.

Authors: Brillouet J.‐M., Coulet P.R., Gautheron D.C.
Title: Chemically activated collagen for amyloglucosidase attachment. Use in a helicoidal reactor
Affiliations: Laboratoire de Biologie et Technologie des Membranes du C.N.R.S, Université Claude Bernard de Lyon, Villeurbanne, 69621, France
Authors with affiliations: Brillouet, J.‐M., Laboratoire de Biologie et Technologie des Membranes du C.N.R.S, Université Claude Bernard de Lyon, Villeurbanne, 69621, France; Coulet, P.R., Laboratoire de Biologie et Technologie des Membranes du C.N.R.S, Université Claude Bernard de Lyon, Villeurbanne, 69621, France; Gautheron, D.C., Laboratoire de Biologie et Technologie des Membranes du C.N.R.S, Université Claude Bernard de Lyon, Villeurbanne, 69621, France
Abstract: Amyloglucosidase was covalently bound to collagen sheets by a previously described method. The time of acidic methylation (first step of the collagen activation process) was important to obtain a good enzymatic surfacic activity. Homogeneity of the coupling procedure on the surface of collagen films was shown. Some properties of free enzyme were not affected after grafting: optimum pH and temperature, activation energy, and Km for maltose. Heat stability of the bound enzyme was slightly better; Km for soluble starch increased fivefold. In contrast, the maximal velocity in the presence of soluble starch remained four times that of maltose hydrolysis. Amyloglucosidase collagen membranes were used in a helicoidal reactor to produce glucose from maltose or soluble starch solutions. Tracer studies have shown that the helicoidal reactor behaved as a CSTR. The influence of maltose concentration and flow rate on conversion was studied and confirmed the absence of diffusional limitations for maltose. Recycling of concentrated solutions of maltose and soluble starch indicated strong diffusional restrictions for soluble starch. The catalytic support kept all its activity for 18 days continuous operation at 40°C and 80% after 17 months storage at 4°C. Copyright © 1977 John Wiley & Sons, Inc.

Title: Synthesis, storage and degradation of polyglucose in chlorobium thiosulfatophilum
Affiliations: Botanical Laboratory, University of Oslo, Blindern, Oslo 3, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Sirevåg, R., Botanical Laboratory, University of Oslo, Blindern, Oslo 3, Norway; Ormerod, J.G., Botanical Laboratory, University of Oslo, Blindern, Oslo 3, Norway
Abstract: Cultures of Chlorobium thiosulfatophilum form polyglucose during growth. The polyglucose is laid down within the cells as rosette-like granules, which are made up from smaller grains. The size of each granule appears to be limited to less than 30 nm, since an increase in polyglucose content leads to more granules being formed rather than an increase in granule size. The polyglucose in washed cells is fermented in the dark to acetate, propionate, caproate and succinate, of which acetate by far comprises the largest fraction (68%). During incubation of washed cells without hydrogen donor, the level of polyglucose decreases regardless of whether the cells are incubated in the dark or in the light. Since the products formed from polyglucose under the two different conditions are not the same, it is suggested that polyglucose in the dark serves as an energy source, whereas when in the light the role of polyglucose is mainly to provide the cell with reducing power. © 1977 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Chlorobium; Dark metabolism; Polyglucose

Title: Purification and characterization of arginine kinase from the mantle muscle of the squid, Symplectoteuthis oualaniensis. Role of the phosphagen/phosphagen kinase system in a highly aerobic muscle
Affiliations: Department of Zoology, Duke University, Durham, NC 27706, United States
Authors with affiliations: Storey, K.B., Department of Zoology, Duke University, Durham, NC 27706, United States
Abstract: Arginine kinase (EC 2.7.3.3) from squid mantle muscle was purified to homogeneity as judged by isoelectric focusing and electrophoresis (sodium dodecyl sulfate, starch). The enzyme is a monomer of molecular weight 55,000 ± 6000 and occurs in mantle muscle in a single electrophoretic form with a specific activity of 310 units/g wet wt at 25 °C. The pH optima are 8.2 and 6.9 in the arginine phosphate-synthesizing and ATP-synthesizing directions, respectively. The divalent cation requirement of the enzyme is satisfied by Mg2+ or Mn2+ but added Ca2+, Zn2+, Cu2+, and Fe2+ are inhibitory. Monovalent ions (NH4+, K+, Na+, Cl-) inhibit the enzyme. Michaelis constants for ATP and arginine (both measured at pH 7.6) and for ADP and arginine phosphate (pH 7.2) are 0.8, 1.0, 0.2, and 3.5 mm, respectively, the Km's for any one substrate being independent of the concentration of its cosubstrate. Of over 40 metabolites tested for in vitro effects on the purified enzyme, only NADH, within its physiological range, affected enzyme activity. NADH is a noncompetitive inhibitor with a Ki of 0.15 mm. Like other enzymes of energy metabolism in squid mantle muscle, arginine kinase is tightly regulated, its activity being closely integrated with that of glycolysis and the Krebs cycle by NADH control. A theory is proposed, based on the data obtained, that the arginine kinase/arginine phosphate system in this highly aerobic muscle serves to reversibly regulate glycolytic flux and that its role in "energy storage" is very limited. © 1977.
Index Keywords: arginine kinase; creatine phosphate; in vitro study; invertebrate; muscle; phosphagen kinase; theoretical study; Ammonia; Animal; Arginine; Hydrogen-Ion Concentration; Kinetics; Muscles; NAD; Phosphotransferases; Potassium; Sodium; Squid

Title: Odour control of liquid swine manure by aeration
Affiliations: Agric. Eng. I.B.S. - Rijks Agrarisch Afvalwaterdienst, Arnhem, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Van der Hoek, K.W., Agric. Eng. I.B.S. - Rijks Agrarisch Afvalwaterdienst, Arnhem, Netherlands
Abstract: In Holland a number of farmers use an aerated storage basin for liquid swine manure. A description of this system is given. Two main problems are discussed: first how to minimize the high energy-consumption without odour complaints of the neighborhood and second how much nitrogen is lost, compared to untreated storage in a conventional way. For this reason a calculation of the composition of liquid swine manure has been made. Finally some other methods to save energy are indicated. © 1977.

Title: Experimental study of thermally stratified hot water storage tanks
Affiliations: Illinois Institute of Technology, Chicago, IL 60616, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lavan, Z., Illinois Institute of Technology, Chicago, IL 60616, United States; Thompson, J., Illinois Institute of Technology, Chicago, IL 60616, United States
Abstract: Temperature stratification in hot water storage systems was studied experimentally. In particular, high extraction rates from plastic cylindrical vessels were emphasized. Data were taken at various length to diameter ratios, inlet-outlet temperature differences and mass flow rates. The effect of inlet and exit port configuration on thermal stratification was also studied. The data were empirically correlated to yield useful relations for the design of effective hot water storage systems. Finally, a novel inlet and exit configuration scheme was designed for an 80 gal. (300 l.) and a 500 gal. (1900 l.) storage tank. © 1977.

Authors: Klein S.A., Beckman W.A., Duffie J.A.
Title: A design procedure for solar air heating systems
Affiliations: Solar Energy Laboratory, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States
Authors with affiliations: Klein, S.A., Solar Energy Laboratory, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States; Beckman, W.A., Solar Energy Laboratory, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States; Duffie, J.A., Solar Energy Laboratory, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States
Abstract: A natural extension of the design procedure for liquid-based solar space and water heating systems is a similar analysis for solar heating systems using air as the heat transfer fluid. In this paper, a solar air heating system incorporating a flat-plate air heater and packed bed thermal storage is described and a simulation model for the system is developed. The results of many simulations of the air heating system are used to establish the relationship between system performance and the system design and meteorological variables. The results are presented in analytic and graphical form, referred to as an f-chart for solar air heating systems. The results of simulations in several widely different climates suggest that the information presented in the f-chart is location independent. Methods of estimating the performance of air heating systems having a collector air capacitance rate and a storage capacity other than those used to generate the f-chart are included. A comparison of the performance of air and liquid based systems is afforded by a comparison of their respective f-charts. The air system is shown to perform better at high load fractions supplied by solar energy than a liquid-based system with the same collector thermal performance parameters. © 1977.

Authors: Hautala R.R., Little J., Sweet E.
Title: The use of functionalized polymers as photosensitizers in an energy storage reaction
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, University of Georgia, Athens, GA 30602, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hautala, R.R., Department of Chemistry, University of Georgia, Athens, GA 30602, United States; Little, J., Department of Chemistry, University of Georgia, Athens, GA 30602, United States; Sweet, E., Department of Chemistry, University of Georgia, Athens, GA 30602, United States
Abstract: Insoluble polymer bound photosensitizers, useful for the conversion of norbornadiene (1) to quadricyclene (2), have been synthesized. An acetophenone analogue was produced by Friedel-Crafts acylation of polystyrene resin while treatment of chloromethylated resin with salicyladehyde and triethylamine produced an anlogue of benzyloxybenzaldehyde. Reaction of lithiopolystyrene resin with methyl 4-(N,N-dimethylamino)benzoate gave a ketone equivalent to 4-(N,N-dimethylamino)benzophenone (3). Quantum yields for the conversion of 1 and 2 using the polymer bound sensitizers were generally comparable to, but slightly lower than, the analogous compound in homogeneous solution. The quantum yield of polymer bound 3 was less solvent dependent than that of the homogeneous counterpart. The advantages of isolating the photosensitizer to the photochemical reactor stage of a photochemical solar energy storage device are discussed. Efficient sensitization by polymer bound photosensitizers demonstrates the feasibility of this approach. © 1977.
