Authors with affiliations: Niehoff, R.T., Battelle Columbus Laboratories, Columbus, Ohio, 43201, United States
Abstract: This paper describes the development of an integrated vocabulary of energy terminology and it explores the potential for a fully developed energy vocabulary conversion guide. Eleven vocabularies were analyzed and integrated: AIP, CA, API, GA, INIS, TEST, GEOR, El, PA, DDC, and NASA. The following major concepts were considered within the scope: energy sources (fuels); derived products; exploration, production and processing; energy conversion; energy transportation, transmission and distribution; energy consumption, utilization, and conservation; power generation; energy storage; energy policy and legislation; environmental impacts; transportation modes (land, air, sea); propulsion systems; consuming sectors and economics; and international supply and consumption. The methodology consisted of 1) establishing term selection criteria, 2) analyzing individual system vocabularies for energy‐related terms, 3) processing energy subsets and 4) reviewing the integrated product and generating a final vocabulary. Three broad problem areas were identified during the study: 1) energy definition, 2) analyst viewpoint variances, 3) thesaurus format/convention variances. The conceptualization, identification, and selection of energy terms was especially difficult in several subject disciplines, including such areas as engineering materials, mathematics, electronics, explosives, psychology and other social sciences. Five types of synonym construction were encountered. It was concluded that vocabulary conversion, which permits subject switching, offers some degree of inter‐system compatibility. Conversion is the ability to retrieve all documents on a given subject from all available (and appropriate) data bases with a single query. When coupled with development of a standard system protocol, full information‐resource utilization will be possible. A prototype conversion guide (synonym table) was constructed for further study. One of the significant findings was that, without any additional intellectual efforts, conversion can be increased from 28 percent (exact match only) to 46 percent using exact match plus singular‐plural equivalencies, plus synonym expansion. Copyright © 1976 Wiley Periodicals, Inc., A Wiley Company
Index Keywords: ENERGY RESOURCES; SUBJECT SWITCHING; INFORMATION SCIENCE

Title: Mechanisms of the contracting action of K, acetylcholine and Ba and of the antispasmodic action of Cd and Mn on the pyloric antrum strip of rat's stomach, particularly in relation to Ca
Affiliations: Department of Pharmacology, Kobe University School of Medicine, Ikuta-ku, Kobe 650, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Shino, H., Department of Pharmacology, Kobe University School of Medicine, Ikuta-ku, Kobe 650, Japan
Abstract: Action mechanisms of the contractile agents, K, ACh and Ba and of the antispasmodics, Cd and Mn were investigated. The contractions by K, ACh and Ba are exponential in shape, but consisted of phasic contraction (PC) and the subsequent tonic contraction (TC). PC by K and ACh are initiated by the release and the passive influx of Ca, whereas the PC by Ba is due to the release of Ca. On the other hand, TC by these three agents is maintained by the active influx of Ca requiring energy. Since only the contraction by Ba remains constant in Ca(-) bath solution, it is assumed that the direct stimulation to muscle contractile elements without the mediation of Ca mobilization is also partly related to the contracting mechanism of Ba. Storage sites of Ca in the cell membrane of this preparation are distinguished into three divisions, the first, the second and the third, which contains loosely-, less loosely-, and tightly-bound Ca, respectively. K releases Ca to elicit contraction from the first division, ACh does so from the first and the second divisions, and Ba does so from all of the three divisions. The following assumption was obtained on the antispasmodic action of Cd and Mn, on the basis of the influence of Ca removal from bath solution and of addition of high K to bath solution and the analysis with concentration-action curves. The antispasmodic mechanism of Cd and Mn is due to inhibition of cell membrane (competitive/ inhibition of influx and then release of Ca and subsequently competitive and non-competitive inhibition of influx and release of Ca) followed by the non-competitive inhibition of muscle contractile system, with the increase of dosage. © 1976, The Japanese Pharmacological Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: 2,4 dinitrophenol; acetylcholine; barium chloride; cadmium chloride; calcium; calcium chloride; manganese chloride; potassium chloride; propranolol; yohimbine; acetylcholine; barium; cadmium; calcium; cholinergic receptor blocking agent; manganese; potassium; in vitro study; pharmacology; pylorus; rat; smooth muscle contraction; smooth muscle fiber membrane; stomach; stomach antrum; stomach muscle; theoretical study; animal; article; drug effect; muscle contraction; physiology; rat; stomach antrum; Acetylcholine; Animal; Barium; Cadmium; Calcium; English Abstract; In Vitro; Manganese; Muscle Contraction; Parasympatholytics; Potassium; Pyloric Antrum; Rats

Title: Heat recovery takes a fresh turn
Authors with affiliations: Strauss, S.D.
Abstract: The new plant now under construction for the Harvard Medical Complex is described. Eight medical and two educational institutions will be using it. Its benefits will be: reduced cost of utilities, reduced fuel consumption, minimized environmental impact, future development. By recovering a sizable fraction of the 7000-9000 Btu normally lost in generating every kWh of electricity, an overall heat rate of 5200 Btu/kWh - about half that of most central-station generating plants - is achieved. This means a capital investment of only 205/kW installed - compared with 500 or more for conventional plants now under way. Compared to the alternative of purchasing steam and electricity from a private utility. SO//2 discharge is reduced by 410 tons/yr and particulates by 38 tons/yr; recycle of steam condensate conserves 200,000 gal/yr of water, plus another 100,000 gal/yr normally required for dilution before disposal. Scope of the project is defined by the following utility requirements: electricity 51. 9 MW, steam 994,000 lb/hr, refrigeration 20,000 tons, cooling 42,840-gpm flow, refuse incineration 40 tons/day, oil storage 1,150,000 gal.
Index Keywords: Air conditioning; Heating; Hot water supply systems; CHILLED WATER SUPPLY SYSTEMS; HEAT RECOVERY; ″ALL-FUEL″ PLANTS; ″TOTAL-ENERGY″ PLANTS; Steam power plants; energy resource; hospital; incineration; noise reduction; therapy; waste disposal

Title: Technological alternatives and the Indian energy crisis.
Source title: IN: PROC. NAT. SEMINAR ON ENERGY, (HYDERABAD, INDIA: MAR.5-7,1976)
Authors with affiliations: Reddy, A.K.N.; Prasad, K.K.
Abstract: The changes in the price of oil affected India which imports petroleum. India uses 50% oil, 25% coal and 25% hydroelectric power. Nuclear power, non-commercial energy sources and rural energy are of lesser significance. Means of reducing oil consumption incude changes in transportation methods, an increase in the use of coal and more effective exploitation of hydroelectric power. It is also important to conserve non-commercial energy sources and to adopt alternative energy sources such as solar energy, biogas energy, wind power, animal power and human energy. Wind patterns in India, types of windmills, energy storage and economics are discussed. (A.M.T.)

Authors: Schierholz P.M., Somervell W.L., Babcock W., Hartel R., Watson K.
Title: Wind Powered aeration for remote locations. Progress report 3/5/75-3/15/76.
Authors with affiliations: Schierholz, P.M.; Somervell, W.L.; Babcock, W.; Hartel, R.; Watson, K.
Abstract: This research concerns the use of wind power directly to compress air to increase oxygen levels in polluted rivers and lakes subject to winterkill. A prime advantage may be using the water for storage of oxygen eliminating requirements for energy storage such as batteries. Three sites are proposed for the installation of wind powered systems. One is a lake chosen on the high plains for ease of access, another is a high mountain lake subject to winterkill and the third is a high plains river with pollution problems. Extensive weather measurements will be made at the two lake sites which include both mountain and high plains characteristics. The objective is to gather data to investigate the use of wind powered aerators, correlation of local weather data with system performance, and further development of design correlations for small wind powered systems. (A.) (Microfiche).
Index Keywords: Colorado State Univ

Title: Fresh breeze for Denmark's windmills.
Authors with affiliations: Hinrichsen, D.; Cawood, P.
Abstract: This article is about Denmarks renewed interest in windmills and the present projects underway to produce cheap electricity from the wind. Denmark has no hydroelectric power facilities , and has to rely chiefly on its import of fossil fuels to satisfy its energy demands, which over the years has become increasingly expensive. Comparison studies between wind and nuclear energy have been made, and wind power has been shown to compare favourably with nuclear energy, provided storage of energy can be attained, and that in the long run will prove itself to be least expensive and considerably safer than nuclear power. (F.C.S.)

Title: Some wind-energy storage options.
Source title: IN: PROCS. OF WORKSHOP ON ADVANCED WIND ENERGY SYSTEMS, (STOCKHOLM, SWEDEN : AUG.29-30, 1974)
Authors with affiliations: Eldridge, F.R.
Abstract: This paper looks at some of the methods of storage which use wind power as their source. These methods include batteries, hydrogen storage from water electrolysis, pumped hydro-systems and compressed air systems. Cost evaluation of these differing storage systems is also described. (F.C.S.)
Index Keywords: air; batteries; compressed; costs; electrolysis; generation; hydro-systems; hydrogen; power; windmills

Authors: BECKER L., YEH W.W.G., FULTS D., SPARKS D.
Title: OPERATIONS MODELS FOR CENTRAL VALLEY PROJECT.
Source title: J. WATER RESOUR. PLAN AND MANAG. DIV. PROC. ASCE
Authors with affiliations: BECKER, L.; YEH, W.W.G.; FULTS, D.; SPARKS, D.
Abstract: A MATHEMATICAL MODEL IS DEVELOPED FOR THE 9CENTRAL VALLEY PROJECT.THE MODEL PRODUCES A 12-MONTH OPERATING POLICX THE MODEL IS PROGRAMMED IN FORTRAN IV FOR PROCESSING ON A CDC CYBER 74 COMPUTER.PROJECT OPERATIONS MANAGERS USE THE MODEL AS A DECISION-ADVISING TOOL.THIS MODEL WILL BE COUPLED WITH A DAILY STRATEGY MODE.A FOUR-DIMENSIONAL INCREMENTAL DYNAMIC PROGRAMMING ALGORITHM IS DEVELOPED TO OPTIMIZE THE OPERATION OF THE FOUR-RESERVOIR SYSTEM.THE OBJECTIVE OF THE MODEL IS TO MAXIMIZE ENERGY GENERATION WITHIN THE LIMITS OF FIRM WATER AND POWER CONTRACTS, MANDATORY RELEASES, AND FLOOD CONTROL.A UNIQUE TECHNIQUE GIVEN THE ACRONYM RECIP FOR RECOMPUTED INITIAL POLICY IS DEVELOPED TO COMPUTE THE INITIAL OPERATING POLICY THAT IS OPTIMIZED.THE RECIP TECHNIQUE IS AN ITERATIVE PROCESS USING THE RESULTS OF THE INCREMENTAL DYNAMIC PROGRAMMING ALGORITHM TO COMPUTE A NEW INITIAL POLICY TO SATISFY THE REQUIRED END OF OPERATIONAL PERIOD TARGET STORAGES DESIRED BY THE USER.(A).
Index Keywords: CALIFORNIA CENTRAL VALLEY PROJECT; Mathematical models; Reservoirs; Systems analysis; Water resources

Title: TRANSIENT RESPONSE OF SOLID SENSIBLE HEAT THERMAL STORAGE UNITS - SINGLE FLUID.
Source title: TRANS. A.S.M.E. SER. C. J. HEAT TRANSFER
Authors with affiliations: SCHMIDT, F.N.; SZEGO, J.
Abstract: THE TRANSIENT RESPONSE OF A SOLID SENSIBLE HEAT STORAGE UNIT WHICH RECEIVES OR SUPPLIES HEAT TO A SINGLE FLOWING FLUID IS PRESENTED.THE STORAGE UNIT IS COMPOSED OF A NUMBER OF RECTANGULAR CROSS-SECTIONAL CHANNELS FOR THE FLOWING FLUID, CONNECTED IN PARALLEL AND SEPARATED BY THE HEAT STORAGE MATERIAL.THE ENERGY EQUATION FOR THE FLUID AND THE TRANSIENT CONDUCTION EQUATION FOR THE STORAGE MATERIAL ARE SOLVED USING FINITE DIFFERENCE TECHNIQUES.THE PARAMETERS WHICH CHARACTERIZE THE TRANSIENT BEHAVIOUR OF THESE UNITS ARE IDENTIFIED.RESULTS SUITABLE FOR THE PREDICTION OF THE RATE OF HEAT STORAGE AND THE OUTLET TEMPERATURE OF THE FLUID LEAVING THE STORAGE UNIT ARE PRESENTED AS FUNCTIONS OF THE IDENTIFIED NONDIMENSIONAL PARAMETERS.(A).
Index Keywords: BROT NUMBER; COMPUTERISED ANALYSIS; FOURIER NUMBER; GAS/SOLID HEAT EXCHANGERS; HEAT STORAGE UNITS; OUTLET TEMPERATURE CHANGES; PARALLEL FLUID FLOW; THEORETICAL ANALYSIS; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; TRANSIENT RESPONSE

Authors: Dickinson W.C., Clark A.F., Day J.A., Wouters L.F.
Title: The shallow solar pond energy conversion system
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore Laboratory, Livermore, CA 94550, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dickinson, W.C., Lawrence Livermore Laboratory, Livermore, CA 94550, United States; Clark, A.F., Lawrence Livermore Laboratory, Livermore, CA 94550, United States; Day, J.A., Lawrence Livermore Laboratory, Livermore, CA 94550, United States; Wouters, L.F., Lawrence Livermore Laboratory, Livermore, CA 94550, United States
Abstract: The concept of a shallow solar pond energy conversion system is presented as an effective way to produce large-scale electric power from solar energy. Water is used both for heat collection and heat storage. Inexpensive layers of weatherable transparent plastic over the water suppress heat loss to the environment. The hot water is stored in an insulated reservoir at night. The stored hot water heats a thermodynamic fluid, probably Freon 11, which drives a turbine and an electric generator. A shallow solar pond system can be built using materials, fabrication techniques and geometries that are presently used on a large scale in U.S. insustry. A 10 MWe plant built in the Southwest would require a total area of about 2 km2 and could provide power for a community or a manufacturing process. The estimated busbar cost of electricity (1975 dollars) for a shallow solar pond system, which could come on line in as short a time as 5-7 yr, is 56 mills/kWh. This cost could be reduced with the development of improved and cheaper plastics and more efficient turbines. Another potentially important use of shallow solar ponds is to provide process hot water, up to the boiling point, for industrial and commercial purposes. Also, a shallow solar pond could provide hot water for the space heating, air conditioning and hot water needs of a community of homes or apartments. © 1976.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION; ENERGY RESOURCES; HEATING - Hot Water Systems; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; ENERGY CONVERSION SYSTEMS; SHALLOW SOLAR PONDS; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: An improved computer program for the thermal performance of a solar water heater
Affiliations: Engineering Faculty, University of Malaya, Kuala Lumpur 22-11, Malaysia
Authors with affiliations: Ong, K.S., Engineering Faculty, University of Malaya, Kuala Lumpur 22-11, Malaysia
Abstract: An imporved theoretical model to predict the thermal performance of a natural-recirculation (thermosiphon-flow) solar water heater system is presented. The model considers the entire system to be broken up into a finite number of sections, each individual section having a uniform mean temperature. By considering an energy balance over each section, finite difference equations were written to enable the mean section temperature to be evaluated. Mass flowrate was evaluated from the temperature distribution of the whole system. Good correlation was obtained between predicted and experimental results during the main part of the day. The effect on thermal performance of height of storage tank with respect to absorber unit was examined. © 1976.
Index Keywords: MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SOLAR ENERGY; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; WATER HEATERS

Title: The effect of heat loss on solar heating systems
Affiliations: Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nash, R.T., Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Williamson, J.W., Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States
Abstract: The influence of structural energy loss on the performance of a solar heating system has generally been given limited consideration. Yet, failure to account for the character of structural energy loss is equivalent to a naval architect ignoring the drag associated with the hull, while concentrating his attention on the propulsion equipment. More attention must be given to this factor if solar heating systems are to become successful in areas of the United States where comfort heating requirements are greatest. In this paper the influence of structural energy loss on the performance of a solar heating system is developed first. Then, a general method for determining the most economically desirable conbination solar energy gain, structural energy loss, thermal energy storage, and auxiliary energy use is presented. © 1976.
Index Keywords: SOLAR ENERGY; STRUCTURAL ENERGY LOSS; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; HEATING

Title: Lithium’s role in supplying energy in the future
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore Laboratory, University of California, Livermore, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Borg, I.Y., Lawrence Livermore Laboratory, University of California, Livermore, CA, United States; Connell, L.G.O., Lawrence Livermore Laboratory, University of California, Livermore, CA, United States
Abstract: Lithium’s unusual properties as a metal have propelled it into the forefront of materials destined to play an important role in the economy of the next century. It promises to be an important component of the breeder blanket of controlled thermonuclear reactors as well as hybrid fission-fusion reactors that may serve to transmute high-level waste generated by conventional fission reactors. About 100-1000 kg of natural lithium are required per megawatt-electric. Lithium-water-air and lithium-sulfide batteries have been tested and show great promise of becoming the batteries for electric automobiles in the future. One of these batteries can just as well serve for local off-peak energy storage in the utility industry. Similarly, they can be used for intermittent energy sources (wind, tidal, and solar power). The current lithium reserves and resources will be hard put to meet customary demands for lithium, which are increasing at a rate of 8-10%/yr, so the U.S. supply will have to be expanded by increased exploration. © 1976 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES, PRIMARY; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY; ENERGY RESOURCES; LITHIUM DEPOSITS - United States; NUCLEAR REACTORS - Fast Reactors; BREEDING BLANKETS; LITHIUM-SULFIDE BATTERIES; LITHIUM-WATER-AIR BATTERIES; LITHIUM AND ALLOYS

Authors: Sipp B., Miehe J.A., Lopez-Delgado R.
Title: Wavelength dependence of the time resolution of high-speed photomultipliers used in single-photon timing experiments
Affiliations: LURE Service National CNRS, Université Paris Sud., Université de Paris-Sud, Bât. 200, 91405 Orsay, France
Authors with affiliations: Sipp, B., LURE Service National CNRS, Université Paris Sud., Université de Paris-Sud, Bât. 200, 91405 Orsay, France; Miehe, J.A., LURE Service National CNRS, Université Paris Sud., Université de Paris-Sud, Bât. 200, 91405 Orsay, France; Lopez-Delgado, R., LURE Service National CNRS, Université Paris Sud., Université de Paris-Sud, Bât. 200, 91405 Orsay, France
Abstract: Since fast synchrotron radiation pulses (from the Orsay Storage Ring) can be considered as a "standard of length of time", independent of the photon wavelength, these pulses have been used to study the influence of the incident photon energy on the time resolution of photomultipliers with a bialkali cathode. © 1976.
Index Keywords: ELECTRON TUBES, PHOTOMULTIPLIER

Title: Energy conservation
Affiliations: School of Mechanical Engineering, Cranfield Institute of Technology, Cranfield, Beds., Great Britain, UK, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Hinde, P.T., School of Mechanical Engineering, Cranfield Institute of Technology, Cranfield, Beds., Great Britain, UK, United Kingdom; Probert, S.D., School of Mechanical Engineering, Cranfield Institute of Technology, Cranfield, Beds., Great Britain, UK, United Kingdom
Abstract: Current energy sources and consumption patterns are reviewed, with emphasis on the UK. A survey is made of the main technological means of energy conservation: more efficient conversion of fuels to mechanical and electrical power; utilisation of waste heat; reducing energy requirements for materials and manufacturing; reducing distribution/storage losses, and heat losses from structures. Potential savings resulting from exploitation of novel energy resources are also considered. Sociotechnical aspects of energy conservation are discussed, with particular reference to transport and per capita consumption of materials/manufactured goods. It is concluded that very substantial savings could be made in these areas. Despite the additional environmental benefits associated with many such savings, their political feasibility is judged to be low. Suggestions are made for realistic legislation that could be introduced to effect savings by individual users with minimum capital expenditure. © 1976.
Index Keywords: DIRECT ENERGY CONVERSION; FUEL ECONOMY; WASTE HEAT UTILIZATION; ENERGY CONSERVATION; ENERGY RESOURCES

Title: Turbo machinery systems for compressed air energy storage.
Authors with affiliations: Berman, P.A.
Abstract: Soaring prices for premium fuels, along with the desire to reduce utility dependence on petroleum-derived fuel, necessitates looking for other means of providing for system peak power requirements. Complete elimination of premium-fuel-fired plants and a total reliance on coal, or coal and nuclear is not the answer. This paper shows that the rational answer is energy storage. (A)
Index Keywords: generation; Pneumatics; power; pumped storage

Title: Energy storage and temperature distribution in lakes.
Source title: IN:FUTURE ENERGY PRODUCTION SYSTEMS,DENTON,J.C. AND AFGAN,N (EDS.)
Authors with affiliations: Bloss, S.; Grigull, U.
Abstract: With certain simplifications the temperature distribution in lakes can be treated as a non-steady, one-dimensional heat conduction problem. Two conditions are sufficient for the development of a thermocline: heat exchange at the surface by convective heat transfer, evaporation and/or long wave radiation on the one hand and the absorption of short wave solar radiation on the other hand. The thickness and temperature of the upper layer (epilimnion) of the lake are determined by averaging the internal energy corresponding to the calculated unstable temperature profiles. Transient energy exchange can be taken into account by a stepwise calculation. The calculated temperature profiles are in good agreement with field measurements of other authors. (A)

Title: Environmental effects on the mechanical properties of high performance fibres
Affiliations: MRL MARIBYRNONG
Authors with affiliations: Brown, J.R., MRL MARIBYRNONG; Browne, N.M., MRL MARIBYRNONG
Abstract: [No abstract available]
Index Keywords: AGEING (STORAGE); AROMATIC POLYAMIDE; BREAKING ELONGATION; BREAKING ENERGY; BREAKING STRENGTH; DAYLIGHT; DIMENSIONAL STABILITY; FIBRES; FLAME RESISTANCE; FLAME RESISTANT (TYPE); GAMMA RADIATION; HEAT RESISTANT (TYPE); HEAT TREATMENT; IRRADIATION; KEVLAR (TN); MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; NOMEX (TN); PBI (TN); POLY (PHENYLENE DIBENZIMIDAZOLE); POLY (PHENYLENE PHTHALAMIDE)

Title: THE US-NSF/NASA WIND ENERGY CONVERSION SYSTEMS (WECS) PROGRAM.
Source title: PROCS. OF WORKSHOP ON ADVANCED WIND ENERGY SYSTEMS, SPONSORED BY STU, SV AND NSF/NASA, HELD IN STOCKHOLD, SWEDEN, AUGUST 29-3
Authors with affiliations: DIVONE, L.V.; SAVINO, J.M.
Abstract: THE MAIN OBJECTIVE OF THE WECS PROGRAME, WAS TO ADVANCE THE TECHNOLOGY OF WIND ENERGY CONVERSION SYSTEMS - TO BE COST COMPETITIVE AND CAPABLE OF RAPID COMMERCIAL EXPANSION FOR PRODUCING SIGNIFICANT QUANTITIES OF ENERGY.THE MAJOR PROGRAM ELEMENTS WERE: MISSION/REGION ANALYSIS; WIND CHARACTERISTICS; COMPONENT/SUBSYSTEMS SUPPORTING RESEARCH AND TECHNOLOGY; ADVANCED RESEARCH/CONCEPTS; ENERGY STORAGE; ENVIRONMENTAL, LEGAL, AESTHETICS, ETC.(FROM PAPER)
Index Keywords: AESTHETICS; Economics; ENERGY; LEGAL ASPECTS; Storage; U.S.A; Wind; Wind power

Title: Performance characteristics of a high-pressure, moderate temperature, electrolysis system.
Authors with affiliations: Allison, H.J.
Abstract: An electrolysis cell system for use as an energy storage mechanism for conventional and unconventional power systems has been under development since 1961, and a two kilowatt prototype system, based on a unique electrode design has been constructed and tested. The paper describes this system, summarises the basic theory associated with the electrolytic production of hydrogen, and presents data related to the performance characteristics of the prototype cell. (based on Author's abstract)
Index Keywords: Energy storage; fuse cells; Power generation

Title: A computer program to calculate and plot wind-generated stored energy at constant consumption.
Authors with affiliations: Valeriote, E.M.L.
Abstract: A computer program is described which gives printed and plotted outputs of the quantity of wind-generated energy remaining in a storage system under given conditions. The program permits simulated variations of storage capacity, constant electrical load and conversion efficiency by simple data changes. Further alterations to the program itself are detailed, to adapt it to carry out similar calculations for wind turbines of various sizes or construction. The program has been tested by simulation of a hypothetical system of energy production, storage and consumption. It is planned that its predictions will be compared with data obtained from an experimental program currently in progress. (A.) (Microfiche)

Title: Three-dimensional wall attachment elements as sandard components for sequential controls.
Source title: IN: PROC. 2ND AACHENER FLUIDTECH. KOLLOQUIUM, (AACHEN, FED. REP. GERMANY: MAR.17,18, 1976)
Volume: 2 , Aachen, Fed. Rep. Germamu, VDMA, 1976, p.87-115.
Authors with affiliations: Ernst, A.
Abstract: Spatial fluid elements are proposed which manifest multistable storage properties and as well be shown by examples-can be used to advantage for sequential controls. The effort involved in coding the internal states can thereby be diminished. In addition they are very well suited to the construction of slipped function chains. Controls with single and multi-chained programme structures can be developed with reduced effort. The overall circuit construction facilitates eventual trouble-shooting and simplifies the necessary changes. The multi-stable standard components manifest improved reliability in control system relative to conventional fluid-mechanical storage elements; in addition the element demand, the convection effort and the energy consumption are very much reduced. (B.D.H.)
Index Keywords: Fluidics

Title: Some factors affecting the storage of powders.
Source title: IN: POWTECH '75, PROC. THIRD INT. POWER TECH. AND BULK SOLIDS CONF., (HARROGATE, U.K.: FEB.18-20, 1975), GOLDBERG, A.S. (ED.)
Authors with affiliations: Dollimore, D.; McBride, G.B.
Abstract: Aggregation upon storage is due to surface forces causing adhesion between adjacent particles, leading to the growth of small particles forming larger ones. The surface forces are caused by an inbalance in the attractive forces between the molecules, atoms or ions, at the surface and those in the bulk of the particle. These forces can also result in the adsorption, upon the surface of the particle, of materials in the vicinity of the particle. The adsorbed film will have a major effect upon the nature of aggregation between particles. This property is used when aggregation is brought about intentionally, and the adsorbed film occurs as a thin layer sandwiched between adjoining particles. The maximum adhesive force occurs between particles when they have perfectly clean surfaces, and the force is then a measure of the surface energy possessed by the particles. Contamination of the surface lowers the surface energy and affects in turn the adhesive forces between particles. (from paper)
Index Keywords: effect; temperature

Title: Transfer of energy by storage of compressed air.
Authors with affiliations: Fleury, J.
Abstract: The possibility of storing surplus energy from power stations during off-peak hours and recovering it at peak demand periods by means of compressing air in underground reservoirs is discussed. The compressed air is used in a gas turbine, which by being freed from the need to compress its own air can produce up to three times the power from a conventional gas turbine of the same rating. A number of planned and projected schemes of this type are considered. (A)

Title: Pumped hydro storage for wind energy in Sweden.
Source title: IN: PROCS. OF WORKSHOP ON ADVANCED WIND ENERGY SYSTEMS, (STOCKHOLM, SWEDEN : AUG.29-30, 1974)
Authors with affiliations: Svenningsson, P.J.
Abstract: Swedish hydro storage of power in combination with wind power are analysed in this report. Attention has been given to the suggestion that to make wind power worth while, water could be pumped from one reservoir into another at a higher level. (F.C.S.)
Index Keywords: generation; hydro; power; pumped; storage; Sweden; windmills

Title: An economic evaluation of small-scale wind powered electric generation systems.
Authors with affiliations: Obermeier, J.L.; Townes, H.W.
Abstract: Presented is an economic evaluation of several commercial wind powered electric generation systems of the type which could be used by an individual home owner. A system includes a wind plant, tower, storage battery and d-c to a-c inverter. The analysis considered a total of 12 different system configurations. The evaluation of energy output was based on wind speed data for several locations in the state of Montana. The analysis can be extended to other locations on the basis of mean annual wind speed. The results of the evaluation indicate that some of the home built' systems are competitive economically at the present time in some windy' locations. None of the systems which are economic could individually supply the entire power requirement for a single family dwelling. (A)

Authors: Gergis I.S., Chen T.T., Tocci L.R.
Title: The effect of dc in plane field on the operation of field access bubble memory devices
Affiliations: Electronics Research Division of Rockwell International, Anaheim, CA 92803, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gergis, I.S., Electronics Research Division of Rockwell International, Anaheim, CA 92803, United States; Chen, T.T., Electronics Research Division of Rockwell International, Anaheim, CA 92803, United States; Tocci, L.R., Electronics Research Division of Rockwell International, Anaheim, CA 92803, United States
Abstract: The effect of a small dc in-plane field on the start-stop operation of field access bubble devices has been studied. Experimental results show that the bias margin in this mode is very sensitive to the magnitude of the field and its orientation relative to the start-stop direction of the drive field. In a T-I circuit a complete margin loss was observed for an in-plane field of 3 Oe oriented antiparallel to the start-stop direction. For parallel orientations of the in-plane field the. start-stop margin improved and approached that of the continuous propagation margin at an in-plane field of approximately 6 Oe. Dependence of the start-stop margin on the orientation of the start-stop direction relative to the pattern was also observed. Measurements of the bubble collapse field at various points in the pattern show a very strong dependence on the in-plane field and the permalloy geometry. The collapse-field results and magnetostatic energy considerations which take into account local field variations and bubble-bubble interactions provide a basis for understanding the experimentally observed start-stop margins. These results show that a small tilt (2 to 3) should be introduced in the bias field to overcome normal alignment tolerances and ensure that a favorable in-plane field is always present. This assures reliable start-stop operation. Copyright © 1976 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: MAGNETIC MATERIALS - Bubbles; DATA STORAGE, MAGNETIC

Title: An analysis of magnetic suspension.
Authors with affiliations: Aronson, E.A.
Abstract: Recent interest in energy storage by a high speed rotating cylinder has led to interest in magnetic bearings for the frictionless suspension of the cylinder. Magnetic suspension is inherently unstable and requires feedback control for stability. This report discusses magnetic suspension and the associated control system. There is also a discussion of the 'three-loop' suspension system. An ancillary result shows that tapering of the magnetic pole pieces at the gap is detrimental to the magnetic suspension. (A)
Index Keywords: magnetic bearing

Title: Air storage power.
Source title: IN: PROCS. OF WORKSHOP ON ADVANCED WIND ENERGY SYSTEMS, (STOCKHOLM, SWEDEN : AUG.29-30, 1974)
Authors with affiliations: Norberg, L.
Abstract: The STAL-Laval air storage is applied to gas turbine electric system and could also be used with wind energy. The author claims that with the same gas turbine elements, three times more electric output power can be generated, with the storage scheme, than achievable with the standard gas turbine cycle. (M.P.P.)
Index Keywords: air; efficiency; gas; generation; power; schemes; storage; turbine

Title: Direct Coupling of Solar Cell Arrays to Electric Power Networks
Affiliations: Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, United States; Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Toledo, Toledo, OH 43606, United States
Authors with affiliations: Alvarado, F.L., Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, United States; Eltimsahy, A.H., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Toledo, Toledo, OH 43606, United States
Abstract: Results of the investigation of the performance of solar cells when directly coupled to a conventional three-phase power network are presented. This approach dissociates the electricity production problem from the electric energy storage problem. Extensive studies of the required power inverter are performed. Preliminary simulation results indicate that ac power outputs of better than 90 percent of the optimum cell power output can be easily achieved by means of a suitably controlled inverter, thereby justifying the elimination of dc loads or local dc electric energy storage devices. It is also shown that the controlling policy for the inverter must depend on the operating conditions of the system, such as cell temperature, solar intensity, and power system voltage variations, otherwise the performance of the inverter can deteriorate quite dramatically. Copyright © 1976 by the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC INVERTERS; SOLAR ENERGY; SOLAR CELLS

Title: Laws for work-hardening and low-temperature creep
Source title: Journal of Engineering Materials and Technology, Transactions of the ASME
Affiliations: Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kocks, U.F., Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL, United States
Abstract: The true stress-strain curves of polycrystalline aluminum, copper, and stainless steel are shown to be adequately represented by an exponential approach to a saturation stress over a significant range. This empirical law, which was first proposed by Voce, is expanded to describe the temperature and strain-rate dependence, and is put on a physical foundation in the framework of dislocation storage and dynamic recovery rates. The formalism can be applied to the steady-state limit of creep in the same range of temperatures and strain rates; the stress exponent of the creep rate must, as a consequence, be strongly temperature dependent, the activation energy weakly stress dependent. Near half the melting temperature, where available work-hardening data and available creep data overlap, they match. Extrapolation of the proposed law to higher temperatures suggests that no new mechanisms may be necessary to describe hightemperature creep. A new differential equation for transient creep also follows from the empirical work-hardening law. © 1976 by ASME.
Index Keywords: ALUMINUM AND ALLOYS - Strain; METALS TESTING - Creep; STRESSES - Analysis; DISLOCATION MECHANISMS; WORK-HARDENING; METALS AND ALLOYS

Title: Long-term prospects for compressed air storage
Affiliations: Central Electricity Generating Board, Marchwood Engineering Laboratories, Marchwood, Southampton, SO4 4ZB, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Glendenning, I., Central Electricity Generating Board, Marchwood Engineering Laboratories, Marchwood, Southampton, SO4 4ZB, United Kingdom
Abstract: The compressed air storage (CAS) concept has been reviewed in the light of the long-term requirement for energy storage to effect load following in a predominantly nuclear generating system. This requirement would eventually lead to the operation of storage plant on a daily cycle of storing energy for 6-8 h and generating for 12-16 h. Conventional CAS schemes, typified by the Nordwestdeutchen Kraftwerke (NWK) installation in West Germany, are shown to be incapable of fulfilling this duty on merit. The basic concept is then re-examined and a novel development is proposed which, by using uncooled compressors and conserving the compression energy, constitutes a true energy storage scheme requiring no fuel other than the off-peak energy taken from the electrical grid. The efficiency and other performance characteristics of this proposal are discussed. The capital cost of an 8 GWh storage scheme is tentatively put at £125-175/kW (at 1974 price levels), depending on the air store construction, well within the £200/kW cost target which storage plant would need to meet to be of interest for storing off-peak nuclear power by the end of the present century. It is concluded that, once developed, CAS schemes which incorporate heat storage could provide an attractive method for storing off-peak electricity. © 1976.
Index Keywords: COMPRESSED AIR

Authors: Katsube T., Adachi Y., Ikoma T.
Title: Memory traps in MNOS diodes measured by thermally stimulated current
Affiliations: Institute of Industrial Science, University of Tokyo, 22-1, Roppongi 7 chome, Minato-ku, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Katsube, T., Institute of Industrial Science, University of Tokyo, 22-1, Roppongi 7 chome, Minato-ku, Tokyo, Japan; Adachi, Y., Institute of Industrial Science, University of Tokyo, 22-1, Roppongi 7 chome, Minato-ku, Tokyo, Japan; Ikoma, T., Institute of Industrial Science, University of Tokyo, 22-1, Roppongi 7 chome, Minato-ku, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Thermally stimulated current was measured to determine trap distribution and charging and discharging mechanisms in a Metal-Nitride-Oxide-Semiconductor (MNOS) diode with 16 Å oxide thickness. By changing gate voltage, heating rate and the initial flat-band voltage, the memory traps near the nitride-oxide interface were separated from the others. The general formula was derived for the thermally stimulated current in an MNOS diode and was applied to obtain the trap distribution as well as effective emission time constants. The results indicate that the memory traps are distributed 50 Å deep into the nitride film from the nitride-oxide interface. The energy level lies at around 2·55 eV from the bottom of the nitride conduction band. The charging and discharging mechanism is the cascade connection of tunneling and thermal excitation or trapping. The obtained trap distribution and the charge transfer mechanism are successful for interpreting the write-in and retention characteristics. © 1976.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, SEMICONDUCTOR - Storage Devices; SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES, MIS

Authors: Asmussen E., Bonde‐Petersen F., Jørgensen K.
Title: Mechano‐Elastic Properties of Human Muscles at Different Temperatures
Affiliations: Laboratory for the Theory of Gymnastics, August Krogh Institute, University of Copenhagen, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Asmussen, E., Laboratory for the Theory of Gymnastics, August Krogh Institute, University of Copenhagen, Denmark; Bonde‐Petersen, F., Laboratory for the Theory of Gymnastics, August Krogh Institute, University of Copenhagen, Denmark; Jørgensen, K., Laboratory for the Theory of Gymnastics, August Krogh Institute, University of Copenhagen, Denmark
Abstract: The effect of changes in the muscle temperature on their ability to store elastic energy was studied by having 5 trained subjects perform maximal vertical jumps on a force platform, with and without counter movement, at muscle temperatures between about 32°C and 37°C. The results showed that the heights of vertical jumps were considerably reduced at lowered temperature, but the gain in height after a counter movement in the form of a jump down from a height of 0.4 m over the force platform, was significantly higher in the cold condition. To test whether this was due to an increased stiffness of the muscles, experiments with imposed sinusoidal length variations at 14 Hz were performed. Δforce ×Δlength‐1 (i.e. stiffness) increased with isometric tension independent of muscle temperature. Experiments in which the rate of tension development and relaxation in voluntary maximal isometric contractions were measured at different muscle temperatures showed that maximal isometric tension changed by less than 1 % per degree but the rate of tension development and relaxation by 3–5 % and 5 % per degree, respectively, in the temperature range studied (30° to 40°). These data may be explained by the hypothesis that the series elastic components of the active muscle are located in the cross‐bridges between myosin and actin filaments. The storage of elastic energy would be enhanced if the rate of breaking of these bridges were decreased at lower temperatures. © 1976 Scandinavian Physiological Society
Author Keywords: Elastic energy; muscle stiffness; muscle temperature; rate of tension development and relaxation; vertical jumps
Index Keywords: elasticity; jumping; muscle; muscle contraction; normal human; temperature; theoretical study; article; body temperature; elasticity; energy metabolism; exercise; human; male; metabolism; muscle; physiology; Body Temperature; Elasticity; Energy Metabolism; Exertion; Human; Male; Muscle Contraction; Muscles

Title: Algebraic constraints on state variables - a tutorial introduction.
Authors with affiliations: Iyengar, S.K.R.
Abstract: In almost all dynamic systems modelled with lumped parameters, due to the presence of one or more energy storage elements (i.e., inertance or capacitance), the mathematical model takes the form of differential equations. In fluid power systems, the inertia of moving parts (including fluid) is responsible for inertance, and the fluid bulk modulus and springs account for capacitance. Generally, it is expected that the order of the mathematical model, which is equal to the number of state variables, is equal to the number of energy storage elements. The exceptional cases, in which the order is less than the number of energy storage elements, are referred to as those involving algebraic state constraints. Since an overwhelming majority of analytical and simulation techniques depend on an explicit evaluation of state variables, systems analysts resort to the in troduction of storage elements and a consequent reformulation of the mathematical model in order to remove algebraic constraints. This reformulation can often lead to inefficient simulation due to drastic changes in the eigen values. This tutorial explores the physical origins of algebraic constraints on state variables with examples from fluid power systems and delineates their influence on further analysis. It illustrates the need for careful conceptualization of the system model and gives an examples in which the same system is modelled with and without algebraic constraints. The resultant effects on both the system representation and simulation methods are explained step-by-step. (A)

Title: Turbo machinery systems for compressed air energy storage.
Authors with affiliations: Berman, P.A.
Abstract: Soaring prices for premium fuels, along with the desire to reduce utility dependence on petroleum-derived fuel, necessitates looking for other means of providing for system peak power requirements: the Author indicates that complete elimination of premium-fuel-fired plants and a total reliance on coal, or coal and nuclear is not the answer and suggests that the rational answer is energy storage. The paper and discussed Underground Compressed Air Energy Storage concept: following a general introduction; sections of the paper deal with Application; Operation; Subterranean Air Storage; Advantages and Disadvantages; Evaluation Parameters; System Selection; Machinery Arrangement and HP set Selection; Starting Method; Cycle Variations; CAES versus Simple Open Cycle. (A)

Title: WIND-POWERED AQUEDUCT SYSTEMS.
Source title: PROCS. OF WORKSHOP ON ADVANCED WIND ENERGY SYSTEMS, SPONSORED BY STU, SV AND NSF/NASA, HELD IN STOCKHOLM, SWEDEN, AUGUST 29-3
Authors with affiliations: ELDRIDGE, F.R.
Abstract: ONE OF THE IMPORTANT POSSIBLE APPLICATIONS OF WIND ENERGY CONVERSION SYSTEMS (WECS) INVOLVES THE PUMPING OF WATER FOR SUCH PURPOSES AS THE TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION OF WATER IN AQUEDUCTS, PUMPED-STORAGE FOR HYDROELECTRIC SYSTEMS, CROP IRRIGATION SYSTEMS, WATERING OF STOCK ETC.ALTHOUGH SMALL-SCALE WIND-DRIVEN WATER PUMPS ARE USED EXTENSIVELY IN THE U.S.FOR STOCK-WATERING, AND TO A LESSER DEGREE FOR IRRIGATION PURPOSES, LITTLE OR NO RESEARCH HAS YET BEEN UNDERTAKEN IN THE U.S.TO DEVELOP LARGE-SCALE WIND-DRIVEN PUMPS FOR USE IN OPERATING AQUEDUCTS OR PUMPED STORAGE HYDROELECTRIC SYSTEMS.THE MITRE CORPORATION IS PROPOSING TO DEVELOP A PRELIMINARY DESIGN FOR A SYSTEM THAT WOULD USE LARGE-SCALE WIND-DRIVEN UNITS TO PROVIDE POWER FOR THE PUMPING OF WATER FROM THE MAIN RESERVOIR TO AUXILIARY RESERVOIRS IN OTHER PARTS OF AN AQUEDUCT SYSTEM.THE STUDY WOULD INCLUDE A COMPARISON OF THE COST AND EFFECTIVENESS OF THE FOLLOWING ALTERNATIVE METHODS OF PERFORMING SUCH OPERATIONS: THE DIRECT MECHANICAL PUMPING OF WATER IN THE AQUEDUCT SYSTEM; THE DIRECT GENERATION OF ELECTRICITY BY WIND-TURBINE UNITS, AND THE USE OF THIS ELECTRICITY TO OPERATE ELECTRICAL WATER-PUMPS INCORPORATED IN THE AQUEDUCT SYSTEM; THE USE OF WIND UNITS TO PUMP WATER FROM AN AUXILIARY RESERVOIR BELOW A HYDROELECTRIC DAM, BACK INTO THE MAIN RESERVOIR, AND THE USE OF THE ELECTRICITY GENERATED BY THE HYDROELECTRIC UNIT TO OPERATE ELECTRICAL PUMPS INCORPORATED IN THE AQUEDUCT SYSTEM; THE POSSIBLE USE OF VARIOUS MEANS FOR MATCHING THE WIND ENERGY SUPPLY OF THE SELECTED REGION WITH THE ENERGY DEMAND OF THE SYSTEMS, TO REDUCE THE NUMBER OF WIND ENERGY CONVERSION UNITS REQUIRED; INCLUDING INTERCONNECTION WITH A PUBLIC UTILITY NETWORK, OR THE USE OF SOME MEANS FOR ENERGY STORAGE (E.G.PUMPED-WATER STORAGE, PUMPED AIR STORAGE, HYDROGEN STORAGE, BATTERIES, FLYWHEELS, ETC.) (FROM PAPER)
Index Keywords: AQUEDUCTS; PUMPED STORAGE; PUMPING; Storage; Wind power

Authors: Krsmanovic L., Pejovic S., Jemcov R.
Title: Economy of operation in reversible pumped storage power plants.
Volume: 1 , 1976, Session B - Hydro-Electric Power Plants in the Power Supply, Paper B6
Authors with affiliations: Krsmanovic, L.; Pejovic, S.; Jemcov, R.
Abstract: This paper analyzes the dependence of reversible power-plant income on the price and performance of units, amortisation and operation costs of power-plant, price of energy expanded and generated, as of the intensity of utilisation. The developed treatment is explained by using examples of high head and large capacity storage power-plant. (from Authors' abstract) Four types of generating unit are considered: the three-unit set with separate pump and turbine and a single electric machine operated either as a motor or a generator; the reversible pump-turbine; the Isogyre two-unit set; and the Hone two-unit set
Index Keywords: Hone turbines; Hydraulic turbines; Hydroelectricity; Isogyre turbines; power stations; pump-turbines

Title: Storage of low temperature heat: solar energy thermal storage.
Authors with affiliations: Wettermark, G.; Kowalewska, J.
Abstract: The major means available for thermal storage of solar energy are reviewed and the general conditions for heat storage are discussed. The various types of sensible and latent-heat storage are covered.

Title: An assessment of energy storage systems suitable for use by electric utilities, Volumes 1 and 2.
Abstract: The report covers the entire range of mechanical, chemical and electromagnetic energy storage technologies that are considered to have potential for utility use. These comprise: hydro pumped, compressed air, thermal. flywheel, battery, hydrogen and superconducting magnetic energy storage systems. A comparison on the concepts examined identifies several promising near-term and future technologies for application as peaking and intermediate generating capacity.

Authors: Fischer H.C., Christain J.C., Hise E.C., Holman A.S., Miller A.J., Mixon W.R., Moyers J.C., Nephew E.A.
Title: The annual cycle energy system: initial investigations.
Authors with affiliations: Fischer, H.C.; Christain, J.C.; Hise, E.C.; Holman, A.S.; Miller, A.J.; Mixon, W.R.; Moyers, J.C.; Nephew, E.A.
Abstract: Initial analytical and experimental investigations were conducted to establish data and design procedures prior to a demonstration of the Annual Cycle Energy System (ACES) in an actual building. ACES is an integrated system for supplying space heating and cooling, and domestic hot water to a building through the use of a heat pump , a thermal storage unit, and an outdoor radiative/convective panel. The heat pump extracts energy from a tank or stored water to provide winter heating. The ice that is formed is accumulated for subsequent use in meeting the cooling requirements of the building in the summer. A components test assembly was constructed to measure the rates of heat transfer during ice buildup and brine chilling operations, to assess the design requirements of the evaporator and the desuperheater for producing domestic hot water using refrigerant superheat, and to investigate the mechanical stability characteristics of the ACES freezing coils which are submerged in the water storage tank. The findings of the experimental program are presented and analytical methods for optimally sizing system components according to the thermal characteristics of a building and the climatic zone where it is located are developed. The calculation of the annual coefficient of performance for the ACES is illustrated. (A)

Title: Proceedings of the Workshop on Compressed Air Energy Storage Systems held at Airlie House, Virginia, U.S.A. on December 1975.
Abstract: Twenty papers were presented, dealing with economic feasibility studies, work by Stal-Laval, choice of rock caverns, adaptation of aquifers, legal considerations, health, safety and environmetal problems.
Index Keywords: CAES

Authors: Martin H.F., Tapper D.N., Alston M.T.
Title: Sustained fast valving applied to Tennessee Valley Authority's Watts Bar Nuclear Units.
Authors with affiliations: Martin, H.F.; Tapper, D.N.; Alston, M.T.
Abstract: The first application of sustained fast valving nuclear units is planned for units 1 and 2 at the Tennessee Valley Authority's (TVA) Watts Bar Nuclear Plant. The proposed turbine cycle and the advantages of sustained fast valving to the power system are presented. The turbine cycle simulation is discussed and the effects of feedwater heater energy storage on short term power transients are demonstrated. The mechanical reliability of the turbine and related equipment is determined from the turbine cycle simulation. (A)

Title: LONG-TERM OPERATION OF STORAGE HYDRO PROJECTS.
Source title: J. WATER RESOUR. PLAN AND MANAG. DIV. PROC. ASCE
Authors with affiliations: CASELTON, W.F.; RUSSELL, S.O.
Abstract: THE INTRODUCTION OF LARGE STORAGE HYDROELECTRIC PROJECTS INTO AN EXISTING MIXED HYDRO AND THERMAL GENERATING SYSTEM INCREASES THE NEED FOR SOUND LONG-TERM OPERATING POLICIES AND SYSTEM DEVELOPMENT PLANS.THE COMPLEXITY OF THE INTEGRATED OVERALL OPERATION OF SUCH A GENERATING SYSTEM IS TOO GREAT FOR DIRECT APPLICATION OF OPTIMIZATION TECHNIQUES.THE PAPER DESCRIBES A METHODOLOGY WHICH PERFORMS A DETAILED OPTIMIZATION OF THE LONG-TERM OPERATION OF A PART OF THE GENERATING SYSTEM, COMPRISING A LARGE STORAGE HYDRO PROJECT AND A THERMAL PLANT, UNDERY VARYING CONDITIONS OF THERMAL CAPACITY AND FIRM ENERGY DEMAND.WHEN THE METHODOLOGY WAS APPLIED TO AN ACTUAL LARGE STORAGE HYDRO PROJECT THE RESULTS PROVIDED CONSIDERABLE INSIGHT INTO THE LONG-TERM INTEGRATED OPERATING CHARACTERISTIC OF HYDRO AND THERMAL PLANTS.A BASIS FOR COORDINATING LONG-TERM OPERATION WITH THE LARGE STORAGE HYDRO PROJECTS IS SUGGESTED.(A).
Index Keywords: BRITISH COLUMBIA HYDRO AND POWER AUTHORITY SYSTEM; OPTIMISATION; POWER STATIONS-HYDROELECTRIC; POWER STATIONS-THERMAL; PUMPED STORAGE; Water resources

Title: Simple thermal decomposition reactions for storage of solar thermal energy
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Solar Energy Laboratory, University of Houston, Houston, TX 77004, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wentworth, W.E., Department of Chemistry, Solar Energy Laboratory, University of Houston, Houston, TX 77004, United States; Chen, E., Department of Chemistry, Solar Energy Laboratory, University of Houston, Houston, TX 77004, United States
Abstract: Simple thermal decomposition reactions have been investigated for the purpose of solar thermal energy storage. Ten criteria regarding the thermodynamics and kinetics of the reaction and the physical properties of the components of the reaction have been established. One particular reaction, the decomposition of ammonium hydrogen sulfate, has been evaluated in a preliminary manner and appears to satisfy all of the established criteria. The efficiency of storage is high and the decomposition occurs in the vicinity of 500°C. Other compounds such as ammonium halides, alkali and alkaline earth metal hydroxides, carbonates, sulfates and oxides have also been examined. © 1976.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL REACTIONS - Reaction Kinetics; ENERGY RESOURCES; THERMODYNAMICS; SOLAR THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: Thermal Storage in Melts of Salt and Metals. [SPEICHERUNG VON THERMISCHER ENERGIE IN SALZ- UND METALLSCHMELZEN. .]
Authors with affiliations: Horsthemke, A.; Marschall, E.
Abstract: Proposals for storing thermal energy in salt and metal melts are made. Some characteristic properties of thermal storage are analyzed. It was concluded that salt offers more advantages for thermal storing than metals.
Index Keywords: Heat transfer

Authors: Suzuki Eiichi, Komiya Yoshio, Tarui Yasuo
Title: MEASUREMENTS OF TRAPS OF MAOS STRUCTURES BY OPTICAL METHOD.
Authors with affiliations: Suzuki, Eiichi; Komiya, Yoshio; Tarui, Yasuo
Abstract: The basic approaches to an MAOS structure which is used as a nonvolatile semiconductor memory have been described. The spatial and energy distribution of traps which contribute to memory behavior has been measured by the nondestructive optical method. It has been found that the spatial centroid of the traps in the MAOS structure is situated at a considerable depth of the Al//2O//3. The measurement of the energy distribution of the traps reveals that both the traps in the Al//2O//3 bulk and SiO//2 bulk and the traps near the Al//2O//3 - SiO//2 interface which are supposed to be dependent on the fabrication process, contribute to the memory action of the MAOS structure.
Index Keywords: Data storage, Semiconductor

Title: Distribution of Energy in Measurement Sections of Outlet Pipes of Pumps and its Influence on the Accuracy of a Thermodynamically Measured Efficiency. [LA REPARTITION DE L'ENERGIE DANS LES SECTIONS DE MESURE DE CONDUITES DE POMPAGE ET SON INFLUENCE SUR L'EXACTITUDE D'UN RENDEMENT MESURE PAR LA METHODE THERMODYNAMIQUE.]
Authors with affiliations: Brun, Joseph
Abstract: For the purpose of studying the energy distribution in outlet pipes of pumps on three model pumps of different design, the distributions of the hydraulic and the total energy are measured in different sections of the outlet pipe as well as at different flow quantities. These tests have been completed by measurements executed on a storage pump of prototype size. As characteristic values of the energy distribution, its standard deviation and its greatest deviation from the mean are calculated. The influence of flow quantity, equalization distance (distance between pump outlet and measurement section) and machine design is shown.
Index Keywords: Thermal variables measurement; Thermodynamics; Pumps

Title: The NASA-Langley building solar project and the supporting Lewis solar technology program
Affiliations: National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ragsdale, R.G., National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States; Namkoong, D., National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States
Abstract: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration will use solar energy to heat and cool a new office building that is now under construction at its Langley Research Center in Hampton, Virginia. Planned for completion in December 1975, the 53,000 ft2, single story building will utilize 15,000 ft2 of various types of solar collectors in a test bed to provide nearly all of the heating demand and over half of the air conditioning demand. This is a cooperative project involving joint participation between Langley and NASA's Lewis Research Center in Cleveland, Ohio. Drawing on its space-program-developed skills and resources in heat transfer, materials and systems studies, NASA-Lewis will provide technology support for the Langley building project. A solar energy technology program underway at Lewis includes solar collector testing in an indoor solar simulator facility and in an outdoor test facility, property measurements of solar panel coatings, and operation of a laboratory-scale solar model system test facility. Based on results obtained in this program, NASA-Lewis will select and procure the solar collectors for the Langley test bed. The selection will be made in late 1974 or early 1975. Early results from simulator tests indicate that non-selective coatings behave more nearly in accord with predicted performance than do selective coatings. Initial experiments on the decay rate of thermally stratified hot water in a storage tank have been run. Results suggest that where high temperature water is required to drive a chiller, excess solar energy collected by a building solar system should be stored overnight in the form of chilled water rather than hot water. © 1976.
Index Keywords: HEATING - Solar; OFFICE BUILDINGS - Air Conditioning; SOLAR ENERGY; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; SOLAR PANEL COATINGS; AIR CONDITIONING

Title: Operating experience with the DORIS electron positron double storage ring
Affiliations: Dtsch. Elektr. Synchrotron (DESY), Hamburg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Wille, K., Dtsch. Elektr. Synchrotron (DESY), Hamburg, Germany
Abstract: The DORIS double storage ring has supplied physics experiment with luminosity which is now available for 90% of the operating time since the autumn of 1974. Luminosities averaging above 4. 10**2**9 cm** minus **2 s** minus **1 are reached at energies between 1. 5 and 2 GeV, peak values are about 10**3**0 cm** minus **2 s** minus **1. The life of the beam exceeds 10 h. Detailed studies of the beam properties, such as optical resonances and instabilities caused by cavities, and technical measures for their reduction are presented.
Index Keywords: POSITRON STORAGE RINGS; Electron beams; methodology

Title: Spectral Dependence Of The Photorefractive Recording And Erasure Process In Doped LinbO3
Affiliations: Philips Forschumslaboratorium Hamburg GmbH, Hamburg, 54, Germany
Authors with affiliations: KräTzig, E., Philips Forschumslaboratorium Hamburg GmbH, Hamburg, 54, Germany; Kurz, H., Philips Forschumslaboratorium Hamburg GmbH, Hamburg, 54, Germany
Abstract: Photo currents respoasible for the phot ore fractive recording sensitivity have been investigated in the absence and presence of external electrical fields in oxidized and partially reduced LiNbO3: Fe- and LiNbO3: Cu-crystals. Optical erasure and absorption have also been measured in the spectral range between 1.5 and 4.0 eV. The comparison of the spectra reveals the contributions of different centers and transitions to the photorefractive recording and erasure process and some details on the energy levels of transition metal centers in pyroelectric LiNbO3. © 1976, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: FERROELECTRIC MATERIALS; LITHIUM NIOBATE; DATA STORAGE, OPTICAL

Title: CORNMOD, a dynamic simulator of corn production
Affiliations: Agricultural Engineering Department, Ohio Agricultural Research and Development Center, Wooster, OH 44691, United States; Agronomy Dept., University of Missouri, Columbia, MO 65201, United States
Authors with affiliations: Baker, C.H., Agricultural Engineering Department, Ohio Agricultural Research and Development Center, Wooster, OH 44691, United States; Horrocks, R.D., Agronomy Dept., University of Missouri, Columbia, MO 65201, United States
Abstract: Aftern an extensive literature search, CORNMOD, a comprehensive mathematical model that simulates energy and gas exchange at the plant-air interface, was developed. Predictions of profiles (CO2 concentration, water vapour, temperature, light, photosynthesis) in the canopy were biologically good enough for many applications, but they revealed the inadequacies in our understanding of the environment within the plant canopy. Also considered were spring and fall tillage and harvest operations. After calculating several spring freeze-thaw periods for the test year, 1969, enough work days were accumulated to complete tillage operations, allowing completion of planting by 12 May. Two 63 hp tractors and associated equipment were used to farm the 81 ha hypothetical farmstead used for test purposes. Without this large investment in equipment, planting date would have been delayed until late June or early July since the spring of 1969 was very wet. The simulated crop was grown under actual 1969 weather conditions. On 4 September the corn crop reached harvest maturity as gauged by a GDD (Growing Degree Day) 'clock'. The simulator predicted a yield of 7368 kg/ha. This was a gross over-prediction of the 4088 kg/ha average reported for 1969 in central Missouri. This over-prediction was accounted for by the ideal conditions given the simulator when actual data were not available. This included leaf angles, CO2 concentration, and stomatal resistance. Harvesting took 30 days to complete, using one four-row sheller, two trucks, a farm elevator, and 127 272 kg of storage capacity. It appered that the farm dryer was the limiting piece of equipment in the harvesting operation. This crop production simulator forms the basic framework that can eventually analyse more complex systems. However, at this point, the simulator is only in the initial stages of development, and it should be realised that much more extensive development is necessary before the ultimate simulator is achieved. © 1976.

Authors: Van der Plas L.H.W., Verleur J.D.
Title: CN-resistant respiration in potato (Solanum tuberosum L.) changes after storage of the tuber
Affiliations: Department of Botany, Free University, De Boelelaan, 1087 Amsterdam, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Van der Plas, L.H.W., Department of Botany, Free University, De Boelelaan, 1087 Amsterdam, Netherlands; Verleur, J.D., Department of Botany, Free University, De Boelelaan, 1087 Amsterdam, Netherlands
Abstract: The resistance of respiration to KCN induced in potato tuber tissue after wounding is located in the mitochondria and sensitive to metal chelators. The succinate-consuming respiration of isolated mitochondria becomes resistant after wounding, while the NADH-consuming respiration remains KCN-sensitive. The alternative oxidase most likely is located at the succinate dehydrogenase complex. From the inhibition characteristics of metal chelators it can be concluded that the alternative oxidase functions also in uninhibited respiration. Induction of alternative oxidase is low or absent in tubers before harvest and increases afterwards. While uninhibited respiration decreases during storage the relative importance of the cyanide (CN)-resistant respiration rises sharply. In the same period the formation of wound periderm cell layers decreases which might be related to a less efficient energy production (ATP) from substrate. © 1976.

Title: Optical absorption in the 4 d transition metals from 20 to 250 eV
Affiliations: Synchrotron Radiation Center, University of Wisconsin, Stoughton, WI 53589; Ames Laboratory, United States Energy Research and Development Administration, Ames, IA 50010
Authors with affiliations: Weaver, J.H., Synchrotron Radiation Center, University of Wisconsin, Stoughton, WI 53589; Olson, C.G., Ames Laboratory, United States Energy Research and Development Administration, Ames, IA 50010
Abstract: The optical absorption of Y, Zr, Nb, Mo, Rh, Pd, Hf, and W has been measured between 20 and 250 eV using synchrotron radiation from the Tantalus I electron storage ring. The samples were thin, self-supporting films, and transmission measurements were performed at normal incidence. The results were compared with our results from previous reflectivity measurements in the range of overlap (20-40 eV), as well as with electron-energy-loss measurements where available. The data were interpreted in terms of largely atomiclike transitions of the 4 p-to-4 d type. Arguments were presented to support this interpretation, and analogies were drawn to the higher-energy 4 d-4 f transitions in the rare earths. Structures were observed on the low-energy side of the onset which were interpreted in terms of the spin-orbit splitting of the initial 4p12 and 4p32 states. The broadening of the p-d structure was interpreted qualitatively in terms of multiplet splitting and autoionization processes. At higher energy, structures related to 3 d transitions were observed. © 1976 The American Physical Society.

Title: Primary Li/SOCl2 Cells-I. Performance characteristics of hermetically sealed D cells
Affiliations: P.R. Mallory and Co. Inc., Laboratory for Physical Science, Northwest Industrial Park, Burlington, MA 01803, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dey, A.N., P.R. Mallory and Co. Inc., Laboratory for Physical Science, Northwest Industrial Park, Burlington, MA 01803, United States
Abstract: The design, construction and evaluation of hermetically sealed Li/SOCl2 D cells are presented. The cells delivered high energy densities (184 WHr/1b and 13.5 WHr/in3) when fresh and showed excellent retention of intrinsic capacity but loss of rate capability on storage at 72° and 55°C. The cells showed severe voltage delays at -30°C following 72° or 55°C storage, particularly at drains of 0.5A or greater. The cells tended to explode on 10A discharge, on short circuit and on overdischarge. Approaches to alleviate these problems have been explored and the results will be discussed. © 1976.

Title: Electrical energy storage and intercalation chemistry
Affiliations: Corporate Research Laboratories, Exxon Research and Engineering Company, Linden, NJ 07036, United States
Authors with affiliations: Whittingham, M.S., Corporate Research Laboratories, Exxon Research and Engineering Company, Linden, NJ 07036, United States
Abstract: The electrochemical reaction of layered titanium disulfide with lithium giving the intercalation compound lithium titanium disulfide is the basis of a new battery system. This reaction occurs very rapidly and in a highly reversible manner at ambient temperatures as a result of structural retention. Titanium disulfide is one of a new generation of solid cathode materials.
